fields.headline: Crozier moves on fake passports
fields.trailText: FA chief executive Adam Crozier is to meet Fifa to ensure that punishments levelled at players involved in falsifying passports are applied around the world.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin  and  Vivek Chaudhary  in Nyon
fields.body:
Fifa has implored its member countries to take firm action against anyone trying to circumvent European employment laws by falsifying passports for non-EU footballers.

The Football Association yesterday received a letter from the world game's ruling body and Adam Crozier, the FA chief executive, has arranged to meet Fifa's general secretary Michel Zen Ruffinen for talks in Zurich next Wednesday.

"Adam Crozier will be making our position clear to Fifa and discussing ways in which this problem can be tackled on a worldwide level," said an FA spokesman. "It is the FA's firm belief that any punishments and sanctions imposed on players in this regard should apply around the world."

The practice of using forged passports has surfaced in a number of countries, among them England, Italy, Portugal and France, where yesterday St Etienne lost an appeal and were docked six points for fielding two players with fake passports in a December fixture with their fellow strugglers Toulouse, which Les Verts won 1-0.

Toulouse, who have now been awarded the three points, objected as St Etienne fielded a Brazilian striker, Alex, and a Ukrainian goalkeeper, Maxim Levytsky, both of whom were subsequently suspended for holding forged documents.

Fifa, which is asking all national bodies to seek "meticulous verification of the relevant documents", also registered concern about the damage being done to the game's reputation. "Firm action must be taken both by national and international football authorities against all those individuals and entities which in some way facilitate the propagation of this improper practice," the letter read.

Meanwhile football's warring parties have moved a little closer on the question of player contracts after high-level negotiations over the future of the European transfer system. Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's general secretary, said after a meeting in Zurich involving Fifa, Uefa and Fifpro, the organisation that represents international players, that the parties were close to agreeing that players should honour five-year contracts for a minimum of three years.

Fifpro had originally insisted that contracts should be honoured for only a year. "Three years are needed as a minimum for coaches, team building, technicians and economic planning of a club," Aigner said. "I think that Fifpro accepts that it's pretty clear that clubs must offer this stability."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Holidaying with a teenage daughter
fields.standfirst:
I am a single mother with a 14-year-old daughter. We enjoy going away together but this year I am absolutely stuck. I don't know where to look for a summer holiday that we can both enjoy. We both want to go somewhere warm and preferably near the sea. We both dislike noisy crowds and over-commercial resorts. But beyond that, we have different needs: She would like to be able to meet other teenagers and take her first steps towards a safe night-life. I would like to be able to encounter aspects of the culture we are visiting and find a quiet place to read. Are we asking the impossible? Has anyone got any suggestions?
Lee Bennett
fields.trailText: I am a single mother with a 14-year-old daughter. We enjoy going away together but this year I am absolutely stuck. I don't know where to look for a summer holiday that we can both enjoy. Has anyone got any suggestions?
fields.body:
 I would suggest the Peublo Indalo complex in Mojacar, on Spain's Costa D'Almeria. Very different from the other, busier, costas, life here is as hectic as you want. For your daughter, the hotel's own animacion team organise things for older (11+) kids, such as archery, snorkelling, various ball sports. They also put on a nightly show in the plaza, until 11 pm (ish) After that, there is a disco next door (free tickets from reception) which is really geared towards the younger teens, and is perfectly safe. For you, Granada & the Alhambra are only a couple of hours away, less to the cave houses at Guadix. Nice beaches, reasonable snorkelling, very picturesque village (halfway up a hill, behind the resort). All in all, not what I expected from a Spanish Costa, but a very pleasant surprise. Packages from Portland, Thomson, JMC & Airtours.
Iain Henderson

 I am 18 years old and for most of my life our family have spent our summer holidays in Club Meds arounds the world. The company has resorts on all continents at prices to suit all pockets, and while the accomodation can often be very simple (there are several straw hut villages for example) the service and quality of holiday is beyond compare.

The beauty about Club Med (or similar style) holidays is that you can do as little or as much as you want to do; if you're worried that you might not want to be as active on holiday as your daughter, then the amount of activities laid on at Club Med resort makes it perfect for you; you can sit by the pool reading and taking in the sun while your daughter amuses herself. Most clubs also arrange excellent tours to nearby attractions which might interest the traveller in you, but might bore your daughter. What I suggest is that you try and find one of the clubs that are marketed at families - these tend to have "kids' clubs"; organised activites for kids of different age groups which will give your daughter a chance to meet friends.

As I say, we've been going to Club Meds for several years and have very rarely found anything to complain about - in fact Club Meds have been the source of some of the greatest and most memorable holidays I've had.

Hope this has been helpful,
Kristian Brodie

&#'149; Why not try an activity-based holiday, where there are clubs for teenagers? Mark Warner and Club Med are two. We went on a Sunsail holiday in Turkey last year and our 14 year old daughter and 17 year old son had a fantastic time - no pressure to join in activities, but loads of young people around and also excellent company for adults. There were several single parents and their children there during August and everyone got along very well.
Olivia Montuschi, London

 While I don't have a teenage daughter, I was a teenager until a few years ago and I went on holiday with my parents until I was about 16. My advice is to go to Italy, to one of the many holiday villages along the Adriatic coast. These offer excellent facilities for the daytime, and have a variety of accommodation from bungalows to hotel rooms, fully equipped trailers, caravans and tents, and many activities for all ages (sport, music, etc). They are usually packed with teenagers from all over Europe so your daughter shouldn't have any trouble making friends. And there is obviously the appeal of the good food and great culture. If you go to Jesolo (just north of Venice) there is excellent nightlife, and you are about 20 miles from Venice. You can take day trips as far as Verona and go to see the opera in the Arena. Holiday resorts often organise coaches to nightclubs so that teenagers can go for a couple of hours, knowing they have a safe lift back.
Linda Lo Castro

 When our daughter was in her teens (and since) we had a number of holidays with Club Med. It provides the nearest thing to a safe environment in which to experiment with being grown up, ie going to the Club-run nightclub but only having a short walk back to your room. The centre part of each village is noisy and bouncy with lots going on at certain times of the day but there are always quiet areas. There are lots of activities to join in with, and in doing that you do get to know people. The atmosphere is very international: in some villages French is very much the main language, in others French and English are used more equally. There are excursions to visit local attractions and historic places, and it is well worth organising yourself to go out of the village so as to get to know the country in which the club is situated!
Margaret Gregory

 I would like to suggest Turkey. We have been twice through Tapestry holidays who have a selection of uncommercial resorts in beautiful locations. Although we had no teenagers with us we did talk to several families who said it was wonderful for young people, and we made friends with some teenage girls who were enjoying themselves very much. There were plenty of places for quiet reading plus opportunities for cultural visits and superb swimming. Good luck.
Bousfields

fields.headline: Booking tickets for La Scala
fields.standfirst:
I want to go to Milan in October to see Macbeth at La Scala. How can I obtain opera tickets before I go?
Sheila Burns
fields.trailText: I want to go to Milan in October to see Macbeth at La Scala. How can I obtain opera tickets before I go?
fields.body:
 You have several options. You could phone La Scala (full name: Teatro alla Scala) yourself on 0039 028 8791; a simple "Parla inglese?" will get you someone who can speak enough English to help you. You could book via the English-language section of La Scala's internet site; but don't use the box office telephone number from there as it is incorrect. You could join a planned group tour (try www.travelforthearts.co.uk or www.brompton.co.uk, both advertised in Opera magazine). Finally, either of those companies will also arrange an individual tour including tickets for you.

 There is a great company called Liaisons Abroad who specialise in obtaining opera tickets abroad - particularly in Italy. They can sort out tickets for La Scala, the Verona festival etc. I know that this year, Verdi's centenary, they have tickets for all the small opera festivals taking place in obscure towns throughout Italy. Their website is www.liaisonsabroad.com, or telephone 020 7376 4020. Alternatively, for a packaged city break with opera tickets included, try Magic of Italy (08700270500)

 There is little point in looking for a mid-price hotel near La Scala. Frequent tram services pass La Scala and connect well with the Metro. Just look for a hotel on a tram route or near a Metro station. Public transport in Milano is good.
John R, Batts

 In Wednesday February 7th one of your readers posted a note regarding booking opera tickets etc abroad. I'd like to add my own response to this especially as I used the lady's advice (obviously no hard feelings towards her or the Guardian)

However, I have been severely short-changed by Liaisons Abroad. While good for providing information, they are a wholly unprofessional organisation who could not resolve the fact that my tickets were not delivered, and then when they were, only being valued at one third of what I had paid. My advice to travellers, therefore, is to book directly with theatres or wait until they get to the country in question and pick up tickets from vendors there, as I discovered on arrival the tickets were available for all shows at a third of the price.
Michelle Anthony
(one very pissed off never-again-to-be-customer of Liaisons Abroad)

webTitle: The press complaints commission's greatest hits

fields.headline: The press complaints commission's greatest hits
fields.standfirst:
The PCC has dealt with 23,000 complaints over its 10-year lifetime. Here are some of the landmarks and some of the more notorious cases.

MediaGuardian
fields.trailText: The PCC has dealt with 23,000 complaints over its 10-year lifetime. Here are some of the landmarks and some of the more notorious cases.
fields.body:
2000: Prince of Wales v the Sunday Times
Complaint: Prince Charles took the unprecedented step of objecting to a story after the newspaper claimed that he planned to marry Camilla Parker Bowles.

The offending article claimed that he and Mrs Parker Bowles were in secret discussions with the Church of Scotland about a possible wedding in Scotland. The Church of Scotland permitted divorcees to marry in church.

Verdict: After an intervention from the PCC, the Sunday Times climbed down and printed a correction and page 2 apology. The paper said: "The story was based on information from a source close to the Church of Scotland. Following assurances from St James's Palace that there was no foundation to this story, we acknowledge that the story was inaccurate and are happy to set the record straight. We apologise for the error."

2000: Carol Smillie v Sunday Mail
Complaint: The BBC presenter claimed that a report in the Sunday Mail headlined "TV star Carol's grief over mum" was intrusive. The article, on the front page and two inside pages, reported the funeral of Ms Smillie's mother and was accompanied by pictures taken outside the crematorium.

Her solicitors said that the piece was an unjustified intrusion into Ms Smillie's grief which had been compounded by its prominence. Photographers at the church had been asked to leave, but the mourners had not noticed those at the crematorium, who were clearly some way away using long-lens photography.

Verdict: The complaint was upheld. The PCC deemed it a breach of the code of practice.

2000: Jacquline Pirie/Granada Television v the News of the World
Complaint: The Coronation Street star was appalled by an article headlined "Street star's 8-month marathon of lust", which labelled her as a "man eater" in a "kiss and tell" sold to the paper by a former fiance, who divulged intimate details of their sexual relationship.

Verdict: Complaint is upheld. The newspaper had pointed to the fact that an article in another newspaper by a former boyfriend had been published without complaint, but the commission did not consider this a valid justification for further intrusion into her privacy.

2000: Prince William v OK! Magazine
Complaint: The publication of photographs taken of the prince in Chile during his gap year despite the PCC's ruling in the wake of Princess Diana's death. The editor argued that the jungles of Chile were a public place and thus the photos were not taken as a result of persistent pursuit.

Verdict: Upheld. The PCC deemed that Prince William was not in a place where photographers would normally have been and must, therefore, have been followed there by foreign paparazzi.

1999: Tony and Cherie Blair v the Mail on Sunday
Complaint: A front page headline - Parents' fury over Blairs in school place row - claimed that the prime minister's daughter had unfairly gained a place at the Sacred Heart high school in Hammersmith at the expense of other children. The prime minister and Mrs Blair were not poor, the leader commented, and could have paid for private education instead.

Verdict: The complaint was upheld as there was no evidence of special treatment in her favour. In breach of clauses on accuracy and on children.

2000: The PCC v Piers Morgan
Complaint: That Mr Morgan, the Mirror editor, had breach newspaper codes on ethical financial journalism after he bought shares in a company tipped by his City Slickers column.

Verdict: The PCC found he had breached the newspaper code on three counts and was forced to publish a four-page apology. Although it looked like a harsh rebuke, Mr Morgan, 35, survived and was given the backing of Trinity Mirror bosses. The share-dealing is still being investigated by the Department of Trade and Industry.

1998: George Michael v the Sun
Complaint: The paper gave away the location of the singer's new house by publishing a map and photographs alongside the article.

Verdict: The following apology was published in the Sun: "An article about George Michael 's new home, published on May 25 1998, was accompanied by a map of the area and photographs of the mews in which he lives. We are sorry if these identified the whereabouts of his home as this was not our intention."

1997: The press v the PCC on Princess Diana
The code of practice was tightened after the death in 1997 of Princess Diana. Guidelines on long-lens photography banned the paparazzi from private property, including restaurants and churches.

It was the first time the PCC had defined precisely what constituted private property. Lord Wakeham made it clear that celebrities bathing on public beaches could not expect to be off limits, hence the continuing use of paparazzi pictures of celebrities such as Michael Winner and Sir David Frost displaying their paunches on the seashores.

New controls on doorstepping were also introduced, stopping hordes of journalists (and particularly TV cameras) camping at private addresses in the hope of getting an interview.

1995: Judy Finnigan and Richard Madeley v the Daily Mail
Complaint: After Judy, the queen of daytime TV, appeared on This Morning with a black eye, the Mail rang an article asking "What IS up with Judy?"

The couple complained that the paper had used the incident to "peddle unsubstantiated old rumours and tittle tattle" about their private life. They also complained that Judy's elderly mother had been harassed by the paper, which sent a reporter to her home and telephoned her.

Verdict: The complaint was not upheld. The PCC said it saw no reason why polite and discreet approaches could not be made about public personalities.

1996: The press v PCC on the Rosemary West trial
Complaint: The courts expressed concern that trials could be prejudiced when witnesses were paid to tell their stories to newspapers. The alarm bells rang following revelations that several witnesses in the West trial had lined up lucrative deals with the tabloids following the verdict.

Verdict: The PCC tightened up its rules outlawing payments except in cases of overriding public interest.

1995: Selina Scott v the News of the World
Complaint: Ms Scott, then one of Britain's biggest television stars, was furious after the Sunday paper in a "kiss and tell" classic had an affair with a man 15 years earlier. "It was a downright lie," Ms Scott told the PCC. "I have never slept with the man in my life."

Verdict: Complaint upheld.

1995: Lady Victoria Spencer v the News of the World
Complaint: On behalf of his wife, Earl Spencer complained about a story headlined "Di's sister-in-law in booze and bulimia clinic" which included a photograph of Lady Spencer taken with a telephoto lens.

Verdict: News of the World writer Piers Morgan was subjected to a public flogging following the investigation by the PCC, which agreed with Earl Spencer that his wife's privacy had been invaded.

The PCC chairman, Lord Wakeham, was so determined to make an example of Mr Morgan, he somehow forced his boss, Rupert Murdoch, to reprimand his wayward editor by way of a public letter. "The young man went over the top," said Mr Murdoch.

1994: Germaine Greer v the Mail on Sunday
Complaint: Germaine Greer was fuming when a young journalist from the Mail on Sunday won his way into her house by pretending to be one of the homeless to whom she had made the offer of free accommodation.

Verdict: The complaint was upheld.

Verdict: The PCC tightened up its rules outlawing payments except in cases of overriding public interest. 1995: Selina Scott v the News of the World Complaint: Ms Scott, then one of Britain's biggest television stars, was furious after the Sunday paper in a "kiss and tell" classic had an affair with a man 15 years earlier. "It was a downright lie," Ms Scott told the PCC. "I have never slept with the man in my life." Verdict: Complaint upheld. 1995: Lady Victoria Spencer v the News of the World Complaint: On behalf of his wife, Earl Spencer complained about a story headlined "Di's sister-in-law in booze and bulimia clinic" which included a photograph of Lady Spencer taken with a telephoto lens. Verdict: News of the World writer Piers Morgan was subjected to a public flogging following the investigation by the PCC, which agreed with Earl Spencer that his wife's privacy had been invaded. The PCC chairman, Lord Wakeham, was so determined to make an example of Mr Morgan, he somehow forced his boss, Rupert Murdoch, to reprimand his wayward editor by way of a public letter. "The young man went over the top," said Mr Murdoch. 1994: Germaine Greer v the Mail on Sunday Complaint: Germaine Greer was fuming when a young journalist from the Mail on Sunday won his way into her house by pretending to be one of the homeless to whom she had made the offer of free accommodation. Verdict: The complaint was upheld. webTitle: Papers enjoy party at Last Chance Saloon

fields.headline: Papers enjoy party at Last Chance Saloon
fields.standfirst:
As the press regulator throws its 10th birthday bash, media correspondent Matt Wells asks if the watchdog really works

The PCC's greatest hits

MediaGuardian
fields.trailText: As the press regulator throws its 10th birthday bash, media correspondent Matt Wells asks if the watchdog really works.
fields.body:
If we are to believe the Sun, it will be the social event of the year. But if you pay attention to the list of acceptances rather than invitations, the press complaints commission's 10th anniversary bash looks more like the launch of yet another shopping channel.

Carol Vorderman, Richard and Judy and half the cast of Coronation Street doesn't exactly sound like an A-list party. It's just as well that William, Charles and Camilla are there, otherwise coverage would be relegated to the pages of the Mirror's 3am girls.

The party has, nevertheless, been a shrewd publicity wheeze dreamt up by the commission's director, Guy Black. It has ensured that discussion of the role of the PCC has been splashed across the papers for days.

The received wisdom (that is, the received wisdom of the press) is that the arrangement - designed to escort the press out of the Last Chance Saloon before closing time - been a great success. The press has curbed its behaviour, complainants are given a chance to air their grievances and editors have occasionally been censured.

While it is true that the worst excesses of the tabloids have been eased since the 1980s, there remain serious questions over the cosy relationship between the press and its regulator.

The PCC is more akin to a conciliation service than a court. It attempts to work out a compromise between the complainant and the newspaper, which in most cases results in an inconspicuous printed apology, or a letter on the newspaper's comment pages. Many complainants find this arrangement less than satisfactory - mud sticks.

Second, the PCC rules do not allow for complaints by third parties or groups of people. There is no recompense, therefore, for asylum seekers to complain about the biased and prejudiced reporting of their plight from some sections of the press.

Third, in cases where the complainant's word is set against that of a journalist, many feel it is the reporter who come off best. The PCC has no independent means of investigation.

But the flawed arrangement appears to be working. There is a truce, albeit an uneasy one, between the press and the royals. (Yet even this arrangement has shades of the old boys' network, having largely been brokered by Mr Black and his predecessor, flatmate and close friend, Mark Bolland - who happens to be deputy private secretary to the Prince of Wales.)

"As long as the editors stick to the code, then we will be all right, and I think the editors have every intention of sticking to the code," the PCC chairman, Lord Wakeham, said today.

And therein lies the key: the code was drawn up by editors, and they are hardly likely to break their own rules. They know that any major infraction would result in the doors of the Last Chance Saloon being slammed in their faces.

fields.headline: Shots fired outside White House
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: A gunman was shot outside the White House fence this afternoon after he refused to surrender to secret service officers, a law enforcement officer said.
fields.body:
A gunman was shot outside the White House fence this afternoon after he refused to surrender to secret service officers, a law enforcement officer said.

The US president, George Bush, was reported safe inside the residence, where he had been exercising at the time of the security scare.

The secret service said one of its officers shot the gunman - reportedly in the knee - and he has been taken to hospital.

The US park police said 47-year-old Robert Pickett was in custody. One report said the gunman had threatened to commit suicide before being arrested.

Mr Bush "was never in any danger," the White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said of the incident. The gunman was taken to nearby George Washington university hospital, a fire department spokesman said. The gunman's injuries are not life-threatening, the police said.

One law enforcement official said at least one shot was fired in the incident by the public fence alongside the back lawn of the White House.

There have been conflicting reports over whether the gunman - whom police confirmed was carrying a handgun - actually fired any shots. One report said he fired three.

However, the secret service said only one shot was fired during the incident and that was by their agent.

A witness, Sook Jo, said she heard a load sound, followed by smoke. Then, she said, secret service agents came out yelling "drop it" while shouting at a man who sat slowly down on the ground.

Another witness, Martin Manley, told CNN the gunman, "was just standing in the street and randomly fired a few shots".

He said the man jumped into bushes and was surrounded by police but initially refused to surrender.

"Police were talking to him, telling him 'it doesn't have to be this way, put the gun down'. Then I heard one shot and the police all rushed in".

Secret service agents and police surrounded the White House after the incident at around 11:30am local time (1730GMT).

webTitle: Job uncertainty fuels above-inflation NHS pay awards

fields.headline: Job uncertainty fuels above-inflation NHS pay awards
fields.trailText: Health managers have defended massive pay rises of up to 17% and average reward packages of more than £80,000 for NHS trust chief executives, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
Health managers have defended massive pay rises of up to 17% and average reward packages of more than £80,000 for NHS trust chief executives.

A survey of trust chief executives' pay, published today, found salaries increased by an average of 6% in 1999-2000, almost double the limit recommended by health secretary Alan Milburn.

The NHS confederation said the inflation-busting rises reflected the increasing insecurity of senior NHS management jobs, which are notoriously vulnerable to political intervention and trust mergers.

Andrew Foster, NHS confederation human resources policy director said: "NHS chief executives have relatively poor job security and this is becoming more and more of a problem."

One NHS manager told SocietyGuardian.co.uk: "You are paid this kind of money because they can sack you like that. I don't think any managers are under any illusions about this."

The confederation said high salaries were also needed to attract and retain good managers to an increasingly complex and stressful job.

Turnover in NHS boardrooms continued to run at high levels, with more than 50 chief executives leaving or being replaced as a result of mergers in 1999-2000, the study by pay analysts Incomes Data Services said.

The study reveals that the average trust chief executive received a package of pay, benefits and bonuses worth between £74,000 and £98,000.

The highest paid chief executive, Dr Jonathan Michael - employed at the time of the survey with University Hospital Birmingham NHS trust - received £144,000.

He has since moved to Guy's and St Thomas' trust, London - where his predecessor Tim Matthews was paid the second highest trust chief executive salary - £135,000 - before moving to a civil service job.

 NHS boardroom pay report 2001 is available from Incomes Data Services, priced £160.

fields.body:
Rage Online (www.rageonline.co.uk) is the fanzine's presence on the internet. As well as daily news updates (web-editor's laziness permitting) there is editorial comment and a space for supporters to write in with their views.

In addition there is an extensive links page and an archive which lists every article the magazine has ever published.

The site also boasts the most extensive collection of Oxford United related poetry ever gathered together in one place (not really a difficult achievement) and all the usual internet guff, such as forums and a voting booth (the current poll - "when will United be mathematically relegated?" - even gaining Rage Online a mention in the Guardian recently).

webTitle: Why we don't want the chairman out

fields.headline: Why we don't want the chairman out
fields.standfirst: United are having a terrible time of it, but Rage On haven't been calling for heads to roll. Here's why
fields.trailText: You would expect a fanzine to take a long hard look at the current state of Oxford United and to be at the forefront of calls for at least a change of manager, if not the resignation of the chairman. You might be wondering why a fanzine with the reputation of Rage On, which in its previous incarnations was threatened with prosecution by Robert Maxwell and had its editors publicly berated by managing director Keith Cox, is not mounting a 'Sack Kemp' campaign, or asking why 'Kassam Out!' doesn't regale our front cover. Well may you ask and, guess what, we're going to tell you!
fields.body:
You would expect a fanzine to take a long hard look at the current state of Oxford United and to be at the forefront of calls for at least a change of manager, if not the resignation of the chairman. You might be wondering why a fanzine with the reputation of Rage On, which in its previous incarnations was threatened with prosecution by Robert Maxwell and had its editors publicly berated by managing director Keith Cox, is not mounting a 'Sack Kemp' campaign, or asking why 'Kassam Out!' doesn't regale our front cover. Well may you ask and, guess what, we're going to tell you!

When Firoz Kassam took over the ownership of United in early 1999, he inherited a club that was millions in debt, losing thousands every week, had a half-built rusting stadium that had lain untouched for over two years and was facing imminent receivership as a result of many years of financial mismanagement (remember that Robert Maxwell "saved" the club with a loan of £128,000 back in 1981). At that time, Rage On was calling for Keith Cox to step down, believing that the club would have been better off in receivership than under his stewardship and with no apparent saviour in sight.

Since Kassam arrived out of the blue we have been reasonably supportive of him, whatever his motives, because he generally delivered on his promises and because of his businesslike methods. Despite the current clamour for him to leave (if half-a-dozen mouthy people on the internet can be described as a clamour) we can see no reason to change our opinion. There is only the most circumstantial of evidence to suggest that Kassam is trying to shaft United (we were never under the illusion that he took over the club out of purely philanthropic considerations) and, since Kassam has rid the club of a lot of its debt burden, we no longer believe that administration is a viable alternative. Of course, if we believe that the evidence exists to make us change our minds then you can guarantee that we will do so vociferously.

Rage On has never really believed in the "saviour" ethos of football-club ownership. There are very few Jack Walkers around, and certainly none who support Oxford (unless the very shaky rumours concerning Richard Branson are to be believed), and once their benevolence is exhausted, the chickens come home to roost (look at Blackburn's recent troubles; look at the problems that have beset United since Maxwell fell off his boat). We have always favoured the Community Club model, as at Bournemouth, as a meaningful and practical way forward, even if it means that realistically we would have to give up any dreams of ever competing in the top flight again.

As for manager David Kemp, we cannot deny that we are disappointed with the lack of improvement on the playing front since he arrived, although we do accept that it is still early days and that he has inherited a squad of substandard, disinterested and demoralised individuals. We also appreciate the difficulties Joe Kinnear must face in trying to persuade players to make the move to what is, effectively, a lost cause, although we were hoping to see more inward movement than has happened, and of better quality players. We were also hoping for more outward movement, especially of those players who are clearly not performing, but we have learned to be patient and, unlike some, we never believed in Kinnear's Midas touch, or that things would improve dramatically once the stadium work had recommenced.

fields.headline: No 4: Oxford United
fields.standfirst: Martin Brodetsky, co-editor of Oxford fanzine Rage On, introduces us to his club
fields.trailText: Martin Brodetsky, co-editor of Oxford fanzine Rage On, introduces us to his club.
fields.body:
What makes Oxford so special

Being an Oxford United supporter means never having a dull moment as the clubs lurches from crisis to crisis, with the occasional silver lining making its presence known. None of this has deterred a hard core of around 4,000 supporters following the club as it languishes at the foot of the Second Division, and it is United's supporters which make the club so special.

From as far back as the Southern League days of the 1950s the supporters pulled together to raise funds and actually build the stands at the Manor. More recently they clubbed together to deliver food parcels to the backroom staff when they had to endure two months without pay, and the independent supporters group FOUL (Fighting for Oxford United's Life) has been instrumental in ensuring the survival of the club during the past two years of City Council hesitation and many other obstacles as the club has struggled to build its new stadium.

The high points

The high point for most Us supporters is undoubtedly the 1986 Milk Cup final victory at Wembley, during United's first year in the (proper) First Division. Oxford beat QPR, managed by former United boss Jim Smith, 3-0 to record the highest winning margin at Wembley in the League Cup (to give the tournament its real name).

In fact, the only player in a yellow shirt playing for United who had arrived since Smith's departure ten months earlier was the inspirational Ray Houghton. The victory was rounded off by a wonderful gesture from the late Maurice Evans, when the United manager sent physio Ken Fish up the steps to collect the winners medal in his place.

The low points

The low point, and there are so many to choose from, may be just around the corner as the latest legal challenge to the new ground at Minchery Farm could cause chairman Firoz Kassam finally to throw in the towel and walk away, leaving United to the administrators and, probably, worse.

The lowest point that has actually occurred was that period just over two years ago when the club had no money to pay backroom staff wages, players were being sold for a fraction of their value just to keep the bank from foreclosing and results were indicative of the off-the-field turmoil. There was one specific 2-0 defeat at Watford when the team was forced to wear the Hornets' away strip, their own having been left in Oxford, leading to rumours that United had been unable to pay the laundry bill and the club was on the brink of closure. The frightening thing is that at the time these rumours were deemed entirely credible.

How we're doing at the moment

At the moment the team's performances have led to United becoming the laughing stock of the football league, with even Cambridge or Colchester looking forward to our visit in the knowledge that three points is virtually guaranteed them. In the whole squad there are maybe half a dozen players of the required standard to keep United in the Second Division but there is not one who is a natural captain.

However, all this pales into insignificance compared to events off the field where yet again the club is fighting a legal battle in an attempt to prevent work on the new stadium, recommenced in November after a four-year gap, from stopping again. This time it is an adjacent landowner who has been given leave to seek a judicial review into the granting of planning permission for a multiplex cinema in the leisure complex adjacent to the stadium, and on which the ground is dependent for funding. The review process could last anything from three months to a year, but with the work scheduled for a late July finish and Oxford needing the stadium before the start of next season, any delay could be potentially fatal.

Our last game

United's last game was an abject capitulation at Peterborough, where the U's went down 4-2 despite, or possibly because of, taking a 19th-minute lead through Matt Murphy. One of the hallmarks of Oxford's recent form has been their inability to hold onto a lead, even a two-goal lead on more than one occasion, and so going ahead so early is always going to be dangerous given the club's penchant for self-destruction.

Our next game

Next up, United welcome Wycombe to the Manor which, for the Chairboys at least, should be an entertaining derby. Oxford still doesn't regard its nearest neighbours as true rivals, reserving that accolade for Swindon, but some spice should be added by the fact that we still haven't beaten Wanderers at the Manor in the league. Optimism dictates that we should be worth a draw, but realism is likely to rear its ugly head and give United a 2-1 defeat. After going ahead, of course.

Sore point

The current sore point must surely be the departure of Joe Kinnear, who left his position as Director of Football last week citing family and health reasons. Fair enough, except he has now commenced the same position at Luton Town, just one place above Oxford in the league. This leads one to suspect that Mr Kinnear was being somewhat economical with the truth and, if the rumours that his move to the Hatters was arranged prior to Christmas are true, he has embarrassed himself, the club and his friend, chairman Firoz Kassam.

The chairman

Firoz Kassam took over United two years ago, just as it seemed that the club was going to have to fold. He had no footballing background but was a successful, and very rich, hotelier. His time at Oxford has been dogged by controversy and he has been on the verge of leaving more than once, but he has stuck with it and his determination was rewarded when Birse Construction began work at Minchery Farm at the end of last year.

Supporters of Oxford are still split in their assessment of Kassam: is he an unscrupulous businessman using the club as a tool for a lucrative hotel and leisure complex, or is he a neophyte fan who has ploughed millions into the club with little or no likelihood of recouping his investment? Time will tell, but the majority of fans are inclined towards the more generous viewpoint. Whatever his motives, though, Kassam's presence has guaranteed at least two more years of professional football in Oxford than appeared likely the day before he arrived on the scene.

Our traditional rivals

A number of clubs claim to be United's rivals, including the aforementioned Wycombe as well as Reading, but it's only Swindon Town that really excites the emotions up the Manor. Why it should be the Robins rather than the Biscuitmen is more due to our poor record against the team from the wrong end of the A420 than any logical reason. Indeed, logic would dictate that Reading should receive our ire following the ill-fated attempt of Robert Maxwell to merge the two clubs. However, it is the fact that the U's have only ever won once at the County Ground that means we save up our fervour for a visit to Wiltshire more than anywhere else.

The feud even led to an all-out war between the two local papers a few years ago, the Oxford Mail firing the first shots with a story listing the advantages of living in Oxford over Swindon. Whilst most United supporters are resigned to relegation this season, the pill will be sweetened immensely if we are joined in the Third Division by our local rivals.

Our kit

The current kit is the least popular creation that Oxford players have ever had the misfortune to turn out in. United used to play in old gold and black, similar to Wolves, and in the early seventies this changed to yellow and royal blue. The blue later became navy and those are the colours that the club adopted until this season. The yellow is almost green and under floodlights it is a cause for eyestrain trying to spot the Oxford players, especially given their tendency to disappear anyway. This kit is even more unfortunate given that last season's was probably the best that the players have ever worn: plain, traditional yellow with no fancy design work to distract from the team's shortcomings. Marvellous.

Mascots

United have, thankfully, steadfastly refused to follow the ridiculous trend of dressing some poor chap in an oversized furry suit and pretending that he's some kind of talisman. The nearest we come is when local commercial radio station Fox FM sends their Freddy the Fox character to the Manor, which doesn't happen too often luckily, but the club's commercial team has always shared the fans' views that these creeping Americanisms are there to be withstood. Let's hope that this is a stance that continues.

Players we love

The current most popular player at United, and there aren't many popular players to choose from, is local boy Chris Hackett. Hackett, 17, only made his home debut in December against Northampton and capped off a defence-destroying performance with an excellent individual goal. Hackett is a former sprint champion and he has the pace to worry any defender. He is most effective on the right wing but has also been played up front. He has already been scouted by Premiership clubs but will hopefully show the same loyalty to United as the lad on the opposite wing, Joey Beauchamp.

The most popular player ever to have donned the yellow shirt is probably John Aldridge, although Matty Elliott runs him a close second. Aldridge was largely responsible for bringing the Glory Years to Oxford in the mid-80s, whilst Elliott single-handedly made a sub-standard United into a decent First-Division team (we were eighth when he was sold to Leicester in December 1996 and narrowly avoided relegation that season). There are very few players from other teams that the United crowd readily accept, and all the ones who do receive the applause of the London Road end tend to be popular ex-Us.

Players we hate

As with any club with a record similar to Oxford's, there are a number of players who incite the wrath of the crowd, especially those on high salaries who are deemed to be under-performing. Included in this category are Steve Anthrobus, a centre-forward who has only scored three league goals in his eighteen months at the Manor, and Peter Fear, who constantly reminds us that he is an ex-Premiership player but whose commitment would be considered questionable in a Sunday League side. Matt Murphy also comes in for mass condemnation, although to be fair it's not really his fault that he doesn't have the ability to do the job that is asked of him, namely to play professional football.

The least popular player ever to have played for United is harder to call, not due to a lack of possibilities. My personal bete noire is Billy "the Whale" Whitehurst, a lumbering oaf of a centre forward who was playing in the old First Division, about four divisions above his talent level. A lot of others cite Marco Gabbiadini, on loan for just four weeks from Derby but whose waistline was more prominent than his goalscoring prowess.

The ground

The Manor is a unique, but small and increasingly tatty, venue. It is consistently voted the worst ground in the country by away supporters who are kept behind anachronistic fences, but home fans will certainly miss the place when the time comes to leave. It is in the middle of residential Headington and as well as no parking facilities there is no room for expansion.

As the capacity decreases season by season for safety reasons, the necessity to move has been apparent for many years and for the last three seasons the club has had to apply for special dispensation from the Football Licensing Authority in order to continue playing there. There is little chance for a fourth successive exemption and so, should Minchery Farm fail to be completed for whatever reason, United will have nowhere to play next season.

The crowd

The atmosphere at the Manor, especially on those midweek cup nights, has always been special and during the eighties the place was justifiably known as Fortress Manor, the home crowd often quoted as being United's special advantage (along with the sloping pitch, of course). Nowadays there are no chants unique to United and there is an unfortunate minority which insists on thinking that it is big and clever to sing No Surrender. These are most likely the same people who throw coins at opposition goalkeepers and who tore the goal nets down at Macclesfield. Sadly there are some United fans who are still living in the 1970s.

Local knowledge

The best pub near the ground is the Butchers Arms, a Fullers pub which is also away-fan friendly (although not to Chelsea fans, after their last visit to the Manor). There are a number of other decent hostelries around Headington, including the Black Boy, the Bell and the White Hart down nearby back streets. Most away fans will notice the White Horse, the Britannia and the Royal Standard, being as they are on the main London Road, although if it's real ale you want then these are not the places to frequent. For food there is Smart's Fish and Chips close to the ground and not too far away is the Mediterranean Fish Bar. More upmarket is the Café Noir, next to the club shop but not really tailored to cater for most football fans' tastes.

Fanzines

Apart from Rage On, United only has one other fanzine that has lasted the pace - Yellow Fever, more known for its Viz-style humour than its insights into the club's politics, but a good complement to Rage On. Two others - Mad Ox Review and Shott Away - only lasted for one and two issues respectively. Recently some independent United websites have ceased functioning, leaving the official site (which has improved immeasurably recently), the Rivals.com site (which has deteriorated), the From the Terraces site and the recently revamped Oxford Mail site as the primary ports of call for Oxford supporters.

fields.headline: Mandelson exit splits Lib Dems
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat high command is at odds over whether it has blundered by helping topple Peter Mandelson.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat high command is at odds over whether it has blundered by helping topple Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary and one of the party's closest allies within the Labour cabinet.

Sir Paddy Ashdown, the former Liberal Democrat leader, has told colleagues that Mr Mandelson's downfall may be a definitive turning point in the so-called "project", the attempt to realign centre-left politics.

Since becoming party leader two years ago Charles Kennedy has hardly spoken to Mr Mandelson about inter-party co-operation and does not regard him as an indispensable conduit. However, other senior Liberal Democrat MPs fear the party has shot itself in the foot.

Mr Mandelson's downfall was triggered by a parliamentary written question tabled by Norman Baker, the relatively junior Lib Dem MP for Lewes.

Mr Baker had been relentlessly pursuing Mr Mandelson over his stewardship of the dome, including his contacts with Hinduja brothers, the sponsors for the faith zone.

Sir Paddy, who still regularly attends meetings of the parliamentary party, has told friends his belief that the departure of Mr Mandelson may mark a decisive change in Labour's relations with the Liberal Democrats, is broadly shared by Lord Jenkins, the former Lib Dem leader in the Lords who chaired the official government inquiry into electoral reform for the Commons.

Lord Rodgers, the current Lib Dem leader in the Lords, also believes that his party's cause has been seriously set back.

Sir Paddy and his close adviser Lord Holme saw Mr Mandelson as a vital figure in pushing issues such as electoral reform and Europe. The former Lib Dem leader was a close student of the balance of forces inside the Labour cabinet as he fought to extract concessions from Mr Blair over PR for European elections and the Commons.

Mr Baker, however, is unrepentant about his role and insists his actions have been fully cleared with Mr Kennedy. He has said: "Charles and I have been talking constantly about this matter, and he fully backs me."

webTitle: Leader: Portillo's package has nothing for the poor

fields.headline: Wooing middle England
fields.standfirst:
Portillo's package has nothing for the poor

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: This year may see the first election in recent memory in which Labour and the Conservatives will be falling over each other not to be different.
fields.body:
This year may see the first election in recent memory in which Labour and the Conservatives will be falling over each other not to be different. The Tories say they will match any spending increases Labour is planning in such key areas as health and education (while still claiming the government is spending too much). They now say they will also match any tax cuts Gordon Brown whips out of his box on budget day. Maybe, but the most interesting thing about the policies announced this week is that they are actually different. Mr Brown, commendably, will put aside £3bn to help working people with families while the Tories will use £2.3bn to abolish tax on savings and dividends for all but the highest tax payers in another bid to woo the stray sheep of middle England back to their flock.

Michael Portillo's surprise package will not do anything for the very poor because they do not have savings but it will make a lot of rich people happier. In the process some - those liable for higher tax rates who will pay 22% on part of their savings - will face un-Tory marginal tax rates of 62%. The biggest beneficiaries will be the comparatively few rich people living entirely off dividends and interest who could gain £5,700 a year simply by doing nothing. There will be some welcome beneficiaries, such as low rate taxpayers who leave their money in building societies unaware it could earn more in tax-shelters such as Isas. Their savings and dividends will no longer be taxed.

But for people whose spare cash is already stashed away in government tax schemes it will not make much difference. It will just add yet another twist to a labyrinthine fiscal system and is unlikely by itself to be a major factor in the election. Nor will it have much macro-economic impact, since the number of people deciding to save more could be offset by those deciding that targets for savings they had previously set themselves had already been met - so they might simply spend Mr Portillo's bounty.

If saving does, unexpectedly, turn into an election issue then Mr Brown still has resources in reserve to make matching provisions in his budget. It would not, it seems, be politically proper for the main parties to approach the election with radically different fiscal policies. It is a good job joining the euro is still around as a contentious issue or it might be difficult for shortsighted people to tell the parties apart.

webTitle: Labour peer bids for digital radio licence

fields.headline: Labour peer bids for digital radio licence
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Lord Waheed Alli is heading a consortium bidding for the third London digital radio multiplex licence, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Lord Waheed Alli is heading a powerful consortium bidding for the third London digital radio multiplex licence.

The Labour peer and former TV executive is chairman of the Digital Radio Group, a consortium backed by leading radio groups GWR, Emap, Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group and Virgin Radio owner SMG.

The Carphone Warehouse is also part of the DRG consortium.

The group is planning to offer more than eight digital radio services, including country music station Ritz 1035 and Purple Radio, a service aimed at London's gay community.

Lord Alli, the Planet 24 co-founder who left his last job as Carlton Productions managing director in November, has been campaigning for a gay radio station for the past five years.

"We want to increase access for a range of different groups of people," he said.

"This is a consortium run by highly experienced people. They know all about radio but, above all, they are interested in providing choice."

Other yet to be announced digital audio and data services will be supplied by GWR (which operates Classic FM), Emap (which runs the Kiss network), Talk Sport (which owns the Wireless Group) and SMG.

Applications for the third London digital radio multiplex must be submitted to the Radio Authority by Tuesday March 13.

A decision is expected in the summer.

webTitle: Chairman quits after Hull go into administration

fields.headline: Chairman quits after Hull go into administration
fields.trailText: Nick Buchanan has quit as chairman of Hull City, hours after the club went into administration.
fields.body:
Nick Buchanan has quit as chairman of Hull City, hours after the club went into administration.

The Tigers survived a winding-up order in the High Court today, but the future of the Third Division club remains in doubt.

Kroll Buchler Phillips, a leading corporate recovery and financial restructuring group, were appointed joint administrators of Hull City AFC Limited by order of the High Court.

The order was issued by Customs and Excise and the Inland Revenue for payment of £500,000 and other debts believed to total £1m.

Buchanan saw the administrators this afternoon and offered his resignation, which was accepted.

After ending his two-and-a-half year association with the Tigers, Buchanan said: "I always said I would resign from the club if I felt I was holding them back and I've felt this week that I've been a handicap to them rather than a help.

"I also did it because I want the club to have a future and I feel the only way for that to happen is for me to step aside and let someone else come in.

"There are no sour grapes about this," he stressed. "I am passionate about Hull City and want them to survive. I have battled, fought and toiled for the last two-and-a-half-years for no financial reward.

"I wish the next person who comes in here to take this job all the very best and hope that they can build a team which the fans can be proud of."

One of the first tasks facing the club will be to find a venue for this Saturday's home league match with Leyton Orient.

The club's Boothferry Park ground was yesterday locked up by owner and former club chairman David Lloyd, who claims he too is owed substantial sums by the club.

The Tigers now hope to play this Saturday's home league match against Leyton Orient at Grimsby's Blundell Park.

One of the first tasks facing the club will be to find a venue for this Saturday's home league match with Leyton Orient. The club's Boothferry Park ground was yesterday locked up by owner and former club chairman David Lloyd, who claims he too is owed substantial sums by the club. The Tigers now hope to play this Saturday's home league match against Leyton Orient at Grimsby's Blundell Park.

fields.headline: Appointment is race equality breakthrough
fields.trailText: Will the appointment of Daphne Obang as the UK's first ever black female social services director herald a new era of ethnic minorities in management?
fields.body:
The appointment of Daphne Obang as the UK's first ever black female social services director is being welcomed as a major race equality breakthrough in a profession dominated at grassroots level by women and ethnic minority staff.

Ms Obang, assistant director of community care at Camden council, will take up the £70,000-plus job at Bracknell Forest in May.

Historically, social services have struggled to identify, appoint and keep ethnic minority top managers.

The careers of three of the four previous black social services directors in the UK - Olsen Samuel at Haringey council, Patrick Kodikara at Camden and David Divine at Brent council were all short-lived.

The fourth - Ram Ramadhan, who served at Oldham council for more than a decade - was suspended for several months in 1998 after severe disagreements with an assistant director. The council denied the suspension was linked to the announcement of his retirement on his return to work.

With an embarrassing dearth of senior managers from ethnic minorities, the Association of Directors of Social Services and the Improvement and Development Agency last March joined forces to launch a black mentoring scheme, which has since being adopted by the Cabinet Office.

Schemes such as this to promote more positive action - rather than positive discrimination - to help staff develop key skills are welcomed by Chris Williams who became the UK's first Asian social services director in 1993.

"What needs to happen for black and Asian staff is the same thing that happened for women," he said. "People were accepting of gender discrimination before they were of race discrimination and there was a lot of positive discrimination around work with increased opportunities for women."

Neelam Bhardwaja was among the first 13 senior managers to graduate from the mentoring scheme in December and has since been promoted to children's services manager at Peterborough council. She believes Ms Obang's appointment is a much-needed boost to ethnic minorities across all sectors.

"Because they [ethnic minority managers] are so few and far between in terms of representation - and social services aren't the exception in local government - having role models at the head of any organisation is an inspiration," she said. "Not everybody is going to make it but at least it will be a motivational factor to see that it can be done and barriers can be overcome."

There are presently five black assistant social services directors - all based in London. But Jabeer Butt, researcher and consultant at the government's race equality unit doesn't necessarily believe Ms Obang's appointment heralds a new generation of black senior managers breaking through the ranks.

"There have been a number of black senior managers around for a number of years but the difficulty is in being promoted from assistant director to director level," he said.

Lack of support at director level and the huge influence of councillors who are reluctant in appointing directors are major issues that must be addressed, he added.

"Real work needs to be done with the local government association and the people it represents. What needs to be recognised is that Daphne is an exceptional person in her own qualities and while her achievements are encouraging we mustn't necessarily see this as a huge sign that things are changing."

webTitle: First black female social services director appointed

fields.headline: First black female social services director appointed
fields.trailText: Exclusive: A Conservative-run council has made history by appointing the UK's first black woman social services director. Marcia White reports
fields.body:
A Conservative-run council has made history by appointing the UK's first black woman social services director.

Bracknell Forest borough council has hired Daphne Obang, assistant director for community care at Camden council, to overhaul its failing social services department.

Ms Obang was this week finalising details of the move, which is expected to be formally announced on Friday. She will head Bracknell's social services and housing department. Expected to start in May, Ms Obang's salary will be between £75,000 and £80,000 a year, near the top end of the pay scale for social services directors.

Bracknell Forest chief executive, Gordon Mitchell, said: "Bracknell Forest is pleased to be the first authority to be appointing a black woman as its director of social services. Daphne got the job because she was the best candidate - she was chosen because of her ability."

Ms Obang will become one of just two ethnic minority social services directors in the UK's 211 social services departments. The other is Dudley council's Chris Williams, the first ever Asian social services director.

The appointment comes just a fortnight after the Royal College of Nursing appointed its first black general secretary, the US nursing union leader Beverly Malone.

Ms Obang succeeds Trevor Farmer, who took early retirement last August just before an inspection by the social services inspectorate and the Audit Commission revealed serious problems with Bracknell's social services.

The joint review report published last week uncovered staff vacancies of 16%, and a lack of strategic direction.

Urgent areas for improvement listed by inspectors included assessments of children and adults, commissioning of services, quality assurance arrangements for services, and inter-agency partnerships, particularly with the voluntary sector.

Ms Obang trained as a community psychiatric nurse and took up her first local authority post as a mental health social worker with Lewisham council in the early 1970s.

Her career has spanned Croydon council, as assistant area team manager, Tower Hamlets, where she was manager for adult services and then resources manager, and Newham council as manager for mental health and learning difficulties services before being promoted to head of adult services.

In 1997 she was appointed as one of five senior managers to run Camden social services department where she has been praised for playing a key role in modernising adult services and implementing innovative change.

Ms Obang described the challenges at Bracknell Forest as not that different from the inner city problems experienced at Camden.

She said: "After having completed three and a half years at the London borough of Camden, I am now looking forward to an exciting and challenging time in the role of director of social services and housing at Bracknell Forest borough council."

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), said: "ADSS has been working hard to make sure that access to senior management posts in social services is open to all candidates with the proper skills, experience and qualifications.

We hope Daphne's appointment is a sign that senior management in social services will progressively come to reflect the majority of our workforce and wider community."

There have been four black social services directors in the UK, all of them men - Ram Ramadhan at Oldham council, Olsen Samuel at Haringey council, Patrick Kodikara at Camden council and David Divine at Brent council, all of whom are no longer social services directors.

fields.headline: Blunkett drops £15m volunteer groups charge
fields.trailText: Charities have welcomed the government's announcement that it has dropped plans to force voluntary groups to pick up the bill for running security checks on community helpers.
fields.body:
Charities have welcomed the government's announcement that it has dropped plans to force voluntary groups to pick up the bill for running security checks on community helpers.

The proposal, which would have meant a £10-£15 vetting charge per volunteer, had outraged voluntary groups who claimed that it flew in the face of government plans to encourage an army of volunteers alongside the state.

Each volunteeer would have been required to pay the full cost of a criminal records check with the new criminal records bureau. Some organisations, such as the Scouts, feared an annual charge of £650,000, and it was estimated the checks could cost the voluntary sector as a whole as much as £15m a year.

Mr Blunkett announced that the cost of vetting would be met by the government at a conference today, organised by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO).

NCVO chief executive Stuart Etherington said: "Charging volunteers for a police check would have acted as a major discincentive to volunteering and run counter to the government's aims of encouraging community activity."

For the NSPCC, the announcement marks the successful end to an 18-month campaign on the issue of free record checks for the voluntary sector as a way of increasing child protection.

Liz Atkins, NSPCC head of policy and public affairs, said: "This is a great victory for child protection. It provides greater protection for children involved in community activities and gives parents peace of mind that their children are not in the care of known offenders. We know sex offenders are cunning in gaining access to children. Today's announcement makes it far more difficult for paedophiles to infiltrate these organisations."

Support for volunteering did not mean the government was off-loading its responsibilities, Mr Blunkett told the conference, but recognising that it cannot deliver all the services that are needed in the community. "The government is engaging with the voluntary sector to expand and add value," he said.

He also called on the voluntary sector to come up with ideas to increase access to funding. "We want to cut bureaucracy," he said.

The introduction of citizenship in the national curriculum was high on his agenda. "We want young people to understand the part they play in the life of the community," he said. Again Mr Blunkett asked delegates to come up with ideas which were "creative, not dreary and off-putting" to engage young people.

In an effort to increase the pool of potential volunteers, Mr Blunkett announced a relaxation in rules which deter jobless people from volunteering by requiring them to be available for work within 48 hours, as well as unveiling plans to encourage older people to give time to community work.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, recently called for a huge extension of volunteering, but his initiative was blunted by criticism over the criminal records charges.

The lifting of the charge, which was to have been imposed from next year as part of an attempt to protect vulnerable people from paedophiles, was agreed yesterday between the Treasury, the Home Office and the Department for Education.

The Scottish executive has already decided to provide free checks for volunteers.

Mr Blunkett yesterday pledged an extra £1m to the Community Champions fund, which encourages local people to contribute to their community.

The fund is now in its second year and has so far helped more than 700 individuals and community groups to set up projects.

The Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has also secured a further £1m a year from the Home Office Active Community fund allowing the programme to extend for a further three years.

The DfEE works in partnership with individual leaders in the voluntary and community sector to galvanise local people into becoming more involved in community and regeneration activity.

Mr Blunkett presented awards to 29 groups and individuals that have participated in the Community Champions fund. Winners include a Manchester sports programme that is working to cut crime and a project bringing IT to a rural community in Cornwall.

He said: "We need local people to get fully involved in driving change forward, if we are to see real improvements in our deprived communities. These 29 Community Champions are doing just that. Their dedication and enthusiasm means that money spent on an area is spent on what local people need."

He added that the extra money for the fund meant it could offer a greater focus on groups, such as older volunteers and people with disabilities and those from ethnic communities.

fields.headline: United formally announce Yankees tie-up
fields.trailText: Manchester United today announced they are joining forces with baseball club the New York Yankees in a marketing partnership.
fields.body:
Manchester United today announced they are joining forces with baseball club the New York Yankees in a marketing partnership.

United will use the baseball giants huge merchandising network to target existing and new fans in the States.

But United officials insist the deal does not mean they are looking to abandon the Premiership and become a 'superclub' in a breakaway league.

Paddy Harverson, United's director of communications, said today: "Manchester United are fully committed to the Premier League and domestic English football.

"There is no suggestion whatsoever that we are looking to leave the English game and join any kind of breakaway league."

The Yankees will use United's own vast network in Europe and the Far East to sell their distinctive merchandise.

The teams will share market information, develop sponsorship and joint promotional programs and sell each other's licensed goods.

Under the deal, David Beckham and Fabien Barthez will be paraded at the Yankee Stadium, with Yankees' El Duque and outfielder Bernie Williams visiting Old Trafford.

"The YankeeNets are an icon sports organization," Manchester United chief executive Peter Kenyon said at a news conference in New York.

"Their executive staff know that North American markets better than anyone. Soccer has developed dramatically in the US over the last 10 years and we believe there is a market for Manchester United content among football fans of all ages."

Shares in United went up 20p to 233.75p - an increase of around 9% - this morning after news of the partnership leaked out.

Kenyon and director Sir Bobby Charlton travelled to New York for the announcement.

United, worth a staggering £1bn, are already the richest football club in the world with revenue that dwarfs the rest of the Premiership and major European clubs like Barcelona, Real Madrid and Juventus.

There are comparisons between United, who are chasing their seventh Premiership title in nine years, and the Yankees, who have won three of the last four titles - the World Series - and, in all, a record 26.

United's £1billion wealth is far in excess of the Yankees who are believed to be capitalised at around £400m. They are, however, the wealthiest baseball team in the United States.

The company that owns the Yankees, YankeeNets, also controls the NBA's New Jersey Nets and ice hockey side the New Jersey Devils.

The deal will also see United play a pre-season tour of North America in 2003. Harvey Schiller, chairman of the baseball club's parent company YankeeNets, said: "This is a unique alliance in sports and shows that YankeeNets and Manchester United are real pioneers."

Kenyon added: "The YankeeNets have interests in baseball, basketball, icehockey and a marketing partner of the New York Giants. They have a particularly well developed multi-media business."

Peter Draper, United's group marketing director, will work with John Krimsky, president of YankeeNets Properties, to implement the new initiative.

From a sporting point of view, the two clubs with swap information on player training, fitness and health.

Schiller added: "Manchester United has done a great job internationalising their business with the sale of sponsorships and merchandise. This partnership puts our franchises in the company of one of the strongest brand names in the international sports world".

fields.headline: The rehabilitation of Austria
fields.standfirst: One year after Austria's far-right Freedom party rose to power as part of a conservative coalition, the party seems to be over or is it? Kate Connolly reports
fields.trailText: One year after Austria's far-right Freedom party rose to power as part of a conservative coalition, the party seems to be over or is it? Kate Connolly reports.
fields.body:
Tradition has it that when a new Austrian government is sworn in they walk the short distance across Vienna's Ballhaus square to the imperial palace, basking in their success and greeting well-wishers along the way.

Last February there were few well-wishers to be found amongst the paint-throwing, whistle-blowing, stone-hurling crowds who had tied black ribbons to the trees in angry protest at the new incumbents.

Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel was forced to lead his cabinet through an underground passageway from Vienna's chancellery to the palace where their first meeting was to be held.

The protesters were vocalising a Europe-wide wrath that Schüssel's conservative People's party (ÖVP) which had come third in elections the previous October, had made a coalition pact with populist firebrand Jörg Haider, allowing his far-right Freedom party (FPÖ), which had gained over a quarter of the vote, into power.

Pictures of President Thomas Klestil, steely-faced as he swore in a government of which he thoroughly disapproved, went round the world. The European Union immediately slapped sanctions on Austria and overnight the land of the Sound of Music became a pariah state.

Recalling those heady days in a background press talk held recently in the winter garden of a hotel in Vienna city centre, a high-ranking ÖVP politician chuckled: "Now we're sitting in a glass house, but a year ago we had to go via a tunnel for our swearing-in ceremony."

He curiously seemed to see it as a metaphor for the stability the alpine republic has reverted to in such a short time. Nobody pointed out to him how vulnerable people in glass houses can be.

But he is quite right in thinking that the dust has largely settled following elections which shook up an all too cosy political scene that had dominated Austrian politics for years.

It pushed the Social Democrats into opposition, ending their staggeringly long 30-year grip on the chancellery. Few disagree that such a shake-up was long overdue.

The EU sanctions that disappeared in a puff of smoke in September after they were deemed more harmful than helpful by three wise men from Brussels have now more or less been consigned to the history books.

And according to economic observers, they did little harm to Austria's economy: two of their biggest exports, Red Bull and Wolford tights have reported no slump in demand. Tourism is booming.

And while last year Belgium's foreign minister was declaring that it was "immoral to ski in Austria", launching an ad campaign for Belgian resorts showing an Austrian skier forming a swastika on his downhill run, this year Austria's St Anton is hosting the world's skiing championships.

The reaction shown by the outside world shocked most Austrians to the core, but it also forced them to deal with many issues linked to the past which have been constantly pushed onto the Germans, or under the carpet.

Most significantly, although not before time, a compensation fund for Nazi-era slave labourers and those deprived of their property by the Nazis is now in full swing.

Other reforms are underway, including a huge wave of privatisation, moves to cut the infamous bureaucracy and a long-term stability programme to cancel a large budget deficit.

But the unease about a country which collaborated closely with Nazi Germany and just over half a century later voted for a party whose leader had shown himself sympathetic to Nazi policies certainly remains.

Relations between Vienna and its European partners, Paris and Berlin in particular, remain cool.

And this week the fierce criticism received by the Count and Countess of Wessex for simply being caught on film with Haider's successor as FPÖ leader, Susanne Riess-Passer, proved how damaging the prominence of the FPÖ continues to be to Austria's image abroad.

And what of the man at the eye of the storm, who benefited from Austrians' yearning for the new but who then renounced his leadership post to vice-chancellor Riess-Passer in May and retreated to the southern province of Carinthia where he is governor?

Observers and acquaintances say the 51-year-old has now all but given up his lifelong dream to become chancellor, realising that there's hardly a leader in Europe who would dare to be seen shaking his hand.

He snarls from the sidelines now and again, this week telling French president Jacques Chirac to stop behaving like Napoleon, but has largely lost the magic charm that won his party so many votes and is said to be bitter that although he remains its most dominant figure, his party appears to do just fine without him.

Or maybe not. Despite its strong showing 16 months ago, the FPÖ is struggling in the polls, putting in poor performances in regional elections and it's expected to suffer badly in Vienna's local elections next month.

On the streets of Vienna the fight is still on to oust the government. Every Thursday evening a mix of young and old meet in front of the parliament building, demonstrating against a government which is identified by the party colours which make it up - black for the conservatives, blue for the Freedom party.

As up to 10,000 gathered last week to mark the coalition's first anniversary, one woman held a banner which read: "Stop! Austria has been black and blue for long enough."
