Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel was forced to lead his cabinet through an underground passageway from Vienna's chancellery to the palace where their first meeting was to be held. The protesters were vocalising a Europe-wide wrath that Schüssel's conservative People's party (ÖVP) which had come third in elections the previous October, had made a coalition pact with populist firebrand Jörg Haider, allowing his far-right Freedom party (FPÖ), which had gained over a quarter of the vote, into power. Pictures of President Thomas Klestil, steely-faced as he swore in a government of which he thoroughly disapproved, went round the world. The European Union immediately slapped sanctions on Austria and overnight the land of the Sound of Music became a pariah state. Recalling those heady days in a background press talk held recently in the winter garden of a hotel in Vienna city centre, a high-ranking ÖVP politician chuckled: "Now we're sitting in a glass house, but a year ago we had to go via a tunnel for our swearing-in ceremony." He curiously seemed to see it as a metaphor for the stability the alpine republic has reverted to in such a short time. Nobody pointed out to him how vulnerable people in glass houses can be. But he is quite right in thinking that the dust has largely settled following elections which shook up an all too cosy political scene that had dominated Austrian politics for years. It pushed the Social Democrats into opposition, ending their staggeringly long 30-year grip on the chancellery. Few disagree that such a shake-up was long overdue. The EU sanctions that disappeared in a puff of smoke in September after they were deemed more harmful than helpful by three wise men from Brussels have now more or less been consigned to the history books. And according to economic observers, they did little harm to Austria's economy: two of their biggest exports, Red Bull and Wolford tights have reported no slump in demand. Tourism is booming. And while last year Belgium's foreign minister was declaring that it was "immoral to ski in Austria", launching an ad campaign for Belgian resorts showing an Austrian skier forming a swastika on his downhill run, this year Austria's St Anton is hosting the world's skiing championships. The reaction shown by the outside world shocked most Austrians to the core, but it also forced them to deal with many issues linked to the past which have been constantly pushed onto the Germans, or under the carpet. Most significantly, although not before time, a compensation fund for Nazi-era slave labourers and those deprived of their property by the Nazis is now in full swing. Other reforms are underway, including a huge wave of privatisation, moves to cut the infamous bureaucracy and a long-term stability programme to cancel a large budget deficit. But the unease about a country which collaborated closely with Nazi Germany and just over half a century later voted for a party whose leader had shown himself sympathetic to Nazi policies certainly remains. Relations between Vienna and its European partners, Paris and Berlin in particular, remain cool. And this week the fierce criticism received by the Count and Countess of Wessex for simply being caught on film with Haider's successor as FPÖ leader, Susanne Riess-Passer, proved how damaging the prominence of the FPÖ continues to be to Austria's image abroad. And what of the man at the eye of the storm, who benefited from Austrians' yearning for the new but who then renounced his leadership post to vice-chancellor Riess-Passer in May and retreated to the southern province of Carinthia where he is governor? Observers and acquaintances say the 51-year-old has now all but given up his lifelong dream to become chancellor, realising that there's hardly a leader in Europe who would dare to be seen shaking his hand. He snarls from the sidelines now and again, this week telling French president Jacques Chirac to stop behaving like Napoleon, but has largely lost the magic charm that won his party so many votes and is said to be bitter that although he remains its most dominant figure, his party appears to do just fine without him. Or maybe not. Despite its strong showing 16 months ago, the FPÖ is struggling in the polls, putting in poor performances in regional elections and it's expected to suffer badly in Vienna's local elections next month. On the streets of Vienna the fight is still on to oust the government. Every Thursday evening a mix of young and old meet in front of the parliament building, demonstrating against a government which is identified by the party colours which make it up - black for the conservatives, blue for the Freedom party. As up to 10,000 gathered last week to mark the coalition's first anniversary, one woman held a banner which read: "Stop! Austria has been black and blue for long enough." webTitle: Lecturers and employers come to agreement

fields.headline: Lecturers and employers come to agreement
fields.trailText: Academic union officials have called off part of their industrial action after university employers agreed to retain nationally set terms and conditions for lecturers' pay.
fields.body:
Academic union officials have called off part of their industrial action after university employers agreed to retain nationally set terms and conditions for lecturers' pay.

University staff have been protesting at a below-inflation 3% pay offer and poor working conditions, as well as university employers' attempts to tear up the nationally set contracts for academics.

Recent industrial action has included withholding students' examination marks, boycotting exam boards and working to contract. Under the agreement reached today, lecturers will no longer withhold exam marks for nursing students completing their qualifications.

Both the lecturers' union, NATFHE, and the Universities and Colleges Employers' Association welcomed the outcome of this week's talks over pay for academic staff.

Tom Wilson, head of NATFHE's universities department said: "We are delighted that the talks have been positive, useful and realistic. We believe we have achieved a significant breakthrough. NATFHE's strong stand has clearly helped sway vice-chancellors. In the light of these positive developments, and as a gesture of goodwill, NATFHE is willing to suspend the withholding of exam marks for nursing students completing their qualifications."

The university employers' association, which represents vice-chancellors, has asked the unions to suspend all industrial action while the talks continue.

The union is putting this request to members and a decision is expected on February 14 when the talks are due to recommence.

webTitle: Teacher training applications on the rise

fields.headline: Teacher training applications on the rise
fields.trailText: Applications for teacher training in England and Wales are up by 12% on this time last year - the first increase in teacher training applications in eight years, the government has announced.
fields.body:
Applications for teacher training in England and Wales are up by 12% on this time last year - the first increase in teacher training applications in eight years, the government has announced.

Applications have increased in chemistry (up by 45%), physics (up by 23%), and technology (up by 52%).

The increase is being attributed to the success of the 'golden hellos' scheme. This year the teacher training agency is offering 'golden hellos' of £4,000 for those working in secondary school shortage subjects, such as mathematics, science, modern foreign languages and technology.

The agency is also offering teacher training salaries of £6,000 for teachers in England.

However, applications in secondary school subjects for the UK as a whole are down in French (-10.8%), history (-1.5%), geography (-3.2%), mathematics (-0.7%) and English (-0.4%).

For England and Wales a total of 19,986 applications for postgraduate teacher training courses were received by February 5 this year, compared with 17,908 at the same point last year, reveal figures from the graduate teacher training registry.

Education secretary David Blunkett said: "It is still early days and applications will continue to be received until September. However, these figures suggest that the introduction of teacher training salaries and golden hellos for shortage subjects are making teacher training a much more attractive choice for graduates. We are continuing to see a turn around in teacher recruitment."

webTitle: Ferries to Scandinavia from the north of England

fields.headline: Ferries to Scandinavia from the north of England
fields.standfirst:
Can I get a family of four and a car direct from Newcastle upon Tyne to Esbjerg? It isn't really very far as the crow flies... Frustratingly, however, the ferries don't go via a direct route, with the result that we are faced with a long drive either to a port in the south east of England, or a long drive on the continent - or both. Is there perhaps an alternative; say a banana boat which can take a car as cargo and a few passengers, maybe from one of the north east's industrial ports?
Haydn Jenkins

fields.headline: Worsening behaviour 'linked to teacher shortage'
fields.standfirst:
Ofsted says rise in use of supply staff is contributing to poor attitudes among secondary school pupils

Education
fields.trailText: Ofsted says rise in use of supply staff is contributing to poor attitudes among secondary school pupils.
fields.body:
Staff shortages are contributing to worse behaviour by pupils, lack of academic progress from ages 11-14, and a widening gap between low and high performers at secondary level, the chief inspector of schools in England warned yesterday.

Delivering his first annual report, Mike Tomlinson said there was "much to celebrate", particularly in primary schools where in 40% of those inspected there was no unsatisfactory teaching at all. "The great majority of parents are pleased with their children's education," he said.

The proportion of poor teaching has fallen from one lesson in five in 1995 to one in 20 now, and the proportion of good or better teaching has risen from 40% to 60% over the same period. In primary schools, the improvement was greatest in the most disadvantaged areas.

But as the differences between the best and worst-performing primary schools reduced, the gap was widening among secondary schools. Secondary schools serving the most disadvantaged pupils had improved their results but the biggest gains were made by schools already performing well.

The chief inspector said there was a "clear link" between inadequate staffing and underachievement. Schools in poorer areas were also much more likely to have temporary teachers.

"Urgent action is more than ever needed on the recruitment and retention of teachers, as the government plainly acknowledges," Mr Tomlinson said. "The very real progress made by schools in recent years in raising standards is at risk unless current trends are reversed and gaps are filled with well-qualified specialists.

"There is growing evidence of the adverse impact of high staff turnover, widespread use of temporary teachers and a poor match between teachers' qualifications and the subjects taught."

There were shortages not only in subjects such as technology, foreign languages and maths, but also religious education, music and, in some London schools, even English.

Mr Tomlinson's verdict was welcomed by the teaching unions but was a blow to ministers, who have spent the past few months playing down union talk of crisis level teacher shortages.

Tony Blair and David Blunkett will next week launch a green paper on the secondary sector which they have identified as the key education challenge in their second term.

For the first time in recent years, inspectors reported an increase in poor behaviour at secondary schools. One secondary school in 12 had unsatisfactory behaviour.

A small minority of pupils had behaviour and attitudes which challenged even the best teachers, the report said. But inspectors also recorded inconsistent behaviour by some pupils. "You can go from one class to the next and watch behaviour turn from angelic to devilish within 35 minutes," said Ofsted's head of inspection, David Taylor. Teacher unions blamed a reduction in the number of pupils excluded after a government initiative.

The report said that too many pupils fail to make good progress in the early years of secondary school. "Although pupils generally begin their secondary education enthusiastically in year seven, there is a tendency for commitment and motivation to fall away in years eight and nine," Mr Tomlinson said. He added that schools were not doing enough to support the transition from primary level.

Ofsted linked the problems to the increased use of supply staff and temporary teachers. "I think it is hardly surprising that in these circumstances pupils, in a sense, decide this is not for them and vote with their feet in one way, shape or form," Mr Tomlinson said. Mr Taylor said that in schools with shortages, permanent staff concentrated on GCSE classes at the expense of the 11-14s.

Mr Tomlinson released a list of 281 "successful" schools, who have had good inspection reports and performed well in national tests given the circumstances of their schools. Some 226 formerly failing schools were removed from special measures in the period covered by the report, the academic year 1999-2000. Inspectors visited 4,700 schools, about one-sixth of those in England.

Mr Tomlinson echoed many of the themes of his predecessor, Chris Woodhead, whom he replaced in December. He repeated complaints about funding disparities which Mr Tomlinson said varied at primary school between £1,400 and £2,600 per pupil and at secondary between £1,700 and £3,000. The relative poor performance of boys showed no sign of changing - "something of a national scandal," said Mr Taylor.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, welcomed the report, and congratulated teachers but said: "The extent of improvement is still too variable, especially in secondary schools, and this will be an important challenge in the coming years." She added that the government was spending £174m on tackling bad behaviour - 10 times more than the last Tory government.

John Dunford, of the Secondary Heads Association, spoke for most in welcoming "the balanced account of the state of our education service". Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "Ofsted's warnings about the effects of teacher shortages echo the NUT's own warnings and should cause the government to end its complacency."

But Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said the fact that standards had risen was down to the dedication of teachers across the country rather than the government. "[The government] has done everything it can to hinder heads and teachers with centralised diktats, pointless initiatives and mountains of time-consuming bureaucracy," she said.

Statistics

 In schools where 5% or fewer pupils take free school meals, temporary teachers account for 3% of staff

 In schools where 50% of pupils take free school meals, temporary teachers account for 10% of staff

 Seven out of eight secondary schools are effective, as are nine out of 10 primary schools

 More than six out of 10 lessons in both primary and secondary schools are well taught

 Behaviour is unsatisfactory in one in 50 primary but in one in 12 secondary schools

webTitle: Violence, theft and abuse in the classroom

fields.headline: Violence, theft and endless abuse
fields.standfirst:
How girls undermined their teacher

Education
fields.trailText: Breaking up fights between teenage girls and confiscating mobile phones and even knives were all in a day's work for Sarah (not her real name) who spent six years teaching at an east London girls' secondary until she recently moved to another school.
fields.body:
Breaking up fights between teenage girls and confiscating mobile phones and even knives were all in a day's work for Sarah (not her real name) who spent six years teaching at an east London girls' secondary until she recently moved to another school.

But she said that despite seeing pupils taken to hospital after extreme incidents involving craft knives, what shocked her most was the constant foul language used by pupils towards staff.

"The pupils regularly told the teachers to fuck off," she explained. "There was just no respect for us or what we were trying to do. If I managed to get any teaching done it was a miracle. Most of my time was spent simply keeping the girls under control and stopping them from assaulting each other and, sometimes, even me. It was a major achievement just to get them to listen to what I was saying.

"You would go in at the beginning of the day trying to feel positive and with plenty of energy, but by the end of the day you were completely drained. It was soul-destroying. Often I was grateful just to be able to keep them all in the same room".

The school where Sarah worked was marked down by Ofsted for unsatisfactory teaching at key stage three - the 11-14 age group referred to in its report yesterday for a worrying downturn in discipline.

Although she taught dance, drama and PE, Sarah also had to keep an eye out for looting from lockers, fires being started in wastepaper bins, vandalism and graffiti. There was even suspected drug use among older girls who were "high as kites" after lunchtime sessions in the toilets.

Tackling parents about their children's poor behaviour created even more problems for teachers. "Complaints to parents inevitably led to us being verbally and even physically abused when they took sides with their daughters," she said. "On one occasion the police had to be called to physically remove a couple from the school premises."

Now Sarah runs a learning support unit, or "sin bin", at another London school, where at least she is able to give pupils one-to-one advice on strategies to improve their behaviour, away from the chaos of the classroom.

webTitle: Hague plans 'common sense revolution' for voluntary sector

fields.headline: Hague plans 'common sense revolution' for voluntary sector
fields.trailText: William Hague plans to revolutionise the voluntary sector with two one-stop shop websites, send 5,000 young people a year abroad to serve as volunteers and champion the cause of faith groups.
fields.body:
William Hague plans to revolutionise the voluntary sector with two one-stop shop websites, send 5,000 young people a year abroad to serve as volunteers and champion the cause of faith groups.

The opposition leader set out his agenda for charities at the NCVO annual conference today. In what he terms a "common sense revolution", he said the next Conservative government would establish a website and call centre to match the needs of the developing world with "willing helpers in Britain".

The Conservatives will also set up a website to record basic information about public-sector grant opportunities and promise to make applying for money much simpler. At the moment, Mr Hague said applying for government grants involved "navigating a jungle of bureaucracy".

Mr Hague mentioned the importance of faith groups several times in his speech and suggested transferring funding decisions to a more local level. "By devolving funding packages to mediating groups, we can limit the way that government money shackles the voluntary sector." He gave the example of local churches being more comfortable applying to the Salvation Army or Shaftesbury Society than local government.

He elaborated on a new body called the Office of Civil Society, saying that it would be staffed by charities, faith communities and family groups. Its role would be to encourage greater independent-sector involvement in public services, offer training to civil servants and review progress made on the Compact between government and the voluntary sector. It will also examine the extent to which faith communities have been fairly treated in terms of government grants.

In a final flourish, he said: "The interests and aspirations of families, faith communities, the voluntary sector and all good neighbours will be at the heart of the Conservatives' common sense revolution."

Although he didn't explain how this would work, he put forward the idea of charity vouchers and tax credits to ensure money reaches charitable groups that most enjoy the confidence of local communities. The Conservatives will make further tax announcements in the coming weeks.

fields.headline: Hull, Chipping Sodbury, and Oviedo
fields.trailText: LOCK-DOWN, STOCK-TAKE AND BARREL
fields.body:
LOCK-DOWN, STOCK-TAKE AND BARREL

So there was the Fiver, at 8.30 this morning, freezing its extremities off outside Boothferry Park. With Hull City set to be hauled over the coals in the High Court, it seemed like as good a time as any to stock up on Christmas presents. Plastic bucket seating for Granny Fiver - check. Empty cardboard packets from Mr Chu's Chinese Restaurant for Comrade Fiver - check. One used Brian Little for erm oh forget that. Suffice to say that we were all ready to clean up, but would Hull oblige us? Would they heck.

Instead of being declared a non-club at a winding-up hearing this morning, Hull were given a two-week reprieve after their affairs (extra-marital or otherwise) were placed into the hands of "corporate recovery specialists" Kroll Buchler Phillips. Despite being named after a rubbish 80s sci-fi flick, Kroll and co will be given the task of restructuring the club's affairs and providing a sound long-term foundation for the club. A spokesman for Kroll said: "We intend that the club will continue to fulfil its obligations to the Football League during this period and that the club will trade as normal."

Not that it's any of the Fiver's business, but we might suggest that, for starters, they could look at getting Hull some keys to their own ground. Boothferry Park remains on lock-down after landlord David Lloyd shut it up yesterday. Hull have a home game against Leyton Orient on Saturday and may be forced to play it at Grimsby's Blundell Park if arrangements (or a big rope ladder) can't be made in time. "We are in some negotiations about the ground," said chairman - and pal of Mr Chu - Nick Buchanan. "I hope everything will be settled before the weekend." Yada yada yada.

Marvel at our joint marketing deal, under which a 'superclub' will be formed with the two clubs selling themselves to potential sponsors and TV networks for millions! Marvel at our exchange of merchandising, as we sell each other's souvenirs and kit!

Marvel at how Paddy Harverson, our director of communications, flies to Manhattan to explain how "we are fully committed to the Premier League and domestic English football. There is no suggestion whatsoever that we are looking to leave the English game and join any kind of breakaway league!"

Marvel as we don't disclose the financial terms of the deal!

If you jump the gun and announce a transfer before you dot the Is and cross the Ts, you can end up looking very daft indeed - a point conclusively proved by transfer fiascos like John Hartson to Tottenham, John Hartson to Rangers and John Hartson to Coventry. So you can't blame Ipswich for not responding to reports that they are about to sign a "mystery player", can you?

Assuming the Fiver didn't mishear and George Burley is in fact about to sign Mr E Player (a retired newsagent from Chipping Sodbury, Gloucs), it's a puzzle alright. And chairman David Sheepshanks isn't about to help. "There can be no certainty there will be a new arrival but I am hopeful," teased the great big temptress. "There is no further progress at the moment because we are dealing with a very reluctant seller," he pouted.

But luckily for us, the gaff has been well and truly blown. According to Planet Football, the player in question is none other than AB Copenhagen's Danish superstar Brian Steen "Brian Stein" Nielsen. "My lawyer is discussing a deal with a club whilst I am away," the busy 32-year-old midfielder said. "The only thing that could stop a transfer is that I have not seen the conditions at the club." webTitle: The different patterns of social policy in Scotland and Wales

fields.headline: Distinct cousins
fields.standfirst: There's a lot more to devolution than just national identity. The go-it-alone spirit in Scotland and Wales is providing a lead for the rest of Britain on progressive social policy.  Lynn Eaton reports
fields.trailText: There's a lot more to devolution than just national identity. The go-it-alone spirit in Scotland and Wales is providing a lead for the rest of Britain on progressive social policy. Lynn Eaton reports
fields.body:
Scotland's revolt over free personal care for all elderly people, regardless of their means, has thrown into sharp focus what devolution is going to mean in Britain. There had already been well publicised differences over student tuition fees, not to mention the recent 21% pay award for Scottish teachers, but the parting of the ways on long-term care has shown that very different patterns of social policy can now be expected.

The differences, however, will not just be between England and Scotland. Important differences are emerging also in Wales, where the idea of a children's commissioner - doggedly opposed by English ministers - has been readily accepted and acted upon.

Westminster has sought to appear relaxed about all this. John Hutton, health and social care minister, says: "Devolution means that it is for the Scottish parliament to make decisions on its response to the royal commission on long-term care. Both the government and the Scottish executive are committed to improving health and social care services for older people, but we are doing this in different ways."

Yet it is clear that when SMPs first proposed to accept the royal commission's recommendation that per sonal care should be free, which England and Wales had rejected, frantic efforts were made from London to head off the go-it-alone plan. Only the imminent collapse of the Labour/LibDem coalition in Scotland forced the Scottish executive to commit to free personal care for all "as soon as practicable".

Historically, Scotland has always had different legal and education systems. Devolution alone is not the reason for diversity. Scottish children's hearings panels, which keep young offenders out of the court system, have long been held up as examples which the rest of Britain might follow.

Scotland also had the misfortune to be the testing ground for the poll tax, introduced there in 1989 a year before England and Wales. Despite its appalling reception, the Tory government ploughed ahead with its introduction across Britain - with disastrous results.

The establishment of a separate Scottish parliament in 1999, however, has underlined just how distinctive Scottish policy can become. The Welsh assembly, albeit with fewer powers than its Scottish equivalent, has similarly opened the door for policy contrasts. The assembly lost no time in agreeing to appoint a children's commissioner - Peter Clarke, now settled in the post - in response to the recommendation of the Water house inquiry into abuse in north Wales children's homes. Northern Ireland has also announced it is to have a commissioner and it looks as if Scotland will follow suit. But England, apparently, will not.

So is this developing diversity a good thing? Or will loss of central control create dysfunction and widen existing fissures in British society?

David Hinchliffe, Labour chair of the commons health select committee, has no doubt that what is happening in Scotland over long-term care is a positive step. "This is the inevitability of devolution," he says. "I have long looked to Scotland, having worked in social services, at things like their children's panels. The fact that they can have the ability to develop new approaches is very positive. In fact, I have come back from visiting social work schemes in Scotland and been green with envy."

Hinchliffe personally welcomes the Scottish move towards free personal care. "It is a development I don't see any problems with - but that is if you believe in devolution, which I do."And, as a Yorkshireman, he half jokes about the day his own beloved county will get devolved powers.

In an ideal world, the four constituent countries of the UK might even learn lessons from diversity. But experience suggests not. A recent Northern Ireland report suggested that the province's joint health and social services boards have done little to improve joint working between the two sectors. Yet the Westminster government seems set on forcing England down the same route.

While it is still too early to learn lessons from the Welsh children's commissioner, few observers can understand why English ministers already appear so resistant to the idea. "Child abuse does not stop at the border between England and Wales," says Mary Marsh, the NSPCC chief executive. "Similar posts must be created in the rest of the UK, with wide-ranging powers to investigate, report and act, so that children have the protection they deserve."

Failing that, the NSPCC wants the Welsh commissioner to be allowed to comment on British government policies which affect children in Wales, such as the children's tax credit, youth justice and the national minimum wage for young people, and to have powers to investigate where a Welsh child is placed in England.

Hugh Gardner, who chairs the Association of Directors of Social Services in Wales, argues that one of the positive aspects of devolution is closer relations between the centre and the grassroots. "There really is a culture of partnership all the time," he says. "The assembly has set out to try to encourage a variety of interests. They have users and carers coming to the social services committee, and the minister is there as well."

Another emerging difference between Wales and England is that while checks on English childminders and nurseries will from September be carried out by the schools inspectorate, Ofsted, Welsh regulation will be by the care standards commission. "It is seeing the children's interests in a wider context - not just education," says Gardner.

With more coalition governments likely in Wales and Scotland, policies will have to adapt to encompass disparate opinions. They will also need to be more attuned to the ordinary elector, whose views - and votes - can hold far more sway than in national elections. "How the next [general] election, the first since devolution, is going to pan out is going to be very interesting," says Mitchell. "It will throw up a lot of anomalies. The devolved countries are becoming quite a force, putting pressure on Westminster to move forward."

Lobbying groups will sometimes be able to use policies adopted in one country to put pressure on another. Scottish voluntary organisations scored a recent victory on charging for checks on people working with children, the Scottish executive agreeing to foot the fee of at least £10 a head for every check carried out. Voluntary groups in England and Wales, however, will still have to pay.

"The Scottish decision is obviously very important," says Campbell Robb, head of campaigns at the London-based National Council for Voluntary Organisations. "Hopefully, it will give us leverage in our ability to press the Home Office to have free checks."

Martin Sim, chief executive of the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations, is delighted with the deal. "At one level, across the UK, the government is trying to promote volunteers, yet another arm of government is saying it is going to cost you £10 or £15 to get checked," he says. "That doesn't make a lot of sense. The same arguments apply in England and Wales as in Scotland, and the sums involved are relatively modest."

Sim had thought that, had the Scottish executive failed to accept the proposal, it might have become a crunch issue like long-term care. Luckily for him, it never got that far. "We do have a coalition government with a fragile majority," he says. "The political process in Scotland is a bit more sensitive than in England. It makes for a more sophisticated process."

Has that lesson sunk in at Westminster? Just a few days after the Scottish long-term care debacle, chancellor Gordon Brown told an audience in Manchester: "We are moving away from the old Britain of subjects, where people had to look upwards to a Whitehall bureaucracy for their solutions, to a Britain of citizens where region to region, locality to locality, we are ourselves in charge."

David Hinchliffe's home rule for Yorkshire may not, then, be just a distant dream.

Pioneers, not guinea pigs

It is not just social policy but health, too, which will differ under devolution. While English community health councils face abolition next year, they will live on in Scotland and Wales.

Jim McCormick, research director at the Scottish Council Foundation, an independent think-tank, believes ministers north of the border see no mileage in following what looks like an unpopular change in England. "There is so much else to do," he says.

One thing they are doing is scrapping Scotland's 28 NHS trusts and bringing service provision under the control of 15 new health boards, in what may appear a reversion to the health service structure before the Conservatives' 1991 reforms. The change will end the purchaser/provider split, but it will also strip out bureaucracy in a country with a population of just 5m.

In Wales, health and social services minister Jane Hutt last week announced proposals to abolish the five health authorities by 2003. Local health groups - equivalent to, but not the same as, primary care trusts in England - will be strengthened and will include local authority representation.

The idea is part of the new NHS plan for Wales. Hutt says: "It is a plan made in Wales and designed to meet Welsh needs, breaking down the barriers between institutions and organisations to provide integrated services that are simpler for people to use and understand."

There is, McCormick admits, a risk of policy-making being hijacked by the devolution agenda. "I think the difference with long-term care is that Scotland wants to see itself as being a pioneer, rather than being a guinea pig," he says. "It is a total reverse from the poll tax.

"I would like to think that we are mature enough to be doing things where there is evidence that it is best for us, rather than just political point-scoring."

Hutt says: "It is a plan made in Wales and designed to meet Welsh needs, breaking down the barriers between institutions and organisations to provide integrated services that are simpler for people to use and understand." There is, McCormick admits, a risk of policy-making being hijacked by the devolution agenda. "I think the difference with long-term care is that Scotland wants to see itself as being a pioneer, rather than being a guinea pig," he says. "It is a total reverse from the poll tax. "I would like to think that we are mature enough to be doing things where there is evidence that it is best for us, rather than just political point-scoring."

webTitle: William Hague's speech to the NCVO annual conference

fields.headline: William Hague's speech to the NCVO annual conference
fields.trailText: Thank you for your invitation to address today's annual conference of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations and for the opportunity to record my appreciation for the work that you do across Britain.
fields.body:
Thank you for your invitation to address today's annual conference of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations and for the opportunity to record my appreciation for the work that you do across Britain.

Today I want to talk about the principled partnership that the next Conservative government will build with you. A principled partnership that will give the voluntary sector a voice at the top of government. A principled partnership that will revolutionise the process of applying for grants. A principled partnership that will give charities new opportunities to run schools, regenerate disadvantaged communities and take development projects to every corner of the globe.

Twenty years ago the first Conservative revolution began. Battered by regulations, taxes and inflation the enterprise of British people - which had once produced the world's most prosperous country - was exhausted.

That first Conservative revolution proved that there were no shortcuts to prosperity. I want to extend the same Conservative principles to the creation of a more compassionate society. It is not enough to define the economic limits of government.

We must be realistic about the state's ability to address social needs too. Just as wealth creation depends upon the energies of a free people, a good society depends upon the active compassion of free and independent families, neighbours and charities.

Fifty years ago Beveridge recognised this when he said: "A good society depends not on the state, but on the citizens, acting on motives of various kinds, some selfish, others unselfish, some narrow and material, others inspired by love of man and love of God. The happiness or unhappiness of the society in which we live depends upon ourselves as citizens, not on the instrument of political power which we call the state."

The next Conservative government will improve our public services and protect social security but we will not stop there. The Common Sense Revolution will actively recognise civil society's role in building one nation of opportunity and security for all.

The pensioner who is lonely, the child who has never seen his father or the teenager turning to drugs don't always need another government initiative or taskforce of the great and good. They are crying out for the care and attention of another human being.

And every day millions of people do show compassion to a child, neighbour or stranger. Within families and communities people find friendship, identity, and belonging. Many of life's greatest obstacles - bereavement, sickness or unemployment - are overcome because of the personal support of a parent, spouse or friend.

But many active citizens are frustrated by the environment created by government. Volunteers are faced with expensive background checks. Applying for government grants involves navigating a jungle of bureaucracy. Political correctness forces charities and faith communities to dilute their essential character.

These barriers that separate good neighbours from people in need must come down. That is why I favour "denationalising compassion". And that is why the next Conservative government will get off the back of charities, volunteers and families.

Often government fails the voluntary sector by failing to even consider its perspective. By establishing an Office of Civil Society reporting to a cabinet minister, the next Conservative government will change this. This office will be staffed by charities, faith communities and family groups. The "good neighbours" who give our country its strength and decency. It is the boldest initiative of its kind for a generation.

I am announcing the office's first four tasks today.

First, we must end the huge diversion of your time into form-filling and paperwork. We must end the master-and-servant relationship between government and grant applicants. The complexity and number of application forms represents an intolerable burden and disenfranchises the smallest and often most innovative charities and community groups. There is a growing danger that groups that get money are the best at hacking the system rather than those who are best at the work in hand.

The whole process can demoralise the charity workers closest to a project's ethos. Complex form-filling betrays the instincts of government to micromanage - managing inputs and process - rather than delivering results. We will still hold charities accountable for results, but the introduction of one simple form across government departments - made up of a la carte sections covering only essential funding considerations - will demonstrate our trust in charities.

Second, the office will help us to end the lottery of identifying sources of funding. Information about grant opportunities is not the property of the government - but the property of every interested citizen. Modern technology gives us an opportunity to establish a one-stop website which will record basic information about all public sector grant opportunities.

I would prefer that groups like the NCVO, the Charities Aid Foundation and the National Centre for Volunteering should be funded to manage this service. They are in the best position to know how this website would best serve their members. This one-stop portal follows our proposal to establish a similar system - Aid Direct - for international development.

Third, the office will coordinate efforts to encourage greater independent sector involvement in public services. It is unreasonable, for example, to expect voluntary groups - often starved of funding for core functions - to be immediately ready to embark on the process of applying to run schools, housing or employment projects.

The office will coordinate investment in the capacity of voluntary groups and faith communities - where they are interested - to seize the new opportunities. By involving the voluntary sector in schooling, housing and urban regeneration, we will create more diverse provision - better suited to the variety of needs in today's Britain.

In education, for example, we will empower the pioneering work of black-majority churches to deliver the highest quality supplementary education to their communities. The office will also help government departments to improve their understanding of voluntary groups by giving civil servants access to training on these same possibilities of greater cooperation with voluntary groups. This training will include specific efforts to encourage more engagement with faith communities.

Fourth, the office will produce a regular review of its work. This review will cover progress made on the Compact between the government and the voluntary sector. It will record trends in volunteering, charitable giving and how policy changes have affected marriage, parents and the extended family. It will examine the extent to which faith communities have been fairly receiving grants. In short it will bring consideration of civil society into the heart of government.

The vital responsibility of international development will epitomise the Conservative approach to helping our neighbour. Through television and cheap and fast international travel we are right to think of the people affected by the Indian earthquake as our neighbours and that we can do something to help them. In the last year the British people have reached out their hand to their neighbours in Mozambique, El Salvador and Gujarat. Some of Britain's development charities have been the fastest and most effective agents of emergency aid as well as the most committed to long-term development projects.

I can announce today that the next Conservative government will restructure the budget of the Department for International Development and so double the percentage of our development expenditure that goes through non-governmental organisations. By making it much simpler for small charities to apply for DFID grants we will ensure that these innovative charities take a big share of this doubled support for charitable groups.

In partnership with the NGO community we will establish a sophisticated website and call centre to match needs in the developing world with willing helpers in Britain. We will invest in technology to twin individuals, charities and faith communities with partners in the developing world. We will also send an extra 5,000 young people to serve abroad every year.

We all have a part to play in helping our neighbour overseas. As we move towards the UN target of giving 0.7% of GNP to international development the next Conservative government will play its full part. That will involve working in a fuller and more principled partnership with international development charities. But however much we improve the voluntary sector's relationship with government we need to do much more to improve the sector's relationship with the rest of civil society.

This is essential if we are to encourage a genuinely "independent sector". When a charity depends upon the state for its income it can lose touch with the community - in the same way that a subsidised business loses touch with its customers. This can lead to charities imitating the management style and ethos of government. The voluntary sector becomes the compelled sector. Compelled to change its character according to its paymasters' demands. Compelled to jump through bureaucratic hoops in response to changing compliance criteria.

A charity that receives a large share of its income from private citizens will be more diverse and innovative. And it won't just receive money. Ideas, time, encouragement and prayers will follow. The love that characterises the hospice movement is perhaps the outstanding example of this fact.

This government may be sincere when it says that the era of centralisation is over but he who pays the piper still calls the tune. And this government has kept very tight control of funding. There are too many contradictions in saying that Whitehall does not know best and still keeping hold of every purse string.

The Office of Civil Society will work with the voluntary sector to pilot more imaginative ways of denationalising the distribution of public funds.

75% of all voluntary organisations have no paid staff. Applying for grants is particularly burdensome for these small platoons although a few hundred pounds might transform their work. By devolving funding packages to mediating groups we can limit the way that government money shackles the voluntary sector. Local churches seeking small grants, for example, are much more likely to work comfortably with the Salvation Army or Shaftesbury Society. Both are professional Christian charities with high accountability standards and yet are also able to stand up to the demands of government funders.

Other possible reforms might involve allowing more money to follow the users of services - whether those services are daycare for the elderly or drug rehabilitation. Users - who know where the shoe pinches - could then discover more innovative and diverse services. Government officials are always going to be more comfortable with groups that approximate to their own way of doing things. They will understandably hesitate before funding new and, perhaps, unusual projects.

Public funders are making progress in consulting communities about service provision. But patterns of consultation are patchy and sometimes rely on unrepresentative voices. The Office of Civil Society will research ways of routeing public money through communities so that consultation is replaced by real power.

The NCVO's idea, for example, of setting up community endowments to fund projects identified by local people merits active consideration. It would certainly be consistent with the Conservative party's existing commitment to endow universities and museums. The OCS could research the use of charity vouchers and the use of tax credits to ensure money reaches charitable groups that most enjoy the confidence of people and communities.

Charitable giving represents the best way of increasing independence. Levels of giving - particularly by companies - are much lower in Britain than, for example, the United States. Although the chancellor has made some welcome changes to encourage giving he has given with one hand, only to take with the other. We are currently considering proposals put to us by the voluntary sector and will make our tax announcements in coming weeks.

We also want to help the whole culture of volunteering in Britain.

The Scouts, the Football Association, the Duke of Edinburgh's award programme, Sunday schools and other countless community groups are all vital parts of our society and depend upon volunteers. Background checks on volunteers are an absolutely necessary protection for children and other vulnerable users of voluntary services. But requiring voluntary groups to pay for these checks is one stealth tax too far and Conservatives would not have imposed it.

Until today this government was threatening to charge voluntary organisations £10 for each occasion on which they have to check the credentials of people employed to work with children. They then heard last night that I was going to announce here that the next Conservative government would not levy any charge. By a strange coincidence, ministers suddenly announced that, despite everything they said before, they will not impose this charge. Don't ever think that the opposition can't do something for you.

We don't crow. We welcome the u-turn. For Conservatives regard this as an unwarranted imposition on the voluntary sector - a sector which does so much to provide quality services at least as efficiently as the public sector could do. Of course, it is important that we now examine the small print of what the government is proposing. Too often these announcements unravel on close examination.

We at least are clear. We will abolish these charges without hidden conditions or costs to the voluntary sector. The net cost - an average of £3m for each of the government departments involved - will be borne from within the budgets of those departments.

The Office of Civil Society will regularly consult volunteers and representative groups. Our Listening to Britain consultations have identified concern at the decline in volunteering amongst young people. Good citizenship is not something that you learn in a citizenship lesson or from a textbook. By spending time volunteering and helping local charities children are encouraged to understand their responsibilities to their neighbours and play a role in building stronger communities. We believe that children should be assisted by schools to take up volunteering opportunities in their local communities.

At the heart of the teachings of the world's great religions and philosophies is the encouragement to love and care for a neighbour. The next Conservative government will be a friend of the good neighbour.

In renewing civil society we will not preach - we will empower. We will not squash the aspirations of good neighbours. We will help to fulfil them.

People want to give, but the tax system is too complex and volunteers are threatened with expensive background checks. Conservatives will create a tax system and a culture of volunteering that encourages generosity.

Churches, synagogues and mosques want to do more in their communities, but their religious beliefs are the subject of scorn. Conservatives will end discrimination against faith and will welcome all religious people who wish to reclaim social responsibilities.

Too many married couples face a tax system that ignores the commitments they have made. We will reform the tax system and introduce new support services for marriage.

The interests and aspirations of families, faith communities, the voluntary sector and all good neighbours will be at the heart of the Conservatives' Common Sense Revolution.

Conservatives will build a kinder, more united Britain by encouraging greater personal responsibility and responsibility for others as the foundation of civil society. Such a Britain must be underpinned by a dynamic economy. Government - through investment in schools, hospitals and social security - will still need to underwrite opportunity. But the rebuilding of communities and the healing of broken lives will most depend upon the vitality of our families, charities, places of worship and local schools.

There is not a social problem that is not being tackled by one small platoon somewhere in Britain. Every minute of everyday one life is changed forever by the care of a parent, friend or good neighbour. That care represents the greatness of our country and Conservatives will be its friend and champion.

fields.headline: Government urged to aid 'digital revolution'
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: ONdigital today called on the government to create a digital TV "champion" to help drive take-up, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Digital terrestrial pay-TV operator ONdigital has today called on the government to create a powerful digital TV "champion" to help drive take-up of the new technology.

ONdigital, which is jointly owned by Granada Media and Carlton Communications, urged the government to appoint a senior figure responsible for encouraging digital take-up and achieving analogue switch-off.

"It is imperative this individual is senior enough and has at his/her disposal a team of high-calibre officials to tackle the range of technical and complex regulatory and legislative issues," said ONdigital.

It made the statement in a submission to the media select committee inquiry on the communications white paper.

"We suggest this person reports directly to a single secretary of state and is made accountable for the delivery of analogue switch-off," it added.

Responsibility for driving digital TV take-up and reaching analogue switch-off is split between the department of culture, media and sport and the department of trade and industry.

ONdigital also proposed the digital TV champion should be backed by a "national digital switchover plan".

This should be formalised in the upcoming communications bill.

The pay-TV broadcaster recommended the switchover plan should tackle a number of issues.

These included maximising digital terrestrial TV coverage, the logistics of phasing out the analogue signal and tackling consumer confusion regarding the types of digital TV equipment and services available.

"A public information campaign was promised by the government 18 months ago and has not materialised due to conflicting agendas of the parties involved.

"No such campaign will be effectively implemented without a lead by government," said the company.

ONdigital also called on the government to back a requirement for the terrestrial channels to carry a minimum number of peak-time infomercials promoting digital free-to-air channels.

fields.headline: The new order of things
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown, the Guardian's Israel correspondent during Netanyahu's leadership, believes Ariel Sharon's version of right wing government will be far more dangerous

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Derek Brown, the Guardian's Israel correspondent during Netanyahu's leadership, believes Ariel Sharon's version of right wing government will be far more dangerous
fields.body:
We've been here before. In the early summer of 1996, the old schemer Shimon Perez was swept aside by the brash right winger Binyamin Netanyahu and the world held its breath.

The peace process is doomed, said the commentators. The region risks a drift into war. Yasser Arafat will never be able to cut a deal with this new hard nut.

That last bit was right, at any rate. But Netanyahu didn't destroy the peace process so much as sabotage it. His distaste for concessions had more to do with his obsessive clutch on political power, than with any visceral notions about the future relationship between Israel and the Palestinians.

The same is broadly true of Ehud Barak, who swept into the prime minister's office in 1999. Just as Netanyahu instinctively distrusted the vision of a separate Palestinian state, set out in the Oslo accords of 1993, so Barak supported it with almost fanatical zeal.

With all the impatience of a military man, the former army chief of staff launched an all-out negotiating assault, believing that if he could deliver the main prize of a final peace treaty, all Israel would fall at his feet.

From an Israeli point of view, he went much too far, much too fast. From a Palestinian point of view, he offered much too little, much too late. Nerves on both sides were scraped raw as Bill Clinton urged them ever onward toward the holy grail of a final settlement.

Last summer at Camp David, Clinton and Barak came tantalisingly close to getting Arafat's signature on a deal which would have given him his cherished state. Later, in what became known as "Camp David plus", Barak impulsively offered him even more - including, to the outrage of the Israeli right, control of much of East Jerusalem.

It was that offer, more than anything else, which cost Barak the election. At the time it was made, the Palestinian territories were in flames.

And so, as in 1996, the electors have turned a negotiator, a compromiser, out of office and turned instead to a man who promises security without concessions, who loathes the Oslo accords, and who believes that the Palestinians must be dealt with from a position of strength.

As the Guardian correspondent in Jerusalem in 1996, I witnessed at close quarters the sudden, dangerous loss of momentum in the peace process after Netanyahu took over.

In the autumn of that year, frustration erupted in a brief but bloody shooting war which the Palestinians inevitably lost but which stamped, for the first time, serious doubts in Israeli minds about their own invincibility.

Ariel Sharon shares those doubts. That, I believe, is what makes him so much more dangerous than Netanyahu. Sharon's perception of Israel is not one of regional superpower; a nuclear tipped military colossus.

He believes his country to be a tiny embattled oasis of democracy, set in an ocean of Arab hostility. His speeches and writings are suffused with the notion that Israel must be ever prepared to defend itself against internal and external attack.

The internal enemies, of course, are the Palestinians: the two million who live in the territories conquered in 1967 and the one million who live within Israel proper, alongside five million Jews.

Sharon is aware of the national aspirations of both Palestinian groups. In his blunt military man's way, he has come up with a stark solution: Jordan is Palestine and Palestine is Jordan.

The argument runs like this: the kingdom of Jordan was artificially carved out of the old Palestine by British colonial authorities, who gave it to the Hashemite dynasty of Saudi Arabia as a reward for services rendered in the first world war.

Now a majority of its population are Palestinians from the west side of the River Jordan (expelled by Israel, though Sharon does not say so).

So now the Palestinians have a state of their own, in a part of Palestine which rightfully should be part of the Jewish homeland as promised by the British.

In their magnanimity, the Jews have accepted the smaller part of Palestine west of the Jordan (so the argument goes on). They have to reach an accommodation with the awkwardly large minority of Arabs who insist on staying on the same side of the river.

So let the minority rule itself locally, but without any trappings of state and certainly without any military apparatus.

Meanwhile, in their own defence, the Jews should be able to colonise those same Palestinian territories with a series of fortified settlements, to prevent the Palestinians from ever threatening the main Israeli population centres on the crowded coastal strip.

Similarly, the teeming squalor of the Gaza Strip should be strategically sprinkled with Jewish settlements as a forward line of defence. Ditto the Jordan Valley. And the Golan Heights, seized from Syria in 1967, should be held in perpetuity to discourage Damascus from any future military adventures.

On the issue which scuppered Barak, the future of Jerusalem, the Sharon line is perfectly simple: the city is ours. Always has been, always will be. All of it. Forever.

Sharon's views, thus encapsulated, might seem brutal or even bizarre to outsiders. In Israel they are very widely shared and not just on the political right.

Sharon's passionate attachment to the Eretz Israel - the Land given by God to the Jews - is deeply embedded in Israeli culture.

The notion that Palestinians might also be passionately attached to the land, the land that was taken from them, tends to provoke puzzlement among ardent Israelis. "They are Arabs, there are 21 Arab countries for them to choose from, but only one for us," they say.

There is still, among eternal optimists, a feeling that only "strong" right wing leadership can deliver a viable peace settlement.

Having defeated the centre-left liberals, the theory runs, Sharon will be able to hammer out an honourable deal with the Palestinians and sell that deal to the nationalist right.

That, in my opinion based on nearly four years in Jerusalem, is balderdash.

Sharon's vision of the future is simply incompatible with the central idea of the Oslo accords: a new partition of the Holy Land, based on mutual recognition and equal status.

To the new prime minister, an independent Palestine west of the Jordan is anathema; an abominable threat to the Jewish state and therefore to Jews everywhere.

Seven years and four months ago, Arafat, Peres and the late Yitzhak Rabin astonished the world by shaking hands on the White House lawn. I remember well the mingled moods of outrage and wonder which swept Jerusalem on that day.

I know that today a similar elation will be gripping those elements in the city which never believed in compromise and which are now enthusiastically preparing for renewed confrontation.

webTitle: Can Warwick close the digital divide?

fields.headline: Can Warwick close the digital divide?
fields.standfirst:
Warwick students are controversially having laptop computers thrust on them, but they should emulate certain American colleges, embrace the policy to the full and make sure the university foots the bill, says Sarah Left.

More net news
fields.trailText: Warwick students are controversially having laptop computers thrust on them, but they should emulate certain American colleges, embrace the policy to the full and make sure the university foots the bill, saysSarah Left.
fields.body:
The University of Warwick could become the first UK university to follow a growing US trend - requiring all students to buy a laptop computer.

Administrators at Warwick have proposed that all first year students should have access to their own laptop computer by 2003, so that they can take advantage of new teaching methods and resources. A package of proposed measures would also see lecture rooms, labs and even residence halls wired up for the internet; campus-wide wireless access is also a possibility.

But the suggestion has angered student union representatives, who fear the extra cost of the equipment will put students further into debt. The National Union of Students has vowed to fight any move to force laptops on students.

Over in North Carolina, Marian Moore cannot understand what all the fuss is about. Ms Moore is the vice chancellor for information technology at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, which required its first year students to have laptops for the first time this autumn.

A number of private universities had already instituted this policy, but UNC is a public school, traditionally the place where the state's relatively poorer students can come for a good university education.

UNC noticed that between 1992 and 1996, computer ownership by students increased dramatically, but by the end of the decade the percentage of students buying a computer had levelled off. Ms Moore checked the numbers and found that about 35% of students did not own a computer of any kind - exactly the same percentage as students receiving financial aid.

"The digital divide was happening on our own campus," she says. "We can repeat all the educational platitudes you like about the importance of technology in education, but the use of computers in support of the educational experience for college students is mandatory."

So this year, out of 3,400 incoming first year students, 1,000 were given free laptops.

Back at Warwick, 70% of students already own a computer, and according to the university, another 25% have considered buying one.

According to Ms Moore, that proves that the technology is indispensable to education. "70% of those students have already voted for the technology without a requirement," she says. "Students overwhelmingly understand this."

The question then is all about financial support. If the current inequalities in technology ownership are truly causing a digital divide, then it's in students' interests for the NUS to both support the introduction of the mandatory laptop policy and demand that the university pick up the tab for anyone who cannot afford it.

"It is very, very difficult to get through even your first quarter of higher education without being in daily contact with a keyboard, mouse and screen," says Perri6, a senior research fellow at the University of Strathclyde, whose university is also considering a mandatory laptop policy.

Better, he says, to let students know about the real cost of an education up front. "No university really accepts handwritten assignments anymore, and students have more email contact with lecturers than they have face-to-face."

He sees another reason for universities and students to push ahead with the change. "If you look ahead three or four years, you will see universities buying in expertise in certain courses from the top universities in the world.

"A political science department anywhere could advertise a Harvard Kennedy class, delivered over an extranet. Support for assignments and marking could be done in a third university, also over an extranet."

And that is a compelling business reason to offer students the necessary financial aid.

webTitle: Pre-trial therapy for children in sexual abuse cases

fields.headline: Trying time
fields.standfirst: For a child alleging sexual abuse, it's a daunting prospect giving evidence in public. Could pre-trial therapy be a solution?  Mike George looks at new national guidance
fields.trailText: For a child alleging sexual abuse, it's a daunting prospect giving evidence in public. Could pre-trial therapy be a solution? Mike George looks at new national guidance
fields.body:
It is a depressing but well known fact that most perpetrators of sexual abuse of children never enter a courtroom. And more than 95% of allegations of abuse which appear to be well founded, according to police and social services investigations, never result in conviction.

The main reasons are lack of corroborative evidence, including acceptable medical evidence; lack of testimony of an independent witness; or because the crown prosecution service (CPS) believes that the child or young person will be unable to provide sufficiently credible evidence owing to their age and vulnerability.

Tomorrow, the first national guidance on provision of pre-trial therapy for child witnesses will be published, following years of mounting concern over the length of time that traumatised children have to wait before gaining access to therapeutic services.

This practice guidance - from the CPS, the Home Office and the Department of Health - aims principally to overcome the perceived conflict between providing pre-trial therapy to aid the child and the possibility of this tainting their evidence.

The guidance is to be circulated to the police and all relevant criminal justice, health and social care agencies, including the judiciary. Bryan Boulter, for the CPS, says it sets out a framework to address the needs of vulnerable young people while trying to ensure that standards of evidence required by courts are met. Its application will be monitored by the CPS.

One of the spurs for this initiative was research undertaken at a Barnardo's project in the north-east, tracking the progress of 483 children referred to the scheme over five years as a result of joint police and social services investigations of sexual abuse. In only 42 instances were criminal proceedings instigated, although the investigating teams were satisfied that all those referred had been abused. Thirteen of the 42 had special needs.

The project has offered individual therapy for child victims of sexual abuse, as well as support for families, since 1987. Working with Cleveland police and local CPS staff, researchers assessed the children and their families in cases where proceedings were taken and used the findings to develop protocols and procedures for wider use.

Most of the children were found to have gained in confidence and self esteem, both before and after trial, as a result of the support they received. Many of the parents or carers also became more able to provide support of their own. Crucially, not a single court case was halted because of any perceived tainting of the evidence. Similarly, the scheme showed that therapists and other care staff were worrying unnecessarily that their normally confidential notes might be read out in court.

Tink Palmer, the project's director, says these positive outcomes resulted from strict observance of procedures. A full assessment of the child's and family's needs was carried out before commencing therapy.

The therapy itself was child centred and proceeded at the child's pace, with regular reviews of progress, and parents requiring support were seen by a separate therapist. Each child received specialised witness preparation, shortly before their case came to court, and they were able to return to the project at any time after testifying.

The study showed a relatively high rate of conviction among the cases involved - presumably because of the improved confidence of the child witnesses in giving evidence.

Graham Davies, professor of psychology at Leicester University and leader of the team behind the guidance, says all the agencies involved hope and expect that progress will be made by what he calls this "joining together of the investigative and trial processes". He stresses, however, there is still much to do to reduce the wide variations in the ways that different courts, and judges, approach children's evidence and status as witnesses.

Similarly, despite the fact that these kinds of cases are supposed to be "fast tracked", there can still be long delays between original investigations and proceedings coming to court. Many of the children in the Barnardo's scheme had to wait more than a year, which, says Palmer, increases the anxiety and distress felt by children and families and may be used to discredit the evidence.

So while the guidance is likely to get a broad welcome, it clearly cannot do everything that is needed. And Davies warns that it will put greater pressure on police, social workers, therapists and counsellors to keep accurate records - even though some child protection staff already complain of being overstretched.

Paul Wilcox, director of the Brighter Futures charity for sexually abused children, says patchy availability of therapeutic provision remains a major problem.

While he applauds Barnardo's and other voluntary agencies for running specialist projects, he argues: "We need to prioritise therapeutic services in all areas so that children and families can access help quickly at their time of greatest need. "In my work with young males who have been sexually abused, it is perhaps no coincidence that those who report difficulties in their later teenage years have often been the ones who did not receive any therapeutic help at the point of their disclosure to professionals."

Provision of Therapy for Child Witnesses Prior to a Criminal Trial will be available from the Crown Prosecution Service on 020-7796 8000. For further information on the Barnardo's project, call 01642-300774.

Courtroom trauma

Recent research by the NSPCC studied the experience of abused children from the point at which they disclosed abuse through to trial and beyond.

The research, commissioned by the area criminal justice liaison committee for Portsmouth, Southampton, the Isle of Wight, Hampshire and Dorset, involved interviews with children, their carers and professionals involved.

It found that abuse commonly triggered severe behavioural and emotional symptoms, many families having been torn apart and/or ostracised by their communities. Only just over half the children who needed therapy or counselling actually received it.

Where children failed to get help, it was because there was no system to identify them, resources were in adequate or there was professional reluctance to use counselling for fear it would contaminate evidence.

Many children had very negative recollections of their experience of the criminal justice system, with cross-examination the worst aspect because of distress felt as a result of accusations of lying.

Distress was also caused by delays and inability to predict when and how evidence would be given, lack of accurate information and "not guilty" verdicts inadequately explained. For many children, the experience seemed to have delayed or even hindered recovery.

As a result of the study, crown courts are establishing specialist child witness services with a remit extended to pre and post-trial support for child victims and families.

fields.headline: The Israeli election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Following a decade of peace talks with the Palestinians, Israel has elected Ariel Sharon, reviled for his role as a war-maker with Arabs, as its new prime minister. Richard Moriarty explains how he has come to power
fields.body:
Following a decade of peace talks with the Palestinians, Israel has elected Ariel Sharon, reviled for his role as a war-maker with Arabs, as its new prime minister. After just 21 months in government, Ehud Barak's attempts to find lasting peace with the Palestinians and Israel's Arab neighbours were rejected at the polls yesterday. With 99% of the vote counted, he received just 37.8% share while Mr Sharon gained 62.5%.

Did Mr Sharon win or Mr Barak lose?
A bit of both. Thought to be unelectable until a few months ago, Mr Sharon was aided by Mr Barak's delicate position as the leader of a minority coalition government in the Knesset. Mr Barak pursued his manifesto by withdrawing troops from Lebanon and holding talks with Syria. But the right hammered him when he offered Palestinians shared sovereignty of Jerusalem and control of 95% of the West Bank - at the same time as the intifada was claiming Jewish lives. For Mr Sharon, his core support came from the 1m Russian immigrants who live in Israel. A Russian was the first Israeli citizen killed by the intifada, and this group, credited with bringing Mr Barak to power in 1999, was unwilling to forgive him for failing to deliver peace.

Due to his past exploits in the army and as defence secretary. In 1953, as a general in the army he led a massacre on Qibya, a Palestinian village, which left 69 villagers dead. In 1982, without explicitly telling prime minister Menachem Begin, Mr Sharon sent the Israeli army into Lebanon, leading to the massacre of more than 1,000 Palestinian refugees living in Beirut by pro-Israeli Lebanese militia. An Israeli report in 1983 found Mr Sharon indirectly responsible for the massacre and recommended that he never be allowed to hold the position of defence secretary again.

What are Sharon's beliefs?
Towards the end of the election campaign, Mr Sharon's language softened from its previous hardline but he is still tough on Israeli security. Noting Jewish Israelis' lack of support for shared sovereignty of Jerusalem, Mr Sharon will not divide the holy city as he sees it as a betrayal of Israel's past. He recognises that a Palestinian state is inevitable, but he will not negotiate with Palestinians until the intifada has ended. While Mr Barak offered a greater share of the West Bank and Gaza to the Palestinians, Mr Sharon is adamant that he will not give them more land than they already control.

What were the main points of his acceptance speech?
"The government, under my leadership, will act to restore security to the citizens of Israel, and to achieve a genuine peace and stability in the area. Peace requires painful compromises by both sides. I call upon our Palestinian neighbours to cast off the path of violence and to return to the path of dialogue and solving the conflicts between us by peaceful means. A government, under my leadership, will act to achieve genuine political settlements that will preserve the existential and historic needs of Israel, which will be based on mutual respect and mutual security."

How was the election result treated across the world?
With trepidation. The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was noncommittal. He said: "We respect the decision of the Israeli people and hope the peace process will continue." Left-wing Israelis also voiced concern. Yossi Beilin, the justice minister and senior negotiator, called the result Israel's biggest gamble. He said: "I hope and pray that this gamble will not be a disaster and the peace process will continue," The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said: "The Israeli people have made their choice and we will of course work with the person that they have chosen as prime minister. Mr Sharon may have won a very substantial victory. There is no doubting the fact that the majority of the people of Israel would like to see that peace settlement." In the US, president George Bush congratulated Sharon in a brief phone call and said Washington would work with him on peace. He also declared the US-Israeli relationship "rock solid".

Will the peace process continue?
Possibly, but probably not in the short term. Mr Sharon has told the world he will suppress the intifada, so his actions during the infancy of his presidency will be crucial. Also, he does not accept the peace terms as set out in the 1993 Oslo accord, and would want a complete renegotiation. Nonetheless, any future peace deal secured with the backing of Mr Sharon has a far greater chance of success than any that Mr Barak might have brokered.

What now for Mr Barak and the Israeli left?
When conceding defeat, Mr Barak also stepped down as the leader of the Labour party - although he told his supporters they had "lost the battle but would win the war". The Labour party now awaits a leadership contest to restore the party's support. Shimon Peres, Nobel peace prize winner, is the favourite to take over, although Avraham Burg, the former Knesset speaker, is another contender. In the meantime, the left will probably concentrate their efforts in the Knesset where Mr Sharon has 45 days to form another coalition government. If he fails to do this, parliamentary elections will be held.
