webTitle: Hague to attack government over volunteers checks plan

fields.headline: Hague to attack government over volunteers checks plan
fields.trailText: Tory leader William Hague will today accuse government ministers of "stealing" his idea to drop controversial charges for police checks on volunteers working with children.
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague will today accuse government ministers of "stealing" his idea to drop controversial charges for police checks on volunteers working with children.

Mr Hague will claim ministers made a u-turn on the issue after hearing that the Tories were to make it an election pledge.

The Conservative leader is due to announce the initiative in his speech to the annual conference of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations in London today at 4pm GMT.

But the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, will announce plans to drop the £10-a-head fee - which the voluntary sector said could cost it up to £15m a year - during his own speech to the NCVO conference this morning.

Shadow cabinet office minister Andrew Lansley said: "Once the government knew earlier today that William Hague was set to announce that a Conservative government would, after the election, meet these costs and lift the burden off the voluntary sector, lo and behold the government policy changes."

William Hague is instead expected to announce Conservative plans to boost voluntary groups and give them "a voice at the top of government".

The Tory leader has drawn up proposals for an office of civil society to help groups to get funding and become involved in major projects such as running schools.

Mr Hague will explain that the office, reporting to a cabinet minister, would cut "funding to bureaucracy" and provide information on other sources of cash.

The Tory leader is expected to say he would simplify the "complexity and number" of application forms presented to groups seeking government grants.

And will add: "There is a growing danger that groups that get money are the best at hacking the system rather than those who are best at the work in hand."

webTitle: Prince William wins award for voluntary work in Chile

fields.headline: Prince William wins award for voluntary work in Chile
fields.trailText: Prince William has been given an award for his high profile voluntary work in Chile, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Prince William has been given an award for his high profile voluntary work in Chile, it was announced today.

The 18-year-old prince has been made an honorary "millennium volunteer" (MV) for his efforts with Raleigh International in the tiny Patagonian village of Tortel, where he helped teach in a local school, spent time as a DJ and worked on community construction projects.

Education secretary David Blunkett announced the award during his address to the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) annual conference. It is the first time the accolade has been given for someone's voluntary work overseas, although 1,600 other young people have received the MV award for dedication shown in the UK.

The prince, whose voluntary work was profiled in a TV documentary last year, was chosen for the award by the Millennium Volunteer projects' national youth forum. He will receive a certificate of excellence signed by Mr Blunkett.

The award is made to young people aged between 16 and 24 who have given up their time for the benefit of others. Mr Blunkett said: "He (the prince) has shown how young people can make a difference by volunteering their time."

webTitle: Doctors and vets vie for viewers

fields.headline: Doctors and vets vie for viewers
fields.trailText: 4.30pm TV overnights: Medics and vets were at the centre of the ratings battle last night, with ITV eventually winning out. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
Doctors, vets, lawyers and police were at the centre of the TV ratings battle last night - with ITV eventually winning out.

BBC1 maintained a fairly steady audience - 13.2 million viewers tuned in to watch Sonia say goodbye to baby Chloe on EastEnders at 7.35pm.

Eight million viewers - 32% of the audience - stayed tuned to watch the drama on the wards of Holby City at 8.05pm.

Meanwhile, 7.3 million viewers were hoping the Bill's DS McAllister would get caught out for sleeping with her informer on ITV at 8pm.

Almost 8m tuned in at 9pm for Peak Practice.

This was pitched against the concluding episode of BBC1's two-part psychological thriller Second Sight, which was watched by 5.1 million - a 21% share.

BBC2 scored a hit at 9pm with the second of its three-part series Congo. The show pulled in 4.5 million viewers.

BBC News at 10pm had 4.7 million viewers, compared with ITV News At Ten's 6.2 million.

Most of the ITV viewers - 5.7 million - stayed tuned for ITV's morbidly engrossing Prime Suspect: Real Life at 10.20pm, about wife-killer Mitchell Quy.

Boston Law, BBC1's 10.35pm real-life law series, pulled in just 2.4 million viewers.

Channel 4's new three-programme series on gender-swapping, Boy Meets Girl, attracted 2 million viewers at 9pm.

Channel 5 got its highest viewing figures of the evening at 9pm, when 1.9 million watched the Harrison Ford thriller Presumed Innocent.

The movie was part of the channel's Murder Week.

webTitle: Feature: How much can you pay for ... a kitchen sink

fields.headline: How much can you pay for ... a kitchen sink
fields.trailText: American self-help guru Deepak Chopra claims that colours have different frequencies which can alleviate maladies from insomnia to depression. Green is said to balance body and mind, blue reduces stress and enhances sleep, and red stimulates the blood and encourages action.
fields.body:
American self-help guru Deepak Chopra claims that colours have different frequencies which can alleviate maladies from insomnia to depression. Green is said to balance body and mind, blue reduces stress and enhances sleep, and red stimulates the blood and encourages action.

Trendy bars such as the Starck-designed Light Bar and Mayfair's 10 Tokyos have separate colour-adjuster switches so punters can dictate their environment as the mood takes them. However, unless you decide to check in to St Martins Lane Hotel for the night, you will come home to regular electric light - if you are sober enough to find the switch when you stagger into the kitchen for a glass of water.

Or you could, of course, invest £599 in a Swink - a translucent kitchen sink to you and me. Made from state-of-the-art polymer, it comes in a range of good-enough-to-eat colours from cranberry ice to chocca mocca zest.

You can turn the lighting on or off by brushing a touch-sensitive disc and it even has an attractive range of colour co-ordinated accessories and matching joystick mixer tap. Energy-saving fluorescent tubes run at a low voltage which is just as well really. These coloured lights make no claims to alleviate your hangover but at least will save you a few stubbed toes.

 From Buyers and Sellers, 120 Ladbroke Grove, London W10 5NE. Tel: 0845 085 5585.

webTitle: Parents: Popstars winner and her secret children

fields.headline: Mum's the word
fields.standfirst: So why did a Popstars winner keep her children secret?
fields.trailText: So why did a Popstars winner keep her children secret?
fields.body:
The sight of the ITV Popstars winner Kym Marsh breaking down in tears as she admitted that she had kept a secret from the organisers was the perfect cliffhanger to ensure that the 10m viewers who tuned in on Saturday night would come back for more. The secret - that 24-year-old Marsh is a mother of two - is a shock because an ambitious, attractive, young would-be pop starlet is not supposed to have a couple of kids in tow. That she assumed her children had to be tucked away illustrates how incompatible being a mother and being an aspiringly successful young woman are perceived to be.

The reality is that having children closes doors. When asked why she had not been honest, Marsh said that in the past it had stood in her way. But why should it be so terrible to have children?

In showbiz, it is almost de rigueur for women already established in the public eye to have kids. From Zoë Ball and Kate Winslet to the All Saints mums and Madonna, the message is that a woman really can "have it all". But these mothers have almost always achieved success before having a family.

Marsh has broken the unwritten rules by being an ordinary girl who wants to live her dreams after having children. Of course, she will need a decent childcare network if she is to have the career she desires, but even then she will be condemned. Young mothers have been scapegoated for every social ill from rising crime to the demise of the nuclear family. We think of young mothers in stereotypical terms as silly, sponging and narcissistic - not the articulate, dedicated young woman that Marsh is.

As a 24-year-old single mother of two children myself, I have often met these prejudices. People are always surprised to learn that I have children, and was a teenage single mother. They are full of admiration that I have completed a BA and MA. But would people be as impressed if I had put in the same hours working at the local supermarket? Rather than the juggling of time and commitments, perhaps the surprise is at my ambition and success, and that I don't look, speak and behave as a young mother apparently should. Neither does Marsh. Although we can't know for sure whether she would have been rejected for acknowledging her children, it may well have been that keeping quiet won her the chance to realise her dreams.

While women's careers are now taken seriously, even after children, mothers are still seen as less committed workers. The price of equality in the workplace is often that women may compete - but only as long as they pretend that their children don't affect them, or don't exist at all.

Marsh's denial is symptomatic of a broader trend. So as not to seem unprofessional, women in high-powered careers avoid talking about their children at work, and know that leaving the office at five o'clock to pick the kids up may be perceived as skiving.

"However important a meeting is, you have to abandon it if you can't get anyone to look after a sick child," says Hannah, a single parent. That it is usually women who have to make this choice reveals that society still sees us as primarily responsible for childcare. It also ignores the juggling of parenting and employment by mothers, and the dedication to their jobs that this requires. Mel, a mother of three young children who is trying to establish a career after staying at home, asks: "Which sounds worse on the CV: a maternity break or nothing at all?"

Given the prejudice that Marsh's plight has illustrated, a potential employer may well look more favourably on the CV with unaccounted-for periods of unemployment. While most mothers know that a woman with kids and dreams must be exceptionally hard-working and determined, many others still see her as a liability to be avoided. Intelligent women are supposed to have a career first, then children. And on becoming a mother, ambition is supposed to fly out of the window - along with free time and a tidy house.

fields.headline: The Panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: A 54-year-old grandmother gave birth for her daughter who had undergone a hysterectomy. Did she do the right thing?
fields.trailText: The Question: A 54-year-old grandmother gave birth for her daughter who had undergone a hysterectomy. Did she do the right thing?
fields.body:
Julia Fabricius
Director of the Anna Freud Centre

It is a rather moving solution that a mother should offer to do this for her daughter. This kind of arrangement has a much better chance of success than surrogacy with a stranger. The grandmother will be particularly attached to this child - but it is right that she should be because the baby is her grandchild. Openness about the child's origins is what is important here - in the same way that adopted children should be told about their backgrounds from the start. If the family relationships are already good, they should be able to work through this.

Verdict: Yes

Professor Ian Craft
Director of the London Fertility Centre

I can't think of a more compassionate act; this is surpassed only by women who deliberately have a baby using their own genes to give away. It's very sad that surrogacy is considered an unprofessional treatment in some parts of the medical profession. We have been doing surrogacy since about 1985 and I don't recollect it ever going wrong. Anyone going through surrogacy at our clinic needs to see two independent counsellors and to be made aware of all the issues. It's wonderful the way they have managed to keep this one in the family.

Verdict: Yes

Sarah Harman
Solicitor specialising in women's health

I have dealt with many young female cancer victims who have considered both surrogacy and adoption. Several have opted for surrogacy and are happy to have had children that way. Straight surrogacy, where the surrogate mother gives away her own genetic baby, can be extremely problematic, but host surrogacy, where the baby is not genetically connected to the surrogate mother, can be very successful. As long as couples have counselling and clear information about what is involved, and use surrogacy as a last resort, it is a welcome option for otherwise infertile couples.

Verdict: Yes

Valerie Riches
Spokeswoman for Family and Youth Concern

I think the question that needs to be asked on this one is: is it the right thing for the child? No one seems to be thinking about the child's role in all of this. It would appear to me that the circumstances of many of these surrogacy cases leave children confused about their heritage, identity and parentage. In this case the girl has been born of her grandmother; that is unnatural and will be confusing for her. There is a time to be a grandparent and a time to be a parent, and they are not at the same time. What is essential is the needs of the child, not the wants of the adults.

Verdict: No

Carol O'Reilly
Counsellor for Childlessness Overcome Through Surrogacy

Our organisation has had sisters doing it for each other and a couple of daughters doing it for their mothers. I have acted as a surrogate mum twice. I have no problem seeing the children I carried now: I knew I didn't want more children myself, and they were not my husband's. The woman who carried a baby for her daughter is not the baby's mother; she was an incubator for the baby, providing nourishment for her while she was growing. This mother saw all the pain her daughter was going through when she had cancer and, like most mothers, would do anything not to see her child suffer.

Verdict: Yes

Clare Brown
Spokeswoman for Child, the infertility support network

It seems that the mother, her daughter and her daughter's husband were completely aware of the ramifications of this arrangement. And it appears that they have been treated extremely well by the clinic. As long as everyone involved in surrogacy receives appropriate counselling and is medically and psychologically checked for suitability first, I don't think there's anything wrong with it. However, things can go wrong if counselling is inadequate. This woman was carrying the baby as it was the only way her daughter could have her own genetic child. All in all, it's worked out brilliantly.

Verdict: Yes

This kind of arrangement has a much better chance of success than surrogacy with a stranger. The grandmother will be particularly attached to this child - but it is right that she should be because the baby is her grandchild. webTitle: Parents: A new glossy for pre-teen girls

fields.headline: Boy zone
fields.standfirst: Paul Morley on a new glossy for pre-teen girls
fields.trailText: Paul Morley on a new glossy for pre-teen girls.
fields.body:
I don't blame Planet 3 Publishing for producing a magazine called Mad About Boys that is aimed at nine- to 12-year-old girls and which features boy pin-ups, love hints, fashion tips and agony aunt advice. But I do wish they hadn't bothered. It's another one of those things that the world could easily do without; that will probably be of short-term appeal to a narrowly targeted audience, perhaps make someone a bit of money, and basically add more junk to the world. Sort of like the Popstars kids (who, for a variety of reasons, should be called Made Up). The magazine is a commercially astute, morally messy publication, slickly targeted at those girls in the bumpy limbo land between toddlerdom and teenagehood.

There has been the inevitable orchestrated outcry that Mad About Boys attempts to sexualise pre-teen girls prematurely. But in reality the kind of make-up tips and hairstyles it features are closer to kiddy face-painting than anything seedy, unless you have an evil mind that sees sexiness in a little girl anyway.

We are in a world where clothing for a nine-year-old girl is size-bracketed as a "young teenager", and teen pop music is so biased towards pre-teens that a band like Westlife might as well be the missing link between the Tweenies and Coldplay. Pre-teen girls have left cuteness behind, and are heading as fast as they can towards the teenage funkiness that is all around them. And here is a magazine that tackily, predictably exploits this. It is difficult to see how Woolworths can ban this publication without also taking out of their shops the belly button-showing tops, little skirts and body accessories they sell for nine-year-olds and under.

The magazine is scary for an adult to look at because it is a fluffy, commercialised representation of the fact that 10-year-old girls are naturally becoming aware of their femininity, and increasingly alert to the physical, mental and environmental differences between themselves and boys. It is also scary because all the boy pin-ups are groomed to within a grinning inch of their tidy lives; they seem blissfully unaware that such a magazine ultimately confirms that, in many ways, the future is female. These are weaker-sex pin-ups.

Of course, it is not nice to see the word "sex" in a magazine for nine-year-olds, but that is because, as an adult, you do not want to believe that your nine-year-old daughter is already thinking about sex, or sexiness, however tentatively. The worst thing about Mad About Boys is that it brazenly hurls the secret new feelings of pre-teen girls, and their need to keep these feelings secret from their parents, right in our faces. It's not called Party! or Girl Fun. It's called Mad About Boys, even if we really think it should be Vaguely Curious About Boys.

I am, perhaps naively, relying on the good taste of my nine-year-old daughter Madeleine not to go anywhere near a magazine with such a name. I am as sure as a dad can be about his daughter when I say that I think it will be a couple of years before she finds the boys featured in the magazine anything other than a bit creepy. Her own feelings about boys at the moment seem to be that she would rather be one than dress to impress one. For her, the magazine's suggestions on how to begin several decades of seduction will seem yucky. Planet 3 might consider launching a magazine called Tom Boy.

But as we parents say more and more about our children: they grow up so fast. That is what is so unsettling about this magazine - not that it is making young girls grow up any faster, but that it is joining in with all those forces that are bringing to an overlit surface changes perhaps best left outside the commercial world. Maddy might flip any minute and become girly and flirty, arriving at the edges of a sexiness that previous generations might have suppressed but which was always there.

My preference would be another new magazine that is aimed at the female tweenies: Sabrina's Secrets. It's based around the TV series Sabrina the Teenage Witch, and appears to pass teenage make-up and party secrets to nine-and 10-year-olds, but without unnerving sensitive adults by overtly dragging into view the boy thing. The free gift that comes with the first issue is a make-up box. The free gift with the first issue of Mad About Boys is an inflatable photo frame.

I might be OK with Maddy having a copy of the magazine as long as the picture she puts in the frame is one of me. Because she is mad about dad, and not yet - not quite yet - mad about boys. I'm pretty sure about that.

fields.headline: Separated by birth
fields.standfirst: Will the new scanning technology help parents to bond with their unborn babies? Luisa Dillner investigates
fields.trailText: Will the new scanning technology help parents to bond with their unborn babies? Luisa Dillner investigates.
fields.body:
Forget those fuzzy ultrasound pictures of your baby as a foetus. Truthfully, you can only see its head - the rest is a two-dimensional blur of black-and-white blobs. When today's teenagers look through the family photo album, they will be ashamed of the poor photographic record of their life in the womb. These days, the fashionable foetus is having a spanking new 3D ultrasound picture that shows the fine detail of a cute face and body. There are reports of not only mothers but obstetricians crying with joy at the perfect pictures. Yes, all foetuses look alike, but with a bit of effort you can start arguing over whose side of the family those hamster cheeks and elfin ears come from.

The latest in ultrasound technology is not widely available. Newspapers publicised some of the first pictures last week. The new device is, most importantly, a diagnostic tool to detect a range of foetal abnormalities such as cleft palate and spina bifida. But doctors have also suggested that this new technology can improve the ability of parents to bond with their growing baby. And who wouldn't want to improve bonding - that primitive love for your baby that makes you want to slap anyone who hurts its feelings or doesn't think it the most beautiful, most intelligent baby in the world?

Most pregnant women have at least two ultrasound scans: a "dating scan" to establish how old the foetus is at around 12 weeks, and then a detailed scan at 20 weeks to detect specific abnormalities. Jane Bates, the superintendent sonographer at St James hospital in Leeds, believes that contrary to popular belief, bonding may not be a side-effect of these procedures.

"There is no evidence in the psychological literature that it does increase bonding,"she says. "Bonding happens whether or not you have an ultrasound. It's mother nature that does the bonding all by itself. When mum and dad see the baby on the scan they get excited about it and it's a wonderful experience, but that's not the definition of bonding."

For Isobel Taylor, a literary editor whose son Joe is seven, the feeling on seeing her foetus on screen was one of incredulity: "I couldn't believe what I could see. I had felt so ill, but had never associated my illness with the reality of having a baby. I could not believe that I would be able to grow a baby. And in some ways I didn't like it - after seeing him I felt I was never on my own."

She doesn't think it helped with bonding. "Even when I could see his elbows and hands, it didn't make me connect with him. It was unnerving. There was an overriding fear that I had this baby in there and I was going to have to get it out. Until you've got it in your arms, you don't engage with it as a baby." For men, however, who may find it even harder to connect with their baby-to-be during their partner's pregnancy, a scan (even the old-fashioned, low-res variety) often brings the reality home. "It makes the little emotional thought that you're having a baby just that bit more tangible," says Rob Barlay, a recruitment consultant, whose daughter Katrina is 13 months old. "I remember getting more excited as we saw scans which showed a recognisable human being."

But did it help with bonding? "It generated a greater feeling of reality and, therefore, love," he says. "So maybe it was the start of some bonding process. I felt a stronger affinity to my child after I saw the scan."

Clearly, though, there is a market for it: several clinics in London already offer "foetal portraits". But, according to David Howe, consultant in foeto-maternal medicine at the Princess Ann hospital in Southampton, it is the detail many parents love that makes it potentially useful - except that this usefulness may not be the positive experience that many parents expect.

"Its main benefit may be in parents being able to see and understand when something's wrong," he says. "If their baby has a facial cleft [such as a cleft palate], this enhanced scan may make it slightly easier for us to pick up. And because parents will be able to see it, they be more prepared for what their baby will look like."

But the scan can only do so much. If the foetus doesn't co-operate, then the picture won't be informative. "At the moment it can take five to 10 minutes with these scans to get just the image of the face," says Howe. "If the foetus has its nose pressed against the womb, then you can't see its face properly and you could still miss a facial cleft."

Many parents, of course, don't expect their foetus to be anything other than perfect. Wary of this, some hospitals even call the 20-week scan - the favourite for cooing over the baby - the "foetal-anomaly scan" in order to warn parents that this isn't inevitably a jolly family event.

"There is a huge discrepancy between parents' and doctors' perceptions of what scanning is for," says Howe. "We do provide information that tells parents they can decline to have a scan. Some people don't want to know if anything is wrong with their baby. But our uptake is about 98.9%. About 1-2% of these will be abnormal - more, if you count early pregnancies."

Jane Bates says that it's only when parents have had an abnormal foetal scan that their attitude changes towards the procedure.

"It can be incredibly hard to tell women when something's wrong. We give them written information about the purpose of the scan before they come here, but for some reason it's hard for people to retain it - maybe women just expect their babies to be normal. Mums who have had problems tend to be more informed about what we're looking for on a scan.

"The scan may be a nice experience, but the NHS is not in the business of screening unless there is a clear benefit. The first reason for these scans is medical: to check the baby's heart is beating; that it is in the womb; that it is growing; and that the placenta is in the right place."

Bates believes there is an argument for parents signing a consent form for the procedure to lend it seriousness. "Some clinics do provide scans just for fun," she says. "It just perpetuates the myth that this is a Warner Brothers experience."

fields.headline: The baby whisperer
fields.standfirst: Hollywood nanny Tracy Hogg is said to have an uncanny ability to read babies' minds. But now her ex says she is a less than perfect mother. So should childcare experts always practise what they preach?  Maureen Freely reports
fields.trailText: Hollywood nanny Tracy Hogg is said to have an uncanny ability to read babies' minds. But now her ex says she is a less than perfect mother. So should childcare experts always practise what they preach? Maureen Freely reports.
fields.body:
Arnold Schwarzenegger swears by her. So do Jodie Foster, Cindy Crawford, and Michael J Fox. They call her "the baby whisperer", and her knack for understanding the babies of the rich and famous is something to behold. Hand her a wailing infant with a household name, or let that infant wail down the phone, and within seconds she can tell you what he is really saying, and how to calm him down.

A word to the wise, though: if you are thinking of hiring her, your first phone call should probably be to the bank. Tracy Hogg, Yorkshire-born nanny to the stars, does not come cheap. Her day rate is £700. A three-week stay could set you back £10,000.

But now we have read things about Hogg's past that make you wonder how she could have had the nerve to set herself up as a child expert. The story comes from her ex-husband, a former miner named Ray Fear, who talked to the tabloids earlier this week, to coincide with - or perhaps sabotage - the publication in Britain of her book, Secrets of the Baby Whisperer.

In it, Hogg claims that she learned most of her magic from her grandmother, and the rest from working as a nurse with disabled children. However, Fear claims that she did little whispering with her own daughters. There was, allegedly, no breast-feeding: Hogg put both girls straight on the bottle and went straight back to work. Even when they were very small, she left their care to her mother and grandmother. Then, eight years ago, she and her second husband moved to California, leaving behind her daughters, then seven and 10. The latter, Sarah, now lives in Hollywood with her mother. The younger one, Sophie, will be joining them after her GCSEs.

Hogg insists that leaving them was the right decision, and that she maintained a close relationship with the girls via school holidays and the internet. But Fear counters that the girls were distraught when their mother moved away. "Sophie would say, 'Mummy is in America looking after all these babies and staying with them. Why isn't she doing it with me?'" It is a question some of her clients may be asking, too.

But is it fair to expect childcare experts to have perfect childcare records themselves? Before condemning Hogg, it is worth examining how her predecessors and peers have managed. Dr Spock, for example, was incapable of the sort of warm and permissive fathering he extolled in his books. "He was very Victorian," one of his sons recalls. He was "never a person who gave a hug. He couldn't kiss me. He never kissed me." Spock was, at least, aware of his shortcomings (not just as a parent but as a stepfather). He even admitted them in public.

The same cannot be said of the father of all childcare experts, John-Jacques Rousseau. In Emile, the widest read manual of its time, he wrote passionately against swaddling and eloquently in defence of breastfeeding. But he left all five of his illegitimate children to the mercy of foundling hospitals where the infant mortality rate was often as high as 100%.

Measure Hogg against such a standard, and she comes off looking like an earth goddess. According to Frank Furedi, a sociologist, it would be wrong to scapegoat her. "We don't need to have a go at her for not being a perfect mother," says Furedi, author of the forthcoming Paranoid Parenting. "This is an impossible burden on anybody."

But the world would be a better place, he thinks, if we could give up on the myth of the perfect expert. In his book, Furedi challenges the idea that anyone "can have an expertise on a very intimate relationship and generalise from that. It misses the fact that each relationship is unique". You learn the most as a parent, he says, by spending time with children and the other parents at the school gate. This sort of learning is best because it is rooted in "the specificity of experiences, and the tissue of organic relationships". If you take your instruction from childcare experts, "it short-circuits this process".

Sheila Kitzinger, whose name is often twinned with words like expert and guru, couldn't agree more. "We are sitting ducks. Sometimes it's the baby who is telling us we are doing the wrong thing, crying all day long, telling us we're a bad mother."

The real problem, she says, is that "a lot of women who have babies are socially isolated. They were working in an office and now they are home. There isn't anyone they can talk to, and so often because there's so much competition to have the perfect baby, they can't tell anyone. And then the experts step in."

Like Furedi, she does not believe they can presume to know best. Parents, she says, learn best from each other, by "sharing what they've learned through experience and observation". She tries to work within that tradition when she writes her books. "What I'm trying to do is not talk to a woman," says Kitzinger, "but talk with her. It's part of a discussion a sharing, an equal relationship, there are some things I know, some things she knows, and some things I'll never know. It isn't me dishing out the answers."

But according to Deborah Jackson, author of the permissive classic Three in a Bed, many readers do prefer experts who play the part. She recalls a speech she gave a few years ago to a group of parents who were, in her view, becoming too cultish about the "continuum concept". (This is the theory that you should hold your child continuously for the first few years of life.) She knew it was going to be a hostile audience, so she left her children at home. The group was furious.

"I got hammered for not bringing the children, for not putting them on view," she recalls. "They didn't just want me to parent perfectly, but parent perfectly in public."

Her new book, Baby Wisdom, looks at the history of of child-rearing across the world. The idea is not to give advice, but to provide a context so that people can make their own informed and imaginative decisions. But Jackson has had to work hard to keep the publishers from using the word "bible" on the cover. She understands why it would make sense in marketing terms, and why first-time parents would warm to it.

"It's a terrifying experience," she agrees, "and our culture doesn't prepare us for it. To get through it, you don't need an ordinary book, you need something spiritual. You need a bible."

But how awful to wake up and find out you have been mistaken for a deity. "What happens with many experts is that we end up deconstructing ourselves," Jackson points out. "We stake a position and we end up backing down the rest of our lives, because we see people are leaning too severely on what we have said. So I say, 'Down with experts.' Let's admit there are no answers, and we are just having a discussion. The more flawed perspectives there are, the better." The trouble is - as Hogg may be learning to her cost - is that flawed perspectives don't sell books.
fields.bodyText: Arnold Schwarzenegger swears by her. So do Jodie Foster, Cindy Crawford, and Michael J Fox. They call her "the baby whisperer", and her knack for understanding the babies of the rich and famous is something to behold. Hand her a wailing infant with a household name, or let that infant wail down the phone, and within seconds she can tell you what he is really saying, and how to calm him down. A word to the wise, though: if you are thinking of hiring her, your first phone call should probably be to the bank. Tracy Hogg, Yorkshire-born nanny to the stars, does not come cheap. Her day rate is £700. A three-week stay could set you back £10,000. But now we have read things about Hogg's past that make you wonder how she could have had the nerve to set herself up as a child expert. The story comes from her ex-husband, a former miner named Ray Fear, who talked to the tabloids earlier this week, to coincide with - or perhaps sabotage - the publication in Britain of her book, Secrets of the Baby Whisperer. In it, Hogg claims that she learned most of her magic from her grandmother, and the rest from working as a nurse with disabled children. However, Fear claims that she did little whispering with her own daughters. There was, allegedly, no breast-feeding: Hogg put both girls straight on the bottle and went straight back to work. Even when they were very small, she left their care to her mother and grandmother. Then, eight years ago, she and her second husband moved to California, leaving behind her daughters, then seven and 10. The latter, Sarah, now lives in Hollywood with her mother. The younger one, Sophie, will be joining them after her GCSEs. Hogg insists that leaving them was the right decision, and that she maintained a close relationship with the girls via school holidays and the internet. But Fear counters that the girls were distraught when their mother moved away. "Sophie would say, 'Mummy is in America looking after all these babies and staying with them. Why isn't she doing it with me?'" It is a question some of her clients may be asking, too. But is it fair to expect childcare experts to have perfect childcare records themselves? Before condemning Hogg, it is worth examining how her predecessors and peers have managed. Dr Spock, for example, was incapable of the sort of warm and permissive fathering he extolled in his books. "He was very Victorian," one of his sons recalls. He was "never a person who gave a hug. He couldn't kiss me. He never kissed me." Spock was, at least, aware of his shortcomings (not just as a parent but as a stepfather). He even admitted them in public. The same cannot be said of the father of all childcare experts, John-Jacques Rousseau. In Emile, the widest read manual of its time, he wrote passionately against swaddling and eloquently in defence of breastfeeding. But he left all five of his illegitimate children to the mercy of foundling hospitals where the infant mortality rate was often as high as 100%. Measure Hogg against such a standard, and she comes off looking like an earth goddess. According to Frank Furedi, a sociologist, it would be wrong to scapegoat her. "We don't need to have a go at her for not being a perfect mother," says Furedi, author of the forthcoming Paranoid Parenting. "This is an impossible burden on anybody." But the world would be a better place, he thinks, if we could give up on the myth of the perfect expert. In his book, Furedi challenges the idea that anyone "can have an expertise on a very intimate relationship and generalise from that. It misses the fact that each relationship is unique". You learn the most as a parent, he says, by spending time with children and the other parents at the school gate. This sort of learning is best because it is rooted in "the specificity of experiences, and the tissue of organic relationships". If you take your instruction from childcare experts, "it short-circuits this process". Sheila Kitzinger, whose name is often twinned with words like expert and guru, couldn't agree more. "We are sitting ducks. Sometimes it's the baby who is telling us we are doing the wrong thing, crying all day long, telling us we're a bad mother." The real problem, she says, is that "a lot of women who have babies are socially isolated. They were working in an office and now they are home. There isn't anyone they can talk to, and so often because there's so much competition to have the perfect baby, they can't tell anyone. And then the experts step in." Like Furedi, she does not believe they can presume to know best. Parents, she says, learn best from each other, by "sharing what they've learned through experience and observation". She tries to work within that tradition when she writes her books. "What I'm trying to do is not talk to a woman," says Kitzinger, "but talk with her. It's part of a discussion a sharing, an equal relationship, there are some things I know, some things she knows, and some things I'll never know. It isn't me dishing out the answers." But according to Deborah Jackson, author of the permissive classic Three in a Bed, many readers do prefer experts who play the part. She recalls a speech she gave a few years ago to a group of parents who were, in her view, becoming too cultish about the "continuum concept". (This is the theory that you should hold your child continuously for the first few years of life.) She knew it was going to be a hostile audience, so she left her children at home. The group was furious. "I got hammered for not bringing the children, for not putting them on view," she recalls. "They didn't just want me to parent perfectly, but parent perfectly in public." Her new book, Baby Wisdom, looks at the history of of child-rearing across the world. The idea is not to give advice, but to provide a context so that people can make their own informed and imaginative decisions. But Jackson has had to work hard to keep the publishers from using the word "bible" on the cover. She understands why it would make sense in marketing terms, and why first-time parents would warm to it. "It's a terrifying experience," she agrees, "and our culture doesn't prepare us for it. To get through it, you don't need an ordinary book, you need something spiritual. You need a bible." But how awful to wake up and find out you have been mistaken for a deity. "What happens with many experts is that we end up deconstructing ourselves," Jackson points out. "We stake a position and we end up backing down the rest of our lives, because we see people are leaning too severely on what we have said. So I say, 'Down with experts.' The trouble is - as Hogg may be learning to her cost - is that flawed perspectives don't sell books.

webTitle: Fears over inequality in 'care trusts' merger plans

fields.headline: Clause for concern
fields.standfirst: Fears over inequality in 'care trusts' merger plans
fields.trailText: Fears over inequality in 'care trusts' merger plans.
fields.body:
MPs were warned yesterday of growing anxiety that government plans to merge health and social services in "care trusts" may lead to an unequal partnership, with community services squeezed to meet the acute needs of a dominant NHS.

Concerns were voiced by the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), the Local Government Association (LGA), public services union Unison and charities Age Concern and Help the Aged as the committee stage of the health and social care bill began to debate the care trust clauses.

Ministers gave assurances in the summer that they did not want the NHS to swallow up social care, but these were not clearly written into the fine print of the bill. The five organisations said in a letter to Alan Milburn, health secretary, that while care trusts could be "an important addition to existing flexibilities" in terms of developing seamless services, their potential would be fully realised only if they "draw equally on the expertise and experience of both local government and the NHS".

The ADSS points out that the bill describes care trusts as NHS bodies, with the result that social services may come to be regarded as a minor partner. "There is evidence from Northern Ireland that, where health and social care has been merged, resources are invested in acute care at the expense of those in the community," the association says. There is "a danger that a medical/clinical model could begin to dominate the development of services", damaging preventative work in the community, such as the home care service.

The LGA is concerned that councils should have the right to withdraw from care trusts if they think the arrangement is not working well. The bill states that this could not be done without government permission. According to the LGA, this would mean local authorities "may find themselves delegating their responsibility for social care to the secretary of state in perpetuity".

There is also anxiety that care trusts could be imposed on areas where services were failing. Yet there are no criteria or procedures for judging failure. The five organisations are seeking "an assurance that the imposition of care trusts will genuinely be an option of last resort".

Other demands by the five include: statutory consultation with service users before any care trust is imposed; greater clarity about which services should be free and which should be charged; and protection of resources to ensure that care trusts do not cut levels of service provided by local authorities that have traditionally spent above government guidelines.

Ministers were expected to try again yesterday to persuade the social care community that it will not be taken over by the NHS. But it was understood that no government amendments were in prospect to consolidate that assurance on the face of the bill.

webTitle: US survey scares Labour off online ads

fields.headline: US survey scares Labour off online ads
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: A survey of voting habits has led Labour to drop plans for an online election campaign, writes Matthew Tempest.
fields.body:
Labour strategists have dropped plans for an internet advertising blitz in the run-up to the election.

They have been prompted by the findings of the US presidential election, which suggested "pop-up" ads can backfire.

Millbank election planners had hoped to use the forthcoming general election to test internet advertising in advance of a massive push for the election after next.

But results gathered by America's E-voter Institute, reported on IT news service silicon.com, showed ads used by both presidential candidates were counter-productive.

A Labour Party strategy insider said "Labour had been planning a major online campaign for this coming election.

"They don't necessarily think it will be important this time round.

"However, they want to gain experience for the future when they expect online campaigns to be huge."

But he added: "This has all been put on hold following the problems experienced in the US."

The e-voter survey showed online political advertising has some unintended and potentially negative consequences.

The survey tracked 40,000 customers of Juno Online Services, a free internet service provider in the US that requires users to allow their surfing habits to be tracked.

It covered the period from June to November 2000.

Participants registered their sympathies before the study began.

Their exposure to advertising was monitored and their voting behaviour was tracked after the election.

Negative ads were not included in the survey.

"Pop-up" ads, so-called because they automatically launch onto a user's screen and have to be clicked away, were mainly used by both parties for rebuttal and appeared to turn off voters.

The survey showed 42% of undecided voters with Democratic sympathies, who saw no internet ads, ended up voting for Democratic candidate Al Gore.

However, 60% of Democrat-inclined voters who saw an ad for Republican George W Bush said they voted for Mr Gore.

Dennis Kavanagh, professor of politics and communication studies at Liverpool University, confirmed the report.

"The Labour Party will be putting online advertising on the backburner following what happened in America," he said.

A spokesman for the Labour Party denied that it had shelved an online campaign.

"Labour is always looking at innovative ways of campaigning and we are ruling nothing out at this stage," he said.

He refused to specify how much the Labour Party had intended to spend on internet advertising * or the style it would take.

A spokesman for the Conservative Party said "We certainly intend to use the internet as a valuable resource in the election."

webTitle: Web failures sting News Corp for £200m

fields.headline: Web failures sting News Corp for £200m
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: News Corporation doomed flirtation with the internet has cost the company £200m, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 7:Murdoch on verge of Sky Global float
Feb 7: BSkyB losses almost double
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has been hit by a £200m loss from its doomed flirtation with the internet.

News Corp recently announced a massive scaling back of its new media operations, including the termination of two joint ventures with online healthcare group WebMD.

The WebMD write-off and the cost of other failed web investments were the main cause of a first-half operating loss of £200m.

This figure compares with a profit of £576m for the same period in 1999.

Analysts are threatening to downgrade shares in News Corp's BSkyB satellite TV station after it reported losses on its new media investments.

Today's news will not improve sentiment.

Elsewhere in Mr Murdoch's media empire, revenues were unchanged at £4.8bn.

This can be put down to falling advertising revenue at Mr Murdoch's Australian newspapers and at the Fox Broadcasting Company in the US.

"With economic growth slowing in several of our key markets, all of our divisions are working more diligently than ever to keep costs down while maximising revenues and profits," said Mr Murdoch, chairman of News Corp.

A small silver lining was provided by News Corp's UK newspapers, which include The Sun and The Times.

Advertising revenues increased by 8% and operating income surged by 19%.

News Corp's considerable assets include the Star TV broadcast station in Asia, Twentieth Century Fox Television and Film, and HarperCollins publishing.

Although today's results will disappoint the markets, investors will be more interested on news of News Corp's proposed merger with US satellite broadcaster DirecTV.

Both parties were unavailable for comment.

However, they are understood to have agreed a deal in which Mr Murdoch will unveil a £40bn satellite TV company called Sky Global Networks.

webTitle: New pay deal raises hopes of an end to Scottish strikes

fields.headline: New pay deal raises hopes of an end to Scottish strikes
fields.trailText: The long-running pay dispute between Scottish councils and town hall union Unison has today come a step closer to being settled as authorities tabled a new offer. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
The long-running pay dispute between Scottish councils and town hall union Unison has today come a step closer to being settled as authorities tabled a new offer.

The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) has formally put the new pay offer to Unison leaders, who are expected to recommend that members accept the deal and bring to an end their campaign of one-day and indefinite strike action.

The pay deal will mean an average wage increase of just over 14% between 2000-04, and secure a minimum local government wage of £5 an hour in 2002.

It will comprise a flat rate £500 pay increase from March next year and a 4% increase from April 2003.

It will also include "inflation proofing" measures, allowing unions to re-open discussions if inflation outstrips pay increases.

A Cosla spokeswoman said: "We really have broken through completely. Everything's been so positive over the last few weeks. I don't think we'd be tabling an offer if we didn't think it was going to go all the way."

Unison has already agreed to put the proposals to its members and the union's pay negotiating team wants to recommend the offer. Unison's local government forum will meet on Monday to decide whether to endorse the negotiators' view.

Scottish local government organiser Joe Di Paola said: "This new offer is a major step forward and we want to ask our members whether they are prepared to accept it. The members' wishes have driven us throughout this dispute. It is the members' action in the one-day and selective strikes that has pushed the employers to this new position."

fields.headline: What the Arab papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Arab world comes to terms with the election of hardliner Ariel Sharon as Israeli prime minister.
fields.body:
The response of the Arab world to Ariel Sharon's stunning defeat of Ehud Barak is clouded by the usual plodding incompetence of the few English-language news sites in the region. Most of the papers rely on bland western agency reports, adding little in the way of comment or reaction.

In the occupied territories most likely to be affected by the change in Israeli leadership, the Palestine National Authority's Palestinian ministry of information round-up of translated headlines from the Arabic press reflects fear and loathing of the new Israeli prime minister. A stark example: "Sharon plans for more assassinations and for tightening the siege of the Palestinian territories".

The Jordan Times affects a nonchalant line on the drastic change of direction in next-door Israel: "The press has been busy vilifying the new Israeli premier, Ariel Sharon, and basing its campaign on his history as a warmonger. Harsh words in reference to Sharon are not unjustified. But we cannot say that under Sharon, Arabs, especially Palestinians, and the peace process are in a worse situation than they were two days ago, or even two months ago. It was the 'dove' Ehud Barak, after all, who helped draw us - Arab and Israeli - back into the abyss."

The paper also carries a thoughtprovoking commentary by Rami Khouri in the USA, who argues that the Arab-Israeli conflict has been downgraded in international eyes to a regional problem: "We have become a kind of long-running Rwanda or Chechnya that evokes humanitarian or emotional concern, but not a lot of strategic will among world powers to intervene directly or deeply. The powers will send us envoys, but not much else."

Khouri acidly dismisses Sharon's lifetime approach to the conflict: "His tough-guy, iron fist, semitic cowboy approach to life and Arabs has been a proven political failure, and a Jewish moral quagmire to boot. Other Likud leaders who promised similar approaches found that this makes fearful and angry Israelis feel good for about, oh, seven weeks, after which the harsh reality of life and pan-semitic politics sinks in: cowboys are good for movies and the cattle business, but not for political leadership."

In the Dubai-based Gulf News, commentator George Hishmeh puts an optimistic gloss on Sharon's triumph: "The odds are that the new Israeli prime minister is bound to inflame international public opinion, as his Likud predecessor did, and lose the automatic support his country receives, especially in the United States, whenever it has a confrontation with its neighbours."

fields.trailText: Can anyone help me regarding a year's trip I plan to make with another female friend next year to the US, taking in Mexico and Canada?
fields.body:
Can anyone help me regarding a year's trip I plan to make with another female friend next year to the US, taking in Mexico and Canada? Is it legitimate to prolong the usual three-month permitted stay in the States by crossing over into the aforementioned countries and re-entering the US a couple of months later? Any advice would be very gratefully received
Caroline Jago

fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
11.15am:Greg Dyke has launched an attack on the much-reviled internal market introduced by his predecessor Lord Birt, writes Lisa O'Carrol.
">Feb 7: Dyke accuses 'foes at the top'
Special report: The BBC
fields.body:
Greg Dyke has launched an attack on the much-reviled internal market introduced by his predecessor Lord Birt.

He revealed buying something as simple as a roll of Sellotape cost producers up to £70.

Mr Dyke said the BBC benefited from an accounting system that forced programme-makers to account for everything they used.

But he added the system had mushroomed out of control and had become damaging to the corporation's image and to staff morale.

Mr Dyke said he discovered some of the more ridiculous aspects of the market while catching up on internal affairs on holiday in Barbados.

"It was just hilarious. You would ask 'can I borrow your Sellotape?' and somebody would say 'what's your number'.

"It cost you £70 every time you charged for something in the internal market."

"The most unpopular aspects were mostly trivial.

"To get a CD out of the library cost £15 but you could get it for £9.99 at HMV.

"That one story alone was really damaging to everything else that was happening at the BBC. Every MP knew it," he explained.

"Then there was the BBC pronunciation unit. If you were a local radio station in Derby you couldn't afford it.

"What is the point of having the unit if your staff can't use it? You might as well close it down," Mr Dyke said.

The director-general said one of his most important missions on arrival at the BBC was to boost staff morale and make them feel excited about their work.

He claimed the atmosphere was poisoned by internecine battles and a "them and us" divide between staff and management.

"You can get away with baronies but the competition today is so intense you have to focus on your competitors.

"You can't do that if the enemy camp is down the corridor.

"You cannot run an organisation like that today. If you do, you do not succeed," he said.

At an address to the Media Society at the London School of Economics last night, Mr Dyke warned the BBC would turn into "another Marks & Spencer" unless it kept up with the competition.

The high-street chain once synonmous with good value and quality is struggling to maintain its edge despite a make-over and the introduction of designer ranges.

"Something like 70% of companies have disappeared from the FTSE 100 in the last ten years. That is because they didn't embrace change," Dyke explained.

"The great fear the BBC has is of becoming like M&S.

"Yet 10 years ago, all the big organisations in this country wanted to be M&S - but M&S didn't see the world changing.

"If you don't change, you don't survive," he said.

He said this was why the BBC1 schedules had to change so dramatically.

Mr Dyke's remarks came just 24 hours after it emerged the BBC is to make way for more drama and entertainment on BBC1 by shunting flagship arts programme Omnibus to BBC2.

The director-general said he had to maintain a competitive edge against ITV and commercial rivals if the licence fee was to survive. "ITV has four daily soaps because that is the way it can get more viewers.

"We can't do four daily soaps and nor should we.

"But if we want to keep a licence fee-funded broadcasting system, we have got to ensure people will pay the licence fee and that means finding things on the channel that matter to them.

"That means programmes that are popular, mixed with other programmes that are not aimed at popular audiences."

Relevant story

fields.headline: Smith floats state lottery plan
fields.trailText: The government is drawing up plans to nationalise the lottery to avoid a repeat of last summer's fiasco over who should run the multi-billion pound game.
fields.body:
The government is drawing up plans to nationalise the lottery to avoid a repeat of last summer's fiasco over who should run the multi-billion pound game.

In a move that will dismay the New Labour faithful, who regard nationalisation as a symbol of their discredited past, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said that a formal review of the future of the lottery would consider taking it into public hands.

Appearing before the Commons culture select committee, Mr Smith said: "It has been said to me by quite a number of people that an option could perhaps be to see a lottery that is effectively owned by the nation through the government.

"Individual services for the running of the lottery would be contracted out to suppliers."

Mr Smith's remarks, which could lead to the first nationalisation by a Labour government in more than two decades, were condemned last night by the Tories.

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, said: "It is difficult to imagine that the lottery would benefit from being owned by the state, which is not generally a good provider of modern services. This is a kneejerk response to the farce of last year and would help Labour's efforts to control the lottery."

Mr Smith made his remarks as he faced intense questions from MPs over the events of last summer when Sir Richard Branson was initially favoured to take over the lottery. After a lengthy review, involving a court case, Camelot's licence was renewed for another seven years.

Gerald Kaufman, the veteran Labour chairman of the select committee, said he saw no problem with government-run lotteries after visiting the United States, where two-thirds of lotteries are run by state authorities. "Here we have a Labour government that is less socialist than republicans in the US," Mr Kaufman said.

Conscious of the sensitivity of talking about nationalisation, Mr Smith insisted that he was "agnostic" about whether the government should take over the lottery.

He added that the government's painful experience of the Millennium Dome would make ministers cautious.

fields.headline: Oftel threatens mobile phone crackdown
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The telecoms watchdog claims the UK's top four mobile phone operators are making too much of a profit, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms watchdog Oftel has threatened a regulatory crackdown on the UK's top four mobile phone operators.

The comments were made in Oftel's mobile phone market review.

This found companies such as Vodafone, BT Cellnet, Orange and One2One were making too much profit from a fully competitive market.

"UK mobile prices overall compare favourably to the rest of Europe and they continue to fall.

"However, there is evidence prices could be lower still," said David Edmonds, director general of Oftel.

He added prices for international calls and for calls between rival mobile networks were not coming down compared with the cost of other services.

"Oftel will carry out further research into companies' pricing and profitability to assess if any of the operators are setting prices too high.

"We will monitor prices for services such as international roaming and for calls between different mobile networks," Mr Edmonds said.

Despite finding mobile prices have fallen by 24% since January 1999, Oftel is prepared impose regulations on the market leaders to prevent anti-competitive behaviour.

Any action against mobile call charges will be a blow to the UK's leading wireless operators.

They shelled out a staggering £22.5bn for next generation UK mobile phone licences last year and will need all the revenues they can get to pay for the franchises.

These fears hit Vodafone's share price in early trading.

The world's largest mobile phone company fell 2.9%, with BT tumbling 5.3% despite a recent strong run.

fields.headline: BSkyB losses almost double
fields.trailText: 9am: BSkyB has been forced to write off £25m on new media investments as losses at the company reach £112m, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BSkyB has been forced to write off £25m on new media investments as losses at the company almost doubled to a staggering £112m.

BSkyB announced it had crashed through the all-important 5m subscriber barrier but its decision to subsidise subscribers continued to eat into the bottom line.

The UK's largest satellite and digital broadcaster has been burning cash in the chase for customers and the trend was underlined in this morning's first-half results.

BSkyB's all-important digital subscriber total climbed from 4m in September last year to 4.66m in December, taking the number of analogue and digital subscribers to just over 5m.

The digital figures receive such close attention because digital broadcasting is widely seen as the future of TV.

Any company ahead at this stage is seen as well set for the future.

BSkyB's nearest rival is Carlton and Granada's ONdigital, with 1m subscribers.

"We are continuing to innovate with the launch of interactive services that will increase our revenues and maintain low churn.

"Sky customers now benefit from the world's most developed interactive television service," said Tony Ball, chief executive of BSkyB.

However, a £25m write-off against several unnamed BSkyB new media investments - and the cost of subsidising subscribers with lucrative offers - resulted in first-half losses of £112m.

This is significant increase from the £61.5m registered in 1999.

Although analysts give lower priority to the pre-tax numbers, they will be concerned at the lack of movement in churn figures.

The churn level, or the amount of customers who turn to a different service, stayed at 9.8% between July and December last year.

It was hoped the rate would decrease to as much as 6.5%, although ONdigital's churn often clips 20%.

The market reaction to BSkyB's figures was muted in early trading, as the shares rose 1.8% to 1120p.

However, if BSkyB chairman Rupert Murdoch ties up the acquisition of US satellite broadcaster DirecTV, BSkyB's shares should expect a boost.

Once the DirecTV deal is completed, BSkyB will be folded into Mr Murdoch's Sky Global Networks satellite TV company.

Sky Global will then float in the biggest media share offering all time.

webTitle: Obang takes on Bracknell Forest challenge

fields.headline: Obang takes on Bracknell Forest challenge
fields.trailText: Daphne Obang will inherit a social care department that has been described as "failing to deliver services that consistently meet the needs of local people", and will need to respond to recommendations to improve services made in a recent report.
fields.body:
Daphne Obang will inherit a social care department that has been described as "failing to deliver services that consistently meet the needs of local people", and will need to respond to recommendations to improve services made in a recent report.

A joint review of Bracknell Forest borough council by the Audit Commission and the social services inspectorate says the department suffers from poor management, a lack of strategic direction and difficulties in recruiting and retaining staff.

John Bolton, director of joint reviews, said: "Bracknell Forest has a way to go to providing all local people with good social services. Although there are committed and capable staff at all levels providing some users and carers with a good service, overall, levels of dissatisfaction with the timeliness, range and quality of service is high."

The review reveals that parts of the social care department are understaffed and that the council has failed to develop enough services in collaboration with the private and voluntary sectors.

The childcare duty team has not had the staffing increase it needs to meet a rising workload, says the report, and this means carers and referrers have tried to bypass the system.

The review, published last week, adds: "Although some people are being served well, the overall conclusionis that without some significant changes, prospects for improvement are poor."

The inspectors say Bracknell Forest should give users, carers and staff a greater role in developing services, develop closer partnerships with outside organisations and agree a set of service priorities to ensure the social care department improves.

It adds, however, that the council's strengths include sound finances and committed staff. The council gained social care responsibilities more than two years ago as a result of local government reorganisation.

webTitle: Wahid supporters demand death for his opponents

fields.headline: Wahid supporters demand death for his opponents
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: An estimated 50,000 people protested today in Surabaya, Indonesia's second largest city, against attempts to impeach President Abdurrahman Wahid today.
fields.body:
An estimated 50,000 people protested today in Surabaya, Indonesia's second largest city, against attempts to impeach President Abdurrahman Wahid today.

Street battles erupted and, in an ominous turn for Indonesia's political crisis, many demanded death for those wanting to unseat Mr Wahid for alleged corruption.

Thousands, some with sickles and knives, besieged the local legislature of Mr Wahid's home province of east Java, where he is revered not only as the nation's leader but also as a Muslim cleric.

Today's protest was the biggest seen in Indonesia in the 15 months since Mr Wahid became its first democratically elected head of state in more than four decades.

Mr Wahid has denied allegations of graft and has refused to quit. He has repeatedly called on his supporters to stay calm. Nevertheless the protests have snowballed in east Java during the past five days.

"The poor people and the farmers will die for Wahid," said one protester, who identified himself only as Sugeng. "Blood will flow if he is forced to step down."

In Jakarta, military chiefs said they would continue to support the civilian government and maintain order in line with the constitution.

Even so, one mob attacked the Surabaya office of Golkar, the party of former dictator Suharto and a major force against Mr Wahid. Three police officers and several protesters were injured, witnesses said.

At one stage police fled after they were overwhelmed by the protesters, but security forces later retook the building. Several cars were torched in the melee.

Elsewhere protesters burned effigies of Mr Wahid's rivals. Others carried banners reading: "If Wahid falls, the country will be destroyed."

Passions ran high within the ranks of demonstrators. The crowd cheered when speakers demanded his political opponents be mutilated or executed. "If anyone tries to topple Wahid, we will revolt," said protest organiser Mohamad Sujadi.

In the nearby town of Mojokerto, several thousand pro-Wahid demonstrators ransacked the offices of three political parties. Also, several hundred anti-Wahid protesters rallied in front of the state palace in Jakarta, the capital.

An investigative committee last week released a report claiming that Mr Wahid knew about an illegal transfer of £2.8m from the state food agency by a former business associate. It also criticised him for failing to declare a £1.4m aid donation from the ruler of Brunei, a neighbouring country.

The panel found no proof that Mr Wahid benefited. But evidence linking him to the scandals has been used against him by legislators angered by his erratic style of government. They accuse him of arrogance and an unwillingness to cooperate with parliament.

Last week's censure approved by the full parliament requires Mr Wahid to explain his actions within three months. If he fails to do so, the legislature can give him one more month. After that he can be impeached.

Some politicians have demanded that the constitutional process be accelerated.

However, Mr Wahid was granted breathing space by vice-president Megawati Sukarnoputri who opposed such moves. Support from Mrs Megawati - whose party controls the largest slice of votes in parliament - is crucial to Mr Wahid.

Although highly critical of Mr Wahid, Golkar is also opposed to attempts to accelerate his impeachment, as are the armed forces, which retain 38 seats in the 500-member parliament.

All three groups say action against the president must be carried out strictly in accordance with the constitution.

webTitle: Brief guide: NHS patient advocacy and public scrutiny

fields.headline: Brief guide: NHS patient advocacy and public scrutiny
fields.standfirst: The abolition of community health councils (CHCs) - local health 'watchdog' bodies - is the most controversial part of the health and social care bill. Patrick Butler examines what ministers plan to put in their place.
fields.trailText: The abolition of community health councils (CHCs) - local health 'watchdog' bodies - is the most controversial part of the health and social care bill. Patrick Butler examines what ministers want to put in their place.
fields.body:
Local government scrutiny committees Health authorities will have a duty to consult local councils on "proposed major changes to service development" - hospital closures, ward closures, and so on. County and unitary councils (which have responsibility for social services) will "lead" on the scrutiny committees, although ministers have promised that district councils will be "involved". Guidance will be issued to ensure that scrutiny is properly coordinated where a health authority covers two or more councils. Scrutiny committees will have representatives from all parties. Where the committee decides that health authority proposals are "not in the interests of local people" it can refer them for a ruling to a new independent national reconfiguration panel (made up of clinicians, patients representatives and NHS managers).

Patients' forums Each NHS trust and primary care trust will have a patients' forum with powers to "monitor, review and inspect all aspects of local health services from the patient's perspective", including hospitals, nursing homes, private hospitals, and GP and community services. The forums will be statutory bodies made up of both individual patients and representatives from patient groups (for example, the Multiple Sclerosis Society) and voluntary organisations (for example, Age Concern). All members will be appointed by an independent NHS appointments commission. Each forum will have the power to appoint a non-executive director to the board of the organisation it monitors. According to health secretary Alan Milburn, patients' forums will be "wholly independent". He said: "Patients' forums will not be managed by the trust, they will not be funded by the trust and they will not be answerable to the trust NHS trusts will have to answer to the patient forums."

Patient advocacy and liaison services (PALS) These services - described by Mr Milburn as "an entirely new tier of service in the NHS" - will be run by patients' forums. PALS will have "the knowledge and clout to sort out problems" for patients (such as filthy wards, discharge arrangements, or mix-ups over waiting lists) before they "escalate into serious complaints". PALS will have the power to take concerns directly to trust chief executives, and the "power to negotiate immediate solutions". Although PALS will be a part of the trust, the patients' forum will be able to recommend that advocacy services are run independently from the trust.

Patient councils Labour backbencher David Hinchliffe persuaded the government to accept amendments to the health and social care bill which would enable the creation of what he calls patient councils. These would act as umbrella bodies to co-ordinate individual patient forums (see above) in order to provide, in Mr Hinchliffe's words, "a comprehensive overview of the work of the (NHS) trusts." Patient councils would also host independent patient advocacy services (see above) where patient forums decide that they should not be run by local NHS trusts. Patient councils will also have the right to scrutinise primary care - a right not held by CHCs.

A new complaints system Unlike the current procedure, where complaints are handled by the body being complained about, there will be "when necessary" an independent advocacy service in each area to support complainants, possibly provided by local authorities. The complaints system is under review, but ministers are keen to make it more responsive to patients and "less adversarial" with the aim of reducing the number of negligence complaints against the NHS.

Feasibility work is being carried out by three patient and consumer groups: the Long term medical conditions alliance; the patients' forum (no relation to the proposed new NHS patients' forums); and the College of Health. Funding is expected to be supplied by the Department of Health.

County and unitary councils (which have responsibility for social services) will "lead" on the scrutiny committees, although ministers have promised that district councils will be "involved". Guidance will be issued to ensure that scrutiny is properly coordinated where a health authority covers two or more councils. Scrutiny committees will have representatives from all parties. fields.headline: BSkyB chief challenges ITV to join Sky
fields.trailText:
2pm: BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball has told ITV it can sign up to the Sky Digital network 'whenever it wants', reports Dan Milmo.
Feb 7: Murdoch on verge of Sky global float
fields.body:
BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball has told ITV that it can broadcast on Sky Digital "whenever it wants".

Mr Ball's challenge is the latest twist in an ongoing battle between the two broadcast giants, with sources at BSkyB recently hinting that the company had gone cold on taking the terrestrial network.

It puts paid to speculation that it suited BSkyB not to have ITV on board because the damage to the terrestrial broadcaster's ratings would continue.

However, Mr Ball said at the presentation of BSkyB's first-half results that nothing is stopping ITV from signing up, which it has so far refused to do.

ITV is said to be experiencing a change of mind because of slippage in its TV audience share, although it has not made any official approaches about using the BSkyB platform.

"We are an open platform and there is nothing to stop ITV from launching whenever it wants. This anticipation that ITV will go on Sky Digital is a good story to tell when ITV advertising revenues are slowing," said Mr Ball.

ITV and ITV2 are on Granada and Carlton Communications' ONdigital platform, but their non-appearance on the Sky network has angered Rupert Murdoch's company in the past.

Sky Digital will have to take ITV when analogue services are switched off around 2006, but Mr Ball is trying to call ITV's bluff on when it will team up with BSkyB.

"We did not have a deal with [Channel 4's] E4 until the Sunday or Thursday before it launched, so signing up with us is hardly rocket science," said Mr Ball.
