webTitle: Sharon has a mountain to climb

fields.headline: Sharon has a mountain to climb
fields.standfirst: Even with his trademark bulldozing style, Ariel Sharon will find it difficult to make a dent in a monumentally complicated political situation, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: Even with his trademark bulldozing style, Ariel Sharon will find it difficult to make a dent in a monumentally complicated political situation, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Whatever else Ehud Barak failed to achieve during his beleaguered 21-month stint as Israeli prime minister, he has, through his departure, succeeded in handing Ariel Sharon a poisoned chalice. One can scarcely imagine a more suitable person to drink it.

Having won a landslide victory in what, for many voters, was a stay-away election, Mr Sharon now faces all the problems that dogged Mr Barak - and more.

He now has to form a government without a majority (his party, the Likud, holds only 19 seats in the 120-seat Knesset) and, as usual in Israel's unmanageable parliamentary system, that will require alliances with odd bedfellows.

Any hopes that Mr Sharon held of forming a government of national unity - with Mr Barak as defence minister - were dashed last night by Mr Barak's announcement that he is resigning as leader of the Labour party and as a member of parliament.

Mr Sharon's immediate problem will be to win parliamentary approval for the national budget by March 31. If he gets past that hurdle, he may soldier on by avoiding meaningful attempts at legislation until parliament rises for the summer recess early in July, resuming again in October.

Alternatively, Mr Sharon could call an early general election (the next one is not due until November 2003), but there is no certainty that it would resolve the chaos in the Knesset. Mr Sharon's sweeping victory in the prime ministerial election was as much a protest against Mr Barak's failure as anything else and does not necessarily reflect the way votes would divide in a contest among Israel's numerous political parties.

Internally then, Mr Sharon faces all the same difficulties as Mr Barak, and analysts' views of his life expectancy as prime minister range from a few weeks to a couple of years.

But internationally, Mr Sharon, with his links to some of the most unsavoury episodes in Israeli history, will face difficulties that Mr Barak never experienced. There will, inevitably, be calls from some quarters to have him arrested and put on trial - just as the Americans are hoping to do with Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia - though it's unlikely to happen.

Mr Barak's image - at least initially - as a smiling peacemaker led to his lionisation in the west. Democrats in the US and centre-left governments in Europe felt an affinity with the Israeli Labour leader that, in the view of many Palestinians, was totally misplaced.

This, according to the PLO, had become one of the major bugbears of the peace process over the last couple of years: they were constantly urged to make concessions and help the nice Mr Barak, on that grounds that if they did not, someone a lot nastier would come along and take his place.

That, up to a point, is what has now happened. The Palestinians didn't concede (or surrender, as they see it) and now Mr Nasty is in charge. But the reality is a little more complex. Over the last four months, since the start of the intifada, Mr Barak has been trying very hard to look like Mr Sharon, while Mr Sharon, in turn, spent the election campaign trying to look like Mr Barak. It is even possible that Sharon he will grit his teeth and continue the Barak impersonations a little longer.

This has led many Arabs (not just Palestinians) to argue - despite their qualms about Mr Sharon's background - that having him as Israel's leader will not necessarily make things worse.

Some even suggest it will be beneficial, forcing western governments to be less sympathetic and more demanding towards Israel. Afif Safieh, the Palestinian representative in London, is one of them. "Sharon in power will damage Israel's relations with the United States and Europe, and embarrass Jewish communities in the diaspora," he said yesterday.

Regardless of what differentiates Messrs Barak and Sharon as leaders, there is, on the more fundamental issue of the peace process, a real choice that Israelis will one day have to make: is it to be peace through security or security through peace?

Both options recognise that peace and Israel's security are inextricably linked, but there the similarities end. Security through peace means making a comprehensive deal with the Palestinians - granting them a viable state, making concessions over Jerusalem, and so on - in order to achieve longterm security of a kind that could be maintained at low cost, without keeping Israel on a war footing.

That goal can only be reached by offering terms which the Palestinians can be persuaded to accept as reasonable, not by browbeating them into submission. The difficulty with this is that it requires more concessions (though perhaps not many more) than Israeli leaders have yet been prepared to make.

Mr Barak did, at times, lean towards the security-through-peace approach - though he never quite managed to get there. The obstacle, on the Israeli side, is that the last few steps - in some cases on cherished issues of principle - seem too unpalatable for the fragmented political system to bear.

Mr Sharon, on the other hand, epitomises the peace-through-security view. What this means in practice is not so much peace as pacification: take it slowly, make interim agreements which give away as little as possible and maximise Israeli control over Palestinian affairs.

Over time, so the theory goes, the Palestinians will become exhausted and settle for next to nothing. It might work, but the history of liberation struggles elsewhere suggests it will not. All it is likely to do is build up resentment among future generations of Arabs, making Israel's security more difficult and costly, in lives and equipment, to maintain.

Of course, Mr Sharon may not get his way. An optimistic view suggests that the kind of constraints that hampered Mr Barak will also temper the more extreme elements of Sharonism.

There is, too, a feeling among some analysts that Ariel Sharon's election victory could prove to be the last gasp of an old warhorse - and everything he represents - before the Israeli public decide that enough is enough and bring their political system to its senses.

webTitle: Home Office faces huge bill for ignoring rules by jailing refugees

fields.headline: Home Office faces huge bill for ignoring rules by jailing refugees
fields.trailText: The Home Office faces a compensation bill which could reach millions of pounds for wrongly jailing asylum seekers for travelling on false passports.
fields.body:
The Home Office faces a compensation bill which could reach millions of pounds for wrongly jailing asylum seekers for travelling on false passports.

Thousands were imprisoned between 1994 and 1999, when the high court ruled that jailing asylum seekers for travelling on false documents breached the 1951 Geneva convention on the the status of refugees.

The Home Office would only confirm that it had received a number of applications, but it will have to compensate those who apply under its ex-gratia scheme which pays out in cases of serious default, or where an accused person is completely exonerated.

Solicitors expect payment of at least £10,000 for the typical case in which the courts imposed a six-month sentence. Some were sentenced to nine months, and a few to a year.

Between 500 and 1,000 are thought to have been prosecuted each year between 1994, when prosecutions were stepped up, and the high court judgment in 1999. Most were attempting to pass through the UK on forged passports en route to the US or Canada.

The judgment came in a test case brought by three asylum seekers, two of whom had served six months. The third was being threatened with prosecution for using false papers, even though the home secretary had since granted him indefinite leave to stay.

The two judges delivered a strong rebuke to the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the crown prosecution service for ignoring Britain's obligations under the convention.

Lord Justice Simon Brown said no one in the criminal justice system, including the CPS and defence solicitors, had given "the least thought" to article 31 of the convention, which states that asylum seekers should not be penalised for entering a country illegally.

He said the combination of visa requirements and carrier's liability, which imposes heavy penalties for conveying passengers without documentation, "has made it well nigh impossible for refugees to travel to countries of refuge without false documents".

Most of those who were convicted had been arrested on arrival and brought before magistrates the next day. Typically, they had pleaded guilty after duty solicitors told them they had no defence and would get a shorter sentence for a guilty plea.

Patrick Allen, senior partner of north London solicitors Hodge Jones & Allen, represents a couple from Kosovo who have had their compensation claims accepted by the Home Office. He said: "Many asylum seekers and refugees have been wrongly prosecuted and imprisoned for travelling with false documents. They will be entitled to compensation and the bill for the Home Office could be enormous."

The Kosovan couple arrived at Heathrow en route for Canada in February 1999 using false Greek passports. They were both convicted the following day and sentenced to six months in prison. The pair are now applying for asylum in Britain.

webTitle: Former Thatcher adviser to chair Wafic Said company

fields.headline: Former Thatcher adviser to chair Wafic Said company
fields.trailText: Margaret Thatcher's veteran foreign policy adviser, Charles Powell, has become chairman of the asset management company whose major shareholder is Wafic Said, the wealthy middleman at the heart of a string of controversial Middle East arms deals.
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher's veteran foreign policy adviser, Charles Powell, has become chairman of the asset management company whose major shareholder is Wafic Said, the wealthy middleman at the heart of a string of controversial Middle East arms deals.

The Syrian-born entrepreneur helped to broker the multi-billion pound Al Yamamah arms deals between Britain and Saudi Arabia. He was also present in the Ritz hotel in Paris during the weekend in September 1993 which eventually led to the fall of his friend, Jonathan Aitken, a fellow guest, then Tory minister for arms procurement.

At 59, Lord Powell of Bayswater - as the former Sir Charles became last year - is the older brother of Jonathan Powell, who now occupies a similar eminence in Downing Street as Tony Blair's chief of staff. Lord Powell's wife, Lady Carla - which is also the name of a racehorse owned by Mr Said - is a social friend of Peter Mandelson.

Since last month Lord Powell has given up his office at the Far East trading group, Jardine Matheson Holdings in the City, to concentrate more on developing business in Europe and North America, he told the Guardian last night as he returned from a fact-finding mission to Brussels by a House of Lords committee.

After making up to 15 trips a year to the Far East on Jardine's behalf, he explained: "It tires you out." But he is remaining on two Jardine boards and retaining a string of other prestigious directorships as well as chairing Sagitta asset management in Berkeley Square, London. Its major shareholder is Mr Said.

Sagitta has become a high-profile sponsor of British horse racing. Though its last report to Companies House in Cardiff in 1999 showed a loss of £998, the Sagitta group is said to manage assets worth over $1bn and is Mr Said's principal investment vehicle.

Lord Powell, a foreign office civil servant who became one of Mrs Thatcher's most trusted advisers after being seconded to Number 10 from 1983 to 1991, was in Downing Street during the years when Britain negotiated the Al Yamamah deals. They kept UK arms makers in business while yielding enormous commissions to middlemen on both sides, including Mr Said.

Mr Aitken, subsequently jailed for perjury during his unsuccessful libel suit against the Guardian and Granada TV, was closely tied to Saudi business interests as a backbencher.

His then partner, Said Ayas, the man who paid the minister's Ritz hotel bill, later alleged that the minister continued to lobby for arms deals from which they both stood to benefit.

After leaving John Major's transition team in 1991, Lord Powell joined the board of Said Holdings as early as 1994 and is on the board of the Said Business School at Oxford University.

The school is still under construction and itself the subject of controversy. Mr Said donated £20mand its location was shifted from a central playing field to a car park by Oxford railway station.

As well as the vice-chancellor of Oxford and three senior academic colleagues, the trustees of the business school include five appointed by Mr Said, subject only to the vice-chancellor's approval. They are Lord Alexander of Weedon (chairman of the NatWest Group of companies), Robert Genillard (a Swiss financier and industrialist), Professor William Pounds (formerly Dean of the Sloan School of Management, MIT) Ms Catherine Roe (Director of the Karim Rida Said Foundation which commemorates Mr Said's late son) and Lord Powell.

They are Lord Alexander of Weedon (chairman of the NatWest Group of companies), Robert Genillard (a Swiss financier and industrialist), Professor William Pounds (formerly Dean of the Sloan School of Management, MIT) Ms Catherine Roe (Director of the Karim Rida Said Foundation which commemorates Mr Said's late son) and Lord Powell.

webTitle: EU looks at Straw's idea to curb migrants

fields.headline: EU looks at Straw's idea to curb migrants
fields.trailText: The home secretary's initiative to stem the flow of illegal migrants into Europe by creating a common asylum system has taken off as a serious project in the European Union.
fields.body:
The home secretary's initiative to stem the flow of illegal migrants into Europe by creating a common asylum system has taken off as a serious project in the European Union.

Strong interest has been expressed in Jack Straw's scheme by Germany, France and Italy as well as support from the Canadian and Australian governments. The European commission has already started a feasibility study into the scheme, which is designed to undermine the growing illegal trade in "people trafficking".

But Mr Straw's initiative for an overhaul of the way Europe deals with asylum seekers, which he launched in Lisbon last year, was met with warnings from refugee groups and lawyers in London yesterday that he was in danger of undermining the individual right to claim asylum enshrined in the 1951 UN convention on refugees.

The new UN high commissioner for refugees, the former Dutch prime minister, Ruud Lubbers, said last night that the EU was in danger of undermining a vital principle. "We should not erode the convention," he warned. "I don't think we should start to water down our international obligations. We have to share the burden in a fair way, but Europe is a very prosperous continent. There is a substantial capacity to receive higher numbers of asylum seekers. But there is a lack of generosity, a lack of funds."

However, Mr Straw insisted that the principles of the 50-year-old convention would remain intact. He justified his radical scheme, which would see the claims of tens of thousands of asylum seekers processed outside of Europe, saying the world had to recognise that the asylum system had drifted out of control of governments and into the hands of criminal people traffickers.

In a speech to the Institute of Public Policy Research, Mr Straw gave details of how Europe could stem the flow of illegal entrants who abuse the asylum system. One option was for the EU to set up a resettlement programme under which an agreed number of refugees would be identified in their own regions and brought to the EU for resettlement, with each country taking an agreed quota.

He said the criteria for selection of refugees would "draw on the experiences of countries such as the US, Canada and Australia".

At the same time new measures would be taken to deter illegal migrants using the international asylum system to enter Europe. "A list of safe countries or groups would be introduced, from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process," said Mr Straw.

He foresaw three separate lists. The first would be a list of "safe countries", such as the US and EU countries, from which asylum applications would not be entertained.

In the second list of countries, such as China, it would be presumed that an asylum application was unfounded and so would have to be made from outside the EU. This list would be drawn up with the advice of the UNHCR. Applicants from a country such as China might have to make their applications in a transit country.

Asylum seekers in this group would also lose the right to claim asylum in an EU country and so could be turned straight back.

The third list would be made up of countries which were internationally recognised to be oppressive regimes and from which asylum applications would be accepted within individual EU countries.

Mr Straw said this overhaul was needed to reduce the attractions of "asylum shopping" by illegal migrants around Europe.

But the Liberal Democrats' Simon Hughes warned that Mr Straw was endangering Britain's "fundamental obligation" to offer asylum to those fleeing persecution, while the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said his plan was a smokescreen to avoid taking real action now to deal with the chaos in the asylum system.

webTitle: 'Accrington boy' to join Wills at PCC party

fields.headline: 'Accrington boy' to join Wills at PCC party
fields.trailText: 1pm: At least one 'ordinary' person will be at the star-studded Press Complaints Commission party tonight.
fields.body:
At least one "ordinary" person will be at the star-studded Press Complaints Commission party tonight.

Mingling with the stars will be one, slightly less famous person whom William will be particularly keen to meet.

"Accrington Boy" is the young man who in 1995 inadvertently boosted the teenage prince's chances of privacy during his school days.

Christopher Livesey was 15 when his mother made a complaint against her local newspaper in Accrington, Lancashire.

Mr Livesey had been questioned by a journalist in breach of the PCC's code of conduct, which says children must be 16 or over to be interviewed.

Mr Livesey was linked to Prince William by the PCC's chairman Lord Wakeham.

In a speech to newspaper editors, Lord Wakeham said: "What goes for a child in Accrington goes for a child in Eton."

William and his younger brother Harry were largely left alone at school by the media.

Mr Livesey is now a 21-year-old graphics student at Leeds Metropolitan University.

He said today he was "thrilled" at being invited to the party, which is to celebrate the success of self-regulation in the industry.

He said: "It was my mum who made the complaint but when Lord Wakeham made that speech it was unreal.

"I was watching TV and I found myself suddenly known as 'Accrington Boy'.

"I am proud my case was used to protect the prince while at Eton. I'm really looking forward to meeting him."

Many of the celebrities and politicians at the party are ones who have made complaints through the PCC.

Many of the other guests are Fleet Street editors against whom their grievances were upheld.

The Prime Minister, himself a successful complainant, today sent his "best wishes" to the PCC but added that it had "proved impossible" for him to attend the party.

In a letter to Lord Wakeham, he said: "It must be right that you have found time to celebrate this milestone.

"I know how hard the PCC, under your chairmanship and that of your predecessor, have worked at trying to strike the right balance between the sometimes competing but important demands of the freedom of the press and the need to treat fairly those who find themselves in the news."

Mr Blair added: "I believe it is a measure of the PCC's growing success over the last decade that there is increasing confidence and support for your efforts from both the press and the public."

Lord Wakeham said today he hoped Prince William's privacy would be respected during his university years.

"When he went to Eton I asked that he should be left alone and, by and large, the press respected that.

"I anticipate they will do the same when he is at university," he said.

"I jolly well hope so, because it simply is not reasonable for a young man to go to university and not have a chance to pursue his university career.

"He will make himself available from time to time and I think the press appreciate that.

"But the deal is they must leave him alone the rest of the time," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

"If the editors refuse to deal and publish photographs taken by the paparazzi, the paparazzi will find exactly the same as they found at Eton - there was no market for it, and therefore they disappeared.

"As long as the editors stick to the code, then we will be all right.

"I think the editors have every intention of sticking to the code."

On another issue - the naming and shaming of paedophiles - Lord Wakeham said the PCC was talking to editors and probation officers to see whether guidelines should be issued.

"This consultation is ongoing and it is getting towards the end.

"I hope we will be able to say something in the fairly near future."

fields.headline: The Knowledge
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: ELEPHANTS ON BALLS
fields.body:
ELEPHANTS ON BALLS

Could anybody tell me the history of the Coventry City crest (ie: an elephant on top of a football wearing red-cross insignia and two burning birds)?" asks Neil Butler. "A phoenix from the flames possibly? That would explain Coventry's history of escapology, I suppose."

It's not an easy one, this. According to Big Fat Gordon's Sky Blue Army Home Page (to visit him click here), in medieval times, the city was granted the elephant as its emblem to ward off scary dragons.

So although Coventry fan Steve Kelly thinks the elephant has something to do with "Paul Williams when he's on the ball", we're going with Big Fat Gordon's explanation for this one.

BFG then explains how the phoenix is "fairly obviously a reference to the bombing of the city during World War II and its subsequent rebuilding", and that "the castle on the tusker's back either reflects the walled nature of the city or the howdah (or shed) that used to contain Imperial types and their Mem Sahibs."

However, that's where the information dries up. The creature opposite the phoenix is "the phoenix's mate who's just come along, if that's alright". And "as for the symbol in the centre of the crest, well that's anyone's guess."

HE LIKES HIS WORLD CUPS

"Joe Jordan scored for Scotland in three consecutive World Cup tournaments," writes Alan Sheridan. "Is this a record for a British player or any player?"

It is indeed a record, for no English, Welsh, Northern Irish or Irish player has matched this feat. Come to think of it, neither has any other Scotsman.

Jordan scored against Zaire in 1974 (much good it did Scotland), Peru in 1978 (much good it did Scotland), and the USSR in 1982 (much good it did Scotland).

Only two men have bettered Big Joe's achievement. Pelé (yawn) scored in the 1958, 1962, 1966 and 1970 tournaments, and Germany's Uwe Seeler did exactly the same thing.

TON-UP INTERNATIONALS

"Please could you settle a discussion I have been having with some friends in my local," asks Marc Pastor. "Could you list all the players that have attained 100 caps or more for England. One of my friends reckons Billy Wright didn't achieve this feat but I say he did."

You're right, Marc. William Ambrose Wright CBE played a total of 104 times for England between 1947 and 1959. And in case you're questioning that total - most authors claim that Wright played for England 105 times - Fifa decided not to recognise England's 4-4 draw with a Fifa select XI on October 21 1953, which meant Wright effectively lost one cap.

The Wolverhampton Wanderers defender made his England debut, aged 22, in the 7-2 thrashing of Northern Ireland on September 28 1946. He went on to captain his country a world-record 90 times (an honour he shares with Bobby Moore), leading his country to three World Cups (1950, 1954 and 1958) and becoming the first-ever footballer to win 100 caps. His 104th and final international was the 8-1 mauling of the United States in 1959.

After he retired, Wright became manager of Arsenal (1962-66) before moving into broadcasting. He died in 1994.

Wright is one of just four England players to reach the 100-cap milestone. The others are Peter Shilton (125 caps between 1970 and 1990), Bobby Moore (107 between 1962 and 1973) and Bobby Charlton (105 between 1958 and 1970). The only other British or Irish players to reach this landmark are Pat Jennings (119 Northern Ireland caps between 1964 and 1986) and Kenny Dalglish, who won 102 caps for Scotland between 1971 and 1986.

NOT-SO-BORING DRAWS

"What was the highest ever drawn game in terms of goals scored?" asked Gary Ross.

Simon Kaplan claims that "the second game I ever attended ended Chelsea 5 West Ham 5. It was during the 66-67 or the 67-68 season." And he's right - the two teams battled this one out on December 17 1966. Meanwhile, Andrew Scott cites a match played on August 20 1991 in the League Cup which ended Barnet 5 Brentford 5.

We can chip in with one ourselves. On September 22 1984, QPR played host to Newcastle in the old First Division. And what gracious hosts they were, because by half-time, Newcastle were 4-0 up thanks to an inspired display by Chris Waddle.

During the break, Rs manager Alan Mullery had a "quiet word" and soon enough the deficit had been reduced to 4-3. But when the Geordies made it 5-3 with six minutes to go, the points seemed wrapped up. Of course, Newcastle being Newcastle, the lead was frittered away in the dying minutes. 5-5.

Any advances?

CAN YOU HELP?

"I think that Southampton have possibly gone longer than any other Premiership club without any player scoring a league hat-trick. Is this true?" asks Charlotte Freemantle.

"After watching the recent Sunderland versus Manchester United game at the Stadium of Light where Sunderland used three different captains (one sent off and the second injured), I was wondering if this was a record or does it happen often? asks Gavin Munro.

"Can you tell me who scored the last First Division goal of the 1991-92 season?" asks Sue Neil.

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

webTitle: World offers Sharon a wary welcome

fields.headline: World offers Sharon a wary welcome
fields.trailText: World leaders today reacted with a mixture of caution and outrage to the election of hawkish Israeli rightwinger Ariel Sharon as prime minister.
fields.body:
World leaders today reacted with a mixture of caution and outrage to the election of hawkish Israeli rightwinger Ariel Sharon as prime minister.

The warmest welcome came from the US president, George Bush , who immediately offered congratulations and a commitment to keeping US-Israeli relations "rock solid".

"The president told prime minister-elect Sharon he looked forward to working with him, especially with regard to advancing peace and stability in the region," said the statement, released by White House spokesman Ari Fleischer.

Speaking at a victory rally in Jerusalem yesterday, Mr Sharon said Mr Bush had "told me about the close cooperation they wanted to have with the government I will be heading".

"We shall act to deepen our special relations with our great friend and ally, the United States," Mr Sharon said. "And we shall strengthen the ties between Israel and the nations of the world."

Addressing his tearful supporters, the ousted prime minister, Ehud Barak said that he may have been "ahead of his time" in pushing Israelis and Palestinians toward a final peace accord before they were ready. "Perhaps the public is not ready to accept the painful truth we have revealed to it," he said. "On the other side, the Palestinian side is not yet sufficiently mature to take decisions and confront their painful reality. Violence has become the refuge for desperate people."

The Palestinian leader , Yasser Arafat , was non-committal in his response to Mr Sharon's victory. "We respect the Israeli people's choice and we hope the peace process will continue," Nabil Abourdeneh, a top aide to Mr Arafat, quoted him as saying.

However, Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat warned that Sharon's hardline views were a "recipe for war", and the Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, called Sharon's election "the most foolish event in Israel's history".

Syrian media echoed the feelings of many in the Arab world by immediately condemning both the Israeli electorate and Mr Sharon.

"The victory of the bloody terrorist and war criminal Sharon as head of the Israeli government is a clear message by the Zionist entity to Arabs amounting to an official declaration of war," al-Baath, organ of the ruling Baath Party, said. "By choosing Sharon the Israelis chose escalation, terrorism and aggression. They cut their final links with the peace process and drove the region into a new cycle of violence."

The Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, said of the election: "We will wait and see what Sharon will do. Will it be a policy of peace or one of suppression?"

European leaders worded their statements carefully, not wanting to upset the Israelis, the Palestinians or the Arab world at large on a day when tensions are high over the election result.

The British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said continued pursuit of a peace agreement was in the best interests of the Israeli people and the international community.

"The Israeli people have made their choice and we will of course work with the person they have chosen as prime minister. And I hope that he will be willing to work with us and the international community to take forward the peace process," he said.

Within Israel, Labour party faithful assessed the damage done to the party by Mr Barak's defeat.

"There's no doubt we suffered a terrible knockout yesterday," said Labour's parliamentary speaker Avraham Burg, who was the first to announce his candidacy to succeed Mr Barak as party leader.

"Without doubt, from the moment Ehud Barak resigned from the leadership of the Labour Party, the contest began and I will be one of the candidates," he said.

fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
12.30pm:Express news editor Nichola Briggs is expected to be confirmed as deputy editor, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Nichola Briggs is expected to be confirmed as the new deputy editor of the Daily Express today.

The move follows the appointment of Chris Williams to replace editor Rosie Boycott.

Ms Briggs, currently associate editor, news, is believed to be in the final stages of negotiations regarding her promotion.

Her appointment scotches rumours that the Express was seeking an external candidate.

An Express source said Ms Briggs was well respected at the newspaper.

"Although she's only in her mid 30s, she's a newsroom veteran," said the insider.

fields.headline: Rifles and the Republican party
fields.standfirst: Which Hollywood actor, National Rifle Association president and Bush supporter was once a gun control and civil rights activist? asks Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: Which Hollywood actor, National Rifle Association president and Bush supporter was once a gun control and civil rights activist? asks Duncan Campbell
fields.body:
At the front of Only the Wicked, the latest LA-noir novel from writer Gary Phillips, there is a bleak, quoted paragraph: "Mainstream America is counting on you to 'draw your sword' and fight for them.

"These people have precious little time and resources to battle misguided Cinderella attitudes: the fringe propaganda of the homosexual coalition; the feminists who preach that it is a divine duty for women to hate men; blacks who raise a militant fist with one hand while they seek preference with the other; New Age apologists for juvenile crime who see roving gangs as a means to only the merchandising of violence as a form of entertainment for impressionable minds; and the gun bans as a means to only the Lord-knows-what.

"We have reached that point when our social policy originates on Oprah. It's time to pull the plug."

So who was the speaker Phillips was quoting in a speech made to an organisation called the Free Congress Foundation?

Well, he was once an active union leader and supporter of the liberal Democrat Adlai Stevenson and took part in attempts to desegregate lunch counters during the civil rights movement.

He was also, more famously, Moses and is now being given credit as someone who may have played a key part in the election of George Bush.

And while Bill Clinton was unable to get the rules changed so that he could run for president for a third time, the speaker has just been the beneficiary of a rule change that allows him to run as the head of his organisation for an unprecedented third term.

It is, of course, Charlton Heston.

What has emerged since the election is that the 77-year-old actor and president of the National Rifle Association is now the most powerful show business figure in the Republican camp.

While the Democrats always had a superfluity of support from actors and directors, writers and musicians, the Republicans have had to scrabble a bit to produce the kind of big names that add numbers to doors at rallies.

But with Heston they have found someone who was able to draw in the faithful as never before.

In a profile in the latest Los Angeles magazine, Ed Leibowitz uncovers some of the statements that Heston made while on the stump for Bush.

In Grand Rapids, Michigan two weeks before the election, he told his audience that Gore, who had backed very mild gun reforms, had reneged on his commitments and said: "In any other time or place, you'd be looking for a lynching mob."

Some of the crowd shouted back: "Let's do it. I've got a rope."

Yet 40 years ago, Heston even favoured forms of gun control and campaigned on issues with such long-standing Hollywood liberals as Paul Newman. So what happened?

He told Leibowitz that in 1964 he was being driven to the set of the War Lord when he noticed a billboard supporting Barry Goldwater, that year's right-wing Republican candidate against Lyndon Johnson, who later won.

The words beside the picture of Goldwater read: "In your heart you know he's right." Said Heston: "That was my St Paul on the road to Damascus."

During the campaign last year the NRA boasted that if Bush won they would have their own office inside the White House.

This week, the latest beneficiaries of the NRA's policy of keeping access to guns as easy as possible were the four people killed by Willie Dan Baker at a factory in Melrose Park, Illinois.

Baker, who was sacked by the firm five years earlier, killed himself after the attack.

The event will have been forgotten by the day after tomorrow by all but those few people personally affected by it. Time to pull the plug, perhaps.

fields.headline: DTI clears Express takeover
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: The DTI will not refer the Express takeover to the Office of Fair Trading, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, secretary of state for trade and industry, will not refer the takeover of Express Newspapers to the director-general of fair trading, the DTI confirmed today.

The announcement clears the takeover of the paper by Northern & Shell, which in November agreed to pay £125m for the Daily Express and Daily Star.

The move is likely to infuriate several MPs, 10 of whom signed an early day motion at the end of last year expressing "grave concerns that the national newspapers within the Daily Express group should have fallen under the ownership of a publisher of pornography".

Northern & Shell boss Richard Desmond has since announced his intention to shed his pornographic interests.

Since the takeover, the Express titles have been through a period of turbulence, with a number of job losses and the departure of senior editorial staff, including editor Rosie Boycott.

fields.headline: Enoch Powell
fields.standfirst: An enigma of awkward passions
fields.trailText: An enigma of awkward passions.
fields.body:
The word most people settled for in trying to describe Enoch Powell , who has died aged 85, was - leaving out the ruder ones - enigmatic. Scholar, soldier, statesman, arch-rebel, philosopher, poet, all crowded so glitteringly into so few early years. Here surely was something to wonder at, this neo-Renaissance figure with a Black Country accent. At the end of the story, the enigma had still not been solved. For we also had a monument of self-contradiction - a man of the hard right who could be a sensitive social reformer, a deeply committed Tory who could urge his colleagues to conspire with the enemy, a master of words who could use them with what many saw as gross irresponsibility, a devout loyalist who could lecture his queen, an atheist and a High Anglican.

At one time and another he was all these. Powell had little time for anything in between, the reasonable man's halfway house where most tolerable life is carried on. Listening to a Powell speech could be a fascinating, benumbing experience he would use headlines to dazzle, plain words to bemuse. The language, perhaps the human mind itself, was never made to bear such logic.

He carried lucidity to the point of obfuscation, even beyond it to somewhere near dementia. His written prose, including many sensible reviews were more normal but his verse, which shows some influence of A E Housman who taught him at Cambridge, clearly indicates the romantic urge driving him.

Powell and Michael Foot, for years the two best speakers in the Commons, were poles apart politically but alike in their power to exert a mesmeric effect over even a hard-boiled Commons audience. They had a mutual regard, and often joined forces in tactical skirmishing against what they both saw as the common enemy, the Common Market.

He was indeed a hard man to understand, and harder still to fit into current political categories. The contradiction clamoured: the imperialist who wanted to withdraw from the far east, the apparently cold man who once burst into passionate tears in the Commons, the confirmed anti-planner who took on the essentially planning job of minister of health in 1960. Nevertheless he regarded himself - and persuaded some admirers to regard him - as a model of logical consistency.

Rational and romantic were at war in him, and it was not always the romantic that won. Nor was there anything obviously romantic, though there might have been to the eye of a Balzac or an Arnold Bennett, about the appearance and manner of this tense, unsmiling man. He looked more like a member of some obscure town council than one of the most controversial politicians of his day.

Provincialism was of his essence and English Midland provincialism at that, than which there is none more introverted. But a Welsh ancestry fired his omplex nature. His parents were teachers, and he seemed born to exert diligence and acquire merit. He shone at King Edward's School in his native Birmingham and was a highly successful prize-winning student at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he became a fellow in the mid-1930s.

By the time he was 25, he was Professor of Greek at Sydney University, and a second world war brigadier not so long after. Characteristically he had rushed home from Australia to enlist as a private in the Royal Warwickshire Regiment, and promotion came quickly - as it did in all he put his hand and mind to, except his chosen career of politics.

He could have been distinguished in academic life his work on Herodotus suggests that he could have made his mark as a classical scholar but his excursions into English verse, collected, in 1990, from several slim volumes, hardly suggest that we lost a poet when we gained a politician. The echoes of Housman - another classicist, controversialist and poet - were too audible.

Powell worked for the Conservative Research Department, collaborating with Angus Maude on the pamphlet One Nation, and entered parliament on the big Tory wave of 1950. Powell's Birmingham voice and Wolverhampton constituency soon provided a new English centre of gravity there. A third dominant characteristic, probably linked with his provincialism and his romanticism, made itself felt. This was the urge to make a gesture, to stand conspicuously apart, to pit himself against established orthodoxies in his own party. He started in a small way, brushing with his local Conservative Association. It was as though he was rehearsing for major rebellions.

The first came in 1958, when as financial secretary to the Treasury, he resigned with Peter (later Lord) Thorneycroft, the chancellor of the exchequer, and Nigel Birch, the economic secretary, in protest against the government's refusal to hold back public expenditure to a level acceptable to them - the episode which Harold Macmillan christened 'a little local difficulty'. The second was when he stood out against the king-making convulsions in the Conservative party which led to Sir Alec Douglas Home's succession.

The third, and by far the most sensational, gesture compelled Heath to sack him from the shadow cabinet in April 1968, because of the 'rivers of blood' speech he made in Birmingham about immigration. It was made without consulting any of his colleagues, who criticised it more for the intemperance of its language than for its basic message. Those who had been patiently working for better race relations bitterly criticised that too.

Whether Powell was truly a racialist is a matter of semantics. (Ironically, his bravest and most passionate speech at Westminster had demanded the exposure of British maltreatment of Mau Mau suspects in Kenya, a decade earlier.) Whether or not he calculated the result of the Birmingham speech in advance - there were few who believed he did not - they were easily calculable and the outcome was ugly. He raised fears and hatreds to a state of tension overnight. A pro-Powell campaign reached a pitch of near-hysteria and there were some unpleasant incidents.

On the best interpretation Powell, a man of strong imperialist sympathies, was ungenerous in treating the post-imperial human legacy with such cynical or at least selfish disregard. Many held that he was also cashing in on genuinely-felt social fears. Nor was logic on his side. In his temperamental war with emotion, reason lost. This episode also brought out his most alarming and sometimes absurd characteristic, the Cassandra complex coupled with a penchant for Delphic utterance. References to 'the Tiber foaming with much blood' needed a sense of classical distancing easily missed in Wolverhampton's back streets .

Powell was not the first or the last politician to be caught between the concept and the act, the purity of the idea and the twist and turns of real life, but in his case the gift for abstraction was so advanced that the gap yawned wider than for most. This created in him a sense of danger, a tension that communicated which was more than his argument always did. As a speaker in the Commons he often seemed to deploy a fiercely private logic, yet his carefully articulated, pedantic performances could make irrelevance sound prophetic. Few could always remember what he said, but they were always impressed by the intensity with which he said it.

One of his early posts on achieving junior office was at Housing (1955-57). Then came the Treasury post from which he resigned over government spending. Yet it was as head of a major spending department, Health, that he reached the cabinet.

The next phase of his career was marked by some searing attacks on political hypocrisy. Though ostensibly over his bitter opposition to the European Community and our part in it, the abandonment, in 1974, of his Wolverhampton seat and the Conservative party (over Europe) looked like self-punishment, almost a kind of self-mutilation for a man with his advanced sense of loyalty.

He was afraid that the credibility gap between parliament and people was growing all the time, as was the need 'to match the person to the institution.' His personal attempt to do this, as he explained with a flash of the charm he could deploy when he chose, was to change 'the ugly accent compounded of Birmingham, Staffordshire and Australia' for the 'beautiful lilting language of Ulster.' But it was a deeper change he really sought it was the best, indeed the only, chance in sight of taking another stand against the demon of ambiguity and double talk.

As Ulster Unionist member for South Down (1983-87) he lived in the world of absolutes, of jet blacks and shining whites. In that sense if in no other, he was at home. Asked in an unguarded moment during an interview how often he went to Ireland he replied coldly that he never went to Ireland but frequently went to Ulster. The continuing atrocities, in particular the Harrods bombing, he blamed on 'double talk and double-dealing on the part of Britain which has kept the IRA and their fellow murderers in business these last dozen years.' It was as MP for South Down that his private member's bill to ban research on human embryos failed to reach the statute books, but not before it had received considerable support.

In December 1985 he resigned his seat in protest against the Anglo-Irish Agreement, and was re-elected at the ensuing by-election - but at the next general election, in 1987, he was out of parliament and it would have taken a brave prime minister to send him to the Lords as a parting present. It never happened.

His last book, The Evolution of the Gospel (1994), was typically challenging, raising questions about how Christ might have died. Powell never grew old gracefully.

He is survived by his wife, Pamela, whom he married in 1952, and two daughters.

Norman Shrapnel

Mike Phillips writes: The first time I met Enoch Powell left me feeling embarrassed, guilty and a little sorry for him. These weren't emotions I would have predicted, given who he was, and the impact he had had on my life, but, this was late in the 1970s, and by then his audience had dwindled and his charisma had begun to fade.

Even so, his name still had enough potency for the prospect of debating with him to carry a substantial emotional charge. The occasion was a BBC programme called The Editors. I am not sure what I was expecting but when we met, before the event, he was punctiliously courteous. He made small talk without being prompted, asking questions like how long it had taken me to get to Wood Lane, and whether the traffic had been bad.

His voice was a surprise, too. I had expected to find it disturbing but, face to face, it was reedy, almost musical. He still sounded stiff, awkward with the cadences of informal chat, but I had no doubt about his sincerity, and resentful as I was, I began to think there was something immensely likeable about him.

On the other hand, he wasn't all charm. As we walked to the make-up cubicle he remarked that since none of the participants appeared to be editors, perhaps the programme should be renamed. I hastened to point out that I was editor of an ethnic paper, but it was too late. He'd taken the high ground.

At the time I was impressed. Over the years I had begun to think of him as a demagogue who'd struck it lucky, but in that moment, the silky fluency of his tone, combined with the sharpness of the glance he gave me was like a snake striking: and suddenly, like a new insight, it hit me that here was a dangerous old man.

Not that I had ever thought of him as anything else. Up until Powell began making his speeches about race the views he was expressing had widespread currency in private but in public they were disreputable, stuck out there in a margin to the right of the Conservatives. Immigrants were accustomed to hearing white people complain, but in general, we had a sense that the Notting Hill riots in 1958 had been a watershed, after which a liberal consensus had emerged among the politicians which would, somehow, protect us if the worst came to the worst.

Powell destroyed our complacency in one night. His speech about seeing the Tiber 'foaming with much blood' was like a key to Pandora's box. I'm not sure how strongly most other immigrants reacted, but we all felt the dramatic change. It was hard to say quite how it had happened, but Powell had become a rallying point for most of the hostility and rage we encountered, a shorthand for hatred and contempt. "I'm with Enoch," they said, or "they should let Enoch sort you lot out," and that was enough.

What was hardest to bear, and most alarming, was the pervasive sense that the politicians, the people who were meant to be in charge, seemed to be afraid of him and what he could do. In those days he cropped up in all sorts of places. Johnny Speight's bigoted Alf Garnett, on TV every week, offered him up in a domesticated package and gave him a renewed currency. He became a myth, a bogyman, in whose name blacks and Asians were to be harassed and assaulted for the next couple of decades.

In hindsight, I think it would be flattering Powell to say that he was entirely responsible for the effect of his speeches, but it's true that by marrying his version of nationalism to racist rage he gave British racism and racist violence in British streets its own peculiar shape for a time, and it bore his name, Powellism. He offered British politicians a model for racialist rhetoric which was to last for a long time - when, a decade later, Mrs Thatcher spoke of British civilisation being "swamped" the Powellite echoes were unmistakable, and successful.

His memory will probably have me looking over my shoulder in the streets of my own city, London, for the rest of my life, and although the thought would probably make him furious, I shall always think of him as part of my history and as part of my identity as a Briton.

John Enoch Powell, politician, born June 16 1912 died February 8 1998

Asked in an unguarded moment during an interview how often he went to Ireland he replied coldly that he never went to Ireland but frequently went to Ulster. The continuing atrocities, in particular the Harrods bombing, he blamed on 'double talk and double-dealing on the part of Britain which has kept the IRA and their fellow murderers in business these last dozen years.' It was as MP for South Down that his private member's bill to ban research on human embryos failed to reach the statute books, but not before it had received considerable support. In December 1985 he resigned his seat in protest against the Anglo-Irish Agreement, and was re-elected at the ensuing by-election - but at the next general election, in 1987, he was out of parliament and it would have taken a brave prime minister to send him to the Lords as a parting present. It never happened. His last book, The Evolution of the Gospel (1994), was typically challenging, raising questions about how Christ might have died. Powell never grew old gracefully. He is survived by his wife, Pamela, whom he married in 1952, and two daughters. Norman Shrapnel Mike Phillips writes: The first time I met Enoch Powell left me feeling embarrassed, guilty and a little sorry for him. These weren't emotions I would have predicted, given who he was, and the impact he had had on my life, but, this was late in the 1970s, and by then his audience had dwindled and his charisma had begun to fade. Even so, his name still had enough potency for the prospect of debating with him to carry a substantial emotional charge. The occasion was a BBC programme called The Editors. I am not sure what I was expecting but when we met, before the event, he was punctiliously courteous. He made small talk without being prompted, asking questions like how long it had taken me to get to Wood Lane, and whether the traffic had been bad. His voice was a surprise, too. I had expected to find it disturbing but, face to face, it was reedy, almost musical. He still sounded stiff, awkward with the cadences of informal chat, but I had no doubt about his sincerity, and resentful as I was, I began to think there was something immensely likeable about him. On the other hand, he wasn't all charm. As we walked to the make-up cubicle he remarked that since none of the participants appeared to be editors, perhaps the programme should be renamed. I hastened to point out that I was editor of an ethnic paper, but it was too late. He'd taken the high ground. At the time I was impressed. Over the years I had begun to think of him as a demagogue who'd struck it lucky, but in that moment, the silky fluency of his tone, combined with the sharpness of the glance he gave me was like a snake striking: and suddenly, like a new insight, it hit me that here was a dangerous old man. Not that I had ever thought of him as anything else. Up until Powell began making his speeches about race the views he was expressing had widespread currency in private but in public they were disreputable, stuck out there in a margin to the right of the Conservatives. Immigrants were accustomed to hearing white people complain, but in general, we had a sense that the Notting Hill riots in 1958 had been a watershed, after which a liberal consensus had emerged among the politicians which would, somehow, protect us if the worst came to the worst. Powell destroyed our complacency in one night. His speech about seeing the Tiber 'foaming with much blood' was like a key to Pandora's box. I'm not sure how strongly most other immigrants reacted, but we all felt the dramatic change. It was hard to say quite how it had happened, but Powell had become a rallying point for most of the hostility and rage we encountered, a shorthand for hatred and contempt. "I'm with Enoch," they said, or "they should let Enoch sort you lot out," and that was enough. What was hardest to bear, and most alarming, was the pervasive sense that the politicians, the people who were meant to be in charge, seemed to be afraid of him and what he could do. In those days he cropped up in all sorts of places. Johnny Speight's bigoted Alf Garnett, on TV every week, offered him up in a domesticated package and gave him a renewed currency. He became a myth, a bogyman, in whose name blacks and Asians were to be harassed and assaulted for the next couple of decades. In hindsight, I think it would be flattering Powell to say that he was entirely responsible for the effect of his speeches, but it's true that by marrying his version of nationalism to racist rage he gave British racism and racist violence in British streets its own peculiar shape for a time, and it bore his name, Powellism. He offered British politicians a model for racialist rhetoric which was to last for a long time - when, a decade later, Mrs Thatcher spoke of British civilisation being "swamped" the Powellite echoes were unmistakable, and successful. His memory will probably have me looking over my shoulder in the streets of my own city, London, for the rest of my life, and although the thought would probably make him furious, I shall always think of him as part of my history and as part of my identity as a Briton. John Enoch Powell, politician, born June 16 1912 died February 8 1998

fields.headline: New mag aims for gap in men's market
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: New men's title Subject will challenge the assumption that covergirls sell magazines, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
New men's magazine Subject, which launches next week, will challenge the assumption that you need a woman on the cover to sell a magazine.

Subject aims to fill a perceived gap in the market between the "tits and arse" journalism of lads' mags and the "exclusivity" of magazines like Sleaze Nation and Limb by Limb, according to managing director Chris Bailey.

Mr Bailey said publisher Stable Publications surveyed 500 students and young people across the UK, who said there was a need for a new approach to the market.

He said: "The lads' sector is clearly suffering at the moment and the markets are changing."

He added Subject would cover all the "traditional" areas of interest to men, including music, sports and the internet.

However, it would also dabble in current affairs.

"While a magazine's got to be entertaining - and everyone likes pretty girls - you can try to introduce new and educational angles," he said.

The magazine will target 20- to 29-year-olds.

Subject's cover price will be £2.80 and it will have an initial print run of 70,000.

webTitle: Charity donation levels from British businesses

fields.headline: Money matters
fields.standfirst: British businesses are well behind US counterparts when it comes to giving to charity.  John Cunningham  on plans for change
fields.trailText: British businesses are well behind US counterparts when it comes to giving to charity. John Cunningham on plans for change
fields.body:
There has been no recorded instance of an enraged shareholder standing up at an annual general meeting to protest that a company is giving too much to charity, according to Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO). His ironic point is that, overall, British business is doing nowhere near enough to help good causes, its annual contribution - some £315m in total - accounting for only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income.

Companies are about to find themselves under pressure to do much more. Armed with a new opinion poll showing that almost two-thirds of respondents feel that business chiefs don't do enough for charity, and that only one-third were aware of companies doing anything for their local communities, Etherington will launch a 10-point plan at the NCVO's annual conference in London today. The aim is to secure an extra £1.25bn a year from corporate coffers.

To help achieve this, the NCVO - the umbrella body for 1,700 charities in England - is asking the govern ment to incorporate aspects of the plan in its policies. And, in a pre-general election manifesto addressed to all political parties, the organisation is calling for the appointment of a cabinet minister for the voluntary sector.

Both Labour and the Conservatives have stressed the importance of a strengthened partnership with the voluntary sector. Chancellor Gordon Brown wants to marshall thousands of new volunteers in a new civic spirit; while William Hague, acknowledging the initiatives of the churches, says that faith communities are a resource which a Tory administration would harness to repair Britain's damaged social fabric.

The NCVO says charities have become the third sector in many respects: one employee in 50 works for a charity; overall, charities employ the equivalent of more than 350,000 full-time staff; and the sector contributes almost £5bn to the GDP. From this position of strength, the NCVO reckons it is time for some straight talking to big business, which both Brown and Tony Blair have been exhorting to do more for the community.

There are certainly good guys in boardrooms, says Etherington, and some household names are well known for their community work. But of that £315m given to charities, almost all of it (97%) comes from 400 top companies; and almost half (46%) from the top 25.

Just a year ago, Brown called for a new chapter in corporate giving, comparing Britain's poor record - an average 0.2% of company pre-tax profits - with 1% in the US, totalling some $11bn (£7.5bn). There has been little evidence of improvement in the past 12 months, in spite of measures to make corporate giving simpler. "Politically, there must at some point be a discussion about whether exhortation is enough," says Etherington. "A lot of firms have said this [corporate giving] is a good thing. We're saying: 'You've got to do this'; we're trying to push it further."

Peter Davies, deputy chief execu tive of Business in the Community, whose members include 75% of the FTSE 100, argues that the voluntary sector undermines its own position of strength by taking the begging bowl approach to charitable giving. "They should be pushing for sustained corporate community investment in partnership with companies and asking for handshakes rather than hand outs," he says.

While the NCVO is keeping its detailed plans under wraps until Etherington's conference address, it is not too hard to guess some of the ideas it may have. It is very likely to press government to set a donations target of 1% of pre-tax profits, with all companies over a certain size having to comply within, say, five years.

More than 100 companies presently belong to the Per Cent Club, set up to meet such a target. Some members exceed the target: Marks & Spencer says that if its contribution to the multi-charity Children's Promise campaign is taken into account, it will be giving more than 1% this year.

One idea that the NCVO is likely to borrow from the US is the recruitment of business leaders with good records of public giving to act as "champions" for their industry. Essentially, this means exerting peer pressure at chief executive officer level; spreading the message that strong support for community programmes is good for business. Another novel way to induce loosening of company purse-strings is for the public sector supply system to start a charter mark scheme, allowing only suppliers with a good record or level of charity work to tender for contracts.

A municipal version of this is currently operating in Brighton. Adopted on a national level, it would allow government agencies and departments to use their massive spending power as coercion on the commercial sector. As such, it seems a relatively painless, no-cost way of moving towards that NCVO goal of an extra £1.25bn a year.

A further idea is simple and totally painless: companies would be required to set out clearly and in full what they do each year on the charitable front, in a section of their annual reports.

It seems clear that the voluntary sector has Brown on-side; and while estimates of his budget surplus vary widely, it would be surprising if the NCVO will not be suggesting a few sweeteners, by way of tax incentives, that he could offer companies if they donated more of their pre-tax profits.

But, overall, how willing are company directors to cough up? What Etherington calls "the really advanced group" already accepts the premise that markets generally function better in an environment of high trust. "Where society is strong, voluntary organisations are strong, self-help is strong and trust relationships are strong, markets flourish," he says.

Unless companies improve their record in line with government expectations, the NCVO's call for regulation could soon find an echo at Westminster.

With a little bit of care

Whitbread is a company that contributes 1.7% of pre-tax profits to the community - a total of £4.3m last year. The hotel, food and leisure group which includes Pizza Hut and Marriott hotels, calculates the value of its support by adding its £1.1m cash contributions - donations and matching the amount some of its 85,000 employees fundraise - with the £738,000 value it attributes to employee-volunteering, the £1.2m worth of equipment recycled to community groups and the £1.3 to manage its community programme.

Its care (community action by recycling equipment) scheme has shifted more than 83,000 items to some 250 voluntary organisations. Much of it is bedroom furnishings from hotel rebranding, which have benefited organisations working with homeless people.

The Amber Foundation provides a temporary home in the Savernake Forest for long-term unemployed 18-24 year olds. "The several donations of furniture and kitchen equipment from Whitbread have saved us approximately £10,000 and have made a tremendous difference to the quality of life for those we support," says a spokeswoman.

webTitle: Feature: Julie Burchill on the Cruise/Kidman split

fields.headline: Cut!
fields.standfirst: Millions of us feasted on the news that Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman were to split. Why? Because no one deserves to be rich, gorgeous, successful  and happy
fields.trailText: Millions of us feasted on the news that Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman were to split. Why? Because no one deserves to be rich, gorgeous, successful and happy.
fields.body:
When I was growing up, I didn't realise that my mum was the coolest, wittiest, most interesting woman I'd ever meet in all my gorgeous life. From the age of 12, I tried to avoid her as much as possible, feeling in some way that identifying with her too closely would rob me of all my sad little ambitions - to live in London, take drugs with pop stars and make it into Who's Who.

Only once a week, regular as clockwork, did I find my mother's company desirable. That was at 11 sharp on a Saturday morning when, the paid working week done and the housework completed, she would go out into the backyard, whatever the weather, and wait by the left-hand fence for her neighbour, Lily. In a low, hypnotic murmur, the two of them would commence a complete run-down on the week's sexual and emotional shenanigans in our street, soon to be joined by Millie, who would vault spryly over the wall into Lily's garden, and Jo, who would jump over into ours. The four of them stood there for a solid hour, and during this time I would use any excuse to wander out into the garden and ingratiate myself with my mother. But she wouldn't have any of it. The minute I strolled out, the murmuring stopped and four irate faces glared at me. Only tempting tell-tale titbits lingered in the air; "living in sin", "a black man!" and once, memorably, "living in sin with a black man!".

My father disapproved of these sessions, and as he never voiced disapproval of anything my mother did I knew that this was powerful stuff. Since that time I've been addicted to gossip, and seen it as not just a source of deep joy and spiteful fun but also as a weapon against all the po-faced politicos who love to lecture us about "the issues mattering, not the personalities".

The only bad thing about moving up the social scale is that your house isn't joined to anyone else's anymore, and you don't know your neighbours anyway.

This is where the internet comes in, of course. No matter how hard Mr Tony may try to convince us that it's a white-hot tool of information technology guaranteed to move us all into the knowledge-hungry middle class, its main function has been to reduce/elevate all of us to the status of ceaselessly gossiping old biddies slinging innuendo, half-truths and downright malicious lies across the worldwide electronic fence - and all on the boss's time, too!

When the Great Crash of 2002 finally happens, it will be less to do with the collapse of confidence in the economy than the simple fact that, thanks to the internet, most people now spend most of their working hours gossiping.

It's lovely, terrible logic when you think about it; the eternal feminine value of human-interest story telling corrupting, weakening and finally destroying the male conceit of dry, cold capitalism.

I dread to think how little work was being done on both sides of the pond yesterday as the news of the end of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman's 11-year marriage broke. All across the world fans were reaching out to dry each others' tears and give testimony to The God That Failed: "I'm incredibly shocked and upset"; "Can't stop crying since I heard about it"; "They were the happiest couple in Hollywood!"; "Don't think I can face work today - but don't have net at home, so won't be able to chat! So must go in".

Over on the PopBitch website, meanwhile, where sour film and muse-biz has-beens and wannabes gather to mock and malign their hated idols, the tone was much less devastated. Stories, obviously untrue, came thick and fast: the time when one particularly strained dinner ended with Kidman flouncing to the desk and shouting: "I'll have the check, and he'll have that guy at the table by the toilets"; the one about how Kidman had signed a 10-year contract guaranteeing her an A-list career if she acted as "beard" to the sexually flexible Cruise, and a few others that could not be repeated in this newspaper.

Why are we so shocked, and so fascinated by the end of just another showbiz marriage? Let's face it, when it comes to sex, actors are a breed apart; the phrase DCOL (Doesn't count on location) doesn't exist in any other profession. It's not even that actors are inherently slacker than the rest of us; it's just that their lives are essentially one long Temptation Island, during which they will be paid huge amounts of money to simulate sex and - even more lethal for a breed who can so easily mistake pretend life for real - love, with a non-stop parade of the most attractive people in the world. How many of us can honestly say that we could keep our hearts in cold storage with a naked Famke Janssen or Josh Hartnett crawling all over us? The wonder is not that film stars get divorced so much, but that any of them bother getting married at all. Why keep a steak at home when you've got a smorgasbord on location?

Nevertheless, because we're spoony old things at heart, we like to believe that some showbiz marriages are different. These become our touchstone romances; proof that if a golden couple can resist all the temptations that the high life can throw at them, then surely we - who, let's face it, aren't very likely to be called upon to French kiss Angelina Jolie in the course of a day's work - can make ourselves stay on the straight and narrow. And we do, despite our sophistication, think we can differentiate between "good" couples and "bad" couples. No one expects Liam and Nicole to grow old together - or even to exchange presents at Christmas. But we expected it, for some reason, of Meg and Noel. And of Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid, Kim Basinger and Alec Baldwin.

If we were wrong about them, what else were we wrong about? If a man can go off Kim Basinger, who's safe? Part of us panics petulantly, as though a favourite toy has been snatched away. And Tom and Nicole did seem . . . different. Why? Well, they lived over here for a few months, basically. The way that we forgave the Cruise-Kidmans anything - their weird rightwing "religion", their nasty habit of making staff liable for huge fines if a word about their private lives got out, their frankly sick-making films - just because they lodged in dear old Blighty for a few weeks is one of the sadder aspects of the whole affair; as with the recent genuflecting towards pub-Madonna by people old enough to know better, it just goes to demonstrate how low our national self-esteem has fallen if the fact that a famous yank takes a few dumps into our sewer system has us wetting ourselves with sheer molten joy. That they've deigned to leave America the Beautiful for five minutes. They take their kids to the park! He went to Blockbuster to get a video out! - our pathetic joy in being used briefly by famous Americans is truly tragic to behold.

But the other part of us - the nasty, honest part - is secretly glad they've gone the way of all flesh, just as we were glad about Cindy and Richard, Ken and Em, Dawn and Lenny. Smug bastards! - filthy rich, gorgeous, successful AND happily married. Stars are meant to be lonely at the top, like Marilyn, Judy and James Dean; it's yer Faustian pact, innit? Come on - wasn't there always something a bit fishy about the Cruises? Especially when they tried to sex up their ailing union by making us all witness their alleged chemistry in Eyes Wide Shut, which backfired somewhat when Kidman, during her big love scenes with her husband, displayed all the transfixed lust of a woman trying to remember if this is the day the dry cleaning can be picked up. And offscreen they were just as non-incendiary; like Diana and Charles, there always seemed to be three people in the marriage - Tom, Nic and the camera.

Look at them turning up at premieres - she kisses him while he smiles for the camera, then vice versa. They never seemed connected, private even in public, as obviously authentic lovers such as Zoe Ball and Norman Cook frequently do.

The professional gossips are now weighing in with their wild, well-paid guesses; he's got another bird, she doesn't want to bring up their adopted children as Scientologists, she's jealous of his career. Whatever, their publicity machine has already trotted out the three great lies of modern divorce; it was pressure of work, it's an amicable break and there's no one else involved. In other words, they found that they both preferred being at work to being at home, the lawyers aren't involved yet and in six months time she'll be pregnant by some new kid on the block while he'll be all hooked up with some fresh-faced young beauty who really, really wants it.

That's showbiz.

It's not even that actors are inherently slacker than the rest of us; it's just that their lives are essentially one long Temptation Island, during which they will be paid huge amounts of money to simulate sex and - even more lethal for a breed who can so easily mistake pretend life for real - love, with a non-stop parade of the most attractive people in the world. How many of us can honestly say that we could keep our hearts in cold storage with a naked Famke Janssen or Josh Hartnett crawling all over us? The wonder is not that film stars get divorced so much, but that any of them bother getting married at all. Why keep a steak at home when you've got a smorgasbord on location? Nevertheless, because we're spoony old things at heart, we like to believe that some showbiz marriages are different. These become our touchstone romances; proof that if a golden couple can resist all the temptations that the high life can throw at them, then surely we - who, let's face it, aren't very likely to be called upon to French kiss Angelina Jolie in the course of a day's work - can make ourselves stay on the straight and narrow. And we do, despite our sophistication, think we can differentiate between "good" couples and "bad" couples. No one expects Liam and Nicole to grow old together - or even to exchange presents at Christmas. But we expected it, for some reason, of Meg and Noel. And of Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid, Kim Basinger and Alec Baldwin. If we were wrong about them, what else were we wrong about? If a man can go off Kim Basinger, who's safe? Part of us panics petulantly, as though a favourite toy has been snatched away. And Tom and Nicole did seem . . . different. Why? Well, they lived over here for a few months, basically. The way that we forgave the Cruise-Kidmans anything - their weird rightwing "religion", their nasty habit of making staff liable for huge fines if a word about their private lives got out, their frankly sick-making films - just because they lodged in dear old Blighty for a few weeks is one of the sadder aspects of the whole affair; as with the recent genuflecting towards pub-Madonna by people old enough to know better, it just goes to demonstrate how low our national self-esteem has fallen if the fact that a famous yank takes a few dumps into our sewer system has us wetting ourselves with sheer molten joy. That they've deigned to leave America the Beautiful for five minutes. They take their kids to the park! He went to Blockbuster to get a video out! - our pathetic joy in being used briefly by famous Americans is truly tragic to behold. But the other part of us - the nasty, honest part - is secretly glad they've gone the way of all flesh, just as we were glad about Cindy and Richard, Ken and Em, Dawn and Lenny. Smug bastards! - filthy rich, gorgeous, successful AND happily married. Stars are meant to be lonely at the top, like Marilyn, Judy and James Dean; it's yer Faustian pact, innit? Come on - wasn't there always something a bit fishy about the Cruises? Especially when they tried to sex up their ailing union by making us all witness their alleged chemistry in Eyes Wide Shut, which backfired somewhat when Kidman, during her big love scenes with her husband, displayed all the transfixed lust of a woman trying to remember if this is the day the dry cleaning can be picked up. And offscreen they were just as non-incendiary; like Diana and Charles, there always seemed to be three people in the marriage - Tom, Nic and the camera. Look at them turning up at premieres - she kisses him while he smiles for the camera, then vice versa. They never seemed connected, private even in public, as obviously authentic lovers such as Zoe Ball and Norman Cook frequently do. The professional gossips are now weighing in with their wild, well-paid guesses; he's got another bird, she doesn't want to bring up their adopted children as Scientologists, she's jealous of his career. Whatever, their publicity machine has already trotted out the three great lies of modern divorce; it was pressure of work, it's an amicable break and there's no one else involved. In other words, they found that they both preferred being at work to being at home, the lawyers aren't involved yet and in six months time she'll be pregnant by some new kid on the block while he'll be all hooked up with some fresh-faced young beauty who really, really wants it. That's showbiz.

webTitle: Anger as man faces court over Sarah Payne murder

fields.headline: Anger as man faces court over Sarah Payne murder
fields.standfirst:
• Whiting remanded in custody
• Angry scenes outside court

More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText:
• Whiting remanded in custody
• Angry scenes outside court
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.body:
The man accused of kidnapping and murdering eight-year-old Sarah Payne was today remanded in custody when he made a brief appearance in court.

An angry crowd of about 200 people shouted abuse and hurled missiles at Roy Whiting as he left Chichester magistrates court.

Mr Whiting, 42, spoke only to confirm his name and age during the 38-minute hearing at Chichester, West Sussex.

He was wearing a red sweatshirt and flanked by three security guards when he stepped into the dock of the small 1970s courtroom.

Presiding magistrate Michael Sugden, sitting with two others, refused an application for bail made on behalf of Mr Whiting, of Littlehampton, West Sussex.

Mr Sugden indicated that Mr Whiting would appear for a preliminary hearing at Lewes crown court on February 19.

Following the hearing, an angry crowd of more than 200 people chased the vehicle carrying Mr Whiting away from the court building.

Members of the public shouted abuse as the van, escorted by police, sped away.

The van stopped 100 yards down the road at a level crossing. The crowd gave chase but the vehicle sped away before they could reach it. One person was arrested and an egg was hurled at the vehicle.
