fields.headline: Lastminute strikes text message deal
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com has teamed up with 12snap.com to text message its deals to customers, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
If you are happy to have Lastminute.com's almost constant barrage of emails clogging up your in-box, from this week you can start collecting text messages from the company as well.

Lastminute.com is to notify consumers about offers by text message for the first time in a deal with mobile phone service company 12snap.

The news comes a week after 12snap announced text messaging deals with McDonald's and American Express.

Customers become a "lastminute.com snapper" by registering for the interactive service on a co-branded site www.12snap-lastminute.com.

Registered users will receive a text message at lunchtime detailing that day's offers, which are exclusive to the service users and will not appear on the website.

The customer is told what time the offers will become available - later that afternoon or evening - at which point they can call to buy.

Some offers will be fixed price and some will allow customers to bid for the deal on offer.

If a bid is unsuccessful, the customer will be notified by a text message and will be invited to submit a new bid.

The service launches tomorrow and for an initial period there will be two one-hour snapper sessions a week.

This means users will get a prompt text message with the deals twice a week - each time having an hour later in the day to respond.

A spokeswoman for 12snap said the service would expand if successful and could become a daily service.

"We could do this every day, it is likely that this will become a more regular service," she said.

A series of competitions will help launch the service - a Valentine's Day promotion gives customers the chance to win a pink Benilli scooter.

Other prizes will include first-class tickets on Eurostar and a luxury weekend break in top UK hotels.

The jointly branded service - messages will have both company's names attached to them - is also set to roll out in Germany and Italy, the other territories where the company has offices.

webTitle: Casting news: Sarandon and Danes drop out for comedy

fields.headline: Sarandon and Danes drop out for comedy
fields.standfirst: Plus: Robbie Williams to star in That'll Be the Day remake
fields.trailText: Plus: Robbie Williams to star in That'll Be the Day remake
fields.body:
 Susan Sarandon and Claire Danes (pictured) are set to star in the indie comedy Igby Goes Down, written and directed by Burr Steers. Scheduled to begin filming on February 28, the movie promises a tale of dysfunctional dropouts in New York. Ryan (Cruel Intentions) Phillippe is reported to be in final negotiations to play the male lead, a suburban rebel who leaves home and finds romance in the big bad city.

 Currently drying out at a clinic in LA, pop star Robbie Williams is tipped to make his movie debut in That'll Be the Day, a remake of the cult 1973 British youth flick that kick-started the career of David Essex. Set in the early 50s, the film charts the dawn of rock and roll through the eyes of one everyday teenager. Rather worryingly, Robbie is also believed to be determined to have a hand in the movie's script.

fields.headline: What the Israeli papers say
fields.trailText: As the electoral dust settles, Israeli political commentators are coming to terms with the extraordinary comeback of Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
As the electoral dust settles, Israeli political commentators are coming to terms with the extraordinary comeback of Ariel Sharon.

Even the rightwing Jerusalem Post is guarded about the election of a rightwing prime minister. Its leader writer makes an extravagant comparison of Sharon with Winston Churchill, who "was also considered a quirky and militant extremist before being ushered into power in a time of crisis."

The paper rejects the notion that the Israeli electorate has turned its back on peace. Rather they have turned to Sharon as the leader most likely to achieve it. The Post has no doubt that his first and most urgent task is to form a broadbased government of national unity.

On its main news pages, the Post points out that Barak's resignation as One Nation (aka Labour) party leader, will greatly complicate prime minister Sharon's task of forming a viable coalition in the perpetually fractious Knesset: "Sharon is left with no one to parley with, when he doesn't have much time to squander. He cannot wait for Labour to choose a new leader and go through the primary process. Until then, though, the major players in Labour will be afraid of risking partnership with him. Barak's departure is bad news for Sharon."

The liberal Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz, strongly backed Barak's campaign, now wishes the new prime minister well, and offers some cogent advice: "Like others holding the post of prime minister before him, Sharon will also discover that the diplomatic and security reality seen from the prime minister's office is not identical to that on the outside. Sharon will have to make adjustments, both in himself and in his plans. The sooner he realizes this the better."

The leader goes on: "The foundation of the agreements reached by Israel and the Palestinians seven and a half years ago rested on Israel's understanding that the time had come to be rid of the occupation, on the one hand, and on the Palestinians' willingness to come to terms with the existence of Israel on part of the Land of Israel, on the other.

"These fundamentals are still valid today, despite the two sides' failure to translate their 1993 agreement of principles into a detailed peace treaty: the occupation of the territories cannot continue...

"Therefore, Sharon's first mission... is to continue moving on the path of reconciliation with the Palestinians, set in train by his predecessors. The need to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has become pressing as a result of the conflagration which erupted four months ago.

"Sharon has a choice: to take up the negotiations from the point at which they halted at Taba and continue in an effort to reach a peace agreement; or to turn in a completely different direction and fulfil the darkest predictions of his rivals, who forecast that his rise to power would mean the destruction of the peace process and the deterioration of Israeli-Palestinian relations into a broadbased armed confrontation. Choosing the second option would be disastrous."

Perhaps the most chilling news story in Ha'aretz points out that Sharon has only until March 30 to complete the fiendishly complex business of coalition-building. If he can't do it, the nation will be condemned to another prime ministerial election on April 15.

Moreover, he has to persuade the Knesset to pass a national budget by March 31. Failure to win a budget majority, also carries the dire penalty of new parliamentary and prime ministerial elections within 90 days.

On paper, Sharon is supported by eight factions in the Knesset, giving him a wafer-thin majority of 62 in the 120-seat chamber. But that cumbersome majority includes at least three orthodox religious parties, notorious for their budgetary scheming.

webTitle: Berlusconi landside may trigger legitimacy crisis

fields.headline: Berlusconi landside may trigger legitimacy crisis
fields.standfirst: Italy's most famous media mogul may soon be prime minister - despite the fact that he has been declared ineligible for public office. Rory Carroll reports
fields.trailText: Italy's most famous media mogul may soon be prime minister - despite the fact that he has been declared ineligible for public office. Rory Carroll reports
fields.body:
Unless the opinion pollsters are lying, or voters are lying to the opinion pollsters, Italy is soon to have Silvio Berlusconi as prime minister.

The leader of the centre-right opposition predicted this week that he would sweep back to power with a 127 seat majority out of a total of 630 seats.

Hubris, cries the government, but privately senior members expect a Berlusconi landslide - which explains an intervention that in any other European Union country would be considered extraordinary. The chairman of Democratic Left, the dominant party in the ruling coalition, declared Mr Berlusconi ineligible for public office.

Massimo D'Alema, himself a former prime minister, effectively declared the government-in-waiting illegal. The election expected in April or May would trigger a legitimacy crisis far graver than any Florida recount, he implied.

"In my opinion the law already regulates this matter: it says he is illegible for office," he said.

Not even during their most heated exchanges have Tony Blair or William Hague hurled such an accusation, for it would stray far beyond the rules of the democratic game. Uproar would result.

In Italy there is merely a shrug, because this is old news. Mr Berlusconi's potential conflict of interest has been denounced since he entered politics in 1993. As conflicts go, it's pretty massive. The country's richest man, worth an estimated £13bn, his unlisted company Fininvest indirectly controls Italy's three private Mediaset television stations and Mondadori, the biggest publishing house.

He swears he has no direct involvement in the empire and that his newspapers, magazines and networks have editorial independence. It just so happens they cheer him and jeer the government.

Mr Berlusconi built this concentration of media power in the 1980s by allegedly exploiting legal loopholes. Once in power he is liable to gain control of the three state-owned Rai television networks, sealing a dominance of the media few democratic states would tolerate.

The so-called Cavalier said he might float 30% of Fininvest and pass a law regulating conflict of interest. "It will be my government's first measure," he said.

The centre-left has scorned the pledge and begged voters to avert the risk. A hollow plea. It has been in power more than four years - easily enough time to enact legislation to rein in Mr Berlusconi. Its failure to do so is a crushing indictment of the blunders, rivalries and hypocrisies which plagued the fractious jumble of ex-communists, ex-Christian Democrats, centrists and Greens.

Mr D'Alema had ample opportunity when he was prime minister from October 1998 until last April. He blew it. Hoping to enlist Mr Berlusconi's support for sweeping constitutional reforms, he soft-pedalled on the conflict of interest. The reforms collapsed and Mr D'Alema changed his mind but vital time was lost.

In-fighting played its part. Hardliners who wanted to prise the Cavalier from his empire were resisted by moderates who favoured a gentler approach, lest the coalition appear vengeful and undemocratic.

Inertia suited many key government supporters - such as Giovanni Agnelli and Vittorio Cecchi Gori - who have media and business empires of their own. And so nothing was done.

Antonio Di Pietro, an independent senator, is scathing. "Well, isn't D'Alema clever! He now remembers that Berlusconi is ineligible for office. My compliments. Where was he when I submitted to parliament interrogations on the matter? He was trying to make friends with Berlusconi, that's where he was."

In fact the system worked rather well, for a time, since there was parity. Mr Berlusconi's Mediaset cheerleaders were balanced by the government's slightly less partisan supporters in Rai.

The problem is that Mr Berlusconi is now poised to sweep everything and it is too late for legislation. A deeply worrying prospect, but it is not all his fault.

fields.headline: Libyan appeals against Lockerbie conviction
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: The Libyan jailed for the Lockerbie bombing today lodged an appeal against his conviction.
fields.body:
The Libyan jailed for the Lockerbie bombing today lodged an appeal against his conviction.

A spokeswoman for the Scottish courts service said an "intimation of notice of intent to appeal" was lodged at the Justiciary Office in Edinburgh today.

Libyan secret agent Abdel Baset al-Megrahi was found guilty of murdering 270 people when the long-running Lockerbie trial ended at a special Scottish law court at Camp Zeist, near Utrecht, Netherlands, last week.

Once the office has the full documentation regarding the appeal it will be submitted to a single judge in chambers, who will grant or refuse leave to appeal.

Legal experts consider it unlikely that an appeal would be refused. If it is, Megrahi's legal team could appeal against that refusal to a panel of three judges.

Megrahi's solicitor, Alistair Duff, today refused to comment on the appeal move.

Families of those who died in the 1988 disaster said they had expected an appeal to be lodged.

Dr Jim Swire, spokesman for the UK Families of Pan Am 103 support group, said: "We anticipated that this would happen and the matter is now back in the hands of the Scottish court."

Clare Connelly, lecturer in criminal law and a member of the Lockerbie trial briefing unit at Glasgow University, said there was no automatic right of appeal under Scottish law and Megrahi had to seek permission to appeal. She said: "He has merely lodged notice of appeal. In Scotland there are only two grounds for appeal - where there's been a miscarriage of justice or where new evidence has come to light.

"When the grounds [of any appeal] are lodged they will not be made public. What's happening now is just a procedural thing where the process is just beginning."

webTitle: In brief: Ridley Scott eyes Britain's hottest stars for Kidd

fields.headline: Ridley Scott eyes Britain's hottest stars for Kidd
fields.standfirst: Plus: Robert Altman to make first movie in Britain; Songs from the Second Floor scores at Swedish Oscars; Anthony Hopkins admits why he really left Britain
fields.trailText: Plus: Robert Altman to make first movie in Britain; Songs from the Second Floor scores at Swedish Oscars; Anthony Hopkins admits why he really left Britain
fields.body:
 Director Ridley Scott is reported to have earmarked a cast of fellow Brits for his follow-up to Hannibal, the pirate adventure, Captain Kidd. Jude Law (pictured) will take the title role, while Ewen Bremner and Rupert Graves will play the captain's lieutenants. The general Brit-pack flavour is complemented by the presence of Sadie Frost and Lena Headey in supporting roles. Sources at Disney, the film's putative backers, suggest that the film will be a slick, swashbuckling adventure along the lines of the poorly received highwayman romp Plunkett and Macleane, directed by Ridley's son Jake. "They are looking at something in the mould of Errol Flynn in The Sea Hawk," an unnamed source explains. "But the studio would like an ensemble cast, very young and glamorous, to rival some of the other movies being made like Ocean's Eleven."

 USA Films has hooked up with London-based Capitol Films at the eleventh hour to finance the new film from movie maverick Robert Altman. Gosford Park, which shoots next month, will be Altman's first British-based movie and stars a cast of homegrown stalwarts including the ubiquitous Jude Law, Jeremy Northam, Emily Watson, Kristin Scott Thomas, Stephen Fry, Helen Mirren and Derek Jacobi. The 1930s-set plot promises a satirical Cluedo-style yarn, as a crop of eccentrics, aristocrats and possible murderers gather for a weekend at a stately home in the country.

 The acclaimed Songs from the Second Floor swept the board at this week's Swedish Film Festival (otherwise known as the Guldbagga) in Stockholm. Roy Andersson's epic picture poem (which premiered at last year's London film festival) scooped the awards for Best Film, Director and Script. With no professional actors in the film, it was left to Lena Endre - star of the forthcoming Faithless - to take the Best Actress Award. Best Actor was Kjell Bergqvist, honoured for his role in Ulf Malmros's The Best Summer.

 Nine months after taking US citizenship, Anthony Hopkins has revealed the real reasons behind his move away from his native Britain. According to the Hannibal star, the decision was prompted not by tax benefits or rampant ambition but by an overriding hatred for luvvie British actors. "I couldn't stand actors with their airy graces. You know: 'the theatah!' That's why I got out and did what I did," he moaned to reporters.

webTitle: In brief: Kidman plans return to London stage

fields.headline: Kidman plans return to London stage
fields.standfirst: Plus: Trainspotting's McGregor and Miller reunite for comedy; Steve Kloves starts work on second Harry Potter script; Morgan Freeman to sign up for third Jack Ryan movie
fields.trailText: Plus: Trainspotting's McGregor and Miller reunite for comedy; Steve Kloves starts work on second Harry Potter script; Morgan Freeman to sign up for third Jack Ryan movie
fields.body:
 Nicole Kidman is putting her broken marriage to Tom Cruise behind her and planning a return to the London stage, according to People News. The National Theatre director Trevor Nunn has confirmed that the 33-year-old star will appear in a production of Ibsen's The Lady From the Sea in the near future. "I can't put a date on it yet, because we are waiting for the film projects to which she is committed to lock into place," he told reporters. "It's taken a long while to sort out, but it's going to happen." Kidman made her London stage debut two years ago in David Hare's The Blue Room in which her performance was described by one critic as "theatrical viagra."

 Trainspotting co-stars Jonny Lee Miller and Ewan McGregor will team up again in the comedy On The Line, according to reports today. The duo will play best friends who set out to find a woman (played by Buffy the Vampire Slayer star Sarah Michelle Gellar) who Miller falls for on a train journey. A source close to the movie says, "Miller and Ewan are a great combination. They spark off each other. Miller's role is basically American but Ewan will be American Italian. The accent is on comedy but there is also a dramatic twist in the tale." Filming is due to start in the spring.

 Work has already started on the script for the second Harry Potter film, according to screenwriter Steve Kloves. Although the first Harry Potter film doesn't hit Britain's cinemas until November, Kloves told gossip site ain't it cool news that he has started writing the second script but whether work goes ahead on a sequel depends on how the first film is received. "I know people are thrilled with what Chris #91;Columbus] has shot so far," he told the site. "If it works, you'll see more. I don't know how quickly they'll come. I think there'll be an attempt to have the second one come out reasonably quickly after. It'll be great to have one come out every year. I don't know how that could be pulled off. It'd be very hard."

 Morgan Freeman is in talks to join Ben Affleck in the new Jack Ryan film, The Sum of All Fears. If The Shawshank Redemption star signs, he will play the role of Ryan's mentor in the third Tom Clancy adaptation. Affleck has taken over the role from Harrison Ford, who played the character in Patriot Games and Clear and Present Danger. James Cromwell and Alan Bates have already signed up for the project.

webTitle: NCVO unveils election agenda at conference debate

fields.headline: NCVO unveils election agenda at conference debate
fields.trailText: Politicians from the three main parties with responsibility for the voluntary sector will participate in a Question Time-style debate today at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations conference.
fields.body:
Politicians from the three main parties with responsibility for the voluntary sector will participate in a Question Time-style debate today at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations conference.

MPs Paul Boateng (Labour), David Lidington (Conservative) and Simon Hughes (Liberal Democrat) will take questions from the audience of voluntary sector representatives at 2pm GMT. The deputy editor of the New Statesman, Christina Odone, will chair the panel, which will also include Sunday Times columnist Melanie Phillips and the chief executive of the NCVO, Stuart Etherington.

The council has issued an agenda for the next general election on behalf of the voluntary sector, in which it asks political parties to sign up to the following set of principles:

 Voluntary and community activity is fundamental to the development of a democratic, socially inclusive society and fulfils a role that is distinct from the state and the private sector

 Government must recognise and support the independence of the sector, including its right within the law to campaign, to comment on government policy, and to challenge that policy, irrespective of any funding relationship that might exist, and to determine and manage its own affairs

 Government has a responsibility to create and promote a favourable tax and fiscal environment in which the voluntary sector can flourish

 Central, regional and local government must recognise that where they work, or want to work, in partnership with the sector, those partnerships must benefit all those involved and that government has a responsibility to invest time, skills and capacity to make them work. Government should ensure that the cost of engagement in partnerships for voluntary organisations is met, particularly at a local and community level

 It is essential that government provides the voluntary sector with a long-term commitment of support. Short-term funding is short-sighted and seriously reduces the potential of the voluntary sector

 Government should strive to ensure that it is consistent in all its dealings with the voluntary sector. A coordinated approach by all parts of the government to all its relationships with the sector would benefit all partners

In addition it proposes that:

 The Compact should become mainstream practice across all government departments

 There should be a cabinet minister with responsibility for the voluntary sector

 There should be a training programme for civil servants so they understand how the voluntary sector works

 The government should consult the sector before the introduction of new legislation affecting charities

 Tax incentives to encourage people to give to charities should be maintained and enhanced

 The government should take responsibility for promoting long-term funding for charities

 The principle of additionality should be observed in the distribution of lottery money - lottery money should not be used to fund government priorities

 There should be a VAT rebate for the voluntary sector. The government needs to persuade the EC to change the rate of VAT applicable to charities

 Charity law should be reformed. NCVO is currently reviewing the 400-year-old law applying to charities. The government should act on recommendations from the review and work to ensure that the sector is not overburdened with red tape

 Free criminal record checks for volunteers and voluntary organisations

 Young people should receive citizenship education with students offered placements and career advice on the voluntary sector

 The government should commit resources to support the sector's own efforts to provide training and development to employers and employees

One in 50 employees now works for the voluntary sector, and charities contribute nearly £5bn to the UK's GDP. The agenda states: "The sector plays a major role in developing an inclusive integrated society and government must allow the sector the freedom to do this."

webTitle: Murder appeal man freed after 27 years

fields.headline: Murder appeal man freed after 27 years
fields.trailText: Stephen Downing, jailed 27 years ago for a murder he says he did not commit, was today freed on bail by the court of appeal.
fields.body:
Stephen Downing, jailed 27 years ago for a murder he says he did not commit, was today freed on bail by the court of appeal.

Downing, 44, was being released from Littlehey prison in Cambridgeshire to await the hearing of an appeal against his conviction and life jail sentence for the killing of married typist Wendy Sewell.

A spokesperson for Downing's parents, Ray, 66, and Juanita, 67, made a brief statement on their behalf outside their home in Bakewell: "The Downings are absolutely over the moon and delighted with the news.

"It has not sunk in yet and they are both rather emotional. They don't know what their plans are and don't know if he is coming straight back."

Mrs Sewell's badly beaten body was found in a cemetery where Downing worked in his home town of Bakewell, Derbyshire.

Bail was not opposed by the crown, which conceded that the appeal was "highly likely" to succeed in the light of serious questions raised over the admissibility of Downing's confession statements, which formed a main plank of the prosecution case.

Downing was 17 at the time of the killing but had the mental age of an 11-year-old.

He has consistently denied murder and so has been ineligible for parole, which could have given him freedom 10 years ago.

The criminal cases review commission referred his case to the court of appeal after years of campaigning by his parents, Ray and Juanita, and by Don Hale, editor of local newspaper, the Matlock Mercury.

Mr Hale said the outcome was "justification for old-fashioned investigative journalism".

He continued: "I am absolutely delighted by the whole thing. It's fantastic news for me and obviously for Stephen and the whole family."

Stephen Downing's parents refused to beyond their initial statement. It is understood they have secured an exclusive deal with a Sunday newspaper.

The victim's husband, David Sewell, said yesterday that he hoped Downing would remain in custody pending the appeal hearing. "My main concern is that he isn't released as a convicted criminal because I think he should remain inside until his guilt is proven either way."

fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 8
fields.trailText: February 8: Yahoo! Europe has promoted European sales chief Fru Hazlitt to sales and marketing director.
fields.body:
Yahoo! Europe has overhauled its marketing structure, promoting European sales chief Fru Hazlitt to the new role of sales and marketing director.

Adidas has hired Duckworth Finn account director Indy Saha as its European advertising chief.

Swatch is reviewing its £16m advertising account.

Handbag.com has called a review of its advertising and marketing.

Diners Club has appointed Ivana Santoro as its UK marketing chief as it looks to rebuild the credit card brand in the UK.

Olympus has awarded its pan-European advertising account to FCB Worldwide.

Procter & Gamble is fighting back against Lever Faberge's Persil Capsules with the launch of Arial Liqui-Tabs.

fields.headline: City Slicker settles with Mirror
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Anil Bhoyrul, the former Mirror journalist at the heart of the City Slickers share-tipping scandal, has settled out of court with the paper's owner, writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.body:
Anil Bhoyrul, the former Mirror journalist at the heart of the City Slickers share-tipping scandal, has settled out of court with the paper's owner Trinity Mirror.

Unfair dismissal proceedings issued by Mr Bhoyrul against Trinity Mirror were due to go ahead next week but have been shelved.

It is thought the group has agreed a pay-off, excluding legal costs.

Mr Bhoyrul and his former colleague James Hipwell were sacked from the Mirror after it emerged the paper's editor Piers Morgan had bought shares in a technology company a day before they were tipped in the paper.

The incident is the subject of an inquiry by the Department of Trade and Industry, which is to investigate whether the City Slickers share-tipping constituted insider dealing.

Mr Morgan was cleared of any wrongdoing by an internal inquiry.

fields.trailText: 9.30am: The regulator has banned electrical goods retailer Currys from using its "unbeatable low prices" slogan, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
An advertising watchdog has barred electrical goods retailer Currys from using its "unbeatable low prices" slogan after rival Comet complained.

The Advertising Standards Authority banned the line, used in Currys' advertising, after an investigation showed Currys' prices are often higher than Comet's.

Currys claimed its line was "common advertising hyperbole and would not be interpreted literally".

The retailer also said it tried to ensure its prices were lower than those of rival retailers but that it was not always possible to respond quickly enough to price cuts.

It said its price promise meant customers would be entitled to money back if they found their purchase was available elsewhere at a lower price.

But the ASA decided the prominence of Currys' claims meant consumers would expect the advertisers' prices could not be beaten - regardless of the price promise - and ordered its immediate removal.

fields.headline: A blueprint for business giving
fields.standfirst: The NCVO is today launching a 10-point plan directed at influencing government policy in a bid to encourage greater business donations to charity
fields.trailText: The NCVO is today launching a 10-point plan directed at influencing government policy in a bid to encourage greater business donations to charity.
fields.body:
1. Government should examine the potential for a more radical approach to encouraging corporate social responsibility, for example by offering lower rates of corporation tax to businesses that demonstrate a good record of corporate social responsibility.

2. Government should review its response to the charity tax review and consider the scope for further action to encourage business giving through the tax and fiscal system. In particular the government should consider further extending corporation tax relief to other types of large capital donations to charity by businesses, than already currently available.

3. Government should invest further resources into the sector-led campaign to encourage giving tax effectively to charity, specifically to raise awareness of the tax reliefs available for company giving and payroll giving.

4. Building on the Taskforce 2002 report, the government should consider providing funding to support the development of pilot projects which:
 provide training and access to information in developing business-voluntary sector partnerships
 provide mechanisms to support organisations in developing effective partnerships, for example brokerage services between business and the voluntary sector at a local level.

5. The government should adopt a strategy of naming and shaming large companies with poor records of corporate social responsibility.

6. The government should review and clarify company reporting requirements for cash donations to create a level playing field for comparison.

7. The government should consider other ways to bring pressure to bear on business, for example through the public sector supply chain and contracting processes.

8. The government should appoint "business champions" to lead the way in demonstrating good practice and to provide benchmarks to encourage others to follow.

9. The government should seek a democracy of business giving and set targets for the levels of corporate support it would like to see achieved by businesses. NCVO would advocate a target of 1% of company profits being given to charity in order to match the average in the US.

10. The minister for corporate social responsibility should coordinate, on behalf of the government, a report on progress by the business sector in meeting challenges and targets set by the government in relation to corporate social responsibility.

fields.headline: Paper chase
fields.standfirst: How far should we go to preserve literary archives, asks John Sutherland
fields.trailText: How far should we go to preserve literary archives, asks John Sutherland.
fields.body:
When Sir Winston Churchill's papers were acquired "for the nation" with £12m of the nation's dosh, the nation went ballistic. Who needed these scraps, for God's sake? Were Winnie's laundry lists really more valuable than a new intensive care unit? The principal repository of such "literary remains" in this country is the manuscripts department of the British Library. No one much loves them; no MP has made this aspect of the nation's "heritage" their special interest.

The admirable aspect of the British Library's current policy is its dedication to intactness. Private collectors, dealers and auction houses have, in the past, combined to fragment literary archives into their atomic particles. A collection would come into the sale room and it would be "broken" into lots. But in the past few years dealers, auction houses and librarians have collaborated to preserve collections. The British Library's latest big acquisition, "the Dickens Archive" as it's called, is less glitzy than some, but none the less pays witness to this new respect for organic wholeness.

Sotheby's put the material up for auction as long ago as July 1999. "Dickens Archive" was, in fact, something of a misnomer: all of the Great Inimitable's major manuscripts (those that survive) were already in publicly accessible collections. What Sotheby's offered was some 30 lots of material that had been in the possession of the Dickens family for several generations and comprised "legal papers used by Dickens himself and his advisers".

Luckily, the Sotheby lots went more or less entire to a London dealer. How much they paid, and how much the BL paid when they were sold on, is "confidential". The reserve price put on them by Sotheby's two years ago was around a quarter of a million pounds. As public spending goes, it's chump change. But it would get you five state-of-the-art ambulances.

In terms of the long-term policy of the BL the Dickens Archive was, I believe, a well-conceived purchase. It signals a strategic intention to invest in infrastructure. Some institutions are taking this to an extreme: the Harry Ransom Center, in Austin, Texas, has acquired the actual library fur niture of writers such as Evelyn Waugh. This seems a desk too far.

But in many ways, the Ransom Center strikes me as the model to follow. It's very well endowed and has one main specialism - the acquisition of literary remains of contemporary English writers. The center recently bought the manuscripts of Tom Stoppard (for a seven-figure dollar sum, rumour has it). They have the bulk of Anthony Burgess's papers. And much, much more.

What is particularly attractive for the British writer is that Ransom is prepared to buy - and pay top dollar - while authors are still alive and in their prime. It is immensely frustrating that the British Library cannot use Heritage Lottery Fund money for this kind of enlightened patronage. Such funds may not by regulation be applied to manuscripts less than 20 years old. If, for example, you went to Zadie Smith and said: "Here's a quarter of a million pounds for all your past, present and future manuscripts", how do you think the author of White Teeth would reply? "No thanks, I'll wait until 130 years after my death, like Dickens"?

The biggest question of all is: will writers like Smith have any literary manuscripts for the BL to curate in future years? Doubtless she, like every other author nowadays, uses a computer and sends copy to her publisher on disk.

Bill Gates (who else?) is riding to the rescue. Microsoft has a "creative writers" package ready for the market. It is, in fact, a clone of the Big Brother packages that employers are installing, to track every keystroke that their employees make during working hours. What this software will do is record all an author's changes of mind, in "pre-archived" form, along with whatever other material was archive-worthy (correspondence, contracts, laundry lists). After 10 years such an electronic database would, I think, be worth five ambulances, at least.

webTitle: Feature: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Money down the drain
fields.body:
Money down the drain

A number of you were startled to read our recent snippet about ground sumps. Those of you in possession of this luxury are exempt from surface water drainage fees included in your water bill, although few of you were aware of this and water companies preferred it that way. Now you want to know why, if the companies have been taking money they weren't entitled to over the years, rebates may only be backdated to last April. "Surely there's something disreputable about the way this fraudulent extra charging has been kept secret for so many years," says Jeffrey Ecclestone of London.

Not so, says the industry regulator Ofwat. In fact there's something very moral in the fact that the companies have now come clean. "The cost of surface water drainage is shared equally among households because customers have to support vulnerable, less well-off householders," says a spokesman piously. "Some areas have a lot of ground sumps and others none, so if rebates were backdated beyond last April, other customers' bills would have to go up to pay for it." The April watershed is due to Ofwat's efforts to break down water bills so householders can see where their money is going. "In April we said we wanted to see surface water drainage itemised separately so that people could apply for a rebate if they didn't use that part of the service," says our spokesman. That doesn't alter the fact that for years customers have been paying for a service they didn't use. "Ah," says Ofwat, "most people weren't even aware they were paying this charge."

Meanwhile, Trevor Jepson of York tried to obtain his rebate from Welsh Water after reading Consumer's article, but was told in a murkily-worded letter that "no reduction is allocated". Funny it forgot to mention that in April it will be obliged to offer rebates. "We gave companies a year's grace to implement the new rules and Welsh Water is one of those which has chosen to leave it till the last minute," says Ofwat. Welsh water assures Consumer that its rebate will indeed come into effect in April and that all customers will be made aware of the fact in their February bills.

Virgin's about-face

At the end of last year we reported smugly how we had persuaded Virgin Trains to change its pricing structure on the 8.33am London to Glasgow train. Alvin Cohan of London had written in to complain that the discounted tickets previously available for that service were withdrawn, sending his commuting costs soaring fourfold. Virgin blamed overcrowding, then admitted that few business travellers used that train. But what's this? A couple of months after that nice bit of PR the discounts have been sneaked away again and Cohan must pay £67 for his journey instead of £25.

Virgin says that "a significant level of business travellers" were taking advantage of the discounted service. A curious phenomenon given that this wasn't a problem when the discounts were previously available. "Unfortunately any leisure travel generated by Virgin Value sales does not compensate for the loss of business travel revenue," says a spokesman sorrowfully. "But you can still get Virgin Value first-class returns which, given it includes a full cooked breakfast, represents excellent value for money." For sure, if you can munch your way through £42-worth of bacon, which is the price difference between Cohan's past and present tickets.

SOS over Ntl

Loud have been the lamentations about Ntl's free internet service. Most from readers who were still awaiting the necessary disc five months after registering. At least Pete Bowler of Cwmbran, Wales, was warned that he'd have to wait. But then he was peeved to discover that two colleagues, who had signed up two months later than him, received theirs within a fortnight. Needless to say his disc didn't come and an hour of listening to Thin Lizzy on the Ntl helpline brought no succour. Promised return calls haven't happened and his emails have gone unanswered. So Gilly Salmon of Loughton, Essex, should rejoice in the fact that her disc turned up safe and sound after a few weeks. "It's brilliantly coloured, covered with cool words and loads up like a dream," she says ecstaticaly. "It doesn't work though. Daily I've mailed the helpline and got an automatic reply suggesting I look at their help web pages [no help] or phone the £1-a-minute helpline."

Tim Hughes also received his disc in good time. "It messed up all my computer settings and wouldn't connect to ntl's server when I dialled for help. When I rang the helpline I was told the service wasn't available in my area and never would be because I live in an ex-Cable & Wireless franchise area," he says. "This is ludicrous because they'd asked me that when I registered."

This unhappy trio are all former Cable &Wireless Communications customers who were wrongly signed up soon after CWC was acquired by Ntl, a spokeswoman explains seven weeks after Consumer gets in touch. "The networks inherited by Ntl from CWC have needed extensive upgrade work in order to bring them up to standard and the service won't be available to these customers until spring [one year after they registered]. Our website now makes clear whether a customer can currently subscribe to the service or not." So those readers still awaiting their discs should waste no time fretting. It might not work when they get it!

Eileen Groser's Ntl disc arrived four months after it had been promised and also failed to work properly. After haemorrhaging her savings on the £1-a-minute helpline she then discovered that her application hadn't been properly registered and that her pin number belonged to a Mrs Mohamed in Nottingham. Since then she has queued in vain on the automated answer service and written a letter which has not been replied to.

Ntl never does get back to us, but a few days after we get in touch an engineer does sort out Groser's problem. So much for Ntl security, though! And whatever happened to poor Mrs Mohamed?

webTitle: Demme in Line for Stephen King script

fields.headline: Demme in Line for Stephen King script
fields.trailText: The director of The Silence of the Lambs is set to direct Asylum, the first script which the horror writer has adapted from another author's work
fields.body:
Prolific horror author Stephen King (pictured) is currently writing the screen adaptation of the Patrick McGrath novel Asylum for Paramount Pictures. The studio have pencilled in Silence of the Lambs director Jonathan Demme to helm.

The Asylum gig marks the first time that King has adapted anyone else's work. In the past, the author of such horror bestsellers as The Shining, Salem's Lot and Misery has penned script treatments of his own novels, but has usually simply sold the rights and pocketed the cheque. At present there is scarcely one of King's 30-plus novels that has not undergone the movie treatment.

Published in the mid 90s, Asylum plays out at a Gothic institution outside London and tells the tale of the wife of a forensic psychiatrist who falls in love with Edgar Stark, a possibly murderous mental patient. According to the Hollywood Reporter, Paramount have cast Natasha Richardson and Liam Neeson in the two main roles, pending Demme's involvement. At present the director is still mired in the production of The Truth About Charlie, a remake of the 1963 comedy-thriller Charade.

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are looking to snog Prince William at a posh party
fields.trailText: Sunderland have been sizing up Bolton's 17-goal striker Michael Ricketts and, according to the Daily Star, are ready to offer the Nationwide contenders £7m for his services. Ricketts, 22, has made his reputation coming off the bench to score, a back-up role that may well suit Sunderland manager Peter Reid.
fields.body:
Sunderland have been sizing up Bolton's 17-goal striker Michael Ricketts and, according to the Daily Star, are ready to offer the Nationwide contenders £7m for his services. Ricketts, 22, has made his reputation coming off the bench to score, a back-up role that may well suit Sunderland manager Peter Reid.

Liverpool sent representatives to watch Cristiano Doni last weekend, according to Planet Football, sharing Manchester United's interest in the Atalanta midfielder. The 27-year-old, whose contract with the Serie A high-fliers runs out at the end of the season, has also been linked with a free transfer to Milan.

The Daily Mail reports that Internazionale have made an attempt to reclaim their on-loan striker Robbie Keane from Leeds, a move swiftly rebuffed by David O'Leary's side. The paper quotes an Inter official as saying: "Robbie Keane did not fail at Inter. He is a very talented player who simply did not get enough time on the pitch for a number of reasons." But Leeds have not been impressed by the flattery and will stick to the loan agreement which will keep Keane at the club until the end of the season. O'Leary said: "At this rate, Robbie could end up firing us into Europe this season."

Ipswich are in the process of bidding for a mystery player. "There can be no certainty there will be a new arrival but I am hopeful," chairman David Sheepshanks said. "There is no further progress at the moment because we are dealing with a very reluctant seller."

Burnley are set to offer Coventry £1m for striker John Aloisi.

fields.headline: Dickens of a haul
fields.standfirst: Prize acquisition for British Library
fields.trailText: Prize acquisition for British Library
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondant
fields.body:
On the eve of Charles Dickens' birthday, on February 7 1812, the British Library announced the acquisition of hundreds of unpublished documents from the writer's family, recording the author's frequently tortuous early dealings with his publishers.

Dickens was determined to gain both recognition and proper reward for his work, and was one of the first to fight for a share of copyright. The papers show that he received £12,000 for the serial publication of his last novel, Our Mutual Friend - a huge sum.

The documents are draft agreements and deeds, many annotated with legal queries and memos in Dickens' hand. They include his life insurance, which he extended to cover his first visit to America in 1842, which helped make him a literary star: the insurance stipulated that he must travel no further south than Charleston, South Carolina.

Curator Chris Fletcher described the archive as a vivid insight into the workings of the nineteenth century publishing world.

webTitle: Asylum seekers put liberals in deep quandary

fields.headline: Can't let them stay, can't send them back. It's a dilemma
fields.standfirst: Asylum seekers put all liberals in a deep quandary
fields.trailText: Sometimes there is no right answer, there is only better and worse. Nothing currently said or done about asylum seekers is good, though it could be worse (some European countries are far tougher on refugees).
fields.body:
Sometimes there is no right answer, there is only better and worse. Nothing currently said or done about asylum seekers is good, though it could be worse (some European countries are far tougher on refugees). Very little honesty is spoken about it: Labour's pollsters warn them it is a wicked issue with voters, Tory politicians use it wickedly. "Bogus" and "abusive" is what politicians call migrants, but bogus and abusive better describes the way most politicians talk.

Jack Straw's plan for protecting Europe from the hordes of the world's poor is starting to take shape. In Stockholm on Friday he will be among the European interior ministers debating how best to form a common EU policy. It plainly makes no sense for the French to allow a camp at Calais of would-be stowaways to Dover, refusing to take them back if Britain tries to return them, claiming they should go instead to wherever they first entered the EU - which can never be proved. Each country has its own immigration angst.

The Straw plan envisages camps set up in neighbouring third countries. Afghans fleeing the Taliban, for example, would stay in Pakistan. Pakistan would be paid by the EU or UN to run camps that would process them: those accepted as genuine refugees would then be assigned to western nations according to quota, as happened in Kosovo. The advantage for Europe is that anyone arriving by any other route could be turned round at port and sent right back to these camps. Few would risk their savings on a terrifying illegal journey only to be sent straight back to the region on arrival. At last, says Straw somewhat disingenuously, this would be a system that makes sense, since not even genuine asylum seekers can currently arrive here legally.

It sounds neat, but this is a looking-glass world where nothing is what it seems, no figures are what they pretend and the law is an ass. What we will see in Stockholm is fortress Europe tugging on the drawbridge to stop waves of migration that can only increase every year. One way or another it has to be done: if it is not done by social democratic governments with at least some semblance of decency it will be done by the Haiders and the Berlusconis far more savagely, sweeping to power on the back of this very issue.

It puts all liberals into a deep quandary. Few genuinely think there could (even should) be a totally open immigration policy into Europe, but understandably squirm at every alternative: the process of keeping the third world out will always be unpleasant and essentially racist. This is the sharp edge of the world's injustice where the faces of the poor appear on our own doorsteps. Eyeball to eyeball we push them back to a poverty only seen on television. Western human rights ideals look shabby when making nice distinctions between those in danger of persecution and those only risking starvation. But until the west converts to global egalitarianism, that is the way it is. Nasty.

Seventy-five thousand people claimed asylum last year - up from 35,000 in 1997. The backlog of old cases stands at 66,000. The government tosses figures around cavalierly - Straw was at it again in yesterday's speech - but they rarely are what they seem. For example, he said 80% of asylum seekers are refused. (The rest are the "abusive" poor).

First of all, "refused" is a term of art. The system requires applicants dumped on God-forsaken sink estates to fill out a 20-page form in English, without a lawyer, within 14 days. If they fail to do it correctly they are deemed "non-compliant" and automatically refused asylum. There are seven days to appeal on another form, in English; most fail - or not. The Home Office triumphantly declares to the press that most are refused. But that's all a technicality, they are not actually sent back. That is not the end of the story. This arbitrary cruelty is all for show. Last year only some 8,000 people were actually deported.

The fact is that almost all people who make it to these shores end up staying. It is practically impossible to send most of them back because there is no "back". Large numbers of Chinese, Filipinos and others have no documents and their embassies will not accept their nationality. (Some countries rely on the foreign money earned and sent home.) Other applicants wait so long to have their cases resolved it becomes impossible to remove them - long married with many children, settled with good jobs and employers who want to keep them. Many slip away and vanish.

Most of the world's refugees are already camped on the borders of their own countries - the poorest nations forced to cope with the great exoduses caused by war-driven famine. According to Professor Guy Gordon-Gill, Oxford professor of international refugee law, only 0.3% of global refugees ever get anywhere near the EU: only the relatively rich or remarkably resourceful make it, so we need not fear a vast expansion of numbers. Keeping more of them in camps will do nothing to stop the criminal gangs bringing in illegals from China or eastern Europe. Nor will it become any easier to return them. Many will come, many will stay. There is no final solution.

A recent UN population study predicts that in the next generation Italy will lose 28% of its population, Estonia 33% and Germany 25%. Already Europe is heavily dependent on unknown battalions of illegals who cook, clean and heave rubbish in the cities, pick and dig East Anglian fields. Illegals who disappear into the fabric of countries are no problem. The worst problems are caused by trying to contain them: for six months on vouchers they are kept in expensive, festering hell-holes, prevented from working though willing to do the worst jobs for the least pay. After that, they will make their own way and assimilate. So why bother?

The Tory plan to lock up all 75,000 migrants and asylum seekers in detention centres indefinitely defies belief. What will happen to those who are not refugees but without papers can never be sent back? Will they stay there for ever? To imprison 60,000 a year would cost £2bn to set up and £1bn in running costs. (Figures not yet in Portillo's tax-spend plan.) Even if the government processed cases faster and the Home Office's catastrophic failure of administration were put right, most migrants could probably still not be deported.

Both Jack Straw and Anne Widdecombe talk through their hat when they each propose new systems that will prevent/deter/end migration. Most asylum seekers come from the poorest most war-torn places - Somalia, Iraq, Iran and Sri Lanka. In the long run, the gradual spread of democracy and peace, solving problems at source - as in Sierra Leone - will be the only solution. How Britain can be rejecting Iraqis as genuine refugees while still bombing their dictator is unclear. But that is just another bizarre example of an impossible policy that can never be right.

fields.headline: Sharon in his own words
fields.standfirst:
'I've always been a moderate'
Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: 'I've always been a moderate'
fields.body:
Here is a selection of the thoughts of the man who, within hours, is likely to become the most powerful man in Israel and indeed the Middle East:

No one will touch Judea and Samaria [the occupied West Bank]! Or Gaza either! (Judea and Samaria) belong to us. They have been ours for thousands of years, eternally.
August 1982

I do not leave here beaten, absolutely not.
Speaking to defence ministry staff after being forced to resign, February 14 1983

Yes, I am for the expulsion of anyone who throws a stone in the occupied territories.
March 16 1988

But while the civilian deaths were a tragedy, the Kibbiya (sic) raid was also a turning point. After so many defeats and demoralising failures it was now clear that Israeli forces were again capable of finding and hitting targets far behind enemy lines.
On the commando raid he led in 1954, in which 69 civilians were killed in the Jordanian village of Qibiya, from his autobiography Warrior, published by Simon and Shuster, New York, 1989

Standing with the cabinet ministers on a high hill, I pointed out exactly what I thought was needed. If in the future we wanted in any way to control this area, I told them, we would need to establish a Jewish presence now. Otherwise we would have no motivation to be there during difficult times later on.
On his plan to move Jewish settlers into the Gaza Strip in the early 1970s, from Warrior

Like everyone who has ever experienced house-to-house fighting, I knew that in such actions there is no way to avoid civilian casualties, no matter what precautions are taken.
On the massacre of up to 2,000 Palestinians in the Beirut refugee camps of Sabra and Shatila by Phalangist paramilitaries as Israeli soldiers looked on, from Warrior

Although I was expecting a conclusion of this sort, I was outraged by the imputation of 'indirect responsibility'.
On the subsequent criticism of the Kahan commission of inquiry, from Warrior

Is the land ours? Are we completely sure we are not taking something from somebody else. Are we grabbing and stealing and laying claims to something to which we have no right? And as the doubts have thickened, the resolution and purpose have eroded.
On Israeli self doubt, from Warrior

(Jordan) is a country where most of the population is Palestinian, most members of parliament are Palestinian, most of the cabinet is Palestinian, and most of the prime ministers have been Palestinian. Jordan is in fact if not in name a Palestinian state...
On the establishment of a Palestinian state, from Warrior

Seize the hilltops.
To Jewish settlers, November 17 1998

I never accepted the Oslo agreement as it was.
January 5 2000

Jewish towns, villages and communities in Judea, Samaria [the occupied West Bank] and Gaza, as well as access roads leading to them, including sufficient security margins along them, will remain under full Israeli control.
Jerusalem Post, July 21 2000

It must be clearly understood that it wan't my visit to the Temple Mount - the holiest site for Jews and under full Israeli sovereignty - that ignited the current outbreak of violence.
On his visit in September to the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem, the Haram al-Sharif, revered by Jews as the Temple Mount, widely seen as a spark for the intifada

I had a bad experience participating in all the wars and the major battles of the state of Israel in the last 50 years. I commanded maybe the best units and formations of the Israeli army, and always in the hardest parts of the battles. And I saw the horrors and the fears of war. I saw my friend being killed. I was badly injured twice in battle, and I felt those terrible pains in hospitals. I had to take decisions of life and death, of others and of myself. And therefore I believe that I understand the importance of peace better than many of the politicians who speak about peace but never had that experience.
Maccabean online, November 14 2000

Yasser Arafat is a murderer and a liar... He's an enemy. He's a bitter enemy.

You know the Koran doesn't mention Jerusalem once ... When the Jews pray, all over the world they face the Temple Mount. When an Arab prays, he prays to Mecca. Even when an Arab is on the Mount, his back is to it. Also some of his lower parts.
On the campaign trail

We must eliminate all those who lift their hand against Jewish children, who prevent the Israeli population from living normally. I prefer not to go into details; the main point is we must eliminate terrorism and those who go after Israelis.
In an interview conducted in November and published in the New Yorker on January 29

I have opened contacts with Arab officials towards a multi-phased peace plan.
Army radio, January 22

When I talk about painful concessions, I mean that we will not reoccupy Nablus and Jericho and other places. For me, this is a very painful concession. Because all these places are the cradle of birth of the Jewish people.

We have to start with the assumption that peace is as important to the Palestinians as it is to us. Instead of our starting position being that Arafat is doing us a favour and we have to pay for peace, we have to begin with the assumption that the Palestinians need peace now less than us, and therefore, we must ask Arafat what he is prepared to give or pay in exchange for peace.
Quotes above published in an ultra-orthodox Jewish weekly, Kfar Habad in January

I've always been a moderate. There is no difference from the old Sharon. After being demonised for so many years, you had the wrong impression.
Campaigning at Tuvlan Post, West Bank, in January

I want to say something about my demonisation. After all, I am known as someone who eats Arabs for breakfast. This is baseless. People are killed in wars. But I never allowed the mistreatment of a prisoner, and I never humiliated anyone.
Yediot Ahronoth newspaper, January 19

webTitle: Israel gives up on peace with Sharon victory

fields.headline: Israel gives up on peace with Sharon victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: The newly-elected Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, will today begin the difficult task of forming a coalition government in a deeply divided political landscape.
fields.body:
The newly-elected Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, will today begin the difficult task of forming a coalition government in a deeply divided political landscape.

Israel yielded to the dark fears unleashed by a Palestinian uprising yesterday, voting by a staggering margin to entrust their future to Mr Sharon, a man famous for making war.

Amid the clatter of gunfire on a Palestinian "day of rage" in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Israelis delivered a crushing defeat to Ehud Barak, and chose a new leader in a battle-scarred warrior with a past so tainted he would only a few months ago have been deemed unelectable.

The result marked an overwhelming rejection by the Israeli people of the eight-year-old Oslo peace process.

With 99.9% of votes counted, Sharon took a historic 62.5% of the popular vote, while Mr Barak - with just 37.4% - resigned from the Israeli parliament, or Knesset, and stood down as leader of the Labour party.

Mr Sharon now has 45 days to form a coalition government to stand alongside his victorious Likud party, a task that will be made more difficult by a Labour leadership crisis.

At Labour's election headquarters, Mr Barak responded to his humiliation with his trademark cocksure style. "My friends, we have lost the battle, but we will win the war," he said. "The path we have chosen is the only right path, the path that will ultimately lead the state of Israel to peace and security."

But as yesterday's vote so amply demonstrated, Israelis have not only lost their faith in the man, but in his mission. Disappointed by a leader who swept to power 20 months ago on a promise of peace only to deliver a bloody Palestinian uprising, they decisively turned their back on negotiations - at least for now.

Mr Sharon, 72, a former general who is reviled in the Arab world as a war criminal, has vowed to hold no negotiations with the Palestinians so long as Jewish blood is shed in the four-month intifada.

He also opposes any territorial concessions - a hardline stand that could squash remaining hopes for peace in the Middle East.

But in his victory speech last night, he clung to the new, softer image adopted for this campaign. "Today, the state of Israel embarks on a new path, a path of peace and unity, striving for a new peace, peace with security," Mr Sharon told an ecstatic crowd of supporters.

At the end of the speech he displayed a flash of his more combative side, vowing "my government will act to restore security to the citizens of Israel and to achieve a real peace and stability in the area."

For Israelis that is shorthand for rejecting further compromises on territory until the uprising ends.

George Bush, the US president, delivered congratulations to the new Israeli leader last night, saying the US-Israeli relationship was "rock solid". Earlier, the US secretary of state Colin Powell had called for calm in Israel and said America would not be "standoffish" in its stance on the Middle East.

Despite the scale of his victory, Mr Sharon comes to power with the lowest mandate of any prime minister in Israeli history. Only 62% of Israel's 4.5m eligible voters bothered to go to the polls yesterday, compared to traditional election turnouts of more than 80%.

Many Arab citizens of the Jewish state boycotted the election, and their turnout was below 20%.

Mr Barak also fared badly with the left and the peace camp, who stayed at home or cast blank ballots in protest at his often brutal efforts to crush the Palestinian uprising. Their abstentions provoked the anger of the Labour elder statesman, Shimon Peres, who lambasted "the stupid, lousy left [which] gave away the leadership with its own hands, into the hands of Mussolini".

But even those two constituencies could not have saved Mr Barak from the wholesale defection of the Israeli centre to Mr Sharon. "The age of moderation in the Middle East is over," said Asher Arian, an analyst at the Israel Institute for Democracy.

Yesterday's vote took place amid stone-throwing protests across the West Bank, as Palestinian militia leaders called for an escalation of the uprising against Israel's occupation.

Despite the intensification of a blockade on Palestinian areas, gunfire forced the army to close a road linking Jerusalem to the Jewish settlement bloc of Gush Etzion. Protesters chanting "Sharon is a butcher" clashed with soldiers in Ramallah and Hebron.

For the Palestinians, Mr Sharon's victory is frightening because of his 50-year history of ruthlessly crushing Israel's enemies, and because he has said he will roll back the compromises on territory offered by Mr Barak during peace talks last month. While Mr Barak was willing to give up 95% of the West Bank to reach a peace deal, Mr Sharon is unwilling to cede a single inch of occupied territory, and has vowed to retain Israeli control over all of Jerusalem.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, made clear his determination to try and keep channels open. "We are insisting on continuing the peace process, the peace of the brave, not only on the Palestinian track but on the Middle Eastern track," he said.

Other Palestinians were less optimistic. The Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, described Mr Sharon's victory as "the most foolish event in Israel's history". A key Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, warned that Sharon's hardline views were a "recipe for war".

Mr Sharon's future course of action remains unclear, although his most urgent task is to piece together a coalition from the fragmented Knesset he inherits from Mr Barak.

In his victory speech last night, he renewed his call for a national unity government with the Labour party.

Israel yielded to the dark fears unleashed by a Palestinian uprising yesterday, voting by a staggering margin to entrust their future to Mr Sharon, a man famous for making war. Amid the clatter of gunfire on a Palestinian "day of rage" in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Israelis delivered a crushing defeat to Ehud Barak, and chose a new leader in a battle-scarred warrior with a past so tainted he would only a few months ago have been deemed unelectable. The result marked an overwhelming rejection by the Israeli people of the eight-year-old Oslo peace process. With 99.9% of votes counted, Sharon took a historic 62.5% of the popular vote, while Mr Barak - with just 37.4% - resigned from the Israeli parliament, or Knesset, and stood down as leader of the Labour party. Mr Sharon now has 45 days to form a coalition government to stand alongside his victorious Likud party, a task that will be made more difficult by a Labour leadership crisis. At Labour's election headquarters, Mr Barak responded to his humiliation with his trademark cocksure style. "My friends, we have lost the battle, but we will win the war," he said. "The path we have chosen is the only right path, the path that will ultimately lead the state of Israel to peace and security." But as yesterday's vote so amply demonstrated, Israelis have not only lost their faith in the man, but in his mission. Disappointed by a leader who swept to power 20 months ago on a promise of peace only to deliver a bloody Palestinian uprising, they decisively turned their back on negotiations - at least for now. Mr Sharon, 72, a former general who is reviled in the Arab world as a war criminal, has vowed to hold no negotiations with the Palestinians so long as Jewish blood is shed in the four-month intifada. He also opposes any territorial concessions - a hardline stand that could squash remaining hopes for peace in the Middle East. But in his victory speech last night, he clung to the new, softer image adopted for this campaign. "Today, the state of Israel embarks on a new path, a path of peace and unity, striving for a new peace, peace with security," Mr Sharon told an ecstatic crowd of supporters. At the end of the speech he displayed a flash of his more combative side, vowing "my government will act to restore security to the citizens of Israel and to achieve a real peace and stability in the area." For Israelis that is shorthand for rejecting further compromises on territory until the uprising ends. George Bush, the US president, delivered congratulations to the new Israeli leader last night, saying the US-Israeli relationship was "rock solid". Earlier, the US secretary of state Colin Powell had called for calm in Israel and said America would not be "standoffish" in its stance on the Middle East. Despite the scale of his victory, Mr Sharon comes to power with the lowest mandate of any prime minister in Israeli history. Only 62% of Israel's 4.5m eligible voters bothered to go to the polls yesterday, compared to traditional election turnouts of more than 80%. Many Arab citizens of the Jewish state boycotted the election, and their turnout was below 20%. Mr Barak also fared badly with the left and the peace camp, who stayed at home or cast blank ballots in protest at his often brutal efforts to crush the Palestinian uprising. Their abstentions provoked the anger of the Labour elder statesman, Shimon Peres, who lambasted "the stupid, lousy left [which] gave away the leadership with its own hands, into the hands of Mussolini". But even those two constituencies could not have saved Mr Barak from the wholesale defection of the Israeli centre to Mr Sharon. "The age of moderation in the Middle East is over," said Asher Arian, an analyst at the Israel Institute for Democracy. Yesterday's vote took place amid stone-throwing protests across the West Bank, as Palestinian militia leaders called for an escalation of the uprising against Israel's occupation. Despite the intensification of a blockade on Palestinian areas, gunfire forced the army to close a road linking Jerusalem to the Jewish settlement bloc of Gush Etzion. Protesters chanting "Sharon is a butcher" clashed with soldiers in Ramallah and Hebron. For the Palestinians, Mr Sharon's victory is frightening because of his 50-year history of ruthlessly crushing Israel's enemies, and because he has said he will roll back the compromises on territory offered by Mr Barak during peace talks last month. While Mr Barak was willing to give up 95% of the West Bank to reach a peace deal, Mr Sharon is unwilling to cede a single inch of occupied territory, and has vowed to retain Israeli control over all of Jerusalem. The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, made clear his determination to try and keep channels open. "We are insisting on continuing the peace process, the peace of the brave, not only on the Palestinian track but on the Middle Eastern track," he said. Other Palestinians were less optimistic. The Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, described Mr Sharon's victory as "the most foolish event in Israel's history". A key Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, warned that Sharon's hardline views were a "recipe for war". Mr Sharon's future course of action remains unclear, although his most urgent task is to piece together a coalition from the fragmented Knesset he inherits from Mr Barak. In his victory speech last night, he renewed his call for a national unity government with the Labour party. fields.headline: Despair as usual for Palestinians
fields.standfirst:
As hardline right winger Ariel Sharon prepares to take the helm in Israel, Katharine Viner gauges the Palestinian reaction

Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: As hardline right winger Ariel Sharon prepares to take the helm in Israel, Katharine Viner gauges the Palestinian reaction.
fields.body:
At the end of September 1982, the French writer Jean Genet entered Shatila, the Palestinian refugee camp in west Beirut. He spent four hours there. "A photograph doesn't show the flies nor the thick white smell of death," he wrote.

"It does not show how you must jump over bodies as you walk along from one corpse to the next."

Estimates vary as to how many were murdered at the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps because there are two mass graves in Beirut which have never been exhumed. The usual reckoning is up to 2,000, overwhelmingly old men, women and children.

But there is no confusion about who was responsible for the massacres. Israel's very own internal inquiry, the Kahan commission, stated that Ariel Sharon, then defence minister, bore "personal responsibility" for the atrocities inside the camps.

The Christian fascist Phalange militia had carried out the murders while Sharon and his men guarded the entrances and provided flares to give enough light to kill by.

That a state so often cited as an oasis of democracy in the Middle East should elect a war criminal as prime minister is shocking enough.

That up to a million Israelis protested at Sharon's behaviour at the time - he was described as "an enemy of the people" and "worse than evil" in the Knesset and the action against him was the largest protest demonstration in Israel's history - shows the depths to which the 34-year-old occupation has taken Israeli society.

There is little doubt that Sharon's election will mean more aggressive treatment of the Palestinians; the settlers' favourite, the man who once urged fellow right wing fanatics to "run, grab hills", is unlikely to grant a Palestinian state or allow freedom or equality or other such radical notions.

So why do so many Palestinians see Sharon's election as more of the same? Why are they not so alarmed as Western observers expect them to be?

The answer is encapsulated in one word: despair. While their leaders were shaking hands on White House lawns, promising compromise and solution and common ground, the real situation for Palestinians was getting worse.

The liberal West might have jumped for joy at the landslide election of Labour's Ehud Barak, but what was happening on the ground? Settlers were snatching away the West Bank; the closure policy meant that movement between cities became impossible; Palestinian GNP fell by 35% after the start of the Oslo peace process.

So while the West was patting its back for solving the Palestinian problem, Palestinians themselves were getting poorer, and angrier. And all the while it was a Labour government in charge.

The Israeli election of a war criminal, known as the "butcher of Beirut" throughout the Arab world, may be a sign of a desperate Israel. But it is the people occupied by Israel who will suffer most.

fields.headline: Granada bounces back
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Granada, the recently relisted media group, made a rare appearance on the FTSE 100 leaderboard yesterday, writes Neil Hume.
fields.body:
Granada, the recently relisted media group, made a rare appearance on the FTSE 100 leaderboard yesterday as analysts decided that recent falls had been overdone.

Before yesterday's rise of 9.25p to 195.5p, Granada shares had slipped 23.25p in the two sessions following the complex relisting as investors, unsettled by its exposure to the weak advertising climate at ITV, baled out.

Yesterday the rot stopped. CSFB repeated its "buy" stance, arguing that even if February ITV advertising is poor (pundits expect it to be down 4-8% year on year) that is already reflected in its shares. Analysts at UBS Warburg were said to be recommending a switch from rival Carlton into Granada, to take advantage of the relative weakness of its share price.

Granada is scheduled to update investors on current trading at its annual general meeting today.

webTitle: Cruise, Kidman head for the courts

fields.headline: Cruise, Kidman head for the courts
fields.trailText: Experts predict that the divorce settlement between two of the world's biggest film stars will be the costliest in Hollywood history
fields.body:
After the civilised announcement of their split, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman will now head for the courts for what experts are predicting will be the costliest divorce in Hollywood history. At stake is an estate conservatively valued at some $450m (£308m). Whatever the final sum arrived at, Kidman's settlement looks set to dwarf the previous record sum of $110m (£75m) paid by Steven Spielberg to Amy Irving in the late 1980s.

Legal experts are today wondering where Cruise will elect to settle the divorce. California law stipulates that divorcing couples must split their estate fifty-fifty regardless of the reasons behind the split. But Cruise could elect to file divorce proceedings in Colorado, where the law is different. Cruise and Kidman, who married in Colorado in 1990, own a lavish mountainside home in the state. In addition to their mountain retreat, the couple own a home in Hollywood, an estate in Sydney, a Manhattan apartment, a villa in Monte Carlo and (most bizarrely) a home in Dulwich in south London. All of these are now up for grabs, but the real bone of contention may prove to be the custody of the couple's adoptive children Isabella and Connor.

In the meantime the media's autopsy of the break-up continues to gather pace, with many tabloids fingering Cruise's Vanilla Sky co-star Penelope Cruz as a possible cause. Yesterday, Cruz, star of All About My Mother and the upcoming All The Pretty Horses, hit back at the rumours. "I did not break up Tom Cruise's marriage," the Madrid-born actress told reporters. "I am not having an affair with Tom Cruise. I am just one of his leading ladies in a film. He is a very nice actor, that's all."

fields.headline: Britney to front global Pepsi campaign
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Pepsi has signed up teen pop sensation Britney Spears in a multi-million dollar advertising deal, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Pepsi is hoping to recreate the massive success of its 1980s link-up with Michael Jackson by signing up teen pop sensation Britney Spears in a multi-million dollar advertising deal.

The deal, announced last night in the US, is one of the biggest ever signed by Pepsi and is being compared to Nike's $100m sponsorship deal with golf star Tiger Woods.

It puts Spears in the same league as Jackson, who starred in the 1984 "Pepsi - the choice of a generation" campaign.

The 19-year-old pop icon, famed for hits such as Oops! I Did It Again and Baby One More Time, will appear in a global campaign for Pepsi.

Her tour will be sponsored by the soft-drinks company.

Terms of the deal were not disclosed but Pepsi is almost certainly paying out at least $50m to use Spears.

"Britney is on the cutting edge of contemporary popular entertainment," said Dawn Hudson, Pepsi's senior vice-president of strategy and marketing.

"She's youthful, inventive, optimistic and fun-loving - the ultimate fit with the Pepsi brand.

"Our relationship will resonate in every corner of the market."

The deal, brokered by the Los Angeles music marketing agency Aaron Walton Entertainment, also covers point-of-sale material, consumer promotions and internet links.

The first Britney ad for Pepsi is being put together by the company's ad agency, BBDO Worldwide, and is expected to premiere during the Oscars on March 25.
