fields.headline: Original sin
fields.standfirst: For such a small population, Ireland has a dazzling wealth of world-class playwrights. Is it all down to violence and Catholic guilt?
fields.trailText: For such a small population, Ireland has a dazzling wealth of world-class playwrights. Is it all down to violence and Catholic guilt?
fields.body:
Joe Penhall is one of the greatest writers working today. So when I was asked to direct a reading of his play Blue/Orange in Ireland recently, I felt both privileged and scared. Joe came over and sat in on the rehearsals and the reading. Afterwards he said to me that it was the first time he had actually heard the play in ages. We used Irish and British actors but the sense of our production seemed very different from the London one.

Naturally I was glad that I had delivered the goods, but I was also intrigued by the cultural differences that made the production so different in Ireland. Joe seemed impressed by the actors' ability to mine the emotional depths in the play, which revolves around a young black man detained in a British psychiatric hospital. Their performances were personal and owned by them. They trusted what they were doing and their confidence allowed them a freedom to express what many people feel fundamentally - loneliness, a need to be loved and a need to feel safe.

These were the things I felt were important in the play. I'm not British, I'm from Dublin, so the collapse of the NHS isn't as important to me as it is for sick people in the UK. And I began to think about what it is that makes Irish plays so different from English ones.

In a densely populated placed like London space is precious. People squeezed together on the tube breast to breast pretend they're not really there. But if you were to walk down a deserted shoreline and saw a figure in the distance, as they came closer to you you'd probably acknowledge them. A nod or a hello.

Ireland is less populated. It's easy to avoid other people. Irish plays tend to explore the inner workings of the human being, how it feels to be alive and the difficulty we have communicating our feelings. British plays veer more towards journalism: "Look at the state of the NHS/British socialism/ what Thatcher did/drugs among our youth/Aids/power struggles in the home/the police/my flat/London, etc."

And I began to think about why a small country such as Ireland has produced more great playwrights than so many more populated countries. It's extraordinary. There are fewer than 4m people in the Republic of Ireland. But in the past century we've produced Synge, O'Casey, Shaw, Wilde, Joyce, Beckett, Friel, Tom Murphy, Billy Roche,Sebastian Barry, to name a few. Their plays have shaped the way people think and are performed all over the world. Why the disproportion?

Although some of the above were Protestants, I think it has something to do with growing up in a predominantly Catholic culture.

When I started school at the age of four, I was educated to believe that I was a bad person. I was told I'd be lucky if God forgave me. Every week I was made to confess to a priest. Until I was nine, corporal punishment was legal. I grew up in a working-class area and the same teachers who taught us religion also physically attacked us.

As a kid I became used to being hit by an adult every day. Some used their hands, some sticks of wood. I remember the exhaustion in a teacher's face after he'd lined up the whole class and beaten each one because we were talking to each other while he left the room. I was eight at the time.

If this constant reinforcement of your badness and guilt happens to you at such a vulnerable age, it seems to me inevitable that you are going to start thinking about the quality of your character. Am I a good person? And that starts you thinking about character in general. About characters.

The storytelling tradition in Ireland is still very strong. Stories allow the listener to go through experiences virtually, without having to face the consequences. You identify with the character: "What if I did that? How would I feel? How would I cope?" And I suppose in a way it's therapeutic. It's helpful.

And I suppose that's the difference between English and Irish plays. Protestants are told they're free to protest. So you have so many playwrights who argue that their work has a political validity - Pinter, Hare, Brenton, Edgar, Wesker, etc - whereas Irish writers are mostly a bit scared. If there's a message, it's a simple one: "I know you're afraid of dying alone in a ditch. I am too. Let's be together." And maybe that's why Irish plays have a universal popularity. Because we all die alone. And we've been told that since we were babies. And it was beaten into us.

fields.headline: Vivendi buys Uproar for £96.6m
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Vivendi Universal has boosted its online gaming portfolio through the acquisition of Uproar, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
French media giant Vivendi Universal has boosted its online gaming portfolio through the acquisition of Uproar for £96.6m in cash.

Uproar, one of the first internet-based gaming companies, will be incorporated into Flipside.com, Vivendi's games and entertainment website, giving Vivendi a leadership position in this market.

The combined entity will reach 14.7m people in the US alone, ranking it the 16th most popular website in terms of traffic, based on Media Metrix data from December.

Vivendi chief executive officer Agnes Touraine said the deal would have immediate benefits for both parties.

"Current market conditions have made it possible for us to make this strategic acquisition to give us a worldwide leadership position in a key content category," she said.

"The combined company will create immediate value for the shareholders of Vivendi Universal and Uproar."

Flipside.com offers free access to more than 40 games.

These range from family entertainment games to action and simulation CD-Rom titles.

Uproar, which is available in 14 different languages, operates similar family-oriented games as well as a lottery website.

Kenneth Cron, chairman and chief executive of Uproar, will become chief executive of the merged company.

Vivendi Universal is pulling out of BSkyB.

Its decision follows an EU watchdog ruling that stated it had to sell its 22.7% stake in BSkyB to comply with EU requirements to complete its merger with Canada's Seagram.

webTitle: Emap ponders sale of US operations

fields.headline: Emap ponders sale of US operations
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Magazine and radio group Emap admitted last night it would consider selling its US publishing business, reports David Teather.
fields.body:
Emap, the magazines and radio group, admitted last night that it would consider the sale of its US publishing business but played down speculation about an imminent disposal.

Shares in the company, which publishes titles including FHM, Empire and Q, climbed nearly 5% to 855p following publication of a research note from influential investment bank Goldman Sachs which hinted that the US arm could be set for divestment.

The note was the second within days to light on the possibility of a radical reshaping of Emap. It followed a similar note from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney at the end of last week which also suggested the group would benefit from the sale of Emap USA and its business magazines division to create a purer consumer-led group. The US business has been valued at around £450m.

Kevin Hand, Emap's chief executive, said: "The purchase of Petersen in the US has gone a little slower than we would have liked and therefore we are working really hard to make up that ground, and that is our intent. But if we cannot see a way forward then of course we have no intention of publishing purely for vanity. We are not going to be in there at all costs."

Mr Hand said the company was not actively seeking buyers for the US business; Emap was under no pressure to sell. The same, he said, was true of the company's business magazines division, which was first rumoured to be for sale at the end of last year. The business magazines have been valued at £750m.

He said the company had set no deadline for turnaround. "We are running both businesses as we run all of our businesses all of the time which means keeping options open."

Speculation of a shake up at Emap has gathered pace due to the arrival of finance director Gary Hughes four months ago who is taking a hard look at the group's portfolio. Emap has high levels of debt.

fields.headline: Man Utd hits Yankee jackpot
fields.standfirst: 'Super club' tie-up with top baseball team expands global dominance
fields.trailText:
Manchester United is to sign deal to become a 'super club' with the New York Yankees baseball team, writes Daniel Taylor.
Feb 6: Man Utd to brand Beckham
fields.body:
Manchester United will capture another slice of the sporting globe today by signing a revolutionary deal to become a "super club" with the New York Yankees baseball team, in an agreement which is potentially worth tens of millions of pounds.

An official announcement will be made in New York today. United's chief executive Peter Kenyon and Sir Bobby Charlton have travelled to the US to finalise a package which the Premiership champions confidently expect will consolidate their status as the world's richest football club.

The Yankees' owner, YankeeNets, also owns the New Jersey Nets basketball team and New Jersey Devils ice hockey club and it signed a commercial tie-up in December with the beaten Super Bowl finalists the New York Giants.

The plan is to form a "super club" which will be able to package itself to potential sponsors and television networks and, on a more basic level, increase merchandise sales by stocking one another's souvenirs and kits.

Neither Kenyon nor the YankeeNets chairman Harvey Schiller was willing to comment last night but it is understood that the next step will be to invite others such as Juventus, Real Madrid, Barcelona and Bayern Munich into the fold.

The Yankees are one of the few sports teams in the world who have the financial muscle to negotiate on the same plateau as United. They were valued recently at around £400m and, though that figure is less than half United's current worth, their financial potential may be even bigger. They have become known as "America's team" after winning three of the last four World Series and a record 26 overall, and there is no more famous sporting name or brand in the US.

The key difference with United is that rather than being a public limited company the Yankees are owned by George Steinbrenner, one of the more notorious characters in US sport because of his infamous short fuse and habit of making impulsive decisions.

United are understood to be disappointed that details of the agreement have been leaked before they could prepare an official announcement, and there are obvious concerns that they will face accusations from supporters of becoming even further detached from their roots.

"United have been accused before of trying to make a quick buck, and now they literally will be," said Oliver Houston of the Shareholders United pressure group. "We are going yet further down the road where the nation's premier sport is guilty of Americanisation and over-commercialism."

Nevertheless, in an industry where money is king, the Old Trafford hierarchy believe they have pulled off another massive coup after their recent agreement of a 13-year kit sponsorship deal with Nike worth £302.9m.

fields.headline: Gap hires first three-brand marketing chief
fields.trailText: 10am: Gap Inc has appointed its first marketing head to oversee Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Gap Inc has appointed its first ever marketing chief to oversee Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy.

The move leaves the three brands without individual marketing heads.

Amy Schoening, 42, has been promoted to the position of chief marketing officer.

She was previously executive vice-president of marketing for the Banana Republic stores.

But last year, Ms Schoening stepped in to help turn around sales for the under-performing Gap chain.

She took the unusal step of going outside the company's in-house advertising teams.

She hired Boston-based ad agency Modernista on a project basis to create the Christmas and spring campaigns.

In her new role, Ms Schoening will report directly to Gap Inc president and CEO Millard Drexler.

Her promotion leaves Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy without individual marketing chiefs.

However, the company is believed to be recruiting to fill the vacancies.

The new marketing directors will continue to report to the presidents of the separate brands.

However, a "dotted line" will be established to Ms Schoening.

The retailer's in-house advertising units will not be consolidated or disbanded.

Ms Schoening joined Banana Republic five years ago from her job as account executive at San Francisco ad agency Foote, Cone & Belding.

Before that, she had worked at Levi Strauss & Co.

webTitle: 'Today the state of Israel has embarked on a new path'

fields.headline: 'Today the state of Israel has embarked on a new path'
fields.standfirst:
The full text of Ariel Sharon's victory speech

Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Good evening, and a wonderful evening to all of you. My friends, Silvan Shalom, chairman of my headquarters, and Reuven Rivlin, chairman of the Parliamentary Party -- the faction, all members of Knesset, from this large camp who are sitting here, people from the Likud and all the other parties: MK Eli Yishai, and MK Natan Sharansky, MK Avigdor Liberman, MK Itzak Levy, Rabbi Menachem Porush and Rabbi Meir Porush, two generations. Michael Kleiner, my friend for many years, David Levy, and mayor of Jerusalem, Ehud Olmert. Together with you we have reached this wonderful point, and made this marvellous achievement.
fields.body:
Good evening, and a wonderful evening to all of you. My friends, Silvan Shalom, chairman of my headquarters, and Reuven Rivlin, chairman of the Parliamentary Party -- the faction, all members of Knesset, from this large camp who are sitting here, people from the Likud and all the other parties: MK Eli Yishai, and MK Natan Sharansky, MK Avigdor Liberman, MK Itzak Levy, Rabbi Menachem Porush and Rabbi Meir Porush, two generations. Michael Kleiner, my friend for many years, David Levy, and mayor of Jerusalem, Ehud Olmert. Together with you we have reached this wonderful point, and made this marvellous achievement.

I want to say that a few moments before I came into the hall, when I was already in the building, the president of the United States, President Bush, called me, and asked me to present his best wishes to you. He told me that they want to cooperate very closely with the government under my leadership.

And he reminded me of the trip I took with him through Samaria and the Jordan Valley. And at that time, he said to me, "No one believed then," he said, "that I would be president and you would be prime minister. But as things turned out, despite the fact that no one believed us," he said, "I have been elected president, and you have been elected prime minister."

Citizens of Israel, my colleagues from various parties, today the state of Israel has embarked on a new path, a path of domestic unity and harmony, of striving for security and a real genuine peace.

I would like to thank every single one of you for your support, for your involvement, for your devotion, for your hard work. It's as a result of your work and this great confidence that you have shown in me and the thousands and thousands of individual activists throughout Israel that we have achieved this great victory. We have achieved this moment, and we thank you from the bottom of our heart.

This night is a very moving night. It's one of great significance for me.

From the very earliest days, I have entirely devoted myself to the country to consolidating its security and building it up. In all of my possessions, in all moments, whether hard or happy, I was accompanied by my dear wife, Lily, who supported me wholeheartedly. At this moment, when the Israeli people have expressed their confidence in me to lead the country in the next few years, Lily is not with me anymore, and I miss her. She's not with me here.

I want, this evening, to thank every single one of Israel's citizens who have expressed their confidence in me. I shall do everything in order to succeed in this mission that you have consigned to me.

This is the state of all of us, and all of us have a joint future and a single destiny. In the course of the years, divisions, incisions in our people and society have proliferated. Baseless hatred and fury have multiplied. The time now has come to seek for as wide-based unity and agreement as possible. There is a deep-felt desire among the people to stand firmly together in dealing with the challenges of the future. I call now for the establishment of as wide a government of national unity as possible.

And I here turn to the Labour Party and call upon it to join us in a partnership in pursuing the difficult path towards security and peace.

Citizens of Israel, today you have called upon me to lead you as prime minister of Israel, and to succeed in the mission you have conferred upon me. I shall, to do this, need the confidence of the Knesset, and the maximum support of its members. We live in a parliamentary system in which the government functions on the basis of a parliamentary majority.

As prime minister, I will act responsibly and with respect to the parliament, to the Knesset, and with regard to all members of the house. The government, under my leadership, will act to implement the rule of law, and to maintain the independence of the judicial system, which is one of the pillars of maintaining a democratic system.

Citizens of Israel, the government, under my leadership, will act to restore security to the citizens of Israel, and to achieve a genuine peace and stability in the area.

I'm aware of the fact that peace requires painful compromises by both sides. Any and every political arrangement will be based on security for all peoples of the region. I call upon our Palestinian neighbours to cast off the path of violence and to return to the path of dialogue and solving the conflicts between us by peaceful means.

The government, under my leadership, will act to achieve genuine political settlements that will preserve the existential and historic needs of Israel, which will be based on mutual respect and mutual security.

We shall act to achieve more profound reciprocal relationships with our great friend and our ally the United States. And we shall strive to achieve closer ties between the state of Israel and the countries of the world.

In Israeli society, there are many areas of distress with which I am familiar. We will do everything we can to wipe these out. A people cannot exist if there is no social solidarity. We shall act to reduce the social gaps and to achieve equality of opportunity to everybody.

We will turn over a new leaf in our relationships with our Israeli Arab citizens in order to achieve a genuine partnership and a feeling of equality between all citizens of the country.

The government, under my leadership, will fly the social flag side-by-side with the flag of security and peace, and we will be greatly supporting the value of education.

And above both flags, there will be the flag of Zionism, the flag of national honour, immigration and settlement. The government, which I shall set up will strive to strengthen and consolidate united Jerusalem, the capital of Israel, and the eternal capital of the Jewish people; to which we always turn, saying, "If I forget thee, oh Jerusalem, may my right hand forget it's coming. May my tongue cleave to the roof of my mouth if I do not remember you, if I do not make Jerusalem the chief of my joys."

The government, under my leadership, will act to achieve constant economic growth, and in this way, we will create new employment possibilities and reduce unemployment. We will maintain price stability and prevent inflation.

We will ensure that we act responsibly in the economic area, without increasing any deficit. And at the same time, we will invest in infrastructure and education. We will reduce the tax burdens on Israeli citizens. We will maintain the principles of a modern, open economy, based on competition and integration in the world economy.

To achieve these goals, it is my intention to establish an economic cabinet, which I shall head.

Citizens of Israel, we have a small country which is blessed with taieved greatly. Let us join forces as one single body, with one single heart, setting out on a new path. Together, we will be ready to face all the challenges confronting us. Together, we will be able to realise all of our hopes and our dreams. Thank you.

But as things turned out, despite the fact that no one believed us," he said, "I have been elected president, and you have been elected prime minister." Citizens of Israel, my colleagues from various parties, today the state of Israel has embarked on a new path, a path of domestic unity and harmony, of striving for security and a real genuine peace. I would like to thank every single one of you for your support, for your involvement, for your devotion, for your hard work. It's as a result of your work and this great confidence that you have shown in me and the thousands and thousands of individual activists throughout Israel that we have achieved this great victory. We have achieved this moment, and we thank you from the bottom of our heart. This night is a very moving night. It's one of great significance for me. From the very earliest days, I have entirely devoted myself to the country to consolidating its security and building it up. In all of my possessions, in all moments, whether hard or happy, I was accompanied by my dear wife, Lily, who supported me wholeheartedly. At this moment, when the Israeli people have expressed their confidence in me to lead the country in the next few years, Lily is not with me anymore, and I miss her. She's not with me here. I want, this evening, to thank every single one of Israel's citizens who have expressed their confidence in me. I shall do everything in order to succeed in this mission that you have consigned to me. This is the state of all of us, and all of us have a joint future and a single destiny. In the course of the years, divisions, incisions in our people and society have proliferated. Baseless hatred and fury have multiplied. The time now has come to seek for as wide-based unity and agreement as possible. There is a deep-felt desire among the people to stand firmly together in dealing with the challenges of the future. I call now for the establishment of as wide a government of national unity as possible. And I here turn to the Labour Party and call upon it to join us in a partnership in pursuing the difficult path towards security and peace. Citizens of Israel, today you have called upon me to lead you as prime minister of Israel, and to succeed in the mission you have conferred upon me. I shall, to do this, need the confidence of the Knesset, and the maximum support of its members. We live in a parliamentary system in which the government functions on the basis of a parliamentary majority. As prime minister, I will act responsibly and with respect to the parliament, to the Knesset, and with regard to all members of the house. The government, under my leadership, will act to implement the rule of law, and to maintain the independence of the judicial system, which is one of the pillars of maintaining a democratic system. Citizens of Israel, the government, under my leadership, will act to restore security to the citizens of Israel, and to achieve a genuine peace and stability in the area. I'm aware of the fact that peace requires painful compromises by both sides. Any and every political arrangement will be based on security for all peoples of the region. I call upon our Palestinian neighbours to cast off the path of violence and to return to the path of dialogue and solving the conflicts between us by peaceful means. The government, under my leadership, will act to achieve genuine political settlements that will preserve the existential and historic needs of Israel, which will be based on mutual respect and mutual security. We shall act to achieve more profound reciprocal relationships with our great friend and our ally the United States. And we shall strive to achieve closer ties between the state of Israel and the countries of the world. In Israeli society, there are many areas of distress with which I am familiar. We will do everything we can to wipe these out. A people cannot exist if there is no social solidarity. We shall act to reduce the social gaps and to achieve equality of opportunity to everybody. We will turn over a new leaf in our relationships with our Israeli Arab citizens in order to achieve a genuine partnership and a feeling of equality between all citizens of the country. The government, under my leadership, will fly the social flag side-by-side with the flag of security and peace, and we will be greatly supporting the value of education. And above both flags, there will be the flag of Zionism, the flag of national honour, immigration and settlement. The government, which I shall set up will strive to strengthen and consolidate united Jerusalem, the capital of Israel, and the eternal capital of the Jewish people; to which we always turn, saying, "If I forget thee, oh Jerusalem, may my right hand forget it's coming. May my tongue cleave to the roof of my mouth if I do not remember you, if I do not make Jerusalem the chief of my joys." The government, under my leadership, will act to achieve constant economic growth, and in this way, we will create new employment possibilities and reduce unemployment. We will maintain price stability and prevent inflation. We will ensure that we act responsibly in the economic area, without increasing any deficit. And at the same time, we will invest in infrastructure and education. We will reduce the tax burdens on Israeli citizens. We will maintain the principles of a modern, open economy, based on competition and integration in the world economy. To achieve these goals, it is my intention to establish an economic cabinet, which I shall head. Citizens of Israel, we have a small country which is blessed with taieved greatly. Let us join forces as one single body, with one single heart, setting out on a new path. Together, we will be ready to face all the challenges confronting us. Together, we will be able to realise all of our hopes and our dreams. Thank you. webTitle: Murdoch on verge of Sky global float

fields.headline: Murdoch on verge of Sky global float
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Rupert Murdoch is set to pull off the £40bn acquisition of DirecTV, paving the way for the long-awaited flotation of Sky Global Networks, writes Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch is set to pull off the £40bn acquisition of DirecTV, paving the way for the long-awaited flotation of Sky Global Networks.

Investors are eagerly anticipating an announcement at 2pm London time, when News Corporation posts its second quarter results.

Speculation of a deal mounted following overnight reports that the mammoth merger had been agreed in principle.

In what would be the biggest deal of his career, the chairman of News Corporation is expected to confirm the acquisition of the US satellite TV company DirecTV.

It is expected that Sky Global Networks will merge with DirecTV's parent company Hughes Electrics, and Mr Murdoch will share ownership of the enlarged group with Hughes owner General Motors.

Sky Global, which is formed by News Corporation's satellite TV interests and includes BSkyB and Asian broadcaster Star TV, will initially form 35% of the new company, with Hughes shareholders controlling the rest.

However, Hughes shareholders will then exit over time, leaving News Corporation as the largest single shareholder and controller of the world's largest satellite TV company.

Mr Murdoch has long considered DirecTV as the potential jewel in the crown of Sky Global, with its 10m subscribers offering a strong US presence to the company.

A bullish News Corporation said it would float the company with or without DirecTV, but the financial markets would have balked at investing in a global media player which did not have a US footprint.

As late as last week, it was feared that GM would scupper the complex deal, with the automotive giant saying it was talking to several interested parties.

News Corporation insiders dismissed GM's claims as an attempt to push up the price of the deal.

webTitle: Leader: Prison reform starts with Jack Straw

fields.headline: Improving the hell holes
fields.standfirst: Prison reform starts with Jack Straw
fields.trailText: No prison director in living memory has been as blunt. In language even harsher than penal reformers use, Martin Narey condemned his own service for "a litany of failure and moral neglect" in a remarkably bold address to its annual conference this week.
fields.body:
No prison director in living memory has been as blunt. In language even harsher than penal reformers use, Martin Narey condemned his own service for "a litany of failure and moral neglect" in a remarkably bold address to its annual conference this week. He described some of the 136 prisons under his command as "hell holes", where inmates were denied dignity and treated as "a sub species". He went on: "I am not prepared to continue to apologise for failing prison after failing prison. I've had enough of trying to explain the very immorality of our treatment of some prisoners and the degradation of some establishments."

If there was any doubt within the institutions that their director was committed to change, there could be no doubt by the end. He openly declared that unless he won the support of managers and staff, he would seek "an easier way of earning a living". He explained: "The only reason, the only justification for my doing this job, the only thing that can make it remotely worthwhile, is a passionate belief that the apologies and the abject explanations will no longer be necessary."

Some progress - even in hell holes - has been made. The director rightly pointed out that lack of cash and excessive overcrowding have been used in the past to excuse the inexcusable. There is no excuse for filthy unclean prisons or refusing to treat inmates with respect. Neither costs much money. As last week's G2 prison series documented, private prisons helped shame the public into introducing more respect for inmates.

Yesterday, the director's indictment received the endorsement of Jack Straw, opening a rare opportunity for radical reform. The home secretary was unequivocal: "I entirely agree with him." Mr Straw went on to spell out what was needed to make such closed institutions more accountable: substantial external pressure to raise standards; tough inspection; and a good director general.

So the ball is now in the home secretary's court. There is one way he could reassure penal reformers that "substantial external pressure" and "tough inspection" will continue: the reappointment, as the chief inspector for prisons, of Sir David Ramsbotham. Mr Straw rightly paid tribute to the "excellent work" of Sir David yesterday. He has been unremitting in his pressure for reform and deservedly earned a reputation as an inspiring leader of the team of prison inspectors. He has also established a good working relationship with the director general, so what more effective duo could there be pressing for change? Yet, true to an unworthy Whitehall tradition, Sir David has been denied a second term. Senior mandarins - and seemingly ministers - still regard the robust independence, which the chief inspector has demonstrated, as a threat, rather than a trait that should be encouraged. This is their weakness, not his. Mr Straw should invite Sir David to accept a second term.

There were two important issues which Mr Narey ignored. The first was last week's call from the lord chief justice - supported by the chief inspector - for fewer people to be sent to prison. This could be excused on the grounds that it is "too political" in the run-up to an election. But the second falls directly within his remit: prison governors' complaints about an oppressive climate and the role of his deputy, Phil Wheatley. A government which is intent on eliminating bullying in schools, should be equally ruthless in eliminating it from the ranks of its administration. It is not just inmates who need respect; prison governors too require it.

webTitle: End of road for humiliated Barak

fields.headline: End of road for humiliated Barak
fields.standfirst:
Labour leader announces his resignation as party reels at scale of defeat
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Labour leader announces his resignation as party reels at scale of defeat.
fields.body:
Convinced of his mission to the bitter end, Ehud Barak resigned as leader of his Labour party last night after suffering the most humiliating election defeat in Israel's history.

In his concession speech after last night's double-digit loss to the hardliner Ariel Sharon, Mr Barak was adamant that his kamikaze course remained the right one for Israel, and for a party that was furious at his leadership.

"I believe one day we will come back because our path is the only path," Mr Barak told a small band of loyalists at party headquarters last night. "It is the right path, it is the true path, and ultimately the truth will win."

A small band of loyalists chanted "stay, stay", but Mr Barak's resignation from the Israeli parliament, or Knesset, and from the party leadership will not be widely mourned.

Mr Barak's exit last night marks an astonishing finish to his prime ministership. After sweeping to power in a landslide victory in May 1999, he alienated his coalition allies by his arrogant style, and frittered away the goodwill of Israeli voters with a bewildering number of policy shifts.

Despite his zig-zag approach to the peace process, and to the four-month Palestinian uprising, Mr Barak last night appeared oblivious to his errors.

"My friends, we have lost the battle, but we will win the war," he said. "Accepting the will of the electorate does not undermine our confidence in the rightness of our path."

He added: "Perhaps the public is not prepared to accept the painful truth. To some extent we have been ahead of our time."

Mr Barak's exit will not spare the Labour party from a bruising succession battle. As opin ion polls showed Mr Sharon stubbornly maintaining his nearly 20-point advantage, leading figures in the Labour party were salivating at the prospect of payback time for a leader whose remote style of functioning frustrated his cabinet colleagues, and alienated voters.

Labour's elder statesmen and the Nobel peace prize laureate, Shimon Peres, delivered the first cut. "If he loses very poorly he will have to draw certain conclusions," Mr Peres told CNN on the eve of the poll.

He added that he should have been allowed to contest the elections instead of Mr Barak. "The people wanted it."

Although Mr Peres is still hankering for power at the age of 77, Mr Barak's exit does not clear his path to the leadership. A younger generation of Labour leadership is also lining up to succeed Mr Barak, and their ambitions could rel egate Mr Peres to the role of kingmaker.

In the recriminations that will follow Mr Barak's crushing defeat, Mr Peres is bound to be blamed for allowing his phantom candidacy in this election to siphon off crucial leftwing support.

That could give a boost to potential challengers from a younger generation: the former Knesset speaker Avraham Burg, and the leftwinger Haim Ramon, who largely sat out these elections.

Popular wisdom has Mr Burg as the strongest contender, although Mr Ramon will probably be the first to rebel. The foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, is also seen to have an outside chance of succeeding Mr Barak.

webTitle: BBC director talks of campaign waged against him

fields.headline: Dyke accuses 'foes at the top' of BBC
fields.standfirst:
BBC director-general talks of campaign waged against him

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke last night spoke about the campaign waged against his candidacy for BBC director general, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke last night spoke for the first time about the virulent campaign waged by senior BBC figures against his candidacy for director general.

Mr Dyke compared the opposition from within the corporation to the campaign conducted against him by sections of the right wing press.

His comments came a few weeks after one of his internal rivals for the top post, the director of news Tony Hall, announced his departure to join the Royal Opera House.

Speaking at the London School of Economics, Mr Dyke said that within three weeks of his candidacy being revealed in 1999, "campaigns had been launched, most notably from the Times, the Daily Mail and the Telegraph, but also from within the BBC".

He suggested that the internal opposition had come from the camps of his rival candidates. "There were a number of people inside the BBC who had been encouraged to go for the job, and they went for the job. All sorts of campaigns were run.

"It was a pretty unpleasant process - although not for me. I'm not sure that when you let five or six people go for a job within an organisation that's a very good way of doing it."

Mr Dyke faced competition from at least four other internal candidates apart from Mr Hall. They were Mark Thompson, now effectively Mr Dyke's deputy as director of television: Mark Byford, now head of the World Service; Matthew Bannister, who until December was director of marketing; and Alan Yentob, now the director of drama and entertainment.

Mr Dyke did not mention any of his rivals by name. During the race to succeed John Birt, a number of anti-Dyke stories appeared in the press, which appeared to have come from supporters of his rivals within the corporation.

He was generous to his predecessor, but identified the failure of Mr Birt to retain the support of his staff during the changes he made. "John Birt's achievements should not be underestimated. But he did not get staff on his side. It was a really interesting challenge (for me) to see if you could turn the BBC around and get the staff on the side of the management."

Mr Dyke also said that the BBC should avoid the fall experienced by some of Britain's most successful businesses. "The great fear at the BBC is 'don't be like Marks & Spencer'."

Mr Dyke was speaking at an event organised by the Media Trust to mark his first year as director general. He said that administration savings would continue to be made, and more money would be invested in programmes. He defended the ratings battle with ITV, and promised continued investment in the current affairs series Panorama. "We may end up the only people doing that sort of thing," he said.

fields.headline: Hope for emotional rescue
fields.standfirst: Hilary Wheat, who has adapted the 12-step plan to tackle depression
fields.trailText: Profile: Hilary Wheat, who has adapted the 12-step plan to tackle depression
fields.body:
Those familiar with the "12-step" programme know it as a treatment for drug addiction or alcoholism. But at a centre in north Wales, it is being used to tackle depression and a range of problems loosely described as emotional illness.

The centre is called Tukes, after William Tukes, the 19th century health pioneer, and it was founded by Hilary Wheat, a mental health nurse. "Through voluntary work, I came into contact with several recovering alcoholics, their family and friends, who had used the programme successfully," she says. "At the same time, I was seeing people on acute psychiatric wards who were self-harming, and others who had depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and eating disorders - and it struck me that the 12-step approach could help them."

Alcoholics Anonymous was the first 12-step programme. In the late 1930s, it was adapted to a clinical setting and subsequently became known as the Minnesota model, or the 12-step abstinence approach. It gives people a regime, helping them to put to one side their dependent behaviour and to learn to handle their feelings in a healthier way.

"People use self-harming, over- or under-eating or even compulsive shopping to manage their uncomfortable feelings and give them some sense of pleasure or relief, just as an alcoholic uses drinking, and in the same way, they become dependent on it," says 38-year-old Wheat. "It's just different behaviour, but they are seeking the same temporary respite from their fears."

In the early 1990s, Wheat, thoroughly disillusioned with the NHS, began to think seriously about establishing an independent treatment centre. "The idea of leaving the NHS was daunting, but I couldn't carry on working in a situation where I felt we were often just maintaining people, when I believed effective change for them was possible.

"The psychiatric system is structured to deal with crises, but not structured to offer effective intervention to help someone manage their problems in the long term. It's down to a lack of training, lack of vision and, of course, lack of resources."

She registered Tukes as a charity in 1994, but it took another four years of fundraising before the centre opened its doors in Aberystwyth, offering places to up to 12 clients. Today, it has three staff and is about to take on more.

"Some of the charities I approached wanted track records, but some thought it was a terrific idea," says Wheat. "Like me, they were disillusioned with the services available on the NHS and saw we were offering something innovative." Her funders now also include the national lottery charities board and the health and social services department of the Welsh National Assembly, although the ultimate aim is to be self-funding through treatment fees.

The majority of clients are paid for by the NHS or social services and referrals come from GPs, the voluntary sector and self-help groups, or direct from individuals themselves. As well as one-to-one counselling and group therapy, clients get the support of a peer group of other residents and their families are also offered assistance and support through the 16-week treatment period.

Overall, Tukes's own monitoring indicates a high success rate with some 80% of clients remaining well after they leave. Those who have benefited include people who compulsively hoard food, are obsessive about cleaning or have irrational fears about contamination. Wheat is especially keen to stress the benefits - and cost-effectiveness - in treating depression, which costs the nation an estimated £370m a year in medication.

Success is also claimed in treatment of people who self-harm. "A woman who came to us for treatment for self-harming was asked by her psychologist to draw marks on her arm in red pen as a substitute for actual cutting and to help her cut less," recalls Wheat. "The intention was to reduce the harm she was doing to herself, and it sounds like a good idea, but it doesn't help the person manage the feelings which lead to self-harming and it can also reinforce the belief that they can't stop.

"We tell people it's possible to stop, though they will feel uncomfortable. We encourage them to talk about the urge to cut, but not to act on it and they will get a lot of support from their peer group in the centre in managing this."

Tukes is drug-free, although most of the people who are referred there have been prescribed anti-depressant or anxiolytic medication by their GPs or psychiatrists. "Prozac and other anti-depressants alter people's moods to an extent," says Wheat, "so we ask people to stop taking them so they can feel their feelings and learn to manage them, rather than having them reduced. It's also the case that some people will be taking more of the prescribed drug than they should and are using it in a dependent way."

Fulfilment of her vision has, for Wheat, vindicated her decision to jump the NHS ship. "Seeing the programme working, with people getting and staying well is great, and it's something I'd love to see taken up elsewhere," she says. "It can offer long-term, cost-effective recovery to people whose behaviour is blighting their lives."

Tukes is on 01970-625851

"Through voluntary work, I came into contact with several recovering alcoholics, their family and friends, who had used the programme successfully," she says. "At the same time, I was seeing people on acute psychiatric wards who were self-harming, and others who had depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and eating disorders - and it struck me that the 12-step approach could help them." Alcoholics Anonymous was the first 12-step programme. In the late 1930s, it was adapted to a clinical setting and subsequently became known as the Minnesota model, or the 12-step abstinence approach. It gives people a regime, helping them to put to one side their dependent behaviour and to learn to handle their feelings in a healthier way. "People use self-harming, over- or under-eating or even compulsive shopping to manage their uncomfortable feelings and give them some sense of pleasure or relief, just as an alcoholic uses drinking, and in the same way, they become dependent on it," says 38-year-old Wheat. "It's just different behaviour, but they are seeking the same temporary respite from their fears." In the early 1990s, Wheat, thoroughly disillusioned with the NHS, began to think seriously about establishing an independent treatment centre. "The idea of leaving the NHS was daunting, but I couldn't carry on working in a situation where I felt we were often just maintaining people, when I believed effective change for them was possible. "The psychiatric system is structured to deal with crises, but not structured to offer effective intervention to help someone manage their problems in the long term. It's down to a lack of training, lack of vision and, of course, lack of resources." She registered Tukes as a charity in 1994, but it took another four years of fundraising before the centre opened its doors in Aberystwyth, offering places to up to 12 clients. Today, it has three staff and is about to take on more. "Some of the charities I approached wanted track records, but some thought it was a terrific idea," says Wheat. "Like me, they were disillusioned with the services available on the NHS and saw we were offering something innovative." Her funders now also include the national lottery charities board and the health and social services department of the Welsh National Assembly, although the ultimate aim is to be self-funding through treatment fees. The majority of clients are paid for by the NHS or social services and referrals come from GPs, the voluntary sector and self-help groups, or direct from individuals themselves. As well as one-to-one counselling and group therapy, clients get the support of a peer group of other residents and their families are also offered assistance and support through the 16-week treatment period. Overall, Tukes's own monitoring indicates a high success rate with some 80% of clients remaining well after they leave. Those who have benefited include people who compulsively hoard food, are obsessive about cleaning or have irrational fears about contamination. Wheat is especially keen to stress the benefits - and cost-effectiveness - in treating depression, which costs the nation an estimated £370m a year in medication. Success is also claimed in treatment of people who self-harm. "A woman who came to us for treatment for self-harming was asked by her psychologist to draw marks on her arm in red pen as a substitute for actual cutting and to help her cut less," recalls Wheat. "The intention was to reduce the harm she was doing to herself, and it sounds like a good idea, but it doesn't help the person manage the feelings which lead to self-harming and it can also reinforce the belief that they can't stop. "We tell people it's possible to stop, though they will feel uncomfortable. We encourage them to talk about the urge to cut, but not to act on it and they will get a lot of support from their peer group in the centre in managing this." Tukes is drug-free, although most of the people who are referred there have been prescribed anti-depressant or anxiolytic medication by their GPs or psychiatrists. "Prozac and other anti-depressants alter people's moods to an extent," says Wheat, "so we ask people to stop taking them so they can feel their feelings and learn to manage them, rather than having them reduced. It's also the case that some people will be taking more of the prescribed drug than they should and are using it in a dependent way." Fulfilment of her vision has, for Wheat, vindicated her decision to jump the NHS ship. "Seeing the programme working, with people getting and staying well is great, and it's something I'd love to see taken up elsewhere," she says. "It can offer long-term, cost-effective recovery to people whose behaviour is blighting their lives." Tukes is on 01970-625851

fields.headline: A radical charity turns 50
fields.standfirst: A letter to the Manchester Guardian inspired the anti-poverty group
fields.trailText: Fifty years ago today the leftwing publisher Victor Gollancz wrote to the Manchester Guardian calling for a negotiated end to the Korean war and the creation of an international fund "to turn swords into ploughshares".
fields.body:
Fifty years ago today the leftwing publisher Victor Gollancz wrote to the Manchester Guardian calling for a negotiated end to the Korean war and the creation of an international fund "to turn swords into ploughshares".

Those who agreed with his letter were asked to send a postcard with the word Yes written on it. More than 4,000 people responded, endorsing his call for a political solution to world poverty. War on Want emerged from the ensuing debate.

From the start the organisation focused on changing public policy to make combating global poverty a priority.

One of its first acts was to mobilise the British people to press the government to allocate 1% of GDP to development overseas - a level of funding yet to be reached. As early as 1961 the charity pointed out that most British aid consisted of loans that would end up as unpayable debts.

"If the proportion of loans in our aid is not reduced," it said, "we are heading for trouble".

War on Want also pressed for greater priority to be given to aid programmes, and in 1964 the Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson - a founding member - created the Ministry of Overseas Development. The first minister was Barbara Castle, an early patron of the charity.

War on Want's first overseas task was helping refugees from the war against the French colonialists in Algeria. It also gave financial support to the Bhoodan movement in India, which was trying in the 1960s to realise Gandhi's dream of a village-based development.

In the 1970s it helped to expose the scandal of manufacturers such as Nestle aggressively promoting the sale of milk powder for babies at the expense of breastfeeding. It also campaigned for tea workers' rights in Asia.

In the Thatcher years, when many young people turned to international liberation movements as an outlet for their radical impulses, it was in the vanguard of the international solidarity movement, led by its general secretary, George Galloway, now a Glasgow MP.

It became a target of the right. Complaints were made to the Charity Commission, which censured it for its headline-grabbing advertisements against apartheid and the US involvement in Nicaragua.

John Denham, now a Labour health minister, spearheaded with others a campaign called Profits out of Poverty, which has been credited with bringing the debt crisis in underdeveloped countries to public attention.

In the same period a Women for a Change campaign led others to recognise the critical role of women in fighting world poverty.

In the late 1980s War on Want nearly went bankrupt when inadequate financial management resulting in funds for overseas projects being mixed with general funds.

It later won a substantial out-of-court settlement from its auditors, Somers Baker, for the damage caused to its reputation and income.

The experience led to a revision of accounting procedures for all charities.

War on Want is leaner now, with 20 staff and volunteers and an annual turnover of around £1.4m.

Its drive to get pension funds to invest ethically has brought positive results: the Labour government now requires firms to say whether they take account of social and ethical issues.

The Asian financial crisis of 1997-98, and the resulting increase in poverty, led War on Want to take up the banner against currency speculators and it is now a leading advocate of the Tobin Tax - a proposal to calm markets and raise money for development by levying a tiny tax on currency markets.

On its first leaflet War on Want wrote that closing the gap between the rich and the poor of the earth was "the supreme challenge of the next 50 years".

So it remains, but the additional challenges set by globalisation has moved the same campaigns against world poverty on to a new battleground.

 Mark Luetchford is a trustee of War on Want and is writing its history

webTitle: Ministers drop check fees for volunteers

fields.headline: Ministers drop check fees for volunteers
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, will today remove a big obstacle to creating a volunteer culture in Britain by announcing that the government has dropped plans to force volunteers to pay a £10-£15 fee to the state for security checks.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, will today remove a big obstacle to creating a volunteer culture in Britain by announcing that the government has dropped plans to force volunteers to pay a £10-£15 fee to the state for security checks.

The proposal had outraged volunteer groups who claimed it flew in the face of government plans to encourage an army of volunteers, alongside the state.

Each volunteeer would have been required to pay the full cost of a criminal records check with the new criminal records bureau. Some organisations such as the Scouts feared an annual charge of £650,000, and it was estimated the checks could cost the voluntary sector as a whole as much as £15m a year. Mr Blunkett will make the announcement today at a conference organised by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations. He is also expected to announce a relaxation in rules which deter jobless people from volunteering by requiring them to be available for work within 48 hours.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, recently called for a huge extension of volunteering, but his initiative was blunted by criticism over the criminal records charges.

The lifting of the charge, which was to have been imposed from next year as part of an attempt to protect vulnerable people from paedophiles, was agreed yesterday between the Treasury, the Home Office and the Department for Education.

The Scottish executive has already decided to provide free checks for volunteers.

webTitle: BBC1 arts flagship to change channels

fields.headline: BBC1 arts flagship to change channels
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC is to make way for more drama and entertainment on BBC1 by shifting its flagship arts series to BBC2, raising fears about the corporation's commitment to serious programming on the main channel.
fields.body:
The BBC is to make way for more drama and entertainment on BBC1 by shifting its flagship arts series to BBC2, raising fears about the corporation's commitment to serious programming on the main channel.

The transfer of Omnibus, after 34 years at its present home, signals the end of a regular arts strand on BBC1 as the channel battles to survive in the multi-channel world. Only a year ago, the BBC promised a regular slot for the series on BBC1.

Omnibus's move is part of a wider shake-up of the BBC's arts programmes. The Review, BBC2's weekly arts show, returns to a late-night slot as part of Newsnight and will be retitled Newsnight Review. The corporation said yesterday it was the biggest investment in arts programmes for five years.

Roly Keating, the controller of arts commissioning, denied the Omnibus move signalled the end of arts programmes on BBC1. Popular shows, including some editions of Omnibus, would continue to be screened on the main channel. "We are absolutely committed to arts on BBC1," he said. But he added that more people watched BBC2 on Saturdays at 7pm, the new peak-time slot for Omnibus, than its floating late-night slot on BBC1.

A BBC spokeswoman said: "Because of the extra investment in BBC1, there is going to be an increase in entertainment and drama programming, although BBC1 will retain a commitment to arts programmes."

fields.headline: ABC's Martin Fry leads bid for Yorkshire FM licence
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The lead singer of 1980s pop group ABC is backing one of the 16 applications for a Yorkshire FM radio licence. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The lead singer of pop group ABC is backing one of the 16 applications for a new Yorkshire regional FM radio licence.

ABC front man Martin Fry, who sang 1980s hits Poison Arrow and The Look of Love, is on the board of the company behind the Y107 music-based bid for the new FM franchise.

The new station will broadcast to around 2.5m people in south and west Yorkshire, covering the cities of Sheffield, Leeds and Bradford.

The Y107 licence application was submitted by GWR subsidiary Yorkshire Regional Radio.

As well as Mr Fry, other members of the YRR board include Yorkshire County Cricket Club president Robin Smith, GWR chief executive Ralph Bernard, operations director Steve Orchard and development director Ian Rufus.

Y107 would be based in Sheffield and is promising a music service for the "Live Aid generation", offering classic hits from the 1970s to the present day.

Other contenders for the Yorkshire regional FM licence include The Arrow, a classic rock format from Chrysalis Radio; Jazz FM; music and lifestyle station 106.2 The Rose, backed by Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group; and Saga Radio.

The Radio Authority is expected to announce the winner of the licence in the summer.

webTitle: Popstars sponsor may buy into band

fields.headline: Popstars sponsor may buy into band
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Popstars sponsor T&T has hailed its deal as a runaway success and may taking a stake in the band itself, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The virtually unknown sponsors of the Popstars TV show, soft drink brand T&T, has hailed its sponsorship deal as a runaway success and is now considering taking a stake in the band itself.

"We have seen a dramatic increase in sales. We had to figure out a way to create brand awareness and we couldn't have asked for more," said Dafer Alazri, managing director and founder of T&T Beverages, an independent company based in the UK and backed by US investors.

The £2m Popstars TV show sponsorship deal has seen demand for the unknown brand rocket. So much so that the company was penalised by Asda for failing to meet delivery times because of overwhelming orders from rival supermarket Tesco.

A fifth flavour variant will be added to the T&T range in the spring and distribution of single cans, retailing at 40p, a 500ml bottle and 1.5-litre bottle will roll out to newsagents and stores such as Superdrug to cash in on impulse purchases.

Mr Alazri added: "It might have been helpful to have the full distribution in place before Popstars but we only agreed the sponsorship on November 11 so it was tight timing. We don't have a supply problem."

T&T Beverages has spent five years creating T&T - a lightly carbonated drink with 10% fruit juice and all natural ingredients. It went on sale in January.

Now T&T has been offered first call on sponsorship of the Popstars band, a deal that would extend past the end of the current TV show sponsorship.

But Mr Alazri is worried about the new stars' staying power.

"We have the first call on sponsoring the band - our ad agency is looking at it. It does look like they will go to number one but I hope they have the ability to carry it through. Popstars is a great theme but we have to move on," he said.

Mr Alazri said the T&T brand wanted to ally itself to promoting talent, a relationship that will be extended to other areas such as acting and dancing.

A TV campaign for T&T will break on terrestrial and satellite TV in March as part of a £6m advertising spend behind the brand this year. The campaign is being created by ad agency Burkitt DDB.

T&T Beverages will also launch a new energy drink in March. Branding consultancy Interbrand is working on the branding and positioning of the product.

fields.headline: Moss Bros in bid to shrug off stuffy image
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Moss Bros has hired ad agency McCann-Erickson in a bid to attract younger consumers. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Struggling suit retailer Moss Bros has hired ad agency McCann-Erickson to help it rebrand in a bid to attract younger consumers who are increasingly casual in their work dress.

The company is to rebrand many of its high street stores under a new name, Code, to help it ditch its stuffy image.

The new stores will be aimed not at the suit wearer, but at the increasing number of men who dress down for work.

McCann is to create a £1m rebranding campaign to promote the new chain of stores, which is being test-marketed in and around London.

The names Savoy Taylors Guild, Blazer and the Suit Company, all owned by Moss Bros, will all eventually disappear from th high street to be replaced by Code.

Seven Code stores have so far opened and the company is eventually planning to run between 80 and 100. The shops will sell suits, but will be dominated by more casual work clothing.

The name, which Moss Bros paid £12,000 to buy from an Italian textile company, derived from the words "Casualwear, Office, Dressing up and Essentials".

No one from Moss Bros or McCann-Erickson would comment on the rebranding plans.

fields.headline: First Direct launches new ads
fields.trailText: 8.30am: First Direct has ditched its 'Little fella' ads to launch a new 'Magical rapport' campaign, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
First Direct has ditched its "Little fella" advertising to launch a new campaign based on the idea that its customers enjoy a "magical rapport" with their bank.

Clive Roe, star of the hit musical Chicago, features in the ad as a man having his hair cut in the local barber's shop.

As the barber brushes the hair from his neck, the customer starts to giggle and his laughter infects the other viewers, who all burst into side-splitting laughter.

The ad ends with the line, "This is the magic rapport you get banking with First Direct".

The £3m campaign was created by First Direct's ad agency, WCRS.

First Direct won a gold at the British Television Advertising Awards for its "Little fella" campaign, which featured an cartoon character. Before that, the bank had a long-running campaign starring Bob Mortimer.

fields.headline: A guy for the big story
fields.standfirst: Charles Stewart-Smith is a man who likes to fight for a cause. As the Hinduja brothers' new PR adviser, he may well have a fight on his hands.
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Charles Stewart-Smith is a man who likes to fight for a cause. As the Hindujas' new PR adviser, he'll have his work cut out. By Julia Day.
Feb 5: Luther Pendragon wins Hindujas account
fields.body:
Charles Stewart-Smith is a man who likes to fight for a cause. As the Hinduja brothers' new PR adviser, he may well have a fight on his hands.

The former editor of News at Ten and co-founder and partner of issue-led PR firm Luther Pendragon appears to relish tasks others may find daunting - like coaxing young people to vote.

As executive director of Rock the Vote, Mr Stewart-Smith has persuaded pop stars and comedians, including Eddie Izzard, Steve Coogan, Radiohead and M People, to take part in the pro-voting campaign.

But he must now persuade UK politicians, businessmen and the public that the brothers at the centre of the Peter Mandelson passport row are free from corruption and blame.

Mr Stewart-Smith is already defending the Hindujas' honour, and his company's principles, with zeal.

"We have no qualms about working with the Hindujas. I am old-fashioned in believing that people are innocent until proven guilty," he said.

He claims to have seen "quite a lot" of the passport-row documentation and is satisfied the Hindujas are innocent.

But he claims to be motivated by another aspect of working for the Hindujas.

"It is fascinating work - understanding a business which is different to any other I've worked with before.

"Theirs is the only corporate brochure I have seen which bears a picture of their grandfather with the words 'My duty is to earn so that I can give' underneath."

His introduction to the Indian billionaires doesn't surprise those who know him.

He is an arch-networker and counts many big media names as his friends, including Sir Trevor McDonald and, ironically, Peter Mandelson.

Further down the pecking order in his contacts is Sada - the Big Brother hippy chick.

They knew each other at Durham university and, when Sada was voted out of the Channel 4 game show, it was Mr Stewart-Smith to whom she turned.

He co-founded Luther Pendragon with former Observer industrial editor George Pitcher.

In nine years, they have built up an impressive client list of 100 companies ranging from McDonald's to the cabinet office.

Knowing "what a story is and where to push it" stems from Mr Stewart-Smith's long career as a journalist.

After leaving Durham, he worked on the Northern Echo before moving to the BBC, where he worked on programmes including Today, the Financial World Tonight, the Nine O'Clock News and Newsnight

In 1987, Mr Stewart-Smith moved to ITN, where he became editor of News at Ten. He is married to Sunday Times City editor Kirstie Hamilton.

Editor of Granada's Tonight show David Mannion, who worked with Mr Stewart-Smith at ITN, said he was always chasing the big guns.

"He was always a guy for the big story," he said.

"I remember literally bumping into him as we were running from opposite directions along the corridor.

"He was a hot-footer. If there was a big story, you wanted him around. He has a sharp sense of what matters."

Although Mr Stewart-Smith was not a politics specialist at ITN, he had "nous" and an understanding for the subject.

"He has an astute sense of how the political world revolves," said Mr Mannion.

Our media industry insider said: "Charles is a consummate professional. He will represent clients from the strategic PR point of view, not a moralistic one."

"I would not categorise him as a straight PR man. He is very well-connected in politics, media, marketing, music and, as his involvement with Rock the Vote shows, he is someone who is engaged with issues. Issues drive him."

Channel 4 head of press and publicity Matt Baker said: "He is not just a PR man - he is well plugged in to the worlds of media and politics and that gives him a fine understanding to inform his PR work."

He is also managing director of Pendragon Productions, the company's TV production business, and a founding trustee of both the European Children's Trust and Medical Emergency Relief International (Merlin).

fields.bodyText: Charles Stewart-Smith is a man who likes to fight for a cause. As the Hinduja brothers' new PR adviser, he may well have a fight on his hands. The former editor of News at Ten and co-founder and partner of issue-led PR firm Luther Pendragon appears to relish tasks others may find daunting - like coaxing young people to vote. As executive director of Rock the Vote, Mr Stewart-Smith has persuaded pop stars and comedians, including Eddie Izzard, Steve Coogan, Radiohead and M People, to take part in the pro-voting campaign. But he must now persuade UK politicians, businessmen and the public that the brothers at the centre of the Peter Mandelson passport row are free from corruption and blame. Mr Stewart-Smith is already defending the Hindujas' honour, and his company's principles, with zeal. "We have no qualms about working with the Hindujas. I am old-fashioned in believing that people are innocent until proven guilty," he said. He claims to have seen "quite a lot" of the passport-row documentation and is satisfied the Hindujas are innocent. But he claims to be motivated by another aspect of working for the Hindujas. "It is fascinating work - understanding a business which is different to any other I've worked with before. "Theirs is the only corporate brochure I have seen which bears a picture of their grandfather with the words 'My duty is to earn so that I can give' underneath." His introduction to the Indian billionaires doesn't surprise those who know him. He is an arch-networker and counts many big media names as his friends, including Sir Trevor McDonald and, ironically, Peter Mandelson. Further down the pecking order in his contacts is Sada - the Big Brother hippy chick. They knew each other at Durham university and, when Sada was voted out of the Channel 4 game show, it was Mr Stewart-Smith to whom she turned. He co-founded Luther Pendragon with former Observer industrial editor George Pitcher. In nine years, they have built up an impressive client list of 100 companies ranging from McDonald's to the cabinet office. Knowing "what a story is and where to push it" stems from Mr Stewart-Smith's long career as a journalist. After leaving Durham, he worked on the Northern Echo before moving to the BBC, where he worked on programmes including Today, the Financial World Tonight, the Nine O'Clock News and Newsnight In 1987, Mr Stewart-Smith moved to ITN, where he became editor of News at Ten. He is married to Sunday Times City editor Kirstie Hamilton. Editor of Granada's Tonight show David Mannion, who worked with Mr Stewart-Smith at ITN, said he was always chasing the big guns. "He was always a guy for the big story," he said. "I remember literally bumping into him as we were running from opposite directions along the corridor. "He was a hot-footer. If there was a big story, you wanted him around. He has a sharp sense of what matters." Although Mr Stewart-Smith was not a politics specialist at ITN, he had "nous" and an understanding for the subject. "He has an astute sense of how the political world revolves," said Mr Mannion. Our media industry insider said: "Charles is a consummate professional. He will represent clients from the strategic PR point of view, not a moralistic one." "I would not categorise him as a straight PR man. He is very well-connected in politics, media, marketing, music and, as his involvement with Rock the Vote shows, he is someone who is engaged with issues. Issues drive him." Channel 4 head of press and publicity Matt Baker said: "He is not just a PR man - he is well plugged in to the worlds of media and politics and that gives him a fine understanding to inform his PR work." He is also managing director of Pendragon Productions, the company's TV production business, and a founding trustee of both the European Children's Trust and Medical Emergency Relief International (Merlin). webTitle: Byers promises early euro poll to anxious firms

fields.headline: Byers promises early euro poll to anxious firms
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, yesterday joined forces with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, to assert Labour will make a decision whether to join a single currency early in the next parliament.
fields.body:
The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, yesterday joined forces with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, to assert Labour will make a decision whether to join a single currency early in the next parliament.

Mr Byers, speaking at the Mansion House in London, insisted Labour's policy on the single currency "has not been changed and will not change".

There have been reports recently that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was seeking to add a sixth test to the five already set out by the government - that any referendum on joining the euro would have to be won by a large majority.

The story was denied by the Treasury, but it appeared to alarm some businessmen and cabinet members concerned that the resignation from the cabinet of Peter Mandelson, a fervent pro-European, would weaken the government's resolve about joining the euro.

Mr Byers' remarks yesterday were designed to reassure British business that the pro-European alliance inside the cabinet will not allow the policy to be altered.

One minister said that the pro-Europeans were probably becoming more confident following the recent rise in the euro and clear statements from senior executives at Ford, Nissan and implicitly at Corus that they will take investment out of Britain if the government rules out joining the single currency.

In his speech Mr Byers said: "It is a policy which is understood by business. Had we ruled out joining then investment decisions which have recently been made would not have been taken in favour of the UK."

The chancellor has refused to provide what he describes as a running commentary on whether the British economy is closer to meeting the tests, including sustainable convergence between Britain's economy and the economies of the single currency.

However, Tony Blair told a meeting of Labour activists in Kettering last week that the most important test was whether "our economy is marching in step with the other mainland economies".

As Mr Byers rallied to the pro-single currency cause - and a poll reported that 76% of London's senior executives favour early UK entry into the eurozone - John Redwood launched a new Conservative drive in the opposite direction.

Britain should copy its European partners in their eternal demands for renegotiation of the EU treaties in search of "ever closer union," he said, except that Mr Blair should demand just the opposite, a deal which recognises that the UK will never go as far as Europe wants "no matter who is prime minister".

"They have constant renegotiation, so why can't Britain? They want more, we want less," the former Tory cabinet minister said at the launch of a book, Stars and Strife, the Coming Conflict, which advocates UK membership of the US-led Nafta trade bloc as well as of the EU.

Mr Redwood, who is to the right of William Hague on Europe, wants to repatriate policy over fishing, farming and overseas aid, and blames Europe, not the US, for disputes on the environment, the nuclear shield, and GM crops.

"The US used to think more European integration was a good thing. Now the US has discovered it just means making a never-ending series of disagreeable phone calls and a growing detachment of the EU from Anglo-Saxon democratic values," he complained.

webTitle: IMF warns on UK's euro plight

fields.headline: IMF warns on UK's euro plight
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Britain's record as a high inflation country meant that the price of joining the single currency would be higher taxes or curbs on public spending, the International Monetary Fund warned last night.
fields.body:
Britain's record as a high inflation country meant that the price of joining the single currency would be higher taxes or curbs on public spending, the International Monetary Fund warned last night.

Fuelling the intense political row over the euro, the fund said that the government may struggle to meet its prime test of meshing Britain's economic cycle with the rest of Europe before it decides whether to hold a referendum.

"Cyclical convergence may not occur naturally by the time that the UK may seriously consider joining", the fund said in a working paper published on its website.

The study of British monetary policy over the past decade showed that growth would have been smoother and more stable had Britain stayed in the ERM and joined monetary union at the outset.

However it added: "Inflationary pressures would have persisted under such a policy, thus creating a dilemma for policy makers."

To keep inflation under control if British interest rates were being set by the European Central Bank, the government would have to resort to cutting spending, raising taxes or keeping wage rises under control through a flexible labour market.

The report, written by two IMF staff economists, broadly endorses the government's cautious wait and see approach to joining EMU. It says that the economic convergence which Labour has set as its first test for EMU entry would be hard to achieve, because the British economic cycle still had more in common with that of the US than other European economies. They add that the reforms of the labour market and the tight fiscal policies followed in recent years had "enhanced the likelihood of convergence".

webTitle: Blair promises euro vote within two years

fields.headline: Blair promises euro vote within two years
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today set a definite deadline for a UK referendum on joining the euro, promising a vote within two years of Labour winning a second term.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today set a definite deadline for a UK referendum on joining the euro, promising a vote within two years of Labour winning a second term.

The prime minister's announcement - during question time in the Commons - is the first time the Labour party has put a concrete definition on its promise of a poll "early in the next government."

It means British voters will have to choose between the pound and the euro by May 2004 at the latest, although if Mr Blair goes to the country as expected on May 3rd then the UK could be in euroland within 27 months.

Responding to a question time dominated by debate on the euro and its cost on British jobs, the prime minister admitted "Early in the next parliament would of course mean within the next two years."

But Mr Blair, under pressure from Conservative leader William Hague to spell out Labour's stance on a referendum, admitted there would be no "snap" referendum during the honeymoon period of a strong second showing by the Labour party in the polls.

Pressed by the Tory leader to say whether that "early" referendum could mean within months of a general election, the prime minister replied "Of course it doesn't mean that."

And the government revealed that, officially at least, it has still to set the exact terms of the of the referendum question - or set of questions. Mr Blair shrugged off demands from the Conservative leader to know the precise composition of the crucial question by saying "The question will be phrased at a later time."

The prime minister opened his session of questions in the House of Commons by pointedly not congratulating new Israeli prime minister Ariel Sharon on his landslide victory.

Instead Mr Blair said: "I spoke on the phone with Ariel Sharon and offered our help in the difficult times that may lie ahead in the Middle East peace process."
