webTitle: Wall Street braced for Cisco slowdown

fields.headline: Wall Street braced for Cisco slowdown
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Cisco, the US company that makes networking equipment for the internet, was expected to announce last night its weakest growth in 18 months.
fields.body:
Cisco, the US company that makes networking equipment for the internet, was expected to announce last night its weakest growth in 18 months.

Cisco is still due to see sales top $7bn - up from $4.4 bn in the same period a year before.

Despite its rise, the chief executive John Chambers warned recently that the current quarter looked more challenging.

"Recent comments by [Mr Chambers] indicate the company has become cautious on current business trends," said Merrill Lynch analyst Michael Ching. "We expect to make some downward revisions to our revenue forecasts.

"We think the most likely scenario is for relatively flat sequential revenue growth for the April quarter, but still up in excess of 45% year over year. This would be the weakest top-line growth in six quarters."

Amazon.com was also in the spotlight yesterday after a bearish note from what the company regards as an antagonistic Wall Street analyst.

The e-tailer attacked a new report from a Lehman Brothers analyst who warned the internet retailer faces a "creditor squeeze" in the second half of 2001 and urged that investors avoid its convertible bonds.

"Obviously you can't take this seriously," said Bill Curry, a spokesman for Amazon.com, of the report issued by Ravi Suria, Lehman's vice president of convertibles strategy.

"He said we would be out of cash by the end of 2000 and he missed by $1.1bn. It's a silly report that is chock full of errors."

Mr Suria was not available for comment.

Sun Microsystems announced its vision of a new generation intelligent internet, a move dismissed by its rival Microsoft as playing catch-up.

Sun Open Net Environment does resemble Microsoft's .NET strategy, although Sun chief executive Scott McNealy said users and developers had no flexibility to work with others if they chose the Microsoft product.

Sun's announcement was the latest blast in a battle between it and Microsoft over a market both see emerging for an intelligent internet that surrounds and follows users.

"The goal here is not to get you on the internet but to get you off the internet and everything around you on the internet," Mr McNealy said.

Cars would tell drivers when and where to get fuel, assembly lines would order components as stocks fell and the web would offer up documents to a user wherever and on whatever device he or she wanted.

fields.headline: Alphameric upbeat despite teething problems
fields.trailText: Alphameric, the retail and leisure IT provider, yesterday admitted there had been teething problems with its electronic gambling technology during trials in a number of betting shops, but said that it would get its equipment to bookies on time.
fields.body:
Alphameric, the retail and leisure IT provider, yesterday admitted there had been teething problems with its electronic gambling technology during trials in a number of betting shops, but said that it would get its equipment to bookies on time.

Chief executive Alan Morcombe said the roll-out of Alphameric's Alphabet bet capturing technology, which allows bookmakers to register bets and calculate risk exposures across the country in real time, had been delayed by six months but was now proceeding without problem.

Bookmakers taking up the technology include Coral, Stanley Leisure and the Tote, with William Hill also showing an interest. Alphabet is seen as central to Alphameric's growth as bookmaking becomes increasingly computerised.

Mr Morcombe said: "There were delays [in the roll-out] for a number of reasons - the trials threw up some software bugs that had to be ironed out, and training betting shop staff to use the system took longer than expected in some cases."

About 45% of Alphameric's business is with bookmakers. Mr Morcombe said it would be considering acquisitions in the US and Europe.

His comments accompanied Alphameric's results for the year to December 2000, which showed operating profits before exceptionals in line with expectations - up 162% to £8m on turnover up 115% to £54.4m. Stripping out the company's four acquisitions made last year, organic growth in operating profits was 36%.

Shares in Alphameric closed up 7.5p at 315p yesterday.

webTitle: Comment: Brown now determining Labour's ideological tone

fields.headline: Turning point
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown seems to be determining Labour's ideological tone since Peter Mandelson departed

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown seems to be determining Labour's ideological tone since Peter Mandelson departed.
fields.body:
We are back to two party politics. Peter Mandelson's departure from government has finally put paid to Tony Blair's project of reunifying the centre left. There is now no prospect of the government joining with the Liberal Democrats in an alliance to keep the Tories out of power. But if we are returning to an older pattern, it is being fought out between parties in the throes of deep change. Under William Hague's leadership, the Tory party has become a ghetto for moral fundamentalists who hate the country Britain has become. At the same time, Labour is well on the way to becoming a vehicle for Gordon Brown's distinctive vision of Britain's future.

The Conservative party is further than ever from being seen as an alternative government - or even a credible opposition. There can be little doubt that the Blair government has been slipping steadily in public esteem for some time; but the Tory party has signally failed to benefit from the slide in its popularity. As a result of Mr Hague's policy of opening it to the loony right, it is now crucially dependent on large donations from businessmen, for whom hostility to Europe is more important than winning elections, and increasingly influenced by fundamentalists whose values have little in common with those of most voters.

The donation to the Tories of £5m by Stuart Wheeler, the chief executive of the spread-betting company IG Index, casts a curious light on the Tories' plight. As a betting man, Mr Wheeler must know that Mr Hague is one of the government's most valuable assets. The Tory leader's thuggish contribution to the parliamentary debate on Mr Mandelson's resignation can only have strengthened the belief of a great many people in all parties that he will never be prime minister. Yet Mr Wheeler's gift can only strengthen Mr Hague's position - and thereby keep the Tories in opposition for the foreseeable future.

In branding themselves as a Eurosceptic party, the Tories aim to exploit a pervasive public mood. The same cannot be said about their flirtation with fundamentalism. Only a few years ago, it was unthinkable that a Tory health spokesman should propose making abortion illegal again. But Dr Liam Fox is not alone in arguing that this should be at the heart of Conservative policy.

No one imagines that Mr Hague's flirtation with the religious right reflects personal conviction. It is an opportunistic gimmick - and a singularly ill-calculated one. Even in America - a much more religious country, as well as a much more divided one - the right has not been able to roll back liberal values. True, the new administration has cut off funds for international agencies that sponsor abortion; but in announcing that he will not seek to overturn laws guaranteeing freedom of choice, President Bush - a subtle and not easily deciphered politician - has shown that he understands the political risks of moral absolutism better than his Tory disciples in Britain.

While the Tories are stuck in a trap of their own making, Labour is fast moving into new territory. Peter Mandelson's departure has not only shifted the balance of power in the government, it has transformed the political map of the country. The most likely scenario in the years to come is continuing Labour supremacy, with the Lib Dems altering course to pick up seats from a risibly diminished Tory party.

Within the government, the impact of Mandelson's exit is clearest on the euro. For all practical purposes, Gordon Brown has a veto on whether a referendum will be held during Labour's second term. It is scarcely imaginable that he will sanction such a decision. The political arguments against it are as strong as ever. A formidable majority of voters has set itself against joining in any near future. A narrow victory cannot be relied upon to resolve the issue. Even if it can be won, a referendum in Labour's second term could jeopardise its chances of having a third. On the other hand, continuing Labour caution on the issue deprives Hague's Tory party of a large part of its reason for existing.

There may be a larger explanation for the chancellor's doubts. Though he has never ruled out joining the single currency, his speeches sketch a future for Britain that is not easily reconciled with deeper integration in the EU. The country he seems to want Britain to become resembles a highly idealised version of the United States more than any thing that exists on the continent of Europe. A Brownian Britain would be meritocratic and socially mobile. Its economy would have more in common with Anglo-Saxon venture capitalism than with German corporatism or French mercantilism.

Mr Brown's goal seems to be to fuse together an American ideal of equal opportunity with the most durable traditions of British social democracy. Its appearance marks a turning point in British politics. Despite its best efforts, the Blair government has yet to come up with a coherent successor to Thatcherism. Could it be that, as we return to two party politics, Labour is giving birth to a new project of modernisation?

 John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE.

A Brownian Britain would be meritocratic and socially mobile. Its economy would have more in common with Anglo-Saxon venture capitalism than with German corporatism or French mercantilism. Mr Brown's goal seems to be to fuse together an American ideal of equal opportunity with the most durable traditions of British social democracy. Its appearance marks a turning point in British politics. Despite its best efforts, the Blair government has yet to come up with a coherent successor to Thatcherism. Could it be that, as we return to two party politics, Labour is giving birth to a new project of modernisation?  John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE. j.gray@lse.ac.uk

webTitle: Ryanair chief to sell £30m of shares

fields.headline: Ryanair chief to sell £30m of shares
fields.trailText: Michael O' Leary, the head of Ryanair, the low-cost airline, plans to sell £30m worth of shares, taking the total he has raised over the last two years to £56m, he said yesterday.
fields.body:
Michael O' Leary, the head of Ryanair, the low-cost airline, plans to sell £30m worth of shares, taking the total he has raised over the last two years to £56m, he said yesterday.

He said: "It doesn't make sense to have everything tied up in one asset. I took a bit off last year. I'm taking a bit off now and I'll probably take a bit more off again this time next year."

He is selling 3m of the 30m shares he owns, with an option to sell a further 1m. Mr O'Leary said he had no plans for the cash, although he would invest some of it in his farm outside Dublin.

Ryanair's shares dipped yesterday from a high of 769p to 748.5 p, making Mr O'Leary's holding worth about £225m.

The firm also announced that it is to raise £82m through a placing of shares to fund investment in 13 new planes over the next two years.

Ryanair achieved record traffic and profit figures for the third quarter up to the end of December last year. Passenger volumes rose 39% to 1.9 m, while profits after tax increased 42% to £21.3m from the previous quarter.

Mr O' Leary said: "The fact that Ryanair delivered 39% growth during an off-peak winter quarter whilst still increasing profit after tax by 42%, demonstrates the strength and robust nature of Ryanair's low fares formula."

The internet has had a marked impact on the company's success. From zero a year ago, internet sales are now running in excess of 65% of all bookings.

Mr O'Leary said that the purchase of new planes from Boeing would increase the company's fleet to 49 within two years. New European routes are to be announced before the end of the month, and by the end of the financial year, Ryanair's passengers are expected to exceed 7.25m compared with 5.4m a year ago.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: As fans of former Book of the Month, Under No Illusion, will be aware (and who can forget his explanation as to why the word "nigger" is not offensive?), there is more to my friend Paul Daniels than magic.
fields.body:
 As fans of former Book of the Month, Under No Illusion, will be aware (and who can forget his explanation as to why the word "nigger" is not offensive?), there is more to my friend Paul Daniels than magic. It is no surprise, then, that his forthcoming national tour will include discourses on religion and other matters. To plug the tour, Paul gives an interview to Ceefax page 597, the Lynn Barber of television text, and is asked if there is any TV show he can't bear to miss and has to set the video to record. "No," says Paul. "As Noël Coward said, 'TV is for appearing on, not for viewing'. You're wasting your life if you sit in front of the goggle box too much." How very true. "How many TVs have you got in your house, and where?" page 597 then asks. "One each in the kitchen, lounge and the two bedrooms," replies Paul, "and two in the office for taping. And I've got a pair of prism glasses I found in Portugal which allow me to watch in bed without getting a crick in my neck." Majestic stuff.

 Emails continue to arrive regularly, on a bewildering range of matters, from Peter Tatchell. I don't know what Peter's finances are like, but if ever he should be looking to trim his phone bill, may we volunteer to be the first to make the painful sacrifice?

 Confusion reigns when my colleague Marina Hyde calls the Home Office and asks for Skippy Hammond QC, but once again as soon as she explains "he's doing the whitewash on the Hinduja passport affair", all is clear. "Ah yes!" says the operator, "I know just who you mean now." Eventually, Marina tells press officer James Sorene we want to send Skippy a 1,000-piece jigsaw. Why, asks James. Well, we're worried he'll be bored sitting there with nothing to do now that Alastair Campbell has followed Jack Straw by publicly announcing his inquiry's findings (Ali has claimed that, unlike Keith Vaz, Mandy admits wrongdoing - a total whopper, in fact, Mandy admitting no such thing). But back to Skippy, as Marina tells James we were thinking of a puzzle depicting the Dreyfus affair. "You're serious, are you?" asks James. Of course. "Why not a book?" A book about the Dreyfus affair? It's possible. But the jigsaw would be better.

 Incidentally, it seems a shame that, despite playing so central a role in one of the defining moments in New Labour history, kangaroo court king Skippy should remain so obscure. We therefore appeal to old schoolmates, college chums, colleagues, friends and relatives for anything that might be included in the Skippy Special planned for next week. Unusually good champagne for all help supplied.

 Consultant psychiatrist Jonathan Bindman emails regarding our plan to snatch alopecian Sun editor David Yelland and have him sectioned for treatment on his dangerous short-term memory problem. "Bear in mind that doing these things quickly is almost impossible," he counsels. "But note that under section 136 of the Mental Health Act, if the person is in a place to which the public has access, then he can be arrested by any police officer who believes he is likely to be suffering from a mental disorder and taken to a 'place of safety'. This may be a quicker way of getting him in than a home assessment." Most intriguing. David's current obsession is tonight's 10th birthday do for the Press Complaints Commission. With Prince William in attendance there will clearly be a police presence - too good a chance to let slip.

 Quite why people like David are so obsessed with this PCC party we're not sure, but they are and the invitation is the hottest ticket around. New Statesman editor Peter Wilby is one of the lucky metro-elite. He received his invite, saw the letters PCC at the top and, unaware of any fuss, instantly threw it in the bin. Well done sir.

fields.headline: Thumbs-up from man on £150k
fields.trailText: Mr X - who agreed to speak on condition of anonymity - is a 33-year-old management consultant living and working in London. Married with children, he earns £150,000 and has the same amount in shares and other investments.
fields.body:
Mr X - who agreed to speak on condition of anonymity - is a 33-year-old management consultant living and working in London. Married with children, he earns £150,000 and has the same amount in shares and other investments.

"I have got Isas and Peps, my own personal pension arrangements, and some directly held shares and unit trusts. I have got about 25 shares, in companies such as Vodafone and less well-known stocks. There are four unit trusts with three different companies - one overseas, one global and two UK. And we have some cash savings.

"It is a bit of a mishmash. I like to think I'm hands-on but I don't have the time to be as hands-on as I would like. I would say I'm reasonably knowledgeable but to do it properly takes an enormous amount of time.

"I have made some money and lost some - I think I'm still positive. I'm reasonably keen to take risks. If I was a bit more knowledgeable I would probably have a better range of unit trusts and probably less in direct equities. It is all completely ad hoc - there is definitely no 'super strategy'.

"I don't have an accountant. I have a financial adviser who has done a couple of good things but I'm sure I could do better.

"I actually think it [Create, the new Lloyds TSB/Goldman Sachs wealth management service] sounds great. Consolidating all my finances into one place would save the postman an enormous amount of time and energy. For example, my wife and I have three online dealing accounts between us. Someone pulling all that together would be great. I like the idea of being still involved with making decisions for myself but with a bit more guidance."

fields.headline: Mandelson exit splits Lib Dems
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat high command is at odds over whether it has blundered by helping topple Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary and one of the party's closest allies within the Labour cabinet.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat high command is at odds over whether it has blundered by helping topple Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary and one of the party's closest allies within the Labour cabinet.

Sir Paddy Ashdown, the former Liberal Democrat leader, has told colleagues that Mr Mandelson's downfall may be a definitive turning point in the so-called "project", the attempt to realign centre-left politics.

Since becoming party leader two years ago Charles Kennedy has hardly spoken to Mr Mandelson about inter-party co-operation and does not regard him as an indispensable conduit. However, other senior Liberal Democrat MPs fear the party has shot itself in the foot.

Mr Mandelson's downfall was triggered by a parliamentary written question tabled by Norman Baker, the relatively junior Lib Dem MP for Lewes.

Mr Baker had been relentlessly pursuing Mr Mandelson over his stewardship of the dome, including his contacts with Hinduja brothers, the sponsors for the faith zone.

Sir Paddy, who still regularly attends meetings of the parliamentary party, has told friends his belief that the departure of Mr Mandelson may mark a decisive change in Labour's relations with the Liberal Democrats, is broadly shared by Lord Jenkins, the former Lib Dem leader in the Lords who chaired the official government inquiry into electoral reform for the Commons.

Lord Rodgers, the current Lib Dem leader in the Lords, also believes that his party's cause has been seriously set back.

Sir Paddy and his close adviser Lord Holme saw Mr Mandelson as a vital figure in pushing issues such as electoral reform and Europe. The former Lib Dem leader was a close student of the balance of forces inside the Labour cabinet as he fought to extract concessions from Mr Blair over PR for European elections and the Commons.

Mr Baker, however, is unrepentant about his role and insists his actions have been fully cleared with Mr Kennedy. He has said: "Charles and I have been talking constantly about this matter, and he fully backs me."

fields.headline: Stock options 'are theft'
fields.trailText: One of Britain's biggest shareholders yesterday branded the stock option plans enjoyed by many US company directors as "theft" and called for new stock exchange rules to prevent the mega-pay packages being exported to Europe.
fields.body:
One of Britain's biggest shareholders yesterday branded the stock option plans enjoyed by many US company directors as "theft" and called for new stock exchange rules to prevent the mega-pay packages being exported to Europe.

Hermes Investment Management, which manages £50bn of pension fund cash for the Post Office and BT, wants American companies to be forced to put their share option packages to a shareholder vote before they are introduced.

It has written to the management of the Nasdaq stock exchange to demand changes in its rules.

"Many of the stock option plans in operation at Nasdaq-listed companies, in particular, involve a considerable transfer of wealth from the existing shareholders to the directors and officers," the Hermes letter says. "This is more than just a capital allocation decision; in any other form of asset ownership such a transfer without the approval of owners would be considered theft."

In the US it is now commonplace for more than 30% of a listed company's shares to be "owed" to directors and senior managers in stock option plans. Such options can severely dilute the existing shareholders' interests, and even investors in huge corporations are not immune. Microsoft, for instance, has a stock overhang of more than 20%. These options can be awarded to management, by management, without the approval of existing shareholders.

Michelle Edkins, director of corporate governance at Hermes, said it was important for shareholders to see option plans before they were put in place "because they are giving away part of the company that shareholders own to the directors. If the directors make the decision there is clearly a conflict of interest."

In Britain, under the London Stock Exchange code, shareholders vote on option packages when they are introduced, but companies can change the terms of an existing scheme without obtaining any additional shareholder approval. The maximum stock overhang permitted is 10% over 10 years.

Ms Edkins said that unless the US authorities took action, the huge option packages being installed in the US would be copied elsewhere. "A lot of the pressure on UK pay is because of the US," she said. "Global companies introduce US-style pay to their UK personnel and that puts pressure on UK domestic companies who have to compete."

Hermes did not object to globalisation or high pay but believed directors must "explain and justify" their stock-based compensation in the light of the company's performance. "Fairness" should be a factor in deciding on compensation levels - including the ratio of employees' pay to directors' salaries.

"We have always maintained that we are happy to be in vestors in companies with the highest paid executives in the world as long as they have earned that pay," the letter says.

It continues: "It can be extremely irksome to shareholders when officers receive large payouts at times when their company has underperformed its peers (as recently occurred at Disney).

"In our experience, too much of the disclosure on compensation is bland and boilerplate. The stock exchanges, and the SEC [Securities and Exchange Commission], could play a key role in setting higher standards in this area."

webTitle: Comment: asylum seekers put liberals in deep quandary

fields.headline: Can't let them stay, can't send them back. It's a dilemma
fields.standfirst:
Asylum seekers put all liberals in a deep quandary

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Sometimes there is no right answer, there is only better and worse. Nothing currently said or done about asylum seekers is good, though it could be worse (some European countries are far tougher on refugees).
fields.body:
Sometimes there is no right answer, there is only better and worse. Nothing currently said or done about asylum seekers is good, though it could be worse (some European countries are far tougher on refugees). Very little honesty is spoken about it: Labour's pollsters warn them it is a wicked issue with voters, Tory politicians use it wickedly. "Bogus" and "abusive" is what politicians call migrants, but bogus and abusive better describes the way most politicians talk.

Jack Straw's plan for protecting Europe from the hordes of the world's poor is starting to take shape. In Stockholm on Friday he will be among the European interior ministers debating how best to form a common EU policy. It plainly makes no sense for the French to allow a camp at Calais of would-be stowaways to Dover, refusing to take them back if Britain tries to return them, claiming they should go instead to wherever they first entered the EU - which can never be proved. Each country has its own immigration angst.

The Straw plan envisages camps set up in neighbouring third countries. Afghans fleeing the Taliban, for example, would stay in Pakistan. Pakistan would be paid by the EU or UN to run camps that would process them: those accepted as genuine refugees would then be assigned to western nations according to quota, as happened in Kosovo. The advantage for Europe is that anyone arriving by any other route could be turned round at port and sent right back to these camps. Few would risk their savings on a terrifying illegal journey only to be sent straight back to the region on arrival. At last, says Straw somewhat disingenuously, this would be a system that makes sense, since not even genuine asylum seekers can currently arrive here legally.

It sounds neat, but this is a looking-glass world where nothing is what it seems, no figures are what they pretend and the law is an ass. What we will see in Stockholm is fortress Europe tugging on the drawbridge to stop waves of migration that can only increase every year. One way or another it has to be done: if it is not done by social democratic governments with at least some semblance of decency it will be done by the Haiders and the Berlusconis far more savagely, sweeping to power on the back of this very issue.

It puts all liberals into a deep quandary. Few genuinely think there could (even should) be a totally open immigration policy into Europe, but understandably squirm at every alternative: the process of keeping the third world out will always be unpleasant and essentially racist. This is the sharp edge of the world's injustice where the faces of the poor appear on our own doorsteps. Eyeball to eyeball we push them back to a poverty only seen on television. Western human rights ideals look shabby when making nice distinctions between those in danger of persecution and those only risking starvation. But until the west converts to global egalitarianism, that is the way it is. Nasty.

Seventy-five thousand people claimed asylum last year - up from 35,000 in 1997. The backlog of old cases stands at 66,000. The government tosses figures around cavalierly - Straw was at it again in yesterday's speech - but they rarely are what they seem. For example, he said 80% of asylum seekers are refused. (The rest are the "abusive" poor).

First of all, "refused" is a term of art. The system requires applicants dumped on God-forsaken sink estates to fill out a 20-page form in English, without a lawyer, within 14 days. If they fail to do it correctly they are deemed "non-compliant" and automatically refused asylum. There are seven days to appeal on another form, in English; most fail - or not. The Home Office triumphantly declares to the press that most are refused. But that's all a technicality, they are not actually sent back. That is not the end of the story. This arbitrary cruelty is all for show. Last year only some 8,000 people were actually deported.

The fact is that almost all people who make it to these shores end up staying. It is practically impossible to send most of them back because there is no "back". Large numbers of Chinese, Filipinos and others have no documents and their embassies will not accept their nationality. (Some countries rely on the foreign money earned and sent home.) Other applicants wait so long to have their cases resolved it becomes impossible to remove them - long married with many children, settled with good jobs and employers who want to keep them. Many slip away and vanish.

Most of the world's refugees are already camped on the borders of their own countries - the poorest nations forced to cope with the great exoduses caused by war-driven famine. According to Professor Guy Gordon-Gill, Oxford professor of international refugee law, only 0.3% of global refugees ever get anywhere near the EU: only the relatively rich or remarkably resourceful make it, so we need not fear a vast expansion of numbers. Keeping more of them in camps will do nothing to stop the criminal gangs bringing in illegals from China or eastern Europe. Nor will it become any easier to return them. Many will come, many will stay. There is no final solution.

A recent UN population study predicts that in the next generation Italy will lose 28% of its population, Estonia 33% and Germany 25%. Already Europe is heavily dependent on unknown battalions of illegals who cook, clean and heave rubbish in the cities, pick and dig East Anglian fields. Illegals who disappear into the fabric of countries are no problem. The worst problems are caused by trying to contain them: for six months on vouchers they are kept in expensive, festering hell-holes, prevented from working though willing to do the worst jobs for the least pay. After that, they will make their own way and assimilate. So why bother?

The Tory plan to lock up all 75,000 migrants and asylum seekers in detention centres indefinitely defies belief. What will happen to those who are not refugees but without papers can never be sent back? Will they stay there for ever? To imprison 60,000 a year would cost £2bn to set up and £1bn in running costs. (Figures not yet in Portillo's tax-spend plan.) Even if the government processed cases faster and the Home Office's catastrophic failure of administration were put right, most migrants could probably still not be deported.

Both Jack Straw and Anne Widdecombe talk through their hat when they each propose new systems that will prevent/deter/end migration. Most asylum seekers come from the poorest most war-torn places - Somalia, Iraq, Iran and Sri Lanka. In the long run, the gradual spread of democracy and peace, solving problems at source - as in Sierra Leone - will be the only solution. How Britain can be rejecting Iraqis as genuine refugees while still bombing their dictator is unclear. But that is just another bizarre example of an impossible policy that can never be right.

fields.bodyText: Sometimes there is no right answer, there is only better and worse. Nothing currently said or done about asylum seekers is good, though it could be worse (some European countries are far tougher on refugees). Very little honesty is spoken about it: Labour's pollsters warn them it is a wicked issue with voters, Tory politicians use it wickedly. "Bogus" and "abusive" is what politicians call migrants, but bogus and abusive better describes the way most politicians talk. Jack Straw's plan for protecting Europe from the hordes of the world's poor is starting to take shape. In Stockholm on Friday he will be among the European interior ministers debating how best to form a common EU policy. It plainly makes no sense for the French to allow a camp at Calais of would-be stowaways to Dover, refusing to take them back if Britain tries to return them, claiming they should go instead to wherever they first entered the EU - which can never be proved. Each country has its own immigration angst. The Straw plan envisages camps set up in neighbouring third countries. Afghans fleeing the Taliban, for example, would stay in Pakistan. Pakistan would be paid by the EU or UN to run camps that would process them: those accepted as genuine refugees would then be assigned to western nations according to quota, as happened in Kosovo. The advantage for Europe is that anyone arriving by any other route could be turned round at port and sent right back to these camps. Few would risk their savings on a terrifying illegal journey only to be sent straight back to the region on arrival. At last, says Straw somewhat disingenuously, this would be a system that makes sense, since not even genuine asylum seekers can currently arrive here legally. It sounds neat, but this is a looking-glass world where nothing is what it seems, no figures are what they pretend and the law is an ass. What we will see in Stockholm is fortress Europe tugging on the drawbridge to stop waves of migration that can only increase every year. One way or another it has to be done: if it is not done by social democratic governments with at least some semblance of decency it will be done by the Haiders and the Berlusconis far more savagely, sweeping to power on the back of this very issue. It puts all liberals into a deep quandary. Few genuinely think there could (even should) be a totally open immigration policy into Europe, but understandably squirm at every alternative: the process of keeping the third world out will always be unpleasant and essentially racist. This is the sharp edge of the world's injustice where the faces of the poor appear on our own doorsteps. Eyeball to eyeball we push them back to a poverty only seen on television. Western human rights ideals look shabby when making nice distinctions between those in danger of persecution and those only risking starvation. But until the west converts to global egalitarianism, that is the way it is. Nasty. Seventy-five thousand people claimed asylum last year - up from 35,000 in 1997. The backlog of old cases stands at 66,000. The government tosses figures around cavalierly - Straw was at it again in yesterday's speech - but they rarely are what they seem. For example, he said 80% of asylum seekers are refused. (The rest are the "abusive" poor). First of all, "refused" is a term of art. The system requires applicants dumped on God-forsaken sink estates to fill out a 20-page form in English, without a lawyer, within 14 days. If they fail to do it correctly they are deemed "non-compliant" and automatically refused asylum. There are seven days to appeal on another form, in English; most fail - or not. The Home Office triumphantly declares to the press that most are refused. But that's all a technicality, they are not actually sent back. That is not the end of the story. This arbitrary cruelty is all for show. Last year only some 8,000 people were actually deported. The fact is that almost all people who make it to these shores end up staying. It is practically impossible to send most of them back because there is no "back". Large numbers of Chinese, Filipinos and others have no documents and their embassies will not accept their nationality. (Some countries rely on the foreign money earned and sent home.) Other applicants wait so long to have their cases resolved it becomes impossible to remove them - long married with many children, settled with good jobs and employers who want to keep them. Many slip away and vanish. Most of the world's refugees are already camped on the borders of their own countries - the poorest nations forced to cope with the great exoduses caused by war-driven famine. According to Professor Guy Gordon-Gill, Oxford professor of international refugee law, only 0.3% of global refugees ever get anywhere near the EU: only the relatively rich or remarkably resourceful make it, so we need not fear a vast expansion of numbers. Keeping more of them in camps will do nothing to stop the criminal gangs bringing in illegals from China or eastern Europe. Nor will it become any easier to return them. Many will come, many will stay. There is no final solution. A recent UN population study predicts that in the next generation Italy will lose 28% of its population, Estonia 33% and Germany 25%. Already Europe is heavily dependent on unknown battalions of illegals who cook, clean and heave rubbish in the cities, pick and dig East Anglian fields. Illegals who disappear into the fabric of countries are no problem. The worst problems are caused by trying to contain them: for six months on vouchers they are kept in expensive, festering hell-holes, prevented from working though willing to do the worst jobs for the least pay. After that, they will make their own way and assimilate. So why bother? The Tory plan to lock up all 75,000 migrants and asylum seekers in detention centres indefinitely defies belief. What will happen to those who are not refugees but without papers can never be sent back? Will they stay there for ever? To imprison 60,000 a year would cost £2bn to set up and £1bn in running costs. (Figures not yet in Portillo's tax-spend plan.) Even if the government processed cases faster and the Home Office's catastrophic failure of administration were put right, most migrants could probably still not be deported. Both Jack Straw and Anne Widdecombe talk through their hat when they each propose new systems that will prevent/deter/end migration. Most asylum seekers come from the poorest most war-torn places - Somalia, Iraq, Iran and Sri Lanka. In the long run, the gradual spread of democracy and peace, solving problems at source - as in Sierra Leone - will be the only solution. How Britain can be rejecting Iraqis as genuine refugees while still bombing their dictator is unclear. But that is just another bizarre example of an impossible policy that can never be right. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com Related articles How to claim asylum An A-Z of asylum seekers The main parties' positions on asylum seekers 06.02.2001: Straw wants to toughen asylum rules 04.02.2001: Tony Blair and Italian counterpart Guiliano Amato write for the Observer 06.02.2001: Asylum seekers to be 'sent back' 05.02.2001: Grim war on human traffickers 28.01.2001: Bosnia's corrupt elite grow fat on human cargo smuggled to West 28.01.2001: People trade makes Bosnia rich Interactive guide Seeking asylum: who, where and why? webTitle: Comment: Bush is making a disastrous error with NMD

fields.headline: It's a friend's duty to speak up
fields.standfirst:
Tell Bush that he is making a disastrous error with NMD

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Tell Bush that he is making a disastrous error with NMD
fields.body:
With the installation of a new US president in the White House, the time for an early test of the "special UK-US relationship" is at hand, on an issue of great importance to the security and well being of British citizens. The issue is the strong commitment of George Bush to the early deployment of a "robust national missile defense (NMD) system".

The dangerous illogic of this commitment is evident in his simultaneous call for deep reductions in the numbers of US and Russian strategic nuclear weapons. Calling for both early deployment of an NMD system and deep reductions in nuclear weapons suggests that he is unaware that both Russia and China have repeatedly warned that any NMD system which violates the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) treaty will stimulate an increase in nuclear weapons - not reductions. Unfortunately, it is not hard to believe that he is oblivious to this danger because he has no experience, knowledge or previous interest in international security matters.

Because Mr Bush has surrounded himself with security advisers who are second-time-around cold war hawks from the first President Bush's team, it appears unlikely that he will hear any cautionary words from them. What is desperately needed is knowledgeable, objective and forceful advice from America's closest allies who will suffer the consequences of an unwise decision in Washington. It is all too easy for the hawks to dismiss threats by Russia and China but it will be much harder to ignore reasoned objections from America's closest friends and indispensable security partners.

Today the US and Russia remain locked in a cold war confrontation with nearly 5,000 nuclear warheads on hair-trigger alert, ready to launch in less than 15 minutes. What little stability exists rests on a fragile framework of arms control agreements which gradually have cut the numbers in half from the peak of almost 25,000 strategic weapons in 1989. Talks already under way could reduce that total to as low as 3,000 if the Russian proposal for 1,500 for each side is accepted. This will not happen - cannot happen - if the foundation of all nuclear arms control agreements, the 1972 ABM treaty, is abrogated by the US. All constructive efforts to reduce weapons will end. Instability will return, not only between the US and Russia but in China, India and Pakistan.

Furthermore, Russia is sending signals that such instability will force it to place more reliance for security on its vast arsenal of tactical, short range nuclear systems. These pose no threat to Americans at home, only to Russia's neighbours in Europe and Asia.

Fortunately, Britain has a strong reason to speak up, plus leverage to apply in Washington where the need for foresight and common sense has never been greater. The two levers are Fylingdales, the RAF radar station in Yorkshire, and the future role of Nato in European security. In a display of superpower hubris, current US planning for the NMD system assumes London's assent to effect a major upgrade of missile tracking facilities at Fylingdales. Such an upgrade would make the UK a willing abettor in America's abrogation of the ABM treaty, as well as create a major nuclear target on British soil. There is also the near certainty that in domestic political terms Fylingdales will become the new Greenham Common. Even Republicans will remember the role that location played in the removal of nuclear-tipped ground launched Cruise missiles from Europe and ultimately in their destruction under the Intermediate-range Nuclear Force (INF) treaty of 1987.

Even more important, British support is essential to US efforts to maintain the primacy of the Nato alliance in European security arrangements. Without such support, the pendulum will inevitably swing to the EU and thus mute America's dominant voice in Brussels. This may happen anyway, but Washington will be loath to speed the process by alienating London with demands for support of an NMD system which will weaken all efforts to prevent nuclear proliferation globally.

While no formal objection has yet emerged in Ottawa, former minister of foreign affairs, Lloyd Axworthy, has called a conference of interested parties in Vancouver on February 16 to formulate a strategy for Canadians to oppose NMD deployment. This could add weight to a growing chorus of allied opposition to an NMD system.

There is an American saying that friends don't let friends drive drunk. The time is right to use the special UK-US relationship as the basis for telling a new American president, with a tenuous grasp on security issues, that the US seems intoxicated with its role as the only superpower. Mr Bush must be cautioned to reasses.

Rear Admiral Eugene J Carroll Jr was on General Alexander Haig's staff in Europe from 1977 to 1979 and director of US military operations for US forces in Europe and the Middle East. He is now vice president of the Center for Defense Information in Washington DC.

webTitle: Full monty: naked Brit shocks Belgium

fields.headline: Full monty: naked Brit shocks Belgium
fields.trailText: Rarely have so many been offended by the spectacle of an Englishman without any clothes as in Belgium, where the quivering rolls of fat and generously proportioned naked torso of an unknown London comedian have caused moral outrage.
fields.body:
Rarely have so many been offended by the spectacle of an Englishman without any clothes as in Belgium, where the quivering rolls of fat and generously proportioned naked torso of an unknown London comedian have caused moral outrage.

Frank Scantori, the comedian in question, may be unknown in Britain but in Belgium he has become a cause célèbre by appearing naked in a television ad campaign which has scandalised the nation.

Mr Scantori plays the part of an overweight office boss doing his best to recruit a young girl to his firm. His methods, however, are unconventional.

His jokey, Full-Monty-style striptease culminates in him clambering naked on to his desk and proffering the startled youngster a contract with which he covers his groin. The ad is for Adecco, one of the world's biggest recruitment agencies, and the message it tries to convey is that young people should not rush to accept the first job they are offered without first trying out a variety of jobs by signing up with the agency.

With its deliberately provocative slogan, Don't let yourself be seduced too quickly, it strikes a special chord in Belgium, where employers are offering all kinds of incentives to attract young graduates because of a national labour shortage.

Intended to amuse rather than offend, the ad has drawn a storm of protest from viewers. It has also triggered a court case and been banned by the country's advertising standards agency.

Several broadcasters have refused to show it.

The problem, they argue, is that it could encourage sexual harassment in the work place, and that is in bad taste.

Duval Guillaume, the advertising agency which came up with the idea, specialises in provocative campaigns - ads in the same series have featured employers as prostitutes soliciting graduates from shop windows and a gaggle of bosses offering a contract to a newborn baby.

Jens Mortier, the striptease ad's creator, is unrepentant.

"It's true that it's provocative, but we're not shocking people just for the sake of it," he said. "If you want to reach people, you have to do something that they notice."

"There is some nudity here, but it's so over the top that it's clearly a parody. If we had used a beautiful woman doing a striptease nobody would have complained. It's just that we reversed the roles."

The ad ended its run last month, but not before millions of people in Belgium and the Netherlands had seen it.

The fuss it is creating shows no signs of dying down either.

RTBF, Belgium's equivalent of the BBC, had to be forced to show it after losing an acrimonious court case with Adecco.

In ultra-liberal Holland, on the other hand, the ad has raised few eyebrows and has even been nominated as one of the best ads of the year.

webTitle: Anger as ex-lobbyist joins drug watchdog

fields.headline: Anger as ex-lobbyist joins drug watchdog
fields.trailText: The Australian government was accused yesterday of pandering to global pharmaceutical companies after a former industry lobbyist was appointed to what is supposed to be an independent prescription drug watchdog.
fields.body:
The Australian government was accused yesterday of pandering to global pharmaceutical companies after a former industry lobbyist was appointed to what is supposed to be an independent prescription drug watchdog.

Eleven health professionals quit the 13-person Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) when a government shakeup of the panel led to the appointment of Pat Clear, a former head of the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association, and a Glaxo-Wellcome executive.

Mr Clear was given the position despite a government review of the PBAC last year which concluded that any appointment of drug industry representatives would be "untenable".

"They've cut our balls off," said Don Birkett, who resigned as PBAC chairman. "To put someone like that on the committee is handing over our national decision-making capacity to the pharmaceutical industry. It's a clear and obvious conflict of interest."

The PBAC decides which prescription drugs qualify for a portion of the A$3.2bn (£1.2bn) annual public subsidy under Australia's pharmaceutical benefits system (PBS), which regulates prices for consumers.

The federal health minister, Michael Wooldridge, denied there was a conflict of interest, stressing that Mr Clear had retired from the drug manufacturers' association last year.

"It is entirely appropriate for a person with previous industry experience to be a member of this committee," he said.

The PBAC is a model for regulatory systems worldwide - Britain's National Institute for Clinical Excellence is one of its counterparts, and was the first watchdog to demand cost-effectiveness from pharmaceutical companies, forcing them to justify their prices for prescription drugs on wider grounds than just their cost of manufacture.

The International Union of Pharmacology, which advises the UN and the World Health Organisation, has written to Canberra in protest at the appointment of Mr Clear.

The union's delegate to the WHO told the Australian government: "Please consider that Australia is a model for drug use in developing countries which, until now, have had a chaotic drug market."

David Henry, who was forced off the committee during the recent shakeup, said: "There is now the possibility that the spiralling cost of the pharmaceutical benefits system will get passed on to the public, who will have to pay more for their drugs.

"As soon as you do that, it's inequitable," he said. "The people who need the drugs most will be the least able to afford it."

Several former panel members alleged that drug companies have been trying to undermine the committee for some time because of the power it has to shape the prescription drug market in the country and to keep prices down.

Last year the panel was taken to the Australian federal court by a US pharmaceutical giant, Pfizer, after refusing to approve a subsidy for its product, Viagra.

The male potency drug costs A$70 (£26) for four tablets but with a state subsidy, it could have cost people as little as A$3.30, netting Pfizer millions in increased sales.

The company lost the initial hearing.

Professor Henry said: "Now we'll have the situation where the next company which takes the committee to court will have somebody on the committee who can tell them exactly what the committee is thinking about the forthcoming court case."

Only two of the new committee members appointed by the health minister in the shakeup have previous experience on the panel.

This, Professor Birkett says, "has caused all the experience and expertise and corporate memory to disappear".

fields.headline: GE keeps up Equitable pressure
fields.trailText: GE Capital last night continued to stalk Equitable Life after spending the day locked in meetings to decide whether to trump the agreed £1bn deal with Halifax.
fields.body:
GE Capital last night continued to stalk Equitable Life after spending the day locked in meetings to decide whether to trump the agreed £1bn deal with Halifax.

The financial services arm of General Electric of the US was refusing to throw in the towel, even though Equitable insisted that the process of integrating its businesses with the Halifax had already begun.

Over the weekend Halifax reached a last minute deal to inject up to £1bn into Equitable in a move which could improve the fortunes of the mutual insurance group's beleaguered policyholders.

However, GE Capital wants the board of Equitable to consider its approach, made on Friday, to pay up to £425m for certain of Equitable's assets and make it a £750m loan.

Last night Equitable said that Halifax's offer was "streets ahead" of the GE approach and described the agreement with the Halifax as a "done deal".

Halifax also insisted that nothing could be done to break apart the agreement. "The deal is done, the ink is dry," Halifax said. Its management team was installed in Equitable's headquarters in Aylesbury yesterday just one day after the deal was agreed.

It is understood, however, that GE is looking for ways to break into the agreement.

webTitle: Rage and hope mix in election of hated enemy

fields.headline: Rage and hope mix in election of hated enemy
fields.standfirst:
Leaders believe Israeli isolation could aid cause
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is ready to meet Ariel Sharon as Israeli prime minister, the PLO confirmed last night.
fields.body:
The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is ready to meet Ariel Sharon as Israeli prime minister, the PLO confirmed last night.

"He'll meet whoever is in power in Israel," Afif Safieh, Palestinian general delegate to Britain and the European community, said. "The election is an internal Israeli matter. Our expectations for the peace process remain constant ... we don't tailor our aspirations according to who the Israelis elect."

Mr Safieh said that Labour governments in Israel - including the outgoing administration of Ehud Barak - "present a more formidable challenge for the Palestinians because of their undeserved good reputation abroad".

He said a Likud government under Mr Sharon would dam age Israel's relations with the US and Europe, as well as embarrassing Jewish communities in the diaspora.

"This will be an additional incentive for the major players in the international system to step in," he said. He expected the international community to become "much more demanding" towards Israel.

In Ramallah on the West Bank, the prominent Fatah activist Marwan Barghouti called on Palestinians to step up a four-month-old uprising in response to the election.

"We have to face Sharon by strengthening the intifada," he said. "I don't think there is any chance to negotiate with Sharon under any circumstances and we call on our Arab neighbours not to invite Sharon, and not to be mediators with Sharon."

Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, the founder of the Islamic militant group Hamas, said Mr Barak and Mr Sharon were cut from the same cloth. "The two men have Palestinian blood on their hands," he told Reuters.

In Ramallah yesterday, Palestinian demonstrators burned effigies of both Mr Barak and Mr Sharon - reflecting a widespread view that there is not much difference between the outgoing prime minister and his replacement.

"We have tried Barak and we faced killings and suffering. We are not sure Sharon would represent a bigger danger to the peace process," said Abdel-Raouf Barbakh, 27, from Rafah in Gaza.

Elsewhere in the Arab world, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said that he would not personally initiate contacts with Mr Sharon, "whom I only met once, unlike Barak whom I was in regular contact with over the phone".

Speaking in an interview with Israeli television, he added: "If he [Sharon] wants to contact me to reach something serious, that would be OK. Otherwise, I am not interested in making contacts."

Ariel Sharon, for most Arabs, is the ultimate symbol of war and represents the worst they know of Israel since its creation in 1948.

"His CV in fighting against Arabs leaves doubt that he could suddenly turn into a man of peace as some people might try to claim," Mohammed Sayed Said, of the Al-Ahram Centre for Political and Strategic Studies, said.

"What he announced in his electoral programme is truly what he believes in. He will not give Palestinians more than 40 to 50% of the occupied land, will seek to build a settlement every day and react with massive violence to any expected attack by Palestinian militants."

For all of the Arab countries bordering Israel - Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria - Mr Sharon's name brings only bad memories. For the Egyptians, he was the one who turned their initial victory in the 1973 war into defeat by leading his unit in across the Suez canal and occupying part of Egypt's territory.

For Lebanon, he is the leader of the 1982 invasion that reached as far as Beirut. A few months later, he watched passively as rightwing Lebanese militias massacred hundreds of Palestinian refugees in Sabra and Shatila.

As far as Jordan is concerned, Sharon belongs to the school of Israeli rightwingers who spouted the slogan "Jordan is Palestine" with the aim of annexing the occupied Palestinian West Bank once and for all.

Sahar Baasiri, Arab affairs editor at the Lebanese daily, Annahar, believes that Mr Sharon's victory reflects "the deep crisis within Israel itself".

"At least 50% of Israelis do not seem to believe any more that those negotiations are the way to reach peace, opting instead to remind Arabs of their massive power. Therefore, they decided to choose the man of war."

But Wahid Abdel-Meguid, an Egyptian expert on Arab affairs, subscribes to another view which is circulating in Arab streets and media: that Mr Sharon might not turn out to be the man every Arab fears.

"He knows of his bad reputation and bloody past. Certainly he will try to change that," he said, adding that in the past it has always been Likud governments that have struck serious deals with Arab countries.

"It was [Menachem] Begin who signed Camp David with Egypt in 1979, and without Sharon's help, Israel would have never got out of Sinai. "Meanwhile, all major wars against Arabs were led by Labour governments."

fields.headline: Smith floats state lottery plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The government is drawing up plans to nationalise the lottery to avoid a repeat of last summer's fiasco over who should run the multi-billion pound game.
fields.body:
The government is drawing up plans to nationalise the lottery to avoid a repeat of last summer's fiasco over who should run the multi-billion pound game.

In a move which will dismay the New Labour faithful, who regard nationalisation as a symbol of their discredited past, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said that a formal review of the future of the lottery would consider taking it into public hands.

Appearing before the Commons culture select committee, Mr Smith said: "It has been said to me by quite a number of people that an option could perhaps be to see a lottery that is effectively owned by the nation through the government.

"Individual services for the running of the lottery would be contracted out to suppliers."

Mr Smith's remarks, which could lead to the first nationalisation by a Labour government in more than two decades, were condemned last night by the Tories.

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, said: "It is difficult to imagine that the lottery would benefit from being owned by the state, which is not generally a good provider of modern services. This is a kneejerk response to the farce of last year and would help Labour's efforts to control the lottery."

Mr Smith made his remarks as he faced intense questions from MPs over the events of last summer when Sir Richard Branson was initially favoured to take over the lottery. After a lengthy review, involving a court case, Camelot's licence was renewed for another seven years.

Gerald Kaufman, the veteran Labour chairman of the select committee, said he saw no problem with government-run lotteries after visiting the United States, where two-thirds of lotteries are run by state authorities. "Here we have a Labour government that is less socialist than republicans in the US," Mr Kaufman said.

Conscious of the sensitivity of talking about nationalisation, Mr Smith insisted that he was "agnostic" about whether the government should take over the lottery.

He added that the government's painful experience of the Millennium Dome would make ministers cautious.

webTitle: Outrage at lack of GM crop 'safety zones'

fields.headline: Outrage at lack of GM crop 'safety zones'
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: The government decided last night to press ahead with 96 new trials of genetically modified crops this spring but unexpectedly refused to segregate them from conventional crops.
fields.body:
The government decided last night to press ahead with 96 new trials of genetically modified crops this spring but unexpectedly refused to segregate them from conventional crops, leaving farmers and environmentalists outraged.

However, ministers accepted the trials will contaminate conventional crops nearby, leaving themselves open to damage claims from farmers whose crops may be unsaleable as a result.

Pleas by the organic and environmental lobby to leave 3km exclusion zones around GM crops in order to protect conventional varieties were rejected. The ministry of agriculture has increased the maximum margin from 50 to 100 metres. Agriculture minister Baroness Hayman accepted this would contaminate conventional crops but only up to 1%.

This could still render many farmers' crops unsaleable since all major British supermarkets now refuse to take GM contaminated food - or even produce from animals fed on GM crops.

Organic farmers have warned Michael Meacher, the environment minister, and Baroness Hayman that they could be put out of business unless the field margins were increased to 3km. They reject the ministry's claims that the contamination would be 1% or less - the Scottish Crop Research Institute, in Dundee, says it could easily reach 5%

The Soil Association, which polices organic farming, had asked for the exclusion zone to avoid members' crops being cross-pollinated by bees or wind-blown pollen.

John Holden, head of the association, said: "Contamination is inevitable."

The govenment hopes that GM oil seed rape plantings will begin in mid-March, sugar beet from the end of March, and maize from April. The purpose of the research is to check on cross-contamination of crops and the effect of GM crops on weeds and wildlife, including bees.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday: 'Air was filled with screams of terror'

fields.headline: 'Air was filled with screams of terror'
fields.standfirst:
There was no reason for troops to open fire, says bishop

Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: The priest who was filmed waving a white handkerchief after the Bloody Sunday shootings nearly 30 years ago yesterday gave his evidence to the new inquiry.
fields.body:
The priest who was filmed waving a white handkerchief after the Bloody Sunday shootings nearly 30 years ago yesterday gave his evidence to the new inquiry.

The retired Bishop of Londonderry, Edward Daly, was a 38-year-old priest when television pictures of him waving the handkerchief in front of those carrying a dying boy, Jackie Duddy, 17, were beamed around the world.

He is one of more than 1,000 witnesses giving evidence to Lord Saville's tribunal into what happened when paratroopers opened fire at a civil rights demonstration in Londonderry on January 30 1972, killing 14 unarmed Catholic men.

The public gallery at the city's Guildhall was packed as Bishop Daly, 67, gave evidence for more than three hours. Jackie Duddy's sisters, Kay and Bernie, were there to hear him speak about the teenager's last moments. Kay still keeps the handkerchief used to tend his wounds.

Bishop Daly, a lifelong critic of violence from all quarters, told how the air was filled with screams of terror as the panic-stricken crowd ran from the soldiers, who fired, in his opinion, with no justification.

He described how another teenager, Michael Bridge, shouted hysterically at soldiers with his hands outstretched just before he was shot and injured, and how later, he gave the last rites to at least half a dozen people in the Bogside.

He also saw just one civilian gunman fire a few shots and yelled at him to go away, but he did not think soldiers spotted this man or they would have riddled him with bullets.

But he dismissed as "offensive nonsense" suggestions, previously raised by lawyers for the soldiers, that up to 34 extra casualties were secretly buried because they included IRA terrorists who had been firing at troops.

While he admitted paramilitary snipers had on other occasions used riots as cover while attacking security forces, he insisted he saw no petrol or nail bombs on Bloody Sunday and that neither Mr Duddy nor Mr Bridge had anything in their hands when they were shot.

Bishop Daly said rioting was commonplace in Londonderry at that time and followed an almost choreographed sequence of events.

But on Bloody Sunday the choreography was broken when the army pressed forward into the Bogside and panic set in. He was aware of Jackie Duddy running alongside him, laughing with fear rather than humour, and his disbelief when he was shot.

"I heard a shot and simultaneously this young boy gasped or groaned loudly," he said. "I looked around and the young boy just fell on his face. I could not imagine that he had been hit by a live round."

Then there was a burst of gunfire and the priest threw himself to the ground amid the terrified crowd. During a lull in the firing, he went back to help Jackie Duddy.

"I knelt beside him. There was a substantial amount of blood oozing from his shirt. I put my handkerchief inside his shirt to try to staunch the bleeding. I administered the last rites to him," he said. Bishop Daly told how he walked in front of the group who tried to carry Mr Duddy to safety, but he could not be sure when the young boy died. A lawyer for the Duddy family thanked the bishop for tending Jackie that day.

Michael Mansfield QC, counsel for some of the bereaved, showed Bishop Daly a statement from an unnamed soldier claiming he was among a team asked to dig up unmarked graves in a cemetery.

Many in the public gallery laughed when the statement said they found the bodies of seven or eight men, not in coffins, who, the soldier suggested, were IRA terrorists shot dead on Bloody Sunday.

Bishop Daly said: "I think it's unthinkable. It's a figment of imagination that the type of thing described by this witness could have taken place." Edwin Glasgow QC, counsel for many of the soldiers, disassociated his clients from the statement quoted by Mr Mansfield and praised Bishop Daly for his condemnation of all violence, including an attack on Aldershot barracks less than a month after Bloody Sunday, in which seven people died.

But when Mr Glasgow asked if he was not concerned that terrorists sometimes took advantage of the cover of civil rights marches, the bishop insisted this was not the case on Bloody Sunday.

"The right to protest about something perceived as a grave injustice is a very important right in a democracy," he said.

fields.headline: Pricey Portcullis
fields.standfirst: Another £10m on bill for MPs' new home
fields.trailText: Another £10m on bill for MPs' new home
fields.body:
The construction of the £233m Portcullis House - new home for many of Westminster's MPs - has cost the public a further £10m, it was revealed yesterday. A national audit office report showed the public purse has been forced to pay out millions more in a settlement with a construction company.

Harmon CFEM Facades (UK) Ltd won a high court case against the House of Commons after a rival company won the contract for the building's bronze cladding, even though Harmon's bid was cheaper . A judge ruled the parliamentary works directorate had committed a "misfeasance in public office" in not awarding the contract to Harmon. The firm was awarded £5.3m compensation. The taxpayer also had to pay a legal bill of some £4.6m. The £10m bill will be added to the already colossal cost of the office building, the most expensive per square foot in Britain, which included £150,000 spent on imported fig trees from Florida, £200,000 for potted plants, and a £440 reclining chair with "snooze" position for each MP.

fields.headline: 'Hundreds of millions are destitute'
fields.trailText:
February 7th [1951]  
To the Editor of the Manchester Guardian Newspapers Ltd
fields.byline: To the Editor of the Manchester Guardian Newspapers Ltd
fields.body:
February 7th [1951] To the Editor of the Manchester Guardian Newspapers Ltd

Sir, We are committed now in Korea to a war for which, since the "branding" of China, no end can be foreseen.

We are committed to a rearmament so vast that our sheer daily absorption in it must rob us more and more of the spiritual freshness and energy indispensable for the achievement of peace.

Every day now our minds are being more completely conditioned: the "hell bomb" is the latest attraction in the Sunday press, and Amiel, whom not one Englishman in ten thousand has ever heard of, is brought on from the grave to warn us that long before "The Hun" invaded Belguim, "the Russians" were barbarians.

It is impossible to exaggerate the deterioration even during the last two months. Useless, then, to repeat like a parrot, that war is not inevitable: war is now quite inevitable unless we make an almost superhuman effort, of a new and more positive kind, to prevent it.

I suggest a two-point programme. First, the proposed conference with Russia, which has been hanging about as if we had eternity at our disposal and now looks like being held up (if it comes off at all) for heaven knows how many further exchanges, should be pressed on with as if our lives depended on its immediate convening ...

Manoeuvring for position, warfare by "Notes", all should be thrown overboard: we just have not time for them ...

The great thing is to get together on anybody's ground and then make a desperate effort to widen things out and achieve agreement. But now comes the crux: however certain our statesmen may be - and I share their certainty - that the Kremlin is primarily responsible for our present disasters, we must yet negotiate, as Mr Nehru has urged, not in the mood of war, but in the mood of peace.

Nothing could be harder, but if we can make so vast an effort to rearm materially, cannot we make a comparable effort to disarm spiritually, to subdue our passions? And I suggest that apart from this particular conference with Russia, we should always and everywhere substitute human negotiations face to face for long-range paper warfare.

Secondly, we should take the initiative in proposing for immediate discussion some variant of the plan already proposed by Walther Reuther [a US labour leader active in world affairs], namely that a great international fund should be established, as an urgent matter of life or death, for improving the conditions of those fellow human beings who, to the number of hundreds of millions, are starving, destitute and in despair.

I should like to see our own country, by the size of its proposed contribution, challenging the world to a new kind of rivalry, a rivalry in the works of peace.

So might international dis cussion, leading to international administration, find itself with a fruitful topic instead of a sterile one.

So might the trend to war, issuing from a concentration on national as opposed to international interests, be reversed. So at last might swords be turned into ploughshares.

May I ask through you, Sir, that all who are in agreement with this letter should send a postcard with just the word "Yes" and their name and address to me at 14 Henrietta Street, London WC2.

I do not guarantee any action of any kind, but if the response is large enough something might possibly come of it.

Yours, Victor Gollancz

14 Henrietta Street

London WC2

But now comes the crux: however certain our statesmen may be - and I share their certainty - that the Kremlin is primarily responsible for our present disasters, we must yet negotiate, as Mr Nehru has urged, not in the mood of war, but in the mood of peace. Nothing could be harder, but if we can make so vast an effort to rearm materially, cannot we make a comparable effort to disarm spiritually, to subdue our passions? And I suggest that apart from this particular conference with Russia, we should always and everywhere substitute human negotiations face to face for long-range paper warfare. Secondly, we should take the initiative in proposing for immediate discussion some variant of the plan already proposed by Walther Reuther [a US labour leader active in world affairs], namely that a great international fund should be established, as an urgent matter of life or death, for improving the conditions of those fellow human beings who, to the number of hundreds of millions, are starving, destitute and in despair. I should like to see our own country, by the size of its proposed contribution, challenging the world to a new kind of rivalry, a rivalry in the works of peace. So might international dis cussion, leading to international administration, find itself with a fruitful topic instead of a sterile one. So might the trend to war, issuing from a concentration on national as opposed to international interests, be reversed. So at last might swords be turned into ploughshares. May I ask through you, Sir, that all who are in agreement with this letter should send a postcard with just the word "Yes" and their name and address to me at 14 Henrietta Street, London WC2. I do not guarantee any action of any kind, but if the response is large enough something might possibly come of it. Yours, Victor Gollancz 14 Henrietta Street London WC2 www.waronwant.org
