fields.headline: Saharan rebels stranded in camps
fields.standfirst: Casualties of the stalemate between Morocco and the Algerian-backed Polisario rebels, 100,000 refugees subsist on aid.
fields.trailText: Casualties of the stalemate between Morocco and the Algerian-backed Polisario rebels, 100,000 refugees subsist on aid.
fields.body:
Crouched in the cave where some of them have lived for 25 years, the Saharan rebels waved as the convoy of armoured personnel carriers roared into the sunset, trailing a dustcloud as they raced west to attack Morocco's defensive wall.

Sappers had gone ahead to clear paths through the minefields and blast open the defences with TNT. That would be the cue for the vehicles to follow with guns blazing. Fresh mines would be laid against enemy counter-attacks.

By midnight, they thought, the horizon would be flashing orange as the Polisario Front and Morocco resumed their colonial war after a ceasefire of almost 10 years.

Polisario had evacuated its hospitals and barracks in expectation of retaliatory air raids but the mood turned festive as zero-hour approached.

Some of the cave-dwellers, part of a mobile artillery unit, had grown old waiting for this moment. Others had grown up.

Two teenagers grinned as they sorted out ammunition for their 23mm self-propelled gun: pink-tipped for tanks, yellow for aircraft. Sidi Ahmed, 48, caressed a BM-21 Katyusha rocket launcher. "If she could speak she would tell you what she did in the past and what she will do tomorrow."

First light brought not retaliatory air strikes but a Toyota Landcruiser bouncing over the dun-coloured plain. Unwinding a black headscarf, out stepped Commander Ibrahim Bedela, smiling tightly to break the news: "The attack was called off. Orders from headquarters after an appeal from our allies."

Stunned silence met this explanation. If the international community has any doubts about Polisario intentions, the men's reaction to that early January false alarm was instructive. Staring at the ground, distraught, they verg ed on tears. They wanted and expected to fight. They still do.

Morocco annexed the territory after Spain abandoned it as a colony in 1975, sending indigenous Sahrawi nomads fleeing into Algeria. Polisario fighters waged a 16-year war of attrition, fighting and dying for a baked lunar landscape the size of Britain.

Stalemate ensued after Morocco built a defensive wall: 1,500 miles of sand, stone, mines and bunkers winding to the Atlantic coast.

The UN brokered a ceasefire in 1991 on the understanding that the following year a referendum would be held to ask if Western Sahara wanted independence or integration into Morocco. But fearing it would lose, Rabat haggled over voter eligibility while consolidating its occupation with settlers and infrastructure.

All the while more than 100,000 Sahrawi women and children have been left to languish in four camps of canvas and mudbrick.

A former US ambassador sent to organise the referendum, Frank Ruddy, quit in disgust at what he called the UN's failure to resist Moroccan intimidation.

Polisario patience ran out, and this year's Paris-Dakar motor rally was considered a good pretext to end the cease fire when the French organisers did not ask Polisario for permission to cross the disputed territory on January 7.

The strategy was not to seek a military victory over the vastly larger Moroccan army but to damage the enemy's economy with a long, expensive war.

A tour of four battalions in the 2nd military region, based at Tifarity, revealed relish for the fight. And then Commander Bedela's radio crackled with orders to withdraw.

Polisario's bluff had been called. The leaders cited an appeal by the Organisation for African Unity, but in truth Polisario was told by its sponsor, Algeria, to stick to the ceasefire.

President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has enough trouble at home and does not want a regional war deterring investors. Evidently he won over such hawkish generals as Mohammed Lamari, who had encouraged the rebels.

Without Algerian funding and military and diplomatic backing, Polisario's credibility and room for manoeuvre shrivelled. Now it can only pray that Algeria rebuffs James Baker, the special UN envoy twho is reported to be suggesting dropping the referendum in favour of limited Sahrawian autonomy within a greater Morocco.

Washington and Paris, allies of Rabat, are humming along. Polisario is afraid that the Foreign Office is preparing to join the chorus.

"We have justice on our side but not the governments who count," an official lamented.

UN resolutions, western promises a ruling from the International Court of Justice have come to nothing. In the face of Rabat's procrastination, Sahrawian self-determination is now thought unrealistic.

In the refugee camps in the empty plains of southern Alberia - thousands of mud brick houses and nomadic tents - February 27 will mark the 25th anniversary of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, a state in waiting.

Each camp has its own hospital, school, garden and governing council. Aid agencies, which supply almost all the food, praise the administrations: no epidemics, no riots.

Everyone works in exchange for rationed but free food and medicine. But lack of fruit and vegetables is blamed for stunted children with brittle bones.

the hospitals are grim. "Bandages, antibiotics, disinfectant, anaesthetics, syringes, sheets, we're always short," said the director of Rabuni hospital, Mohammed Ainina.

Gedaha Kouri, 70, sat on a bed with her head buried in a shawl, ashamed that all she had for eyes were scars. As with many shepherds, glaucoma is the price she has paid for a life spent in the wind and sun.

"We had no drugs, there was no choice so we removed them," Mr Ainina said. Foreign surgeons visit monthly.

The schools run short of copybooks and pens but the barefoot children invent games with cardboard and tyres. A girl with a skipping rope is mimicked by two friends without. A War on Want convoy of toys is due in March.

Some dream of quitting. They approach with discreet queries about visas and border controls. "I do not want to rot," one man said softly.

Others are committed to stay. "I will remain as long as is necessary to free my country," said Buchra Khatri, 25, who may never use her Cuban economics degree.

The thought that their fate is being sealed in New York, Rabat and Algiers makes some desperate. A middle-ranking official spoke of waging war on three fronts: attacks on the wall, an intifada of Sahrawis in the occupied territory, and terrorism in Morocco. "A few bombs at beaches and hotels would destroy the tourism."

Probably it would. But that is an option Polisario ruled out years ago, when it thought other methods would work.

fields.headline: A radical charity turns 50
fields.standfirst: A letter to the Manchester Guardian inspired the anti-poverty group
fields.trailText: A letter to the Manchester Guardian inspired the anti-poverty group.
fields.body:
Fifty years ago today the leftwing publisher Victor Gollancz wrote to the Manchester Guardian calling for a negotiated end to the Korean war and the creation of an international fund "to turn swords into ploughshares".

Those who agreed with his letter were asked to send a postcard with the word Yes written on it. More than 4,000 people responded, endorsing his call for a political solution to world poverty. War on Want emerged from the ensuing debate.

From the start the organisation focused on changing public policy to make combating global poverty a priority.

One of its first acts was to mobilise the British people to press the government to allocate 1% of GDP to development overseas - a level of funding yet to be reached. As early as 1961 the charity pointed out that most British aid consisted of loans that would end up as unpayable debts.

"If the proportion of loans in our aid is not reduced," it said, "we are heading for trouble".

War on Want also pressed for greater priority to be given to aid programmes, and in 1964 the Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson - a founding member - created the Ministry of Overseas Development. The first minister was Barbara Castle, an early patron of the charity.

War on Want's first overseas task was helping refugees from the war against the French colonialists in Algeria. It also gave financial support to the Bhoodan movement in India, which was trying in the 1960s to realise Gandhi's dream of a village-based development.

In the 1970s it helped to expose the scandal of manufacturers such as Nestle aggressively promoting the sale of milk powder for babies at the expense of breastfeeding. It also campaigned for tea workers' rights in Asia.

In the Thatcher years, when many young people turned to international liberation movements as an outlet for their radical impulses, it was in the vanguard of the international solidarity movement, led by its general secretary, George Galloway, now a Glasgow MP.

It became a target of the right. Complaints were made to the Charity Commission, which censured it for its headline-grabbing advertisements against apartheid and the US involvement in Nicaragua.

John Denham, now a Labour health minister, spearheaded with others a campaign called Profits out of Poverty, which has been credited with bringing the debt crisis in underdeveloped countries to public attention.

In the same period a Women for a Change campaign led others to recognise the critical role of women in fighting world poverty.

In the late 1980s War on Want nearly went bankrupt when inadequate financial management resulting in funds for overseas projects being mixed with general funds.

It later won a substantial out-of-court settlement from its auditors, Somers Baker, for the damage caused to its reputation and income.

The experience led to a revision of accounting procedures for all charities.

War on Want is leaner now, with 20 staff and volunteers and an annual turnover of around £1.4m.

Its drive to get pension funds to invest ethically has brought positive results: the Labour government now requires firms to say whether they take account of social and ethical issues.

The Asian financial crisis of 1997-98, and the resulting increase in poverty, led War on Want to take up the banner against currency speculators and it is now a leading advocate of the Tobin Tax - a proposal to calm markets and raise money for development by levying a tiny tax on currency markets.

On its first leaflet War on Want wrote that closing the gap between the rich and the poor of the earth was "the supreme challenge of the next 50 years".

So it remains, but the additional challenges set by globalisation has moved the same campaigns against world poverty on to a new battleground.

www.waronwant.org

Mark Luetchford is a trustee of War on Want and is writing its history

webTitle: Home Office faces huge bill for ignoring rules by jailing refugees

fields.headline: Home Office faces huge bill for ignoring rules by jailing refugees
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The Home Office faces a compensation bill which could reach millions of pounds for wrongly jailing asylum seekers for travelling on false passports.
fields.body:
The Home Office faces a compensation bill which could reach millions of pounds for wrongly jailing asylum seekers for travelling on false passports.

Thousands were imprisoned between 1994 and 1999, when the high court ruled that jailing asylum seekers for travelling on false documents breached the 1951 Geneva convention on the the status of refugees.

The Home Office would only confirm that it had received a number of applications, but it will have to compensate those who apply under its ex-gratia scheme which pays out in cases of serious default, or where an accused person is completely exonerated.

Solicitors expect payment of at least £10,000 for the typical case in which the courts imposed a six-month sentence. Some were sentenced to nine months, and a few to a year.

Between 500 and 1,000 are thought to have been prosecuted each year between 1994, when prosecutions were stepped up, and the high court judgment in 1999. Most were attempting to pass through the UK on forged passports en route to the US or Canada.

The judgment came in a test case brought by three asylum seekers, two of whom had served six months. The third was being threatened with prosecution for using false papers, even though the home secretary had since granted him indefinite leave to stay.

The two judges delivered a strong rebuke to the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the crown prosecution service for ignoring Britain's obligations under the convention.

Lord Justice Simon Brown said no one in the criminal justice system, including the CPS and defence solicitors, had given "the least thought" to article 31 of the convention, which states that asylum seekers should not be penalised for entering a country illegally.

He said the combination of visa requirements and carrier's liability, which imposes heavy penalties for conveying passengers without documentation, "has made it well nigh impossible for refugees to travel to countries of refuge without false documents".

Most of those who were convicted had been arrested on arrival and brought before magistrates the next day. Typically, they had pleaded guilty after duty solicitors told them they had no defence and would get a shorter sentence for a guilty plea.

Patrick Allen, senior partner of north London solicitors Hodge Jones & Allen, represents a couple from Kosovo who have had their compensation claims accepted by the Home Office. He said: "Many asylum seekers and refugees have been wrongly prosecuted and imprisoned for travelling with false documents. They will be entitled to compensation and the bill for the Home Office could be enormous."

The Kosovan couple arrived at Heathrow en route for Canada in February 1999 using false Greek passports. They were both convicted the following day and sentenced to six months in prison. The pair are now applying for asylum in Britain.

fields.headline: Farm family loses squatting claim
fields.trailText: A farming family lost their claim to 57 acres of potential development land yesterday.
fields.body:
A farming family lost their claim to 57 acres of potential development land yesterday.

Caroline Graham and her father Charles Denton had won a ruling in the high court last year that the land, which could be worth millions of pounds, was theirs because a property development company had not evicted them for 12 years while they farmed it.

But yesterday the court of appeal overturned the ruling because the farmers had never shown an intention to dispossess the property company and claim squatters' rights.

Lord Justice Mummery said there was "credible and uncontradicted evidence from the squatters' themselves" that they did not intend to possess but hoped to reach an agreement to use the land.

The company, JA Pye (Oxford) Ltd, had taken no steps to evict the family from the land next to their farm, Henwick Manor, Thatcham, near Newbury, Berkshire, from 1984 while they negotiated with planners to build houses there.

In the high court Mr Justice Neuberger granted permission for the company to take the case to the court of appeal.

JA Pye bought the manor and land in 1975 but sold most of it two years later, keeping the disputed acres because of the development potential.

In 1982, John Graham bought the farm at auction for his son, Michael, who married Caroline in 1987, and farmed it until the son died in 1998.

The company had granted grazing rights to the family but correspondence ceased in 1985 and the Grahams continued to use it without permission.

Kim Lewison QC, representing the farmers, was refused permission to take the case to the Lords. JA Pye is not claiming legal costs for the appeal but the farmers face high court costs estimated at £200,000.

webTitle: EU looks at Straw's idea to curb migrants

fields.headline: EU looks at Straw's idea to curb migrants
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The home secretary's initiative to stem the flow of illegal migrants into Europe by creating a common asylum system has taken off as a serious project in the European Union.
fields.body:
The home secretary's initiative to stem the flow of illegal migrants into Europe by creating a common asylum system has taken off as a serious project in the European Union.

Strong interest has been expressed in Jack Straw's scheme by Germany, France and Italy as well as support from the Canadian and Australian governments. The European commission has already started a feasibility study into the scheme, which is designed to undermine the growing illegal trade in "people trafficking".

But Mr Straw's initiative for an overhaul of the way Europe deals with asylum seekers, which he launched in Lisbon last year, was met with warnings from refugee groups and lawyers in London yesterday that he was in danger of undermining the individual right to claim asylum enshrined in the 1951 UN convention on refugees.

The new UN high commissioner for refugees, the former Dutch prime minister, Ruud Lubbers, said last night that the EU was in danger of undermining a vital principle. "We should not erode the convention," he warned. "I don't think we should start to water down our international obligations. We have to share the burden in a fair way, but Europe is a very prosperous continent. There is a substantial capacity to receive higher numbers of asylum seekers. But there is a lack of generosity, a lack of funds."

However, Mr Straw insisted that the principles of the 50-year-old convention would remain intact. He justified his radical scheme, which would see the claims of tens of thousands of asylum seekers processed outside of Europe, saying the world had to recognise that the asylum system had drifted out of control of governments and into the hands of criminal people traffickers.

In a speech to the Institute of Public Policy Research, Mr Straw gave details of how Europe could stem the flow of illegal entrants who abuse the asylum system. One option was for the EU to set up a resettlement programme under which an agreed number of refugees would be identified in their own regions and brought to the EU for resettlement, with each country taking an agreed quota.

He said the criteria for selection of refugees would "draw on the experiences of countries such as the US, Canada and Australia".

At the same time new measures would be taken to deter illegal migrants using the international asylum system to enter Europe. "A list of safe countries or groups would be introduced, from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process," said Mr Straw.

He foresaw three separate lists. The first would be a list of "safe countries", such as the US and EU countries, from which asylum applications would not be entertained.

In the second list of countries, such as China, it would be presumed that an asylum application was unfounded and so would have to be made from outside the EU. This list would be drawn up with the advice of the UNHCR. Applicants from a country such as China might have to make their applications in a transit country.

Asylum seekers in this group would also lose the right to claim asylum in an EU country and so could be turned straight back.

The third list would be made up of countries which were internationally recognised to be oppressive regimes and from which asylum applications would be accepted within individual EU countries.

Mr Straw said this overhaul was needed to reduce the attractions of "asylum shopping" by illegal migrants around Europe.

But the Liberal Democrats' Simon Hughes warned that Mr Straw was endangering Britain's "fundamental obligation" to offer asylum to those fleeing persecution, while the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said his plan was a smokescreen to avoid taking real action now to deal with the chaos in the asylum system.

fields.headline: Machete attack carer criticises £49,000 payout
fields.trailText: Nursery nurse Lisa Potts, who shielded children from a machete attacker during a picnic at school 1996, yesterday called for reforms to the compensation system after she received £49,000.
fields.body:
Nursery nurse Lisa Potts, who shielded children from a machete attacker during a picnic at school 1996, yesterday called for reforms to the compensation system after she received £49,000.

Ms Potts, 25, broke down at a news conference also attended by senior officials of her union Unison, which branded the current criminal injuries compensation (CIC) process as cumbersome and unjust.

Ms Potts said that she was unable to return to the job she loved because of psychological damage and had also been forced to pick only three of the multiple injuries she suffered to qualify for the payout. She said: "Nursery work was the job I loved and it's been robbed from me. It's totally unfair. I would have loved to have returned, but I can't."

Ms Potts was 21 when she was left with severe scarring to her arms, hands and back, chronic depression and post-traumatic stress disorder by the frenzied attack at St Luke's school in Wolverhampton. She was awarded the George Medal for flinging herself between the children and Horrett Campbell, a paranoid schizophrenic, who was later jailed for life on seven counts of attempted murder in 1996.

Ms Potts has undergone several operations and still has medical treatment to try to restore her grip in one hand. She also described how she had spent four years dealing with medical examinations and injury reports as part of the compensation process.

She said: "I feel disappointed in the amount for both the physical and psychological injuries. I know that it is the full amount that I can get under the system, and I know that Unison has worked hard on my behalf, but it's clear the system needs to be changed."

Dave Prentis, general secretary of Unison, said "Here is a low paid nursery nurse who risked her life to protect children in her care but who has been let down by a tariff system that cannot reflect her suffering.

"I don't think that this level of compensation is adequate or fair. Particularly when you compare it with the £100,000 libel damages awarded to chef Marco Pierre White only a few weeks ago over accusations that he used real ink instead of squid ink in his cooking. Or the £150,000 for Kevin Keegan over false claims of organised betting sessions. Surely we've got our priorities wrong here?"

Ms Potts' compensation, which includes £8,000 awarded shortly after the attack, divides into £28,000 for loss of earnings, £20,000 for psychological damage, £750 for partial loss of grip and £250 for scarring. Under the system, victims are limited to claims for three injuries, with 100% compensation for the most serious, 10%for the next and 5% for the third.

Unison is arguing for a simpler banding of awards. But the CIC authority's chief executive, Howard Webber, said: "Our scheme lets society show its sympathy for victims. You cannot compare it with awards in the court where a guilty party compensates the victim. Nevertheless the scheme pays out around £200m every year to crime victims and is by a long way the largest of its kind in the world."

webTitle: Jeremy Hardy: A better class of snacks

fields.headline: A better class of snacks
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It is perhaps true that Keith Vaz has attracted more flak than he might have done if he were white. It is likely that Peter Mandelson would be more popular if he were heterosexual, or if he seemed a bit more cheerful about the fact that he is not.
fields.body:
It is perhaps true that Keith Vaz has attracted more flak than he might have done if he were white. It is likely that Peter Mandelson would be more popular if he were heterosexual, or if he seemed a bit more cheerful about the fact that he is not. It is, however, discreditable to defend the antics of high-profile people on the grounds that some of their critics have dubious motives. Still, it is more plausible that Keith Vaz gets extra stick for being a successful Asian than for being Europe minister. There is ingrained racism in the media, but, despite hostility to the single currency, I can't see the tabloids launching a campaign to make the police give us the addresses of Europhiles in our neighbourhoods.

I would be more impressed by the defence of Keith Vaz if I saw a letter from Satpal Ram thanking him for all the support he has given. Ram is probably Britain's longest serving Asian prisoner. Having found himself convicted of murder after being the victim of a racist attack, he might hope that Keith Vaz, who knows what it is to face racism, would be working tirelessly for his release. Perhaps he is, behind the scenes. I'd like to think so but I don't know. Politicians often say they are most effective when having quiet words in ears, but this tends to suggest they don't want us to know what they're doing.

I'm not going to argue that Satpal Ram is more deserving than the Hindujas because he was British before his troubles started. I have no objection to the Hindujas being British. In fact, it is a disgrace that citizens of our former colonies were disowned when we'd got all we wanted from our possessions. But it has been observed that there are people in India who would like to talk to the Hindujas about some dodgy arms deals.

Satpal Ram was arrested because of self defence rather than defence contracts. He was a warehouseman, a small work-knife the only thing in his armoury when he was attacked. But, to be fair, he has little to offer by way of hospitality. One can buy a cup of tea and a Mars bar from the WRVS ladies in a prison visiting room, but the protocol usually has it that the visitor treats the prisoner rather than the other way around. Conversely, one can have a high old time with the Hindujas. Labour, Liberal and Tory politicians all flock to their knees-ups.

It has always created a stir, and has always happened, that Labour politicians hobnob with the wealthy. The right see it as an encroachment on their perks. And, when it has been done by the less socially versed, it has been seen as vulgar and embarrassing, wide-eyed Labour arrivistes tasting the forbidden fruit and dribbling it down their ties. These days, however, Labour ministers probably make tycoons feel positively common.

Tories must feel jealous of Mandelson. Many of them would love to be mates with a Murdoch. Mandelson is so well connected that his network links him to some fascinating people. You can get from him to Thatcher or Tim Bell in two steps, and to Augusto Pinochet in a third via either.

It is quite possible that Mandelson is so disliked by Tories because they believe the universal media myth that he won Labour the last election. In reality, all voters are allowed one vote each, and I'm not convinced he cast his for Labour. In fact, despite all protestations about his brilliance, it is becoming obvious that he is stunningly inept. It's just as well that he is wined and dined by the rich every night, as it seems unlikely that he's capable of feeding himself.

But there is a more serious issue in Labour's increasing flirtation with the rich. It goes beyond even party fundraising and the odd donation to the dome. The fact that millionaires have the best snacks adds to the glamour of being a New Labour politician, but it conceals something much more important, namely that Britain is being handed over to big business. It wouldn't much matter if Labour ministers were just fatally drawn to fancy folk and their nibbles - if they just gate-crashed Shell's Christmas bash, got pissed and insulted some people. What matters is that, in New Labour's scale of values, an achiever is a person successfully driven to attain wealth and power above all else; and such people are clearly suited to running everything. It's two steps from friendship to partnership to privatisation. Education Action Zones, City Academies, transport, construction and IT are all routes to the extension of corporate power.

And what makes the Tories so jealous is that they are no longer the chosen instrument of business. Labour is.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Amvescap profits surge
fields.body:
Amvescap profits surge

Anglo-American fund manager Amvescap saw profits jump 73 % last year as acquisitions and strong sales offset turbulence in financial markets.

The parent of the Invesco and AIM fund families said earnings before tax, exceptional items and goodwill amortisation rose to £554.5m from £319.8m in 1999. Revenues increased to almost £1.63 bn from just over £1.07bn.

Car sales boom continues

New car sales in January rose for the fourth consecutive month, up by 1.5%, indicating buyers are cashing in on stronger competition and lower prices, said the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

Start-of-year buying saw 187,908 cars purchased, complementing a surge of 11% during the last quarter of 2000.

Private sales rose by more than 28% to 87,062 cars while fleet and business sales dipped after a strong December.

BOC regains buoyancy

BOC, the industrial gases group which came near to being carved up between its US and French rivals last year, has reported sharply improved first-quarter sales and profits.

Since US regulators scuppered the £7.2bn plan to split BOC between Air Liquide and Air Products, the group has concentrated on squeezing more out of existing operations.

First quarter profit, before tax and exceptional items, rose 16% to £119.4m on sales 15% higher at £1.06bn. But the market, noting cautionary comments by chief executive Tony Isaac, lopped 1.7% off the share price.

The group's star turn during the first quarter was its vacuum technology division where operating profits rose 116% to £26.3m.

Compass beefs up US interests

Catering group Compass is to pay $563m (£380m) for Morrison Management Specialists, a US firm which provides food for hospitals and retirement homes.

The cash deal makes Compass the biggest supplier of catering services to the US healthcare industry - a market estimated to be worth more than $16bn.

Compass, which was split from Granada last week, has a huge number of catering contracts, varying from the Oscars ceremony to Premiership football club Tottenham Hotspur.

Verizon float 'on schedule'

Vodafone yesterday denied speculation that the flotation of its US joint venture Verizon Wireless had been delayed yet again.

According to reports, the company would miss a March deadline for listing Verizon Wireless, prompting suggestions that Vodafone was considering taking full control of the 45%-owned subsidiary.

But a spokesman said: "In October last year we announced we were delaying the initial public offering of the company, but never actually gave out a timetable. When market conditions are better we will look again at the flotation." He also denied that Vodafone planned to buy the remaining 55% of the venture owned by Verizon Communications.

fields.headline: US killer makes fortune on markets from his cell, cell, cell
fields.trailText: Since people often claim to have made a killing on the stock exchange, where better to play the markets than jail?
fields.body:
Since people often claim to have made a killing on the stock exchange, where better to play the markets than jail?

That is just what one convict has done, making $899,969 (about £610,000) according to last year's tax returns and trading around $8m in securities since 1998, all while serving a sentence for manslaughter.

Michael Mathie, 33, was jailed for 10 to 30 years in 1988 for killing Paul Lamariana whom he accused of abusing his daughter. While in jail, Mathie was raped and sexually abused by the head of internal security whom he sued, eventually winning $500,000 in compensation. He used this as his initial stake.

Mathie - Inmate 90T1282 - rises at 4am on weekdays to follow the European markets on the television in his cell at Elmira maximum security jail in New York state. He also consults the Wall Street Journal, Barron's, Individual Investor, and a dozen other publications, much to the irritation of prison staff who complain at all the mail he gets.

He then reverses the charges on calls to his father 10 times a day and tells him where to invest. While a prisoner cannot profit from his crimes by writing about them, there is nothing to stop him making money legally while inside.

Mathie has bought a house for his family in Long Island and purchased four cars, including a $97,000 Dodge Viper, although the pleasures of owning a high-performance vehicle while in a high-security jail are limited.

He has also made a handsome donation to a charity for young offenders and gives free investment advice throughout the prison.

"It runs the whole gamut, from lawyers to inmates to everybody," he told the New York Times.

Among Mathie's coups has been the $150,000 he made in less than three hours by investing in China Prosperity International Holdings as the World Trade Organisation discussed admitting China.

Although The Investor of Elmira Correctional Facility does not have quite the same ring to it as The Birdman of Alcatraz, a film deal surely cannot be far behind.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Germany | Australia | France | Japan
fields.body:
Sirven evades German queries

The former French oil exe- cutive Alfred Sirven was flown out of Germany yesterday to attend the Paris corruption trial in which he is a key defendant.

But he refused to tell investigators in Frankfurt if he knew anything about kickbacks involving the former Kohl government. AP, Wieterstadt, Germany

Australia backs son of Star Wars

The foreign minister, Alexander Downer, voiced Australian support yesterday for the planned US missile defence shield.

America's position must not be weakened by the global proliferation of missile technology, he said. AP, Canberra

Cabinet return for Kouchner

Bernard Kouchner, the doctor-politician who served as UN administrator in Kosovo, was reappointed to his old job as French health minister yesterday.

A founder of Médecins Sans Frontières, he left the health ministry in June 1999 after getting the UN post. Reuters, Paris

Okinawa 'nuts' get US apology

General Earl Hailston, the US military chief on Okinawa, has apologised for calling local Japanese politicians "nuts and wimps" in an internal email.

To his face, the email had said, they praised him for efforts to discipline troops; but meanwhile, they "stood idly by" as the local assembly passed a resolution demanding US troop cuts. Reuters, Tokyo

AP, Wieterstadt, Germany Australia backs son of Star Wars The foreign minister, Alexander Downer, voiced Australian support yesterday for the planned US missile defence shield. America's position must not be weakened by the global proliferation of missile technology, he said. AP, Canberra Cabinet return for Kouchner Bernard Kouchner, the doctor-politician who served as UN administrator in Kosovo, was reappointed to his old job as French health minister yesterday. A founder of Médecins Sans Frontières, he left the health ministry in June 1999 after getting the UN post. Reuters, Paris Okinawa 'nuts' get US apology General Earl Hailston, the US military chief on Okinawa, has apologised for calling local Japanese politicians "nuts and wimps" in an internal email. To his face, the email had said, they praised him for efforts to discipline troops; but meanwhile, they "stood idly by" as the local assembly passed a resolution demanding US troop cuts. Reuters, Tokyo

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Howards End | Kingstonian v Bristol City | Secrets of War
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton, Richard Vine
fields.body:
Films

Howards End (James Ivory, 1992) 8pm, FilmFour Forster's novel got the stately Merchant-Ivory treatment, and scooped a hat-trick of Oscars - for Emma Thompson's acting, Ruth Prawer Jhabvala's script and Luciana Arrighi's design. Miss Goody-Two-Shoes Margaret Schlegel (Thompson) takes on the hard-nosed Wilcox family, led by patriarchal Anthony Hopkins, in an assured and elegant period piece: you get exactly what you expect - except perhaps for finding yourself rooting for saintly Margaret at the end.

Splendour In The Grass (Elia Kazan, 1961) 9pm, TCM Like his James Dean film East Of Eden, Kazan is again concerned with the generation gap, starting to yawn wide in the early 60s. It's a Romeo and Juliet tale of young lovers oppressed by parents in 1920s Kansas, all done in that heated, overwrought Kazan way, though William Inge's keen screenplay won an Oscar. The youngsters are terrific: Natalie Wood's Wilma, driven to nervous breakdown; and Warren Beatty making his sexy screen debut as Bud.

Shine (Scott Hicks, 1996) 11pm, Carlton Cinema Featuring a virtuoso Oscar-winning performance from Geoffrey Rush as David Helfgott, the classical pianist who broke down while playing - "play" hardly seems the word - Rachmaninov's gruelling third concerto, and remained stuck in a twittering, twilight world until redeemed by the love of a woman (Lynn Redgrave). Hicks directs this Australian production with tender care, and the lustre of a polished grand. And while much of the emotional wallop comes from the elemental music, performed by Helfgott himself, there are other moving acts: John Gielgud's music tutor, and Armin Mueller-Stahl as the Polish-born father whose oppression of the young Helfgott (Noah Taylor) sets up the pianist's collapse.

Sports

Kingstonian v Bristol City 7pm, Sky Sports 2 Bristol City are extremely lucky to still be in the FA Cup, having scored from an injury-time corner to force this replay against non-league Kingstonian. The Robins may not be football's biggest fish but neutrals will all be supporting the Conference side as they aim to secure an historic fifth-round tie against Premiership Leicester.

Factual

Secrets Of War 4pm, 10pm, History Channel Charlton Heston narrates this look at the use of psychological warfare in the 20th century. On the basis of this documentary, psyops (as the military call it to save themselves time under fire), seems to be the not-so sophisticated process of leafleting enemy troops in order to encourage them to surrender. Less successful efforts include the German decision to overplay US fears of soldiers' womenfolk being seduced by hordes of Jewish cads at home, and Saddam's suggestion that Bart Simpson might be doing similar things during the Gulf War. Not surprisingly, all the US efforts appear to have come off better.

webTitle: Feature: Country Diary from Wenlock Edge

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: A river runs through it
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Mild and wet again. The tolerance of the saturated earth has become so strained that fields expel all last night's rain in muddy rivulets. They run against the hedges banking silt into marbly dams, then twist down tracks rigged to the streams below. More floods are certain. It feels like a phenomenon far more significant than too much water. Whether it's life-giving or shrivening, this rain is creating a millennial haemorrhage that is reforming the landscape. Some other world is pushing through the mud.

But the new old one, powered by inevitable tides of spring, is also emerging. Green toothy shoots from subterranean bulbs of wild garlic and daffodil poke through the clay gums of hedgerows and wood banks. On a sodden and dripping morning, the woods which cover an old abandoned limestone quarry on top of the hill are glowing with an intensely vivid green. Branched mosses, feather mosses, cushion mosses reach out to form luxuriant lawns with colours varying from bronze to almost fluorescent emerald. On a trip to Powis Castle in mid Wales last week I was amazed to see gardeners using pressure hoses to blast off strange and wonderful colonies of moss which have grown like lumpy sleeves on ancient apple branches over the last year.

Back in the woods something more familiar is happening that still feels unsettling. Dotted around the remains of a long deserted garden were clumps of eerily and indifferent, beautiful, soft white snowdrops. The intractable year has truly turned.

fields.headline: Where the wild things are
fields.trailText: Congo | Blood on the Carpet | Boy Meets Girl
fields.body:
"The Snark was a Boojum, you see." - The Hunting of the Snark.

Congo pygmies have long claimed that a terrifying animal lives in the forest. It can kill an elephant with its horn and, perhaps as proof of its prowess, sleeps on a bed of elephant tusks. They called it Mokele Mbembe.

This is catnip to television. I have a recollection, somehow misty yet insistent, of two American scientists setting out for the Congo with a large selection of solar topees and cleft sticks as recommended in Scoop. They hoped to find a dinosaur. Their visas ran out before they did. I thought then and I think now that that was a pretty feeble excuse. Arthur C Clarke, exploring the mysteries of this and other worlds from the shade of his beach umbrella, raised a quizzical eyebrow. Japanese TV took aerial footage of an unidentified swimming object in a remote lake. There was no reason this happy, inconclusive pursuit should not go on forever.

Congo (BBC 2) solved the mystery and slew our illusions with one brutal blow by showing the pygmies an illustrated book of African animals. Their excitement was intense: "Yes, that's him all right!", "There he is!" It was a rhino.

Oh...boojum!

One little mystery remains. There are no rhino in the rain forest. There are, however, a number of animals, such as antelope, which would look more at home on open grassland. The programme's theory was that the rain forest is a climatic phenomenon which comes and goes. These speedy creatures had been overtaken by trees. The rhino, it theorised, was a folk memory.

Not if it's chasing you, it's not. The pygmies, who seem truthful to a fault, insist it is a real animal. And one said he had run for his life.

Darts has the endearing quality of needing no athletic ability whatsoever. If the Greeks had sent Jocky Wilson, the wee Geordie dumpling, with the match result from Marathon, Athenians would still be tapping their wrist watches and waiting. Darts comes from haunts of booze and pies. It has Del Boy's dazzling grasp of mental arithmetic and a smoker's cough. It makes snooker look snooty.

Blood on the Carpet (BBC 2) reported with mock horror and a pinch of genuine pity how darts tore itself in two. Olly Croft invented competitive darts 20 years ago in a Muswell Hill pub and has run it ever since. Olly and his wife, Lorna, are so close they echo each other's words. "They was like Mum and Dad to me," said Eric Bristow.

Eric was a natural star, Lorna said. "Sometimes a lovely looking girl comes into a room and you see the gentlemen turn their heads - it was similar to Eric." The time could come when they would cripple him.

Darts, once cheerful viewing, became a TV joke. Smith and Jones did a sketch on Not The Nine O'Clock News which rankled. "So, it's Fat Belly to go first. A single pint. Another double vodka. A triple scotch. Oh, would you believe it! It went in but it's come out again."

TV dropped darts, apart from one tournament. Olly said "The word come back that the people that were watching weren't the right people."

Darts, like justice, has to be seen to exist. The professionals founded their own association with their own TV tournament ("Sponsored by top car manufacturer, Lada.") Olly set out to break them. Both sides reached for their lawyers.

Eric Bristow found he was gripping his darts convulsively, unable to throw them. "Dartitis. Something to do with the brain cells, mate. Maybe it was stress." After three years with horns locked, even the lawyers advised a settlement. The professionals now play on Sky.

Olly, however, still maintains his grip on British darts. That is what dartitis is. An extraordinary inability to let go.

Boy Meets Girl (Channel 4) is another of those who's-out-on-their-ear-this-week series. Four men and four women learn to dress, act, behave and generally pass as the opposite sex, with a little help from Tasleen, who runs an image consultancy for transexuals, and other implausibles. Boy Meets Girl will be justified before God and his angels by this exchange. David Dalrymple, gender psychologist at Charing Cross Hospital (which rather to my surprise has the biggest sex change clinic in the world): "Have you ever experienced a persistent sense of identity with the opposite gender?" Pablo: "What do you mean by that?"

The only actor and actress in the group were the first to go. Pablo, you will be cheered to hear, breezed through.

webTitle: Arts: Interview with designers Robin and Lucienne Day

fields.headline: Adventures in polypropylene
fields.standfirst: His chairs are everywhere from the Tube to the Festival Hall. Her fabrics defined an era.  Charlotte Higgins talks to Robin and Lucienne Day
fields.trailText: His chairs are everywhere from the Tube to the Festival Hall. Her fabrics defined an era. Charlotte Higgins talks to Robin and Lucienne Day.
fields.body:
Designers Lucienne and Robin Day are taking a turn round the Barbican's retrospective of their work. There are chairs designed by Robin everywhere, so many that we can't decide on a place to sit. Pressed-steel benches from the London Underground, a seat from the auditorium of the Royal Festival Hall, the chairs used in hospital waiting rooms: they all compete for the designers' attention.

The Days choose to sit in one of Robin's classic 1960s polypropylene chairs and a leather-upholstered Forum sofa, like the ones they had in their Chelsea house for decades, before they moved to Sussex last year. Robin is 85 years old, Lucienne is 84; they have been married since 1942. They still look much as they did in the early 1950s, when Robin was building a career as a furniture designer and Lucienne was in the process of changing the taste of a nation with her witty, abstract, printed fabrics.

Over 60 years in design, they have seldom worked together, but their careers have run in parallel. As soon as they met at London's Royal College of Art, says Robin, they knew they were kindred spirits. "We were both keen to make careers out of designing for industry - most of our contemporaries went in to teaching. As our careers progressed we were each able to get an honest opinion from the other about our work - without being polite. We could say what we thought, that it was bloody awful or whatever."

The Days were also drawn to each other by a shared sense of purpose and principle. Their commitment to designing low-cost, mass-produced, good-quality furniture and fabric was politically motivated, prompted by the needs of postwar society. "If you have any social conscience at all you can't remain an elitist and work just for the few," says Robin. "Good design should - and I still believe this - enhance people's quality of life. I suppose that's a fairly vain thing to say. But that's what we thought."

"It came from our political beliefs," adds Lucienne. "We believed in democracy. And, well, the Labour party."

A key moment in both their careers was the Festival of Britain in 1951. Robin had already made a mark - he had won, with his friend Clive Latimer, a competition to design low-cost furniture run by New York's Museum of Modern Art. For the Festival of Britain, he was invited to contribute two room sets to the Homes and Gardens pavilion, the theme of which was space-saving. Meanwhile Lucienne had prepared a furnishing fabric called Calyx for the pavilion. It was an exceptionally large and bold repeat pattern of abstracted flowers, the petals simplified to Miro-esque cup shapes. Defiantly modern and modishly dynamic, it was nothing like the chintzy florals or drab utility fabrics that had been dominant in Britain till then.

Along with Robin's sleek, simple furniture, Calyx launched an era in British design that translated European modernism into a contemporary style imbued with postwar optimism, colour and playfulness. At the time, says Lucienne, she had no idea what effect the fabric would have. "There were good modern fabrics around, but they were mostly woven fabrics, terribly expensive, not prints. Robin wanted something that the ordinary man or woman in the street could buy. I took the fabric to Heal's to be made, where I had a contact. They said, 'We shan't sell any of this.' But they did - it was instantly a great success."

In 1958, Heal's mounted a solo show of her work, which encompassed not only fabric but wallpaper and ceramics designs. She had gone some way to achieving one of her aims: that designers should be recognised by name for their work. During that decade, Lucienne couldn't put a foot wrong - her work had an originality and energy that still looks startlingly fresh. Designs such as the witty Spectators, in which abstracted, spindly Giacometti-like figures turn out to be cheekily sporting spectacles, are virtuosic in their handling of colour and pattern. The Days became something of a celebrity couple. Their Chelsea house was photographed by stylish interiors magazines. They even posed for a Smirnoff ad in the mid-1950s. They were Britain's answer to the US's famed husband-and-wife design team, Charles and Ray Eames.

You can almost see the sense of principle in Robin's furniture. His pieces are always economical, in use of materials as well as production costs. There is no trickery or artifice, let alone any frippery or flippancy. "I like to see structure clearly expressed and materials expressing their own character," says Robin. "I don't like to see a massive piece of furniture with upholstery concealing some kind of timber framing, and with tiny little feet emerging from it in some mysterious way."

In the 1950s furniture design had certain clear challenges to meet; what does he think the challenges are today? "I think that we are part of a pretty affluent society," he says, "and that the important things are to conserve material and energy and make things that will endure and can be recycled. It's all very well talking about good design. But it can also be dangerous. There are things that are needed; but also a lot of rubbish that is foisted upon the public in the guise of fashion."

The early work of the Days is supremely fashionable now - a reissue of Robin's polypropylene armchair is currently walking out of Habitat stores, while fabric influenced by Lucienne's 1950s work is everywhere. "It gives me a great deal of pleasure," says Robin, "that the idioms that one had all those years ago are still valid and still thought to be OK - that they perhaps have some intrinsic merit."

But there's no time for resting on laurels, for Robin at least. While Lucienne has recently stopped making the fine handworked silk mosaics that have been her main output for the past 20 years, Robin is not slowing down. "If you've been designing for 60 years you - at least I - can't suddenly just stop. One is always looking at things, finding solutions to things. And yes, when I sit on a chair I do find myself analysing it. It's a sort of habit. An obsession."

 Robin and Lucienne Day: Pioneers of Contemporary Design is at the Barbican Gallery, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), from tomorrow until April 16. Lesley Jackson's book accompanying the exhibition is published by Mitchell Beazley, £30.

webTitle: Powell backs plans for EU defence force

fields.headline: Powell backs plans for EU defence force
fields.standfirst:
Secretary of state softens Pentagon chief's views
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, delivered a crucial public thumbs-up to the controversial EU plans to create a rapid reaction defence force within the framework of Nato.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, delivered a crucial public thumbs-up to the controversial EU plans to create a rapid reaction defence force within the framework of Nato.

Just days after the new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, described himself as "a little worried" by the proposal for European force 0f 60,000, Mr Powell told journalists in Washington: "There's no reason to see this as destabilising Nato in any way."

Speaking at a state department press conference beside the visiting foreign secretary, Robin Cook, Mr Powell gave the EU plan exactly the endorsement that British and European diplomats had been hoping for, while disappointing Europhobic Britons who have been looking to the Bush administration to lead efforts to squash the plan.

"We have a very good understanding of what the European security and defence initiative is about," Mr Powell said.

"And I have heard nothing in my conversations today with Robin that would suggest we won't be able to achieve a common understanding on these issues."

webTitle: Arts: Lyn Gardner meets Michael Grandage

fields.headline: Next stop the National?
fields.standfirst: Lyn Gardner meets Michael Grandage, one of the theatre's great overachievers
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner meets Michael Grandage, one of the theatre's great overachievers.
fields.body:
If Michael Grandage were a car, he'd be a sporty number, the kind that goes from 0-60mph in seconds. Grandage's career as a director has gone from standstill to fast lane in what seems like the blink of an eye.

Five years ago Grandage was a frustrated actor in his early 30s who didn't feel he was making the transition from good-looking lead to the meatier roles that sustain older actors. He was also becoming less interested in his characters and more absorbed in the process of putting on plays. So he changed careers.

Now he is a regular director at the Almeida, associate director at the Donmar, where his brilliant Merrily We Roll Along is pulling in the crowds, and associate director at Sheffield Theatres. It is this mixture of metropolitan glamour and provincial clout that has made Grandage a serious contender to run the National Theatre if and when Trevor Nunn vacates the seat. That, and the fact that Grandage is a great director of the classics with a sharp eye for new writing.

And he can do it on a grand scale. There is a world of difference between the intimate 250-seater Donmar and the 900-seater Sheffield Crucible, whose vast thrust stage is as daunting as a football pitch to directors weaned on studio spaces. But Grandage loves the grand scale and his irresistible As You Like It, with Victoria Hamilton as Rosalind, has already won this year's South Bank Show theatre award. Then, in Simon Bent's Accomplices, a story of violence on a northern housing estate, Grandage not only snaffled the best new play of the year but also dared to put it on in the biggest space available.

Though the Crucible stage proved unforgiving for the largely interior drama of the Restoration comedy The Country Wife, Grandage is determined to stretch the boundaries of the classical repertoire and make modern writers aware that this big space is available for their work.

He can also pull in the stars. Next month Joseph Fiennes returns to the stage, not at the trendy Donmar, but at the Sheffield Crucible, where he plays the title role in Grandage's production of Marlowe's Edward II. "I'd like to think that one day maybe I'll be able to programme Edward II without Joe Fiennes in the lead and still get an audience," says Grandage. "But it takes time to build an audience and they don't give you many chances to fail. And why should they? It costs money to go to the theatre. I've only ever done plays that I've been passionate about, but what I've realised here is that it's no good saying, 'I'm passionate about Lorca,' then playing to only 10% capacity."

Grandage admits that he has had good timing. His predecessor at Sheffield, Deborah Paige, not only gave him some of his first breaks as a director but laid the foundations for the theatre's renaissance with ground-breaking work. Grandage's arrival in Sheffield coincided with the Boyden report into the state of British theatre, the promise of new money for regional theatre and a psychological shift that sees theatrical energy moving away from London and beyond the M25.

Not so long ago, regional theatre was seen as the equivalent of being put out to grass, but all that is changing. Grandage now has his own proteges, including Paul Miller, who directed Accomplices, and David Hunt, whose production of Arthur Miller's play The Man Who Had All the Luck is now at the Crucible. "The time has come to be bold in the regions," says Grandage. "We've got to seize the opportunity and the money that are coming our way and put them to good use. For too long people have tried to second-guess what audiences want, and nobody has ever done it successfully. The only way you'll get an audience and keep it is by delivering a constant level of high-quality work. I could put on a John Godber play and get an audience, but I'd prefer to take the risk and put on Accomplices and build an audience from that.

"I always keep in mind what happened at the Citizens in Glasgow when the theatre was on the brink of financial disaster. The team were discussing how they could stay open and somebody said, 'Look, we've given the audience what we think they want and they don't want it. Why not do a season of work in which we give the audience what we want to direct?' It worked and they never looked back. I believe in doing what you want. If I'm not passionate about a play, why should anyone else be?"

webTitle: Man charged with kidnap and murder of Sarah Payne

fields.headline: Man charged with kidnap and murder of Sarah Payne
fields.trailText: A man will appear in court today charged with the kidnap and murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne.
fields.body:
A man will appear in court today charged with the kidnap and murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne.

Roy Whiting, 42, a mechanic from Littlehampton, West Sussex, was arrested in Kent yesterday morning and taken for questioning by murder squad detectives.

The divorced father of one was interviewed in the presence of his solicitor, Elizabeth McGivern, in a video suite at Bognor Regis police station.

He was charged at 3.20pm. Detective Superintendent Peter Kennett, who has led the murder investigation, said he was due to appear before Chichester magistrates at 10am today. He added that Sarah's parents, Sara and Michael Payne, had been informed.

Sarah disappeared after leaving her brothers Lee, 13, and Luke, 11, and six-year-old sister Charlotte in a field where they had been playing on July 1 last year.

Her partially-buried body was found more than two weeks later in a shallow grave 12 miles away in a field off the A29 near Pulborough. Police believe she was strangled or suffocated.

Yesterday's arrest was the third time police had taken Whiting into custody for questioning over Sarah's disappearance and murder. Whiting was first arrested 24 hours after Sarah disappeared but was released without charge. He was rearrested on July 31 but again freed after questioning by officers working on the inquiry.

The murder investigation has cost Sussex police more than £1.25m. At its peak, up to 2,000 people a day were contacting detectives. Detectives took more than 33,000 calls in the month Sarah went missing.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Radio 2 Folk Awards | All In The Mind | Night Waves
fields.body:
Mike Harding introduces a key event of the popular music year, the Radio 2 Folk Awards (8.0pm, Radio 2). The show's producer, John Leonard, claims that there has been a resurgence of interest in folk because "people appreciate real music, played by talented musicians". Among the talents lined up for this year's awards are the Irish singer Mary Black and such newcomers as Bill (Belinda) Jones and the Scottish band Blazing Fiddles. Culture Secretary Chris Smith is on hand to present the gongs.

Dr Raj Persaud opens the new season of All In The Mind (4.30pm, Radio 4) with a discussion of plans to reform our mental health laws. One of the most controversial recommendations from a review committee was to impose compulsory medication on some people with personality disorders. It may fall foul of the Human Rights Act. But, should it surmount that hurdle, Dr Persaud wonders how his fellow psychiatrists will feel about exercising such coercive powers.

Paul Allen takes a cool look in Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) at the reputation of Giuseppe Garibaldi, still seen by most people as the fiery hero of the Italian risorgimento. But he ran the south of the country as a dictatorship and never really accepted the Kingdom of Italy. Now some modern revisionists think that Garibaldi's stubborn failure to compromise on local nationalism underlies Italy's continuing regional divisions.

webTitle: Feature:  Riess-Passer - the respectable face of Austria's Freedom Party

fields.headline: 'We are advancing'
fields.standfirst:
As leader of a party linked with racism and xenophobia, she pulled off a royal coup when she was photographed socialising with Prince Edward. Simon Tisdall on the respectable face of Austria's Freedom Party

Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: As leader of a party linked with racism and xenophobia, she pulled off a royal coup when she was photographed socialising with Prince Edward.  Simon Tisdall on the respectable face of Austria's Freedom Party.
fields.body:
When Prince Edward found himself chatting to a smartly dressed woman at a drinks reception during a recent visit to Austria, he may not have known exactly whom he was speaking to. That is what an embarrassed Foreign Office says, anyway.

This seems unlikely. The lady in black was Susanne Riess-Passer, Austria's vice-chancellor. More to the point, she is the leader of Austria's far-right Freedom Party (FPO) and a close associate of the notorious Jörg Haider, ostracised across Europe for his extremist views.

Riess-Passer has been described as Haider's puppet, as the political cleaning lady who scurries to tidy up the mess and outrage he leaves behind. For many, she is the respectable face of the deeply disreputable.

As a result of her ruthless handling of an internal party dispute three years ago, her fierce commitment to Haider's cause, and perhaps on account of her glinting, dark brown eyes, she is known in political circles by the half-joking, half-fearful sobriquet of King Cobra.

Riess-Passer may be part patsy, part executioner. All the same, she is also arguably the leading lady of hard-right nationalist politics in Europe, the head of a 50,000-strong party identified with racist, xenophobic and anti-immigration policies.

She is a senior member of the coalition government which was formed last year after the FPO took 27% of the vote in national elections and subsequently boycotted by the 14 other members of the European Union. The British government eschews official contacts with the FPO. All of which makes Edward and Sophie's unscheduled social encounter deeply controversial in Austria and beyond.

The EU's sanctions were lifted last September after a so-called "wise men's report" concluded that the new coalition led by Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel of the conservative People's Party remained committed to "European values". But, it warned, the FPO "has exploited and enforced xenophobic sentiments in campaigns".

The Council of Europe's commission against racism also accused Riess-Passer's party of using racist propaganda to gain power. "The main targets . . . are non-EU citizens including immigrants, asylum-seekers and refugees."

Riess-Passer flatly rejects such criticism. Nor does she accept that Haider, who handed over nominal party leadership to her last year, is the lederhosen-clad, neo-fascist Hitler fan that much of the world believes him to be.

"Haider is neither ignorant nor evil," she insists. "He does not believe there was anything at all good about National Socialism." Haider has long since apologised for his infamous remarks praising the Waffen SS and Hitler's employment policies, she says, but the media does not want to know.

Even though Haider has retreated, for now, to his Carinthian stronghold, does Riess-Passer still take orders from him? And does she expect him to become Austrian chancellor at the next elections due in 2003?

"Jörg Haider was leader of the party for 15 years. He shaped it in a very personal way. He changed the definition of the FPO which was a 5% party, with the aim of being part of the game in a two-party system. He made it mainstream. We don't want just a slice of the cake, we want to be strong enough to change Austria."

Although FPO support in recent regional elections fell below its 1999 level, Riess-Passer remains bullish about the future. "We are advancing. We have a chance to gain voters who did not believe we could be in the government . . . and it depends on whether we can prove to our voters that what we promoted for the last 13 years we can now do. There is a feeling things should go faster . . . But there are high hopes."

A triumphal return by Haider as chancellor is definitely a possibility, but it is "too early" to talk about that, she says. And yes, Haider does tell her what to do - and she does it "sometimes, if it's reasonable".

Riess-Passer, who trained as a lawyer and started in politics in 1987 as the FPO's national press officer, made no bones about defending the Haider party line during a recent visit to London. Austria, she says, has experienced a "huge amount" of immigration, principally from the Balkans, in recent years. It was necessary to limit it; and an annual quota of 8,500 is enforced, excluding genuine refugees. It is not a question of racism, she insists, to try to maintain traditional culture and values, to uphold "the rules we have here".

Although she treads carefully, Riess-Passer, like many on the European right, is clearly unenthusiastic about unchecked EU integration, rapid enlargement, and the euro. In fact, she led a Freedom Party campaign against joining the single currency. Although it failed, she believes many of her anti-euro arguments have been borne out by the currency's subsequent difficulties.

Again and again, Riess-Passer places Austria's problems and the FPO's supposed answers in the broader European context, suggesting that when it comes to questions of identity, nationality and prejudice, the challenge for Austria is no different than that for Britain, France and Germany or smaller European countries such as Belgium and Norway (all of which have their own equivalent far-right parties).

But she does admit Austrian society has been slower than most to come to terms with its darker episodes. Although born in Hitler's home town - Braunau am Inn - she says that at her school, history lessons stopped with the end of the first world war.

"We live under the shadow of Austria's past. Linking somebody to the Nazi past is a killing argument. But for decades we did not talk about it at all, except to say that Austria was Hitler's 'first victim'." And when the two main Austrian parties were formed after the war, they both became a refuge for ex-Nazis who conspired to ignore the past. This is changing rapidly now, says Riess-Passer, pointing for example to the negotiation of a compensation package for Jews who lost homes and property after Anschluss, and for the descendants of Holocaust victims. These she supports.

Like most Austrians, Riess-Passer, aged 40, is far too young to remember the Nazi era. But she is also an awful lot smarter, subtler and more plausible than Haider when it comes to presenting views and policies that carry a disturbing echo of former times. She is, perhaps, a more accomplished apologist for the unacceptable.

She is now one of Austria's most powerful politicians with a national platform on which to build. Although she stresses her loyalty to her "friend and colleague" Haider, it is she who is now at the wheel of the FPO. She may not always take advice from backseat drivers.

Despite all the noise and posturing surrounding the drama queen Haider, perhaps it is King Cobra who bears the closest watching. Is it possible poor, over-exposed Jörg could suffer a fatal snakebite one day while out jogging? Riess-Passer just laughs. And her eyes glint.

Although she stresses her loyalty to her "friend and colleague" Haider, it is she who is now at the wheel of the FPO. She may not always take advice from backseat drivers. Despite all the noise and posturing surrounding the drama queen Haider, perhaps it is King Cobra who bears the closest watching. Is it possible poor, over-exposed Jörg could suffer a fatal snakebite one day while out jogging? Riess-Passer just laughs. And her eyes glint.

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: Restless natives
fields.trailText: Last week we, at the Today programme, were in Brussels for a programme of specious, relentlessly biased, pro-European Union drivel, if you are to believe Christopher Booker in one of the weekend's newspapers.
fields.body:
Last week we, at the Today programme, were in Brussels for a programme of specious, relentlessly biased, pro-European Union drivel, if you are to believe Christopher Booker in one of the weekend's newspapers.

Enraging Mr Booker is gratifying, of course, but that wasn't the only objective. The intention was to tackle some of the questions raised by a hefty section of our listeners which, on the issue of the EU, feels disenfranchised by Parliament and badly served by broadcasters.

So, the first question we asked was: should Britain withdraw from the EU and what would happen to us if we did? It's a question we're not encouraged to ask; the vast majority of our politicians, when you ask them, tell you not to be so stupid and quickly change the subject. And yet the only substantial study into the consequences of withdrawal suggests the economic effects would be, at worst, ambivalent.

Given the fervour of our dissenting listeners, the logical second question was: can the BBC be trusted to cover the EU debate fairly? My guess is that there's a substantial proportion of the population - more than the third who believe we should withdraw, less than the two thirds or so who oppose joining a single currency - whose opposition to greater integration is visceral and based on principle, rather than solely pragmatic. Perhaps we sometimes underplayed these arguments in the past, not least because such views are rarely articulated in Parliament. The defence of the BBC - and a commitment to more such programmes - was provided by my boss, Mark Damazer. (Well, one of my bosses. I have more bosses than you could shake a stick at. Or shake a kukri at, that curved Nepalese sword used in the ceremonial dismembering of goats.)

On the mainland, of course, there's bewilderment at our insularity. But the train journey to Brussels provides one clue to the different attitudes here and abroad. As France dissolves into Belgium with no change in language, geography, architecture, and climate, you see why the notion of an inviolable nation state is a less relevant concept over there. The boundaries have shifted too many times. And, you could argue, the Europeans most convinced by the idea of a sovereign nation state are those - like the Flemish Belgians, the Basques, the Catalans - who have never really had one.

Meanwhile, a new language is forming in Brussels; visible in virtually every advertisement, heard in every café, bar and restaurant. It's a sort of ad hoc Esperanto, the difficult stuff in English but with a smattering of French, German and Italian. One advert used four languages in the space of eight words and was intelligible to all. Very democratic, although I doubt the French and Christopher Booker will agree.

 Rod Liddle is editor of BBC Radio 4's Today programme. His column appears every Wednesday

fields.headline: Israel's dark hour
fields.standfirst:
Ariel Sharon, who once seemed destined for exile and disgrace, beats Ehud Barak in yesterday's elections

Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon, who once seemed destined for exile and disgrace, beats Ehud Barak in yesterday's elections.
fields.body:
It's as shocking as if Jean-Marie Le Pen had become president of France, or Ian Paisley ruled over Northern Ireland. Last night Israel, by a massive landslide, turned to a man who has spent two decades as an international byword for extremism - a global hate-figure - and elevated him to the country's top job. Ariel Sharon, who once seemed destined only for exile into disgrace, is now the prime minister of Israel. For anyone who wishes peace for that nation and its neighbours, today is among the darkest of days.

Sharon's been around so long - a fighter in the pre-state, Jewish resistance against the British in the 40s, a key player in every one of Israel's five wars - that there is barely a need to recite the roll call of shame that constitutes his CV. Israelis know of the brutal reprisal raids he led against Palestinian infiltrators in the 50s, just as they recall his blood-soaked invasion of Lebanon three decades later. They know an internal Israeli inquiry held him "indirectly responsible" for massacres at Sabra and Chatila of more than 2,000 Palestinian refugees, slaughtered by Israeli-backed Lebanese Christian militiamen. They know, too, that that same inquiry declared Sharon unfit to serve as defence minister (let alone the job he holds this morning). And they know that he has opposed every move Israel has ever made toward peace - from the 70s Camp David accords with Egypt, right through to the Oslo agreement with the Palestinians of the 90s.

They have seen the company he keeps. Men like Avigdor Lieberman, whose game plan for the Middle East includes setting Beirut on fire, launching missiles at Tehran, destroying the Aswan dam and recapturing villages already handed back to the Palestinians. They know that Lieberman is likely to be part of Sharon's coalition, a government which threatens to be the most rightwing in Israel's history.

They know the likely consequences of a Sharon administration. Ostracism beckons, as the world community turns a cold shoulder toward a nation led by a thug whose own law courts (in a libel case against the Ha'aretz newspaper) have branded him a liar. Foreign investment, which depends on stability, will evaporate further; Israel's economy will struggle. The country's link with the Jewish diaspora will weaken, too: Jews in the United States, Britain and elsewhere may want less and less to do with an Israel that could choose Sharon as its leader.

Above all, they know the most immediate result of their actions yesterday. For the election of a leader who does not be lieve in peace takes Israel one step closer to the alternative: war. Israelis understand that. Asked which candidate was more likely to plunge Israel into an all-out confrontation with its neighbours, a wide majority plumped for Sharon.

And yet, despite all that, there he stands this morning: Ariel, King of Israel. Why have Israelis done it? Why have they taken a step towards what seems, from the outside, national suicide?

There are the conventional, political explanations of course. A new generation of voters (those under 35) and a million new immigrants, chiefly from the old Soviet Union, have no memory of Sharon's past antics: to them the invasion of Lebanon lives only in the history books.

And of course there was Sharon's biggest asset: his opponent. Ehud Barak may have been a masterful soldier, but he was an appalling politician. He came across as arrogant and unfeeling, wholly unskilled in the necessary emolliences of vote-getting. Meanwhile, Sharon was pulling off one of the great political con-tricks of modern times - running TV ads depicting him as a cuddly old man, walking Israel's streets holding the hand of a small child.

Still it was not the image-makers who decided this election. Barak's fate was sealed by forces far more fundamental - starting with fear. Israelis deserted the Labour leader because they no longer believed he could protect them, neither from the random bombs that rip apart a bus or street market in an instant, nor from the Palestinian snipers' bullets that have been raining down on Jerusalem's outermost suburbs for nearly four months. Israelis have complained of a constant, gnawing sense of anxiety - and Barak forgot that his task, as prime minister, was to make them feel safe.

That, after all, is why he was elected in the first place. Like his mentor and predecessor, the slain Yitzhak Rabin, Barak was meant to be "Mr Security" - a former chief of staff who would keep Israelis' enemies at bay. In his determination to forge a peace deal with the Palestinians, Barak forgot that task: on his watch, Palestinian stone-throwing escalated into a conflict just short of a shooting war. It was a critical lapse of judgment, ignoring the lesson of Rabin at Oslo, and even Menachem Begin at Camp David: that in order to be a dove, by making peace, an Israeli leader must first be a hawk, by providing security.

It was this failure, rather than the concessions Barak was prepared to offer, that cost him so dear. It's true that most Israelis found the outgoing PM's willingness to hand back 95% of the West Bank and to divide Jerusalem hard to stomach - but precedent suggests they would have swallowed it eventually, on two conditions. First, if the Palestinians had accepted Israel's offer and signed a genuine peace deal and, second, if everyday life had become more tranquil. Neither of those conditions were met, and so voters moved to punish Barak.

Add to Israelis' fear, their confusion. The left especially still cannot quite figure out why Barak's approach - offering compromises no predecessor had ever dared - so enraged Palestinians that they rebelled more spiritedly against him than they ever did against the iron fist of Begin, Shamir or Netanyahu.

The Israeli left had always argued that compromise would bring peace - only for the events of the past few months to prove them spectacularly wrong. Offer compromise and what you get is an uprising, one bloodier than any protest that came when you offered nothing. Suddenly the right seemed right: the Israeli floating voter looked at Sharon's decades-old contention - that the Arabs regard every concession as a sign of weakness and reward it with violence - and reckoned he'd been right all along.

The result is a rejection of the entire Oslo-Rabin-Barak approach. "We've tried the good cop," Israelis said yesterday, "and that didn't work. Now let's try the bad cop; see how the Palestinians like that."

Or there might be a deeper impulse, one whose origins go back to the very beginnings of Zionism. That movement always contained two conflicting, strands: one which believed the purpose of a Jewish state was to join the family of nations as an equal - and another which saw a separate state as a way of withdrawing from the world, of the Jews turning their back on everyone else. The choice of the reviled Ariel Sharon seems like a victory for that latter impulse - and a defeat for an older, brighter vision of the land of Israel.
