webTitle: Vaz accuser backs down over £2,000 donations

fields.headline: Vaz accuser backs down over £2,000 donations
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: One of the key witnesses against Keith Vaz, the embattled Europe minister, appeared to have backed down last night after tough questioning from MPs investigating the affair.
fields.body:
One of the key witnesses against Keith Vaz, the embattled Europe minister, appeared to have backed down last night after tough questioning from MPs investigating the affair.

Sarosh Zaiwalla, a City lawyer who alleged Mr Vaz received up to £2,000 in donations from him, appeared to be changing his story after being quizzed by MPs for nearly two hours. If Mr Vaz were found to have received such donations he could be in breach of parliamentary rules for not disclosing them.

At a press briefing following the Commons standards and privileges committee hearing Mr Zaiwalla denied he had made direct payments to Mr Vaz - one of the central allegations against the MP. Instead he said he had paid for tables at events organised by the Asian Business Club where Mr Vaz and other ministers had been speaking.

Mr Zaiwalla also denied another allegation, that Mr Vaz had indicated that he could recommend honours for Asian people who might donate to the Labour party.

He disclosed that he had written to Tony Blair directly, raising an issue involving Mr Vaz's wife and an employment tribunal case. He declined to disclose the contents of the letter or what involvement Mrs Vaz had with the case. He told journalists he would have preferred the hearing to have been held in public but this had been turned down by MPs. He said: "I have not come here to defend or oppose Mr Vaz. I came to give evidence so the MPs could get to the objective truth about the matter."

Mr Zaiwalla's comments were similar to a statement issued to a Sunday newspaper by Geoffrey Bindman, lawyer for Mr Vaz. The law firm did not deny that payments had been made but stated they had not been given to Mr Vaz. Mr Bindman said at the weekend: " None of these are payments that ever came to Keith personally. They relate to charitable donations, dinners and a constituency calendar."

Mr Zaiwalla indicated that he was not likely to be called back next week, when the committee will talk to other witnesses. They will also be looking at allegations that witnesses giving evidence to the inquiry by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, had been threatened with disciplinary procedures by the Labour party.

Mr Vaz also faces a separate government inquiry over his involvement with the billionaire Hinduja brothers and his efforts to help them secure British passports. The Hindujas have been named as suspects in an illegal arms deal in India.

webTitle: Briton accused of Saudi car bomb 'sold drinking den' to victim

fields.headline: Briton accused of Saudi car bomb 'sold drinking den' to victim
fields.trailText: Alexander Mitchell, the Briton facing execution in Saudi Arabia after he admitted planting a car bomb, had a business relationship with the man he is accused of killing, sources in Riyadh's expatriate community said yesterday.
fields.body:
Alexander Mitchell, the Briton facing execution in Saudi Arabia after he admitted planting a car bomb, had a business relationship with the man he is accused of killing, sources in Riyadh's expatriate community said yesterday.

Mr Mitchell, 44, was shown on Saudi television confessing - along with a Belgian and a Canadian - to having bombed two cars in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, last November, killing one Briton and injuring five other people.

A total of nine people - none of them Saudis - are being held by the authorities in connection with the investigation. All were members of, or shareholders in, a series of illicit drinking dens in Riyadh - Celtic Corner, Woodlands, Raffles and the Empire Club.

Mr Mitchell, a former soldier, worked as chief anaesthetics technician at the Security Forces Hospital in Riyadh but also had a stake in three drinking dens for expatriates and supplied satellite dishes - officially banned in the kingdom - as a sideline.

He later sold his stake in one of the drinking dens to Christopher Rodway, the 47-year-old Briton who died in an explosion on November 17.

Letters regarding the transaction were written by Mr Mitchell on a hospital computer which has been seized by the Saudi authorities, the sources said.

Oddly, Mr Mitchell also developed a serious interest in religion, friends said yesterday. He read many books on Islam and, on the night of his arrest last December, had been due to attend a party at the hospital where he and several colleagues were to announce their conversion to the faith.

In the televised confessions, Mr Mitchell and his co-accused said they had been ordered to carry out the bomb attacks.

Yesterday the Saudi-owned newspaper, Asharq al-Awsat, quoted the interior minister, Prince Nayef, as saying that "foreign countries were behind the orders" and had "provided them with high-tech explosive materials". He said the countries were "linked to the nationalities of those arrested".

A military plastic explosive called C4 was used in the attacks, he said.

C4 was developed for the US military during the Vietnam war. It has been sold by the US to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iran (under the shah), and several Nato countries possess it. The US also used it in the 1991 Gulf war.

The formula for C4 is not secret and quantities have occasionally been stolen. About 20 years ago a former CIA agent was convicted of shipping 21 tons of C4 to Libya, allegedly for terrorist training.

More recently it was used by terrorists in the bomb attack on the USS Cole in Yemen last October which killed 17 people and injured 39.

Shortly after the killing of Mr Rodway the Saudi authorities began hinting that the attack was not terrorist-related. Their investigation centred on his acquaintances and in particular on any grudges they may have held against him.

The Saudi authorities have now agreed to let British con sular staff visit Mr Mitchell, the Foreign Office said yesterday. The agreement came during an hour-long meeting between the British ambassador and the Saudi interior minister.

"The ambassador requested repeated consular access to Mr Mitchell and the interior minister undertook to grant that request," a spokesman said.

Under Saudi law, Mr Mitchell will only be allowed to see a lawyer once the investigation into his case has been completed.

Lawyer Stephen Jakobi, of Fair Trials Abroad, said the confessions were "show trials" and added: "I would say this is the worst case affecting a European citizen I have seen anywhere in the world."

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, said the Foreign Office should be firm in its demands that the Britons were properly treated.

But he added: "If there's been a breach of the law in Saudi Arabia then the Saudi Arabian authorities are entitled to prosecute."

Mr Rodway's father, Jerry, 69, a retired sales representative from Salisbury, Wiltshire, said that if Mr Mitchell was found guilty of killing his son he should be executed.

webTitle: 'I told the jury a pack of lies'

fields.headline: 'I told the jury a pack of lies'
fields.standfirst: Criminal who claimed Michael Stone admitted Russell killings says he never expected his story to lead to conviction
fields.trailText: Criminal who claimed Michael Stone admitted Russell killings says he never expected his story to lead to conviction.
fields.body:
When Barry Thompson told police what he thought was a silly little story about Michael Stone, he never expected to hear from them again, let alone appear as a key witness in a murder trial.

But when he got into the witness box, Thompson assumed the swagger of a man comfortable with the surroundings of a crown court. As he gave evidence his manner was casual, his answers sharp, and he would have no truck with suggestions that he was a liar. He had no reason to make anything up, he said. "I don't even know the man."

Stone, he said, had threatened him and said: "I made a mistake with her [Josie Russell], I won't make the same mistake with you." But the day after Stone was given three life sentences for murder and attempted murder, Thompson, a convicted criminal who now works as a builder in Basildon, Essex, admitted that he had lied.

Thompson now claims that he fabricated the threat and lied under oath because he considered his own evidence so slight that it would not make a difference. He has even claimed that he was under pressure from police to say what he did.

For some reason Thompson wanted to get his lies off his chest. The day after Stone's conviction he began ringing round tabloid newspaper newsdesks.

Having been rebuffed by the Sun, he phoned the Mirror, which called in its court reporter, Adrian Shaw, to deal with the case. At a meeting in Basildon, Thompson brought with him a handwritten statement in which he admitted he was a liar.

He told Mr Shaw: "Stone never said the words I attributed to him. I told the jury a pack of lies. I did not think I would have to go to court after I made my statement to the police. When I was told I was to be called as a witness I did not want to attend court, but the police took me there and brought me home. Even when I gave evidence I thought the case against him was so thin that he would be acquitted anyway."

Thompson, who had been serving a two-year sentence for dishonesty and intimidating witnesses, gave evidence on the fifth day of the trial at Maidstone crown court.

He said he had worked as an orderly in the segregation unit of Elmley prison in Sheerness, where Stone was on remand, preparing breakfast and dinner for the prisoners and cups of tea for the warders.

"The first time I see Michael Stone he was coming down the stairs to get his breakfast or dinner and I said to him, 'So, you're the one . . .' He said, 'I'll see you on the wing and talk about it' and I said 'That'll be fine.' I served him his breakfast or dinner and he went back up to his cell.

"I see him the following day in the exercise yard. He was on his own. I was in the kitchen making tea. I called him over to the window and asked him what he had been arrested for."

Anne Rafferty QC, prosecuting, asked if that was quite a short conversation. Thompson indicated that it had to be because of the prison officers.

Asked if Stone had had anxieties, Thompson said: "He was saying he was going to an ID parade on Friday and the police were rushing forensic tests through and not to judge him until the results had come back. I said 'I am not judging you'."

Thompson claimed that the next day Stone approached him. "He said, 'I made a mistake with her, I won't make the same fucking mistake with you'." He now says that what Stone really said to him was: "You and me are going to fall out."

"If something had been said to the effect of 'I made a mistake with her, I won't make the same fucking mistake with you,' isn't that something that in the ordinary course of events you would expect a prison officer to hear?"

Thompson responded that there was no prison officer within 50 yards. Mr Clegg then asked: "If you are right, nothing passed between you before the conversation you have told us about that could be interpreted as aggressive."

Thompson: "It doesn't pay to be un-nice to people in that situation. Inevitably, they all go back on the wing."

Mr Clegg later asked: "You had done nothing to provoke a threat?" Thompson, who seemed annoyed at the suggestion, replied: "Quite sure, yes."

Mr Clegg, who later told the jury Stone had been "fitted up by a bunch of convicts", asked: "You are quite sure you are not trying to get in on the bandwagon, making things up about Stone?"

Asked what his motive was, he said: "None whatsoever, apart from the fact that I found it very strange that he would say them sort of words. It was very strange, and the way he looked at me."

When Mr Clegg suggested to Thompson he had made up the conversation, he replied: "You are entitled to suggest that."

Mr Clegg suggested that the entire jail population knew Stone was accused of the murders and he could not safely turn his back, adding: "If you cannot get him one way, you can get him another."

Yesterday that assumption turned out to be right, as Thompson's account was indeed "wholly unreliable".

fields.headline: A warrior returns professing peace
fields.standfirst:
Israelis put trust in Ariel Sharon to end the bloody mess he triggered
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israelis put trust in Ariel Sharon to end the bloody mess he triggered.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon began his march to the prime minister's office on September 28 with an early morning jaunt to the most hallowed ground in Jerusalem's walled city.

All the warning signs were there: peace talks with the Palestinians had collapsed over control of the site Muslims revere as the Haram al-Sharif and Jews as the Temple Mount. In the West Bank and Gaza, frustration with Israel's 33-year occupation was boiling over.

Mr Sharon - nicknamed the Bulldozer - ploughed on. He climbed up to the disputed holy site in a phalanx of Israeli riot police. When the police staggered back down 45 minutes later, ducking chairs and rubbish bins hurled by Palestinian protesters, the intifada had begun.

Four months and 380 deaths later, Israelis yesterday were set to entrust the old warhorse with guiding them out of the bloody mess he unleashed.

In so doing, they are saying they no longer believe in peace with the Palestinians. If war is inevitable, they feel safer with a man who spent 50 years crushing Israel's enemies than with Ehud Barak, the prime minister who promised peace, but delivered a terrifying Palestinian uprising.

In soft-focus campaign ads, which cast Mr Sharon, 72, as a kindly grandfather cuddling baby goats on his 1,000-acre farm, the rotund general insisted he wanted peace as badly as Mr Barak, who pursued negotiations to the last days of his prime ministership.

Rosy rhetoric

"There have been attempts to divide Israel into those who want peace, and those who are opposed to peace. I want to say: we all want peace," he told his final campaign rally in the coastal city of Holon.

"In the army, I made life and death decisions, not just for me but for many men, and so I say I understand peace much better than many politicians."

But Mr Sharon has never explained his vision of peace, or how he can manage to reach a deal when Mr Barak, who was willing to offer much more to the Palestinians, failed so spectacularly.

The execution of Mr Sharon's vague peace policies are also hostage to the kind of coalition he can muster in Israel's fractured parliament, or Knesset. By Israeli law, Mr Sharon must form a government by the end of March - 45 days after the publication of official poll results - or else the country faces new elections.

Mr Sharon says he wants a national unity government with Mr Barak's Labour party. Israeli politicians who know Mr Sharon well, including the Nobel prize laureate, Shimon Peres, believe such a coalition could temper Israel's warrior.

But if Mr Sharon forsakes a unity government for a narrow coalition with extreme rightwing parties, he could ditch his rosy campaign rhetoric and revert to earlier form. Mr Sharon's putative coalition partners from the far-right claim the bulky general would not hesitate to bomb Beirut and Cairo in case of attack.

Such drastic action is in keeping with Mr Sharon's temperament. "A single motif recurs throughout Sharon's military and political life: "Always escalate" writes Avishai Margalit, a philosophy professor at the Hebrew University in an essay on Mr Sharon. "He believes that in the muddle resulting from an increase in violence he will always come out the winner.

He will know how to create a situation in which people turn to him because he is self-confident and he knows what he wants."

Mr Sharon is Israel's original commando, the founder of the army's Unit 101, infamous for blowing up 69 people, half of them women and children, in a 1953 raid on the West Bank village of Qibya.

In the 1970s, he relentlessly expanded Jewish settlements. As defence minister in 1982, he marched Israel's army all the way to Beirut, after assuring the cabinet that troops would only advance to within 40kms of the Lebanese border. He then allowed Christian militias to enter the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps, in Beirut's southern suburbs, where they slaughtered 800 Palestinians. The atrocity forced Mr Sharon to resign, and a government commission said he was unfit to be defence minister.

But voters demonstrated yesterday that they are willing to overlook Mr Sharon's bloody past at a time when the Palestinian uprising is killing their fellow Israelis on an almost daily basis.

"I voted for Ariel Sharon, and that is a vote for going to war," said artist Ariel-Regev Harari, a Barak voter who changed sides when he cast his vote in Jerusalem's genteel German Colony neighbourhood yesterday. "But we are forced into going to war because of the situation. Here in Israel we are like sitting ducks."

Mr Sharon believes a final peace agreement with the Palestinians is impossible now. His recipe is simple: no negotiations with the Palestinians until the uprising ends. "I will not hold negotiations under fire and terrorism and violence. That was Barak's mistake," he told the Ma'ariv newspaper.

'Painful concessions'

Mr Sharon also wants the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to arrest all the "terrorists" who have led attacks on Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza. He wants a ban on "incitement" on the official Palestinian television and radio, and a total overhaul of Palestinian education, with textbooks preaching co-existence with Israel.

Then, when Mr Sharon is eventually willing to talk peace, Mr Arafat will be stuck with the 42% of the West Bank he currently controls. Every Jewish trailer perched on lonely hilltops in the West Bank, or moored in sand dunes in the Gaza Strip, will stay put. There will be no concessions on Arab East Jerusalem, occupied by Israel since the 1967 war.

"When I talk about painful concessions, I mean we will not reoccupy Nablus and Jericho and other places," he told an ultra-orthodox weekly newspaper.

He also refuses to accept responsibility for the 3.7m registered Palestinian refugees who lost their homes when the Jewish state was created in 1948.

In the unlikely event that the Palestinians are willing to accept those conditions then Mr Sharon is prepared to think about a Palestinian state.

"Over the years, we have to see how it develops," he said. "Gradually, step by step, we might reach a peace agreement."

However, Mr Sharon does not have years - or even months. Palestinian officials have described Mr Sharon's policies as "a declaration of war", and in the West Bank and Gaza, the leaders of Mr Arafat's tanzim militia have called for an escalation of the uprising. "The best way to deal with Sharon, the only way to deal with Sharon is the intifada and resistance," said Marwan Barghouti, a senior Fatah leader in the West Bank.

With the Palestinians determined to test Mr Sharon from day one, Israel's old warrior will soon reveal his methods for ending an uprising that Mr Barak failed to contain with tanks, helicopter gunships and the assassination of Fatah commanders.

Members of Mr Sharon's coterie say he is unlikely to indulge in the bombardments of Palestinian cities with which Mr Barak tried - and failed - to end the intifada. But he will tighten the ring of steel around Palestinian cities, and intensify restrictions on Palestinian travel in the West Bank.

The key to fighting the intifada, Mr Sharon said during the campaign, is to put the Palestinian militias on the defensive "from a situation in which they are engaged in planning how to take the lives of Jews and Israelis to the point where they will be forced to be totally preoccupied with how to save themselves."

On the ground, he can be expected to give army commanders a free hand against Palestinian gunmen, and to authorise assassinations of leading Palestinian figures - including members of Mr Arafat's administration - by Israeli hit squads. "Sharon prefers non-conventional methods in which the unknown element will take the Palestinians by surprise," one of his confidants told Ma'ariv yesterday.

Israelis are confident Mr Sharon can fight this uprising. But is he the man to end one? The best that he can offer is that he is a man who will not be pushed around. "I know the Arabs, and the Arabs know me," Mr Sharon said repeatedly on the campaign trail. "They know my word is my word, my yes is my yes and my no is my no. They know I mean what I say and I say what I think."

The next steps

February 13 Knesset reconvenes. Mr Barak stays on as caretaker prime minister, while Mr Sharon tries to form a coalition from a fractured Knesset

February 14 Publication of official election results. Mr Sharon has 45 days from this day to form a government

February 28 Deadline for the appeal of the outcome

March 31 Mr Sharon faces twin deadlines: he must present his government, with at least eight cabinet ministers, or the country faces new elections for prime minister and Knesset. New elections must be held in 60 days.

This is also the last day for him to pass the budget; if he does not, the country faces a new general election in 60 days

fields.headline: JJ Johnson
fields.standfirst: Jazz trombonist who changed the sound of the instrument with his pioneering bebop style
fields.trailText: Jazz trombonist who changed the sound of the instrument with his pioneering bebop style.
fields.body:
With his usual felicitousness of phrase, the New Yorker jazz commentator Whitney Balliett once described the sound of a trombone being played fast as resembling that of "a fat man trying to run uphill". With the treacherous imprecision of notes chosen by a mixture of lip-shape and the loose positioning of a mechanical slide, coupled with the bucolic gruffness of its sound, the trombone was about as unsuited to the arrival of the agile bebop style in the 1940s as could be imagined.

Like the clarinet, which was also eclipsed in jazz during the first wave of the bebop era, the trombone was also closely associated with New Orleans street-band music. This gave it an altogether dated and unhip image in the period of sharp Italian suits, shades and beatnik poetry that followed Charlie Parker's and Dizzy Gillespie's overnight upheaval of jazz music.

But the influence of James Louis "JJ" Johnson, who has died aged 77, was so substantial on the methodology of post-bebop trombone playing that the Indiana-born virtuoso came to be widely regarded as the man who rescued the instrument from the jazz scrapheap almost single-handedly.

Johnson took as his starting point the conviction that the convoluted, chattering bebop melodic language could be expressed on the trombone, and eventually became so fleet and graceful at the execution of it that many who heard his recorded work (including reviewers) refused to believe that he was playing a slide trombone rather than the trumpet-like valved version of the instrument.

Johnson's tone was rugged and assertive in the early 40s, becoming lighter and more elegant later in the decade, and eventually so rounded and warm, even at very fast tempos, that the sound assumed the qualities of a french horn.

If he depended on a repertoire of stock bop phrases during the first phase of his development, when he was concentrating on assembling sufficient of an arsenal of effects to keep up with a spontaneous, improvising genius like Charlie Parker, he relaxed to become more melodically thoughtful and original in the 50s, and some of his most telling solo performances date from this period.

Johnson originally studied piano with a church organist, and took up trombone in his teens. He worked with the travelling "territory bands" in the early 40s, under such leaders as Clarence Love and Isaac "Snookum" Russell - the latter ensemble featuring the young Fats Navarro on trumpet, whose methods were to exert considerable influence on Johnson.

His immediate models were the trombonists Trummy Young and Dickie Wells (Johnson was to work with the latter in Count Basie's band), musicians rooted in the amiable pulse of swing rather than the more manic one of bop, but who also believed that the instrument could be made far more agile than previously seemed possible. Johnson also admired Fred Beckett, a shortlived trombonist with the Harlan Leonard and Lionel Hampton bands.

When he was 18, Johnson joined the great swing altoist Benny Carter's band, and stayed with it for three years, eventually joining Count Basie in 1945 and moving to New York. The city was by now the home of the bebop revolution, and Johnson performed around the 52nd Street clubs with all the pioneers of the movement, including Parker, Navarro, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and Max Roach.

Through the 40s, he worked with the bluesy saxophonist Illinois Jacquet, and briefly with Dizzy Gillespie and the bassist Oscar Pettiford, and in the early 50s he toured with an all-star bop-influenced band that included Miles Davis - but found by the end of 1952 that he was going broke playing jazz. He temporarily retired from the scene, taking up a day job with the Sperry Gyroscope Company.

What brought Johnson back to the spotlight was a duo he formed with fellow-trombonist Kai Winding, an emigré Dane who had worked with Stan Kenton. The intertwining lines of the two leaders (Winding's tone was rougher than Johnson's, but his phrasing almost as fleet) had a mellow fluency that attracted an unexpectedly wide audience, and Johnson's reputation outside the inner sanctum of jazz aficionados was secured by this liaison. It also enabled him to explore his writing and arranging talents, and a series of elegant and highly melodic works found the trombonist investigating hybrids of classical forms and jazz.

For a while, Johnson remained in constant demand as a sideman in the bands of the most illustrious jazz leaders. He toured with Miles Davis in 1961, and then with the fearsome alto-sax virtuoso Sonny Stitt. But the development of his composing talents presented him with both an easier and a more lucrative way to make a living. He moved to Los Angeles in 1970 to work on TV and movie scores, and his work in jazz contexts progressively reduced.

He never lost his instrumental skills, however, as he forcibly reminded audiences and players alike whenever he returned to the stage. Though a few recordings in the 70s showed him rather uneasily attempting to adapt himself to jazz-rock, he remained capable of startling performances - such as the two albums he made within weeks of each other in 1983 (We'll Be Together Again, and Things Are Getting Better All The Time), which, among other things, pitched his delicate embroidery against the more rugged impact of former Basie trombonist, Al Grey.

After 1987, when he returned to his hometown of Indianapolis, Johnson enthusiastically took to live performance again, and as late as 1996 he was still involved in excellent recordings, such as the all-star Brass Orchestra session, including one of the trombonist's most effective larger-scale pieces, El Camino Real.

He had been in ill-health for some months and committed suicide. His first wife of 40 years, Vivian, predeceased him, and he is survived by his second wife, Carolyn Johnson.

 J J Johnson, jazz trombonist, bandleader and composer, born January 22 1924; died February 4 2001

This gave it an altogether dated and unhip image in the period of sharp Italian suits, shades and beatnik poetry that followed Charlie Parker's and Dizzy Gillespie's overnight upheaval of jazz music. But the influence of James Louis "JJ" Johnson, who has died aged 77, was so substantial on the methodology of post-bebop trombone playing that the Indiana-born virtuoso came to be widely regarded as the man who rescued the instrument from the jazz scrapheap almost single-handedly. Johnson took as his starting point the conviction that the convoluted, chattering bebop melodic language could be expressed on the trombone, and eventually became so fleet and graceful at the execution of it that many who heard his recorded work (including reviewers) refused to believe that he was playing a slide trombone rather than the trumpet-like valved version of the instrument. Johnson's tone was rugged and assertive in the early 40s, becoming lighter and more elegant later in the decade, and eventually so rounded and warm, even at very fast tempos, that the sound assumed the qualities of a french horn. If he depended on a repertoire of stock bop phrases during the first phase of his development, when he was concentrating on assembling sufficient of an arsenal of effects to keep up with a spontaneous, improvising genius like Charlie Parker, he relaxed to become more melodically thoughtful and original in the 50s, and some of his most telling solo performances date from this period. Johnson originally studied piano with a church organist, and took up trombone in his teens. He worked with the travelling "territory bands" in the early 40s, under such leaders as Clarence Love and Isaac "Snookum" Russell - the latter ensemble featuring the young Fats Navarro on trumpet, whose methods were to exert considerable influence on Johnson. His immediate models were the trombonists Trummy Young and Dickie Wells (Johnson was to work with the latter in Count Basie's band), musicians rooted in the amiable pulse of swing rather than the more manic one of bop, but who also believed that the instrument could be made far more agile than previously seemed possible. Johnson also admired Fred Beckett, a shortlived trombonist with the Harlan Leonard and Lionel Hampton bands. When he was 18, Johnson joined the great swing altoist Benny Carter's band, and stayed with it for three years, eventually joining Count Basie in 1945 and moving to New York. The city was by now the home of the bebop revolution, and Johnson performed around the 52nd Street clubs with all the pioneers of the movement, including Parker, Navarro, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and Max Roach. Through the 40s, he worked with the bluesy saxophonist Illinois Jacquet, and briefly with Dizzy Gillespie and the bassist Oscar Pettiford, and in the early 50s he toured with an all-star bop-influenced band that included Miles Davis - but found by the end of 1952 that he was going broke playing jazz. He temporarily retired from the scene, taking up a day job with the Sperry Gyroscope Company. What brought Johnson back to the spotlight was a duo he formed with fellow-trombonist Kai Winding, an emigré Dane who had worked with Stan Kenton. The intertwining lines of the two leaders (Winding's tone was rougher than Johnson's, but his phrasing almost as fleet) had a mellow fluency that attracted an unexpectedly wide audience, and Johnson's reputation outside the inner sanctum of jazz aficionados was secured by this liaison. It also enabled him to explore his writing and arranging talents, and a series of elegant and highly melodic works found the trombonist investigating hybrids of classical forms and jazz. For a while, Johnson remained in constant demand as a sideman in the bands of the most illustrious jazz leaders. He toured with Miles Davis in 1961, and then with the fearsome alto-sax virtuoso Sonny Stitt. But the development of his composing talents presented him with both an easier and a more lucrative way to make a living. He moved to Los Angeles in 1970 to work on TV and movie scores, and his work in jazz contexts progressively reduced. He never lost his instrumental skills, however, as he forcibly reminded audiences and players alike whenever he returned to the stage. Though a few recordings in the 70s showed him rather uneasily attempting to adapt himself to jazz-rock, he remained capable of startling performances - such as the two albums he made within weeks of each other in 1983 (We'll Be Together Again, and Things Are Getting Better All The Time), which, among other things, pitched his delicate embroidery against the more rugged impact of former Basie trombonist, Al Grey. After 1987, when he returned to his hometown of Indianapolis, Johnson enthusiastically took to live performance again, and as late as 1996 he was still involved in excellent recordings, such as the all-star Brass Orchestra session, including one of the trombonist's most effective larger-scale pieces, El Camino Real. He had been in ill-health for some months and committed suicide. His first wife of 40 years, Vivian, predeceased him, and he is survived by his second wife, Carolyn Johnson.  J J Johnson, jazz trombonist, bandleader and composer, born January 22 1924; died February 4 2001

fields.headline: Lady Denton of Wakefield
fields.standfirst: As businesswoman, politician and champion racing driver, she was determined to make the world a better place
fields.trailText: As businesswoman, politician and champion racing driver, she was determined to make the world a better place.
fields.body:
The one thing that Jean Denton, who has died aged 65, wanted to achieve in the course of a life that was packed with incident, action and achievement, was a feeling that she had made a difference. She wanted to make the world a better place. It was the motivation that drove her as a businesswoman, that propelled her into politics and sustained her tireless pursuit of a multitude of worthy causes.

But she was also wonderfully reckless, spending three years as a professional racing driver, and twice becoming the British Women Racing Drivers' Champion.

It might have been expected that she would find the pace of life in City boardrooms and the House of Lords somewhat dull by comparison, but nothing ever bored her. She exuded energy, instilling a sense of fun and excitement into whatever mission she had embarked upon.

Her first brush with cancer in 1989 did nothing to diminish her enthusiasms, merely alerting her to the irritating possibility of a shortage of time in hand. She asked her doctors at the time to deal with her honestly, and to tell her if she was not going to recover, so that she might swap her old Granada for a Porsche.

When she recovered from the operation to remove a malignant brain tumour, which had been diagnosed in the autumn of 1998, it was a matter of months before she was back on the opposition front bench in the upper House as trade and industry spokeswoman, proclaiming her determination not to waste whatever time it was that she had been given.

Baroness Denton of Wakefield was nominated for the House of Lords by John Major in 1991, and immediately joined the government as a whip. The following year she was appointed as one of the junior ministers at the department of trade and industry, and she moved from there to the department of employment.

In 1994, she became a Northern Ireland minister, with responsibility for employment and agriculture there, and formed a committed determination to help the peace process. In her three years as a Northern Ireland minister, she also became close friends with Mo Mowlam.

The Northern Ireland Secretary, who had surgery in early 1997 for a non-malignant brain tumour, was one of the first people Lady Denton rang when her own tumour was diagnosed. She spoke movingly afterwards about how Dr Mowlam had helped her face her forthcoming operation and its implications.

Jean Moss was born in Yorkshire, the daughter of Charles and Kathleen Moss, and never lost the tough, forthright, go-getting attributes of her native county. She was educated at Rothwell grammar school and the London School of Economics, and in 1958 married the pioneering marine engineer Dr Anthony Denton. They were divorced in 1974.

She worked in business before her spell as a racing and rally driver from 1969 to 1972, and then worked in the motor industry. She was marketing director of the Huxford Group for six years, worked with the Heron Group for another seven, and then became external affairs director of Austin Rover. She was the deputy chairwoman of the Black Country Development Corporation until she went into the House of Lords.

At the same time, when not in government, she served on numerous other boards and public bodies, including the Teachers' Pay Review Board and the NHS Policy Board. She was on the board of the Royal Academy, a member of the council of the Royal Society of Arts, and a governor of the LSE.

She was a first-class fixer. She knew people in all areas and she was a great networker. She also believed very strongly in working with other women - she used to talk about the strength of what she called the "women's mafia", and she would never hesitate to use her contacts and influence if she could do so to help further a cause. She was a co-founder of Forum UK, the British branch of the International Women's Forum, and she started a fundraising group called Women on the Move Against Cancer after the death of her own mother from mis-diagnosed bowel cancer in the 70s.

She also encouraged other women, and, during the course of the Conservative government, did more than most to seek the public promotion of more women to positions of power and influence. She was outraged by the fact that when she resigned from the board of British Nuclear Fuels, on her appointment to the government, she reduced the number of women nominated by the then department of Energy by 50 per cent - there being only one other woman board member.

She was cheerful, cheery and optimistic, infuriated by her illness and frustrated by anything which diminished her ability to attack life with the force and vigour she had once so enjoyed.

 Jean Denton (Lady Denton of Wakefield), businesswoman and politician, born December 29 1935; died February 5 2001

webTitle: Obituary: The Rt Rev John Taylor

fields.headline: The Rt Rev John Taylor
fields.standfirst: Bishop whose Christian view of the world embraced all faiths
fields.trailText: Bishop whose Christian view of the world embraced all faiths.
fields.body:
John Taylor, who has died aged 86, was Bishop of Winchester between 1975 and 1985, chairman of the Church of England Doctrine Commission from 1978 until 1985, and one of the great missionaries of his generation. Convinced that Christians should leave their church boundaries to listen and think much harder, he pleaded with a startled General Synod to "go into no man's land, for the strange meeting, as Wilfred Owen would have described it".

Taylor's God was cosmic and also worshipped by non-Christians. He felt that there were many, like the novelist George Eliot, who saw that God was to be experienced outside the church.

Yet the gentle thinker was startlingly decisive. As Bishop of Winchester, he agreed to hand over a redundant Southampton church to a Sikh congregation. He quoted Japanese Christians and French Roman Catholic bishops who had allowed non-Christian bodies to take over unneeded churches. He met stiff opposition - better to bulldoze it for a supermarket than to let immigrant non-Christians use the building, was some synod members' view.

Speaking about instability in marriage, he wished the Church had been more forceful about the disgraceful housing and grinding unemployment which put harsh strains on relationships. He criticised the Church Commissioners' African and housing policy. Some felt him too idealistic - but it was an irony that after his retirement, the Church Commissioners lost £800m on unwise American property investment.

Taylor's father was the vice-principal of Ridley Hall, an evangelical theological college in Cambridge, and went on to be principal of Wycliffe Hall, Oxford, and then Bishop of Sodor and Man. His son was educated at St Lawrence College, Ramsgate; Trinity College, Cambridge; St Catherine's Society (now college) and Wycliffe Hall, Oxford; and London university's Institute of Education.

From 1938-40, John Taylor was curate of All Souls in London's West End, and curate-in-charge at St Andrew's church in St Helen's, Lancashire, from 1940-43. In 1945, he was appointed warden of Bishop Tucker College in Mukono, Uganda. He saw that African independence, political and religious, should be welcomed by western Christians.

Back in Britain in 1954, he was a research worker with the International Missionary Council until 1959. He then became African secretary, and afterwards, general secretary of the Church Missionary Society until his appointment as Bishop of Winchester.

What struck candidates, clergy and laity in London and Hampshire was his gentle liberality. He believed the media, especially television, gave the gospel new opportunities. His African Passion Play was beautifully filmed in the 50s, and his Winchester Cathedral Passion and Resurrection (1981) drew on his skills as an actor and poet.

Taylor was always producing plays and reviews, and publishing books. The Primal Vision (1963) had been groundbreaking on African understanding of religion. His other books on Africa, including Growth Of The Church In Buganda (1958), and Christianity And Politics In Africa (1957), showed a fresh appreciation of how Africans saw and practised faith in the gospel.

His two most influential books, The Go-Between God (1972) and Enough is Enough (1975), in some ways more visionary than the church appeared to be, reached a younger generation. The church's wealth in Britain and the United States - in contrast to much of the third world - needed the lifestyle plea which Taylor made. His gentleness, humility and artistic gifts fused in this shy and prophetic thinker.

He died in Oxford after losing his sight, and is survived by his wife, a son and two daughters.

 John Vernon Taylor, priest, born September 11 1914; died January 30 2001

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Your fine obituary of O Winston Link, the most evocative of railway photographers (February 6), missed one subtle point in the photograph of Hot Shot East Bound.
fields.body:
Philip Ashbourn writes: Your fine obituary of O Winston Link, the most evocative of railway photographers (February 6), missed one subtle point in the photograph of Hot Shot East Bound. There is a bicycle leaning against the passenger door of the car in the foreground containing the young couple. Was it his or hers? She looks too formal in dress to be on a bike, but he is sitting in the driving seat. I am sure that O Winston Link would have had a reason for it - perhaps it was his homage to the bicycle engineers who built the first motor vehicles and aeroplanes?

Dr Kay Andrews, director, Education Extra, writes: We first encountered Pat Stack (Obituary, February 1) in 1993, when study support was the minority interest of a few passionate teachers. It proved a decisive moment. Pat was one of those who saw what else could be done, and needed to be done for, and with, pupils outside the formal school day to enrich their learning and lives. He was an exceptional teacher who, when offered the chance to involve pupils in new interests, would say: "When can we start?" We, and everyone involved in the national movement for out of school learning, will miss him very deeply.

Paul Edwards writes: Ivan Hewett's obituary for Iannis Xenakis (February 5) was dispiriting and not very insightful. I fundamentally disagree with his too-obvious conclusions that the music was "atavistic" and was a misguided attempt "to return to a kind of primal innocence". This is missing the point. Milan Kundera put the case for Xenakis perfectly when he wrote in Regards Sur Xenakis (1981): "he revealed the world to me, rich, vast, complex . . . and without sentiment; a space of consoling objectivity in which the aggressiveness of a soul bent on self-expression has no place."

Eric Chandler writes: Some years ago I went to an organ recital at Bath Abbey given by Christopher Dearnley (Obituary, January 24). In those days, the abbey authorities used to request that no applause should be given, but that the audience should show its appreciation by standing in silence at the end of the performance. This we reverentially did. Dearnley bowed in acknowledgement, and then solemnly went to the console and played an encore. The next day I asked a colleague of mine who knew Dearnley at Oxford if he remembered him having a sense of humour. He answered: "Dry."

fields.headline: At this price?  Tate & Lyle
fields.trailText: Tate & Lyle shares were looking sickly again yesterday after the world's biggest sugar maker gave its fourth profit warning in less than a year.
fields.body:
Tate & Lyle shares were looking sickly again yesterday after the world's biggest sugar maker gave its fourth profit warning in less than a year.

The stock, which has underperformed its British food peers by 30% over the past 12 months, yesterday fell a further 5p to 267.5p.

America's largest sweetener manufacturer, Imperial Sugar, has filed for protection against creditors and the price of processed sugar has fallen close to that of the raw variety. Excellent harvests have increased sugar beet volumes while soaring energy prices have driven up costs. The starch and sweetener products markets remain highly competitive partly because of a slowdown in canned fizzy drink sales as consumers switch to water.

Tate & Lyle is trying to sell its Domino cane refining business and find a way out of its Western beet processing division. These US companies are losing a combined £20m and will be hard to sell.

Tate & Lyle has complained about the US government's involvement in the sugar industry and said margins have been squeezed "for an unprecedented period".

The difficulties have been enhanced by soaring US energy costs. In November Tate & Lyle warned energy costs would be more than £30m for the year ending March 30. Yesterday it revised that figure to £40m.

There was some good news in yesterday's update. The US and European starch and sweetener businesses Amylum and Staley are predicted to perform more strongly in the next financial year.

David Lang, food analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, has downgraded his pre-tax profits forecast before exceptionals for this year from £125m to £115m. But Investec and Deutsche Bank expect a T&L recovery in 2002 and 2003.

The share price has fallen from a peak of 580p in April 1998 and now looks cheap, but with uncertainty surrounding the sale of US assets it is likely to underperform for some time. Avoid.

fields.headline: Rumour raises Standard
fields.trailText: It was probably a measure of how dull things were in the London market yesterday that traders were prepared to entertain the idea of a bid for Standard Chartered.
fields.body:
It was probably a measure of how dull things were in the London market yesterday that traders were prepared to entertain the idea of a bid for Standard Chartered.

Not that shareholders were complaining as Standard's shares were chased 18.5p higher to £10.75p. The tale had its origins in the Far East and the appointment of Philippe Paillart (a former Standard Chartered employee) as chief executive of the Development Bank of Singapore (DBS).

Apparently Mr Paillart, who left Standard shortly after Rana Talwar was made chief executive, wants to return and sees a DBS takeover as the perfect way to do it.

However, the speculation overlooked a couple of rather important facts, quickly pointed out by analysts at Fox-Pitt, Kelton. One problem they noted was the fact that DBS is smaller than Standard. It has a market capitalisation of $14.6bn (£10bn), whereas Standard is worth $17.5bn. The other was competition issues in Singapore. At the moment DBS controls 36% of mortgages and 44% of the deposit market in Singapore.

"This rumour has little credibility. It has brought Standard Chartered close to the level at which we would be looking to take profits," the analysts said.

Across the board banking shares were moving higher yesterday, injecting a bit of life into an otherwise lacklustre session. The FTSE 100 index closed 24.2 points stronger at 6,293.4. Elsewhere, the Techmark 100 index added 12.91 points to 2,719.1 as a firmer start to trading on the Nasdaq tempted buyers back into the market.

Halifax, 42p higher at 689p, led the banks and the blue-chips higher as the market warmed to its deal to buy life assurer Equitable Life. Most analysts believe it is a credible deal, done at a good price which sets the former mortgage bank on the road to becoming a bancassurer-asset gatherer.

Elsewhere, hopes that the Bank of England will cut interest rates by 25 basis points tomorrow were supporting the likes of Barclays, up 32p at £22.19, and Royal Bank of Scotland, 27p higher at £15.96p.

But Bank of Scotland missed out on the fun, falling 13p to 707p as its adviser, CSFB, raised £193m through a placing of new shares to finance the recent acquisition of ICC Bank. CSFB placed the new shares with institutions at 690p - a 30p discount to Monday's closing price of 720p.

Away from the banking sector, Marks & Spencer slipped 5p to 233p as the George Davies deal was subjected to further scrutiny by the City's number crunchers. WestLB Panmure said the market's reaction to the agreement - the shares rose nearly 8% on Friday - had been overdone. Even if successful, WestLB thinks the deal is unlikely to create much value for M&S.

British Airways was again in the doldrums. Following on from Monday's 8% drop, its shares eased a further 8p to 413p after a downgrade from Deutsche Bank. Lowering its rating to "underperform", Deutsche said Tuesday's third-quarter figures failed to mask a number of strategic concerns, including BA's vulnerability to a slowdown in North America and Heathrow's limitations as a hub.

News that rival Pfizer has won approval for a new anti-schizophrenia drug, without the need for a "black box" label warning, saw AstraZeneca marked 46p lower at £30.50. Analysts fear the drug could pinch market share from Astra's Seroquel.

Lower down, buyers were still nibbling away at Sema, the IT company that admitted to receiving takeover approaches on Monday. With Merrill Lynch said to be telling clients that a takeout price of 550p-600p was likely, the shares added 3.5p to 452.5p.

fields.headline: Galen set for hormone boost
fields.trailText: Northern Irish health care company Galen Holdings yesterday disclosed a 114% leap in first-quarter profits to £12.8m, and indicated that it was within weeks of launching its widely hyped new treatment for hormone replacement therapy.
fields.body:
Northern Irish health care company Galen Holdings yesterday disclosed a 114% leap in first-quarter profits to £12.8m, and indicated that it was within weeks of launching its widely hyped new treatment for hormone replacement therapy.

Galen recently became Northern Ireland's first £1bn public company. Chairman John King said: "We're usually fairly conservative here but it's fair to say we're pretty upbeat at the moment."

The firm's surging figures were partly down to its £190m purchase of Warner Chilcott, a profitable US manufacturer of contraceptive pills which pro vided Galen with an American sales force.

Mr King said the company was on the lookout for more acquisitions. Galen particularly wants a marketing network in Europe, but is struggling to find anything suitable because of the typically tightly held share structure of continental drugs firms.

He said: "There may be product acquisitions in the States - particularly in female health care or dermatology. In Europe, we'll have to be very opportunistic."

Galen's most promising product is an intra-vaginal ring which gradually releases hormone replacement therapy, reducing the need for women to follow complicated pill-taking regimes.

The company received an "approvable letter" from the food and drug administration for the ring last month, and formal approval is expected imminently.

Mr King said Galen's marketing team had been preparing to launch the product, which could command peak annual sales of £50m. Other rings are in development to improve sex drive, reduce the risk of infectious diseases and provide contraception.

Galen's shares rose 27.5p to 860p. Mr King and the company's president, Allen McClay, have a combined stake of 36%, worth just under £500m.

fields.headline: US crisis knocks power scheme
fields.trailText: The energy crisis in California has cast a pall over Britain's new electricity trading system, which promises lower prices for domestic consumers.
fields.body:
The energy crisis in California has cast a pall over Britain's new electricity trading system, which promises lower prices for domestic consumers.

Energy regulator Ofgem yesterday refused to commit itself to a March 27 launch date for the new arrangements, admitting the political stakes had been raised by the US blackouts.

Callum McCarthy, chief executive of Ofgem, said he still hoped to meet the timetable but would only make a recommendation on going live to the government on March 16 after further testing.

Technical hitches delayed the launch of new electricity trading arrangements (Neta) in November.

Mr McCarthy admitted the situation had become more delicate because of the economic and political problems triggered by energy shortages the US.

The Neta arrangements, which will cost £100m to implement, are aimed at providing a more competitive environment which should eventually drive down domestic prices. They replace the current wholesale market in England and Wales known as the electricity pool.

Under Neta, power and electricity companies are expected to sign their own bilateral trading deals.

fields.headline: House price growth at 5-year low
fields.standfirst: Money site
fields.trailText: The annual rate of house price growth has slumped to its lowest level for five years, according to figures yesterday which contradict data issued last week showing surging prices.
fields.body:
The annual rate of house price growth has slumped to its lowest level for five years, according to figures yesterday which contradict data issued last week showing surging prices.

Average British property is now worth 0.9% more than a year ago, the Halifax said. But Britain's largest mortgage lender seemed embarrassed by the finding that compares with an annual rate of price growth of 7.1% in November.

It said the latest annual price inflation figure was more a reflection of sharp rises in prices a year ago than an indicator of the current state of the market, which, it added, is set to enjoy steady growth in the coming months. In that respect the new figure was "a little bit misleading", a spokesman said.

Halifax also said property values rose 0.1% last month, taking the typical price-tag to £85,666 compared with £85,563 in December and £84,867 in January last year.

The last time the rate of annual house price growth was lower than 0.9% was in 1996.

Halifax's figures are in stark contrast to last week's data from Nationwide building society showing that prices surged 2.5% in January - one of the largest monthly rises since the late 1980's property boom - lifting the annual rate of price growth to 11.2%.

This is not the first time the two leading commentators on house prices have clashed over where they see the housing market going.

The Halifax spokesman said the sizeable fall in the annual rate was in line with expectations and was attributable to a 2.3% increase in prices notched up in January 2000. It did not amount to a downturn in the market, and the underlying trend shows that prices have been broadly stable in recent months.

"A number of key leading indicators of housing market activity suggest a strengthening in demand over the short term," the bank said. "The UK economy also remains in good health and there is the prospect of lower interest rates over the coming months. These factors should support housing demand during 2001."

The bank has not amended its prediction for growth, which stands at 4% for this year. Nationwide's forecast is 7%.

webTitle: CSR takes the lead in unplugged future

fields.headline: CSR takes the lead in unplugged future
fields.trailText: The familiar vision of a brave new world in which domestic appliances conspire to make our lives an effortless joy is just around the corner, says CSR co-founder Phil O'Donovan.
fields.body:
Like a typical science fiction film, Cambridge Silicon Radio's promotional video begins with a handsome hero asleep in his futuristic home. He is awoken by the ringing of a state-of-the-art alarm clock which at the same time sends a radio signal to the coffee percolator in the kitchen, prompting it into action. Before our hero has even thrown back the duvet, another radio signal is sent to the bathroom, and water gushes from the taps, drawing a steaming, hot bath.

This familiar vision of a brave new world in which domestic appliances conspire to make our lives an effortless joy is just around the corner, says CSR co-founder Phil O'Donovan, as the video comes to an end. "By the end of the second quarter of this year we will see our first Bluetooth goods on sale in the high street," he says.

Bluetooth is the radio technology which allows digital goods to communicate over short distances without a cable link-up. Mr O'Donovan's Cambridge-based firm is one of more than 50 companies worldwide racing to develop commercial Bluetooth applications.

The first product using a CSR microchip to be widely available on the high street will be a palmtop organiser able to receive remote messages from Bluetooth-fitted PCs. Mr O'Donovan says this promises to be just one of the many innovative Bluetooth products available to shoppers this year.

CSR's hope of reaching a high volume consumer market is based on its refining of the Bluetooth technology into a single chip, which the company hopes to to market for only £2.40 within six months. This would make Bluetooth gadgets more affordable.

Among the Bluetooth products in varying stages of development are leadless printers, cableless video games consoles and wireless headsets for mobile phones and personal stereos. A study by Forrester Research estimates the market for Bluetooth chips could be worth £3.5bn by 2005.

There have been several false dawns since the Swedish mobile phone group Ericsson developed the first Bluetooth prototypes more than six years ago. But market analysts continue to keep a watchful eye on companies like CSR, not least because of the high profile investors they are attracting. Last month, CSR announced the completion of a £34m funding round, with cash coming from such established names as Sony, Philips, Intel Capital and ARM. Another reason for the continuing excitement surrounding Bluetooth is the industry enthusiasm for the technology.

More than 2,100 companies worldwide - including Microsoft, Intel, and Lucent - are part of a special interest group committed to promoting Bluetooth as an industry standard.

David Johnson, a technology analyst from stockbroker Beeson Gregory, says CSR could be well placed to exploit this interest as the first company to distil Bluetooth down to a single chip. This could equally be the company's undoing if goods manufacturers later demand changes that CSR cannot realise within their single chip. In the meantime, Mr O'Donovan remains irrepressibly optimistic and drops hints about a CSR float.

The market is likely to approach CSR's technology with caution until it attracts consumers in large numbers. It remains to be seen whether shoppers buy in to the vision of Bluetooth-enabled cars, computers, radios, clocks and coffee percolators.

Some cableless technology can be more irritating than its is helpful - as anyone who has lost a cordless telephone down the back of a sofa knows. "Yes, I do have a cordless phone at home," says Mr O'Donovan. And have you ever misplaced it? "Not personally. But, well, I do have children."

Perhaps there is a future for the cable link yet.

Chips in everything

Bluetooth technology allows mobile phones, PCs and other digital goods to communicate with each other without the use of cables. It works through a microchip and an embedded radio transceiver which can relay digital instructions to other products up to 100 metres away. Microchip designers soon hope to be able to sell Bluetooth chips for $5 (£2.40). They say that an inexpensive chip will open up countless commercial opportunities for digital goods manufacturers. Designers have promised - not for the first time since the technology was developed in 1994 - that Bluetooth will be embedded in hundreds of millions of products worldwide by the end of the year.

The technology was born out of research by the Swedish telecoms group Ericsson, and has been named after the 10th century Viking king Harald Bluetooth who unified warring tribes in Denmark and Norway. It was further developed by five companies - Ericsson, Intel, IBM, Nokia and Toshiba - which formed the Bluetooth special interest group.

The group, which has since been joined by more than 2,100 firms worldwide, hopes to establish Bluetooth as an industry standard, allowing differently branded goods to communicate with each other on a globally available radio frequency.

fields.headline: Sleaze's slimy inventiveness
fields.standfirst: Sleaze is back, grinning its slobbering grin. But it never really went away - we just haven't been paranoid enough to detect its presence
fields.trailText: Sleaze is back, grinning its slobbering grin. But it never really went away - we just haven't been paranoid enough to detect its presence.
fields.body:
One day after France's former foreign minister, the almost impossibly grand Roland Dumas, who is on trial for corruption, denounces the proceedings against him - that a personage as distinguished as he should be subjected to such an ordeal! Zut! Alors! - the fugitive businessman Alfred Sirven is arrested in the Philippines, and immediately claims that he could provide evidence of corruption against "100 names" - that is, most of the political élite of the Mitterrand era.

Meanwhile, in Peru, the seizure of more than 2,000 secretly obtained videotapes reveals the extent of the power of the fallen President Fujimori's secret state over just about everyone in that country's ruling class. Journalists, politicians, generals were all being blackmailed for years.

Meanwhile, in India, the Bofors scandal bubbles to the surface again. The rumours of corruption surrounding this 1980s arms deal have already besmirched the reputations of the late Rajiv Gandhi - did he or did he not accept illegal kickbacks? - and the late Olof Palme - was he assassinated by a disgruntled middleman? Now, as the Indian courts turn their attention to the activities of the billionaire Hinduja brothers, the old scandal threatens to hurl new dirt across the oceans, at the British government, which became so improbably friendly with the Hindujas.

(A four-year-old child could have warned the Blairites against this association. Unfortunately, no four-year-old child was available, and as a result the British public presently believes New Labour to be almost as sleazy as the grubby Tories they replaced. Almost as sleazy as Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken! Well . . . gosh.)

Meanwhile, in the United States, ex-President Clinton is under fire for having pardoned the fugitive financier Marc Rich, while his successor, "President" Bush, mouths platitudes about bilateralism while pursuing an agenda of the extreme right; and this in spite of the growing evidence that he lost the election he "won" thanks to the notorious supreme court coup; and lost it, in Florida, by a margin of around 25,000 votes.

Yes, sleaze has resurfaced, grinning its slobbering grin, to remind us that it never really went away - that it remains the great occult force that bends and shapes the age, its existence perennially denied, its empire expanding daily. You can almost admire its inexhaustible inventiveness. Things you never imagined were sleazy - things that actually were never tarnished before - come daily under sleaze's slimy suzerainty, and are hopelessly compromised, or, like innocence or paradise, lost.

Thus, a feature of recent months has been the sleazing-up not only of politics, where it's almost expected, but of sport. Is racing fixed? asks the British press, and you can almost hear the horses laugh. About boxing, nobody even bothers to ask. And the former Liverpool goalkeeper, Bruce Grobbelaar, has at last been found guilty of taking bribes by the court of appeal. Even cricket, whose very name was once a synonym for integrity, is now up to here in the dirt. As for athletics, the recent "doping Olympics" offered spectacular evidence of trouble: the shot-putter CJ Hunter's four positive drug tests; the gold-medal gymnast Andreea Raducan's positive test for pseudoephedrine; Carl Lewis's astonishing comment on Linford Christie's positive test for nandrolone: "They got him at last." So our heroes are at it now, as well as our leaders. In fact, it looks as if they've been at it all along.

Is there anything out there that is not fixed? Reality-TV contests? Literary prizes? University entrance examinations? Your upcoming job interview? Or is it just that we haven't found out how the fixing is being done?

Welcome to the third millennium. The American novelist Thomas Pynchon's redefinition of paranoia has never seemed more firmly on the money: paranoia usefully seen as the crazy-making but utterly sane realisation that our times have secret meanings, that those meanings are dreadful, immoral and corrupt beyond our wildest imaginings, and that the surface of things is a fraud, an artifact designed to hide the awful truth from us ordinary deluded suckers, who keep wanting to believe that things might actually - you know? - be beginning to improve.

The sucker reaction to much of the foregoing would be to point out that many of the sleaze merchants I've mentioned have received or are receiving their come-uppances. Dumas is on trial, Sirven is in custody, Fujimori has fallen, Clinton is history, the bent cricketers were banned and the doping athletes were caught. So that's all right then.

The paranoid knows better. If the crimes of the past are only now being uncovered, the paranoid will retort, how long will it take before we know about the crimes of the present? Are the "innocent" merely the guilty whose guilt hasn't yet been established? Pynchonian analysis leaves true paranoids with few choices: to become obsessed investigators of the world's secret meanings; to accept their impotence and fall into one of a familiar selection of futile, addled, entropic hazes; or to explode into the kind of rage that wants to blow things up.

I knew a man once whose thing it was to wreck the toilets in office buildings and write a slogan on the ruined walls: "If the cistern cannot be changed it must be destroyed." I'm beginning to understand how he felt. And to remember how, in a younger, hairier, angrier phase of life, I often used to feel.

Pynchonian analysis leaves true paranoids with few choices: to become obsessed investigators of the world's secret meanings; to accept their impotence and fall into one of a familiar selection of futile, addled, entropic hazes; or to explode into the kind of rage that wants to blow things up. I knew a man once whose thing it was to wreck the toilets in office buildings and write a slogan on the ruined walls: "If the cistern cannot be changed it must be destroyed." I'm beginning to understand how he felt. And to remember how, in a younger, hairier, angrier phase of life, I often used to feel.

fields.headline: No 1814
fields.standfirst: Chris Packham
fields.trailText: Chris Packham
fields.body:
Who he? The famed naturalist.

Oooh, saucy. No. Naturalist.

Oh. Flowers and bears and things. Packham made his name as co-presenter of kiddies' beast fest The Really Wild Show.

Was he the balding avuncular one? No, that's Terry Nutkins.

Wasn't he in Beatrix Potter? You're getting confused.

So who's this Packham character? He was the dashing, bleached-blond wildlife adventurer with whom a generation of girls longed to get, er, zoological.

And now he' s back. Very publicly. He's calling for Britain's most prolific serial killers to be neutered or shot.

Harold Shipman? Rosemary West? Tiddles.

Come again? In response to recent statistics showing that Britain's 7.5m domestic cats slaughter some 275m wild animals yearly, Packham commented to Radio 4's Today programme this week, "Where did I put my shotgun?"

Lock up your moggies! "They are insidious murderers by nature," he said. "I shoot cats regularly, unfortunately merely with a water pistol."

I've got a bad feline about this. Packham argues that we should adopt the Australia system, where cats found on the streets after a curfew are picked off by gun-toting tabby wardens.

Pussy galore, no more. Never fear, the RSPCA is keeping cat vigilantes at bay. "Anyone in public life who implies that the way to tackle the problem is by shooting them is very disappointing," says a spokesperson, before warning Chris that "the penalty can be six months in prison".

Don't mess with the Royal Society! Dramatically compromising his original scheme, Packham is now suggesting that bells be attached to cats' necks.

Least likely to sing: "He's the boss / He's the VIP / He's a championship / He's the most tip top - Top Cat".

Most likely to scream: "Ready, Aim, Fire!"

Not to be confused with: Curiosity.

fields.headline: Halitosis rex
fields.trailText: The new arrival at the Natural History Museum stopped the religious education class from St Albans in its tracks. When Tyrannosaurus rex sensed their movements, lashed its 10 foot tail, then threw up its great head and bellowed, they were transfixed.
fields.body:
The new arrival at the Natural History Museum stopped the religious education class from St Albans in its tracks. When Tyrannosaurus rex sensed their movements, lashed its 10 foot tail, then threw up its great head and bellowed, they were transfixed.

The museum has just accepted delivery of the creature, the most sophisticated animatronic dinosaur ever built. It incorporates movement sensors so that it responds terrifyingly to the approach of a human being, lunging with a jawful of teeth.

It was designed with advice from scientists, and took a team of Japanese engineers three months to construct. It is 20 feet long and 12 feet tall - about three quarters the size of a fully grown T rex - and cost £220,000.

When the model, which was temporarily installed yesterday in the front hall, is moved permanently into the dinosaur gallery it will also smell - of cop-out. The museum has substituted a swampy smell, like carelessly cooked spinach, for the correct stench of rotting flesh.

The dinosaur was a messy eater which probably flattened its prey under one huge foot, then ripped it to bloody shreds with teeth and claws, and would have had revolting breath.

Angela Milner, head of vertebrate palaeontology, said: "T rex had serrated teeth like steak knives, and we know from fossil evidence that it got shreds of meat trapped between the teeth. It undoubtedly had a pretty unsavoury mouth, but we felt it would be a bit too overpowering to subject visitors to that."

The chosen smell, blended for the museum, is Maastrichtian Miasma, named not after the EU treaty, but after 19th century discoveries in a Dutch chalk quarry which gave their name to a stage of the Cretaceous era.

The figure incorporates a wealth of new information about the creatures after important finds in the last 30 years. The first skeleton was found in 1905, and the first models showed it towering upright: scientists now know this was wrong, and it held its body more or less horizontal, counter-balanced by its huge tail.

T rex goes on permanent display on February 17.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Swayne's world brings burst of hilarity

fields.headline: Swayne's world brings burst of hilarity
fields.trailText: 7pm, Monday night. The House of Commons is voting. To everyone's amazement, Peter Mandelson walks in.
fields.body:
Twenty-four hours in British politics: 7pm, Monday night. The House of Commons is voting. To everyone's amazement, Peter Mandelson walks in. At one point he stands behind the Speaker's chair, near the defence secretary Geoff Hoon, one of the ministers who was unsupportive after his resignation. ("Yes, he can distribute leaflets and knock on doors during the election if he wants," he said.) In a voice loud enough for several Tories to hear, Mandelson says, "and I thought you were my friend!".

Later that night, the Tory winter ball is held in a trendy club, Planit 2000, on the fringe of the East End. This is how cool: the first song the band played was Oh, Pretty Woman by Roy Orbison, which may be old but is at least 20 years more recent than the next newest song ever played at this event.

I'm told William Hague made a dreary speech (I wasn't there) on the theme "give us back our country!", Tory-speak for "give us back our jobs". Steve "Shagger" Norris helped with the auction. Two people offered £90,000 for a fortnight's cruise on a yacht. Rather than have one lose the prize, they agreed to pay the full amount but take only one week each. I don't know who they were, but I bet they're moaning about how Gordon Brown has virtually ruined them.

(Shagger is probably the most unpopular man in the party, because of his support for legalising gay sex in public. Some Tory I heard also claimed he was in favour of polygamy, suggesting the world's smallest pressure group, "Gays With Several Wives for Norris").

2.45pm, Tuesday. The Speaker, Michael Martin, still addressed as "Mr Deputy Speaker" by MPs who can't quite get over his election, is trying to persuade ministers not to spend their time attacking the Tories. "They are there to account for their departments," he says. He is, as usual, ignored, though ministers now carefully say to him: "notwithstanding your strictures" before launching yet another attack on the Tories.

3.00pm. Desmond Swayne, regarded by Labour as the second biggest joke in the Tory party, appears to speak from the frontbench for the first time. He stands to a loud burst of hilarity. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is ready for him. "I welcome him. He is highly popular with my honourable friends on this side, though I do not know what Liam Fox [shadow health minister] has done to deserve him." Mr Milburn then accuses him of various dotty remarks. On the need to reduce teenage pregnancy: "they should put something in the water."

This was clearly a joke, and rather enhances Mr Swayne's standing in my eyes. At least Labour MPs have stopped making howling, werewolf noises when he stands up.

3.30pm: Keith Vaz comes in to hear Labour's favourite Tory, Michael Fabricant, make a speech against the EU. Mickey seems to be suggesting that we join the US, Canada and Mexico in Nafta instead. This is because he would be able to emigrate to the US and again become top disc-jockey Mickey Fabb, spinning Eminem platters for the young people of Dog's Breath, South Dakota.

Mickey gets a first reading for his bill, though it will not become law. On the way out he pats Mr Vaz amicably. One wonders which needs the other's help least.

4.30pm. Surprisingly, Ann Widdecombe is opposing a bill which would allow clergy and former Roman Catholic priests to become members of parliament. Miss Widdecombe, a Catholic herself, says scornfully, "I find intriguing the thought of a priest in holy orders, which require poverty, chastity and obedience, functioning in this place." She is met with loud agreement.
