webTitle: NHS rationing on way, say doctors

fields.headline: NHS rationing on way, say doctors
fields.standfirst: BMA says extra resources not enough to meet demand
fields.trailText: Leading doctors admitted for the first time yesterday that health rationing is inevitable and that the guiding principle of the NHS as a comprehensive service "may have outlived its usefulness".
fields.body:
Leading doctors admitted for the first time yesterday that health rationing is inevitable and that the guiding principle of the NHS as a comprehensive service "may have outlived its usefulness".

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, asked for a public debate in the run-up to the general election about which treatments should no longer be freely available so that resources could be preserved for essential public services.

He embarrassed the government by casting doubt on the sufficiency of promises in the NHS plan last year to increase the health budget by a third in real terms by 2004.

The extra resources were a welcome respite from problems of underfunding, but the money could never be sufficient to meet expanding demand and the government's treatment of this long-term problem was simplistic, he said.

"We have to accept the prospect of treatments being excluded from the NHS if we want to maintain a universal service, one which is available to everyone and essentially free at the point of use," he said.

The BMA's intervention came after a year-long review of healthcare funding by representatives of doctors, nurses, patients, pharmaceutical companies and private health providers.

Their report said it would become increasingly commonplace for treatments to be excluded from the NHS if they were not deemed cost-effective or an appropriate use of public funds.

The private sector might fill part of this gap by treating people who were prepared to pay. "However, the private sector cannot be a universal panacea for the perceived failings of the NHS. Unless the government and public are prepared to face up to the inevitability of rationing, the debate addressed in this review will recur perpetually and ... the most vulnerable will continue to suffer," the report said.

Dr Bogle refused to give examples of treatments that were likely to become unavailable on the NHS. But the report mentioned fertility treatment, tattoo removal, cosmetic surgery and gender reassignment as low-budget services that were not provided in every NHS area. Other possible exclusions might include counselling and drugs for baldness, obesity and impotence.

It was understood the BMA was pressing the government to take the debate forward by extending the remit of the National Institute of Clinical Excellence to look at the appropriateness of NHS funding for a range of existing treatments.

The review team rejected a series of possible NHS reforms that might have filled the funding gap. Charging for treatment was not appropriate because those most in need of healthcare were generally least able to pay for it. Tax relief for private health insurance would subsidise those who could already afford it. Lottery funding was likely to remain minimal.

The report came as the Department of Health announced that waiting lists for inpatient treatment at NHS hospitals in England increased by 13,200 in December. Ministers said the rise was less than usual at that time of year and drew satisfaction from a fall in the waiting list for outpatient treatment.

Those waiting more than 13 weeks for an outpatient's ap pointment fell from 435,768 to 399,137 in the three months to December.

The department welcomed the BMA's conclusion that the UK's health needs were best served by a tax-funded system. "We are giving the NHS its biggest funding boost for a generation, a real terms increase of one third in its budget between 1999 and 2004.

"We would not be doing that if we thought there was an alternative which was acceptable to the public and which actually worked in practice," a spokesman said.

Jennifer Dixon, healthcare policy director for the King's Fund think tank, said: "Instead of looking for problems with the way health care is funded, we need to focus attention on how we get the best out of the system we have ... The NHS is not so much short of money as it is vital workers."

fields.headline: Waste of energy
fields.standfirst:
While the government claims to lead the world with its plans to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, the figures tell quite a different story.
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: While the government claims to lead the world with its plans to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, the figures tell quite a different story.
fields.body:
The government is going to find it hard to secure the 20% cut in carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 that it promised, rather wildly, in Labour's 1997 manifesto - allowing ministers to claim world leadership on climate change.

As the authoritative Environmental Data Services - which is not prone to hyperbole - puts it today, the government is basing its plans on some "heroically optimistic assumptions". The culprit department is trade and industry. Over at the environment department, forecasts were made based on data supplied by the DTI about how much electricity would be generated in future from nuclear reactors. This has a direct effect on how much coal and gas will be burnt to produce energy and therefore on the carbon dioxide targets.

The DTI has always supported the nuclear industry, to the mystification of people who understand mathematics and the energy market. The department bears some responsibility for the UK lagging behind the rest of Europe on promoting renewable sources of energy (wind and wave power for example) and so reaching Labour's own target of producing 10% of electricity from "green" sources by 2010. Meanwhile, the nuclear industry has been allowed to disguise its true costs and continue to run at full pelt (safety permitting).

Yet electricity output from the nuclear industry is plum meting - by 10% last year, following a 4% drop in 1999. This means that instead of the overall decrease in carbon dioxide emissions that had been predicted for this year, they will rise.

A "temporary blip", DTI said. It is more like a trend. British Nuclear Fuels was landed by the government with the older generation of Magnox reactors; it is struggling and losing heart. Hinkley Point A in Somerset was closed last year - it had expensive technical problems caused by old age. All but two of the rest of the Magnox stations now have dates for their closure before 2008.

The largest and newest of them, Wylfa on Anglesey, was supposed to keep going till 2021 but has been shut for four months with safety problems involving weld flaws. These are being fixed but it will be "many weeks" before it is back in production.

Meanwhile, the fuel that BNFL was developing to al low Wylfa and its sister station Oldbury in Gloucestershire to keep on into the next decade has proved too expensive to produce. This "Magrox project", as it was called, has been abandoned. The new fuel was needed because Wylfa and Oldbury have to have the fuel they now use reprocessed (dissolved in acid and reduced to plutonium and uranium) in an old works at Sellafield, which BNFL has promised to close in 2012. This is because the UK is committed to reduce and then bring to "near zero" Sellafield's radioactive discharges by 2020.

Magrox was being developed so reprocessing could take place in the newer and less polluting Thorp works on the Sellafield site. Its viability is in question.

The failure of the Magrox project means that neither Wylfa and Oldbury have a future beyond 2008. But this date is uncertain. The arithmetic depends on BNFL's Magnox reprocessing plant, known by its works name B205, being able to deal with 1,000 tonnes of spent fuel a year. The past five years have seen a throughput of less than 600 tonnes a year as the 50-year-old plant creaks and groans and constantly runs into health and safety problems over emissions. Updates and refurbishments have not solved its problems and it too has now been closed for months.

The government's radioactive waste management advisers pointed out that at the current rate of progress B205 could not possibly get through the backlog of fuel to be reprocessed by 2012. That implied the Magnox stations would have to shut down much earlier than the official DTI energy supply forecasts allowed. Although the Magnox stations only represent 4% of the UK's capacity to generate power, they are supposed to run all the time - except for statutory shutdowns to check safety.

Similar problems face the reactors operated by British Energy, the private nuclear generator. It owns the pressurised water reactor Sizewell B and seven second-generation advanced gas cooled reactors. The latter are getting on. Dungeness in Kent, the first to open, has famously never worked properly. It is not functioning at the moment; for the past 20 years it has been more off than on.

Insiders claim that these second-generation nuclear stations were run at such high levels in the pre-privatisation period to prove their high productivity that they will never operate as well again. With a family car it would be time to change it for a newer model, but with nuclear stations that is not an option.

Cue the DTI's heroic optimism. It seems to believe that for the next decade the nuclear industry will run more efficiently than ever before. So the official line is that all is well. Older nuclear will be phased out, but not just yet, and at least not until after 2010. By then, renewables, combined heat and power generation (recycling energy) and the dash for gas will have plugged any gap.

On the evidence we have to hand, most of these things will not be true. Coal burning was up 13% last year. Carbon emissions will be affected. However much the government may be in denial, those are the figures that will eventually spell out the facts of the matter.

Paul Brown is the Guardian's environment correspondent

Coal burning was up 13% last year. Carbon emissions will be affected. However much the government may be in denial, those are the figures that will eventually spell out the facts of the matter. Paul Brown is the Guardian's environment correspondent paul.brown@theguardian.com

webTitle: Scots still battered by wintry weather

fields.headline: Scots still battered by wintry weather
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Scotland endured a second day of misery yesterday as bad weather continued to batter much of the country.
fields.body:
Scotland endured a second day of misery yesterday as bad weather continued to batter much of the country.

Around 15,000 homes were left without electricity after high winds and heavy snowfall overnight brought down power lines.

But thousands of children enjoyed a second day off school - more than 300 closed in the Highlands, Grampian, Tayside and Northern Isles.

Two people were injured when an Edinburgh to Inverness train hit a tree on the line and was derailed at Killiecrankie, just south of Blair Atholl.

The driver suffered facial injuries, while a passenger received leg injuries. Both were treated in hospital, but neither was seriously hurt.

None of the other 39 passengers on board was injured, but they had to wait three hours until a second train could make it through to take them to safety.

The Killiecrankie area has been suffering from heavy snowfalls and blizzards for the past two days and it is believed weather problems caused the tree to fall on to the line.

There was some relief, however, for around 100 passengers who had been stranded on the Lerwick to Aberdeen ferry which left Shetland on Sunday night and had been due to dock in Aberdeen on Monday morning. But high winds meant Aberdeen harbour was closed and the passengers were left stranded in rough seas.

Yesterday afternoon the boat managed to dock further north at Invergordon. Some passengers who had missed appointments, however, decided to wait on the ferry and head back to Shetland overnight.

Drivers across Scotland faced treacherous driving conditions. Several main roads -including the A9, the main east coast road - were closed in places, while commuters in Aberdeen faced difficulties in getting to work.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for Scottish Hydro-Electric said the heavy snow meant engineers were taken by helicopter to attend to repairs. "The biggest problem we have at the moment is access to remote areas," he said.

fields.headline: Austria seeks retraction of tabloid 'defamation'
fields.standfirst:
'Fascist' label offends on picture of Edward and Sophie with Freedom party vice-chancellor
Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: The Austrian authorities demanded yesterday that two British newspapers retract their claim that the deputy leader of the government in Vienna is a "Nazi" and a "fascist".
fields.body:
The Austrian authorities demanded yesterday that two British newspapers retract their claim that the deputy leader of the government in Vienna is a "Nazi" and a "fascist".

The Daily Star and the Sun used the terms in their reports of an encounter between the Austrian vice-chancellor, Susanne Riess-Passer, and Prince Edward and his wife Sophie Rhys-Jones. The three were filmed together at a reception in the ski resort of St Anton at the end of January.

Ms Riess-Passer took over from Jörg Haider as leader of the far-right Freedom party in May. The party's inclusion in the coalition government earlier that year cost Austria seven months of isolation from the rest of the EU.

Even though the EU lifted its sanctions against Vienna in September, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, pointedly avoided meeting Freedom party representatives when he visited the city a month later.

Asked if the Royal couple had been briefed by British diplomats on the sensitive political situation in Austria, an official said: "No official briefing was sought, because they had no formal or informal meetings."

In a letter to the editor of the Daily Star, the Austrian ambassador to London, Alexander Christiani, described his paper's coverage as a "devastating defamation" of the deputy chancellor. He added: "Choose your words more carefully."

Mr Christiani said: "You are outrageously comparing the current Austrian government and one of its members to the inhumane, criminal and genocidal regime of Hitler Germany." He demanded a correction, which the Daily Star last night refused to give.

Its editor, Peter Hill, said: "We are sorry that the Austrian government are upset, but our evidence shows that Susanne Riess-Passer leads a party that has unacceptable right-wing views".

A spokeswoman for the Austrian embassy said an EU inquiry had concluded that the Freedom party could fairly be described as "right-populist with extremist tendencies", but not as Nazi or fascist.

Ms Riess-Passer was one of about 1,000 guests at the reception given after the royal couple inaugurated the 2001 world alpine ski championships. A photograph apparently taken from television coverage of the event was published on Monday in the Austrian news magazine Profil.

Prince Edward's spokesman said yesterday: "It was one photograph among many that were taken and there was no meeting in the programme with [the Freedom] party or any other party.

The picture was reproduced in the Daily Star under the headline "Outrage as Edward hobnobs with Nazi."

The Sun headlined its story: "Edward and fascist." Alongside was another photograph of another Edward, his great-uncle, meeting Hitler in 1937, 10 months after his abdication.

Prince Edward's spokesman said: "Like other members of the royal family, [the prince and his wife] meet thousands of people in the course of their official engagements. They couldn't reasonably be expected to know who everyone was."

It is the second time the royal family has been caught in a row over the Austrian far right. In February 1997, before Freedom won a share of power, the Duchess of York was photographed being kissed on the hand by Mr Haider.

A spokesman for Austria's then governing Social Democrat party said: "She should have been much more careful. She was very naive."

The photograph of the royal couple appeared as part of a report on the Freedom party's publicity techniques.

In an editorial, Profil wrote: "The Freedom party is desperate to become socially acceptable and is delighted by an opportunity like this"

fields.headline: Challenge to £5m 'bet' on Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Parliamentary punters yesterday secured a stewards' inquiry into the record £5m "bet" on a Tory win in the general election stakes.
fields.body:
Parliamentary punters yesterday secured a stewards' inquiry into the record £5m "bet" on a Tory win in the general election stakes.

Elizabeth Filkin has agreed to look into William Hague's acceptance of the £5m from the IG Index chairman, Stuart Wheeler, after receiving a formal complaint by Labour MP Alan Simpson.

Mr Simpson, whose gambling is limited to £1 on the Grand National, met the parliamentary commissioner for standards yesterday to accuse Mr Hague of bringing the House of Commons into disrepute.

The Nottingham South MP said the Tory leader had improved his prospects by taking money from a spread betting magnate who hoped to make money on the number of seats the Conservatives win.

"Mr Wheeler stands to make a considerable amount of money out of the election in which the bookie has ended up in bed with the horse," said Mr Simpson.

"What we are talking about is the biggest single donation in British political history, and it happens to have been placed by someone who is also running a book on the result."

Mr Simpson, who also asked the Financial Services Authority to investigate, said there were clear parallels with the case of Motherwell and Wishaw MP Frank Roy, who was censured before Christmas after betting £20 - and winning £3,400 - on the election of the Commons Speaker.

In that case, Ms Filkin ruled that gambling on a parliamentary proceeding "can hardly fail to undermine the public's trust and confidence in the integrity of parliament and certainly risks bringing members of Parliament and the House of Commons into disrepute."

Mr Simpson took legal advice from Labour MP Bob Marshall-Andrews, QC, who said last night: "If anything has been done to alter a market then it must be worth investigating."

IG Index has raised the spread of Tory seats it expects to be won at the election from 212-220 to 222-230 since last month's announcement of Mr Wheeler's unprecedented political donation. Punters "buy" or "sell" above or below the figure, winning or losing on whether they correctly predict more or fewer seats.

A senior Tory source accused Labour of "sour grapes" over the £5m gift, a large proportion of the £14m it will be permitted to spend at the election.

"Labour is just upset it did not go to them," he said. "Anyway, the money goes to the party, not William Hague, so what case is there to answer?"

IG Index insisted that no rules or regulations had been broken, and added that its customer services manager had asked the half-dozen punters who had made bets before the £5m was handed over if they wanted their money back.

"None did. One even placed another bet," said a company spokesman.

Multi-millionaire Mr Wheeler, 65, admitted the Tories were not a dead cert when he put £5m on them - his own company was predicting Labour would be a clear winner.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • The fine imposed on Arsène Wenger by the FA, referred to in the report Wenger referee could be struck off, page 29, Sport, yesterday, was £10,000, not £100,000. Last Friday Mr Wenger successfully appealed against the imposition of a 12-match touchline ban. That was lifted, but the fine remained.
fields.body:
 The fine imposed on Arsène Wenger by the FA, referred to in the report Wenger referee could be struck off, page 29, Sport, yesterday, was £10,000, not £100,000. Last Friday Mr Wenger successfully appealed against the imposition of a 12-match touchline ban. That was lifted, but the fine remained.

 Alfred Dreyfus, the French officer at the centre of the Dreyfus Affair, mentioned in a column on page 2, Saturday Review, February 3, was imprisoned on Devil's Island off the coast of French Guiana, not French Guinea.

 The lyrics of Eminem's Stan, page 2, G2, yesterday, refer to the hip-hop record label Rawkus, not a band called Ruckus.

 "Mary Shelley's Dracula", mentioned in a column, page 5, G2, yesterday, is, of course, Bram Stoker's. Mary Shelley wrote Frankenstein.

 In Soundbites, notes about radio programmes, page 79, the Guide, February 3, referring to Melly Talks Jazz (broadcast tonight, Radio 2, 10pm), we said the guitarist Martin Taylor took over in 1978 from Django Reinhardt in the Hot Club de France. In fact, Django Reinhardt died in 1953, 25 years earlier.

 Yokohama F Marinos are not a junior league football team as we wrongly said in some notes about the interests of Carlos Ghosn, the president of Nissan, page 28, February 3. They are full members of the Japanese professional football league or J League (winners of the league championship, 1995).

 From a report, page 24, Finance, February 3: "He trained as a dentist for two years but gave up to join Littlewoods as a stock controller in charge of ankle stocks."

fields.headline: On the map
fields.trailText: Like your correspondents (Letters, February 5), I too raised an eyebrow at Shiwa Ngunda being included in the BBC2 series Congo, having visited it in about 1960 during a long spell in Northern Rhodesia/Zambia.
fields.body:
Like your correspondents (Letters, February 5), I too raised an eyebrow at Shiwa Ngunda being included in the BBC2 series Congo, having visited it in about 1960 during a long spell in Northern Rhodesia/Zambia.

But I can now come to the defence of the BBC, for my maps show Shiwa Ngandu just east of the mainly watershed road from Mpika to Tunduma. That puts it in the Congo basin. Just a few miles to the west, over what might be called Africa's continental divide, water drains into the Luangwa valley and the Zambezi basin. And the series is about the Congo basin, not just the river of that name.
Rev John Parry
Haughton, Staffs
john@parry-haughton.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Labour's new image: who boobed?

fields.headline: Labour's new image: who boobed?
fields.trailText: What would a psychoanalyst make of Labour's new logo (Design of the times, G2, February 6)?
fields.body:
What would a psychoanalyst make of Labour's new logo (Design of the times, G2, February 6)? Legs spread, a triangle enclosing some kind of orifice, topped with a couple of boobs. Selling with sex? Or possibly a message: "Vote Labour - get f****d!"
Andy Lake
Cambridge
andylake2000@hotmail.com

I don't understand all the carping about the New Labour logo. Its message seems beautifully clear and utterly appropriate: "New Labour - it's whatever you want it to be."
Simon Wood
St Andrews, Fife
snw@st-and.ac.uk

A glance at the collected works of Molesworth reveals the muse for Labour's new logo. It is Fotherington-Thomas, who famously skipped around proclaiming "Hallo sky, hallo birds". Some of us had long suspected the presence of a Fotherington-Thomas tendency biding its time among the roses.
GM Greenwood
Brighton

The Labour party has received my subscription and I have had a letter and glossy literature from my leader, Tony, welcoming me to the party. I also received a welcoming letter from my MP, Robert Sheldon; both have offered me their help as a new boy. This would have been very ego-massaging except for the fact that I have been a Labour voter and member for 50 years and have done my share of letterbox stuffing. I have replied to my "new" colleagues offering my services in the next election and requesting a snap of Tony in which he is not grinning.
Mike Mitchell
Manchester
mickiam@lineone.net

John Killah (Frome) and Leslie Dalton (Eastbourne) are understandibly ripping up their Labour party membership cards, disappointed with its right-ward drift (Letters, February 6). I note from their addresses, that both men live in Lib Dem/Tory marginal constituencies, as I do (Westmorland & Lonsdale). This is indeed good fortune, because they can now vote for a radical party with principles (the Lib Dems in case you were wondering) and ensure the defeat of a Tory at the same time.
Tim Farron
Milnthorpe, Cumbria
t.farron@lancaster.ac.uk

fields.headline: £25 a week, or 60 grand
fields.trailText: Barbara Roche (Letters, February 6) promises to follow up one abuse of the voucher system: full marks for her attention to detail.
fields.body:
Barbara Roche (Letters, February 6) promises to follow up one abuse of the voucher system: full marks for her attention to detail. But the real issue is not the availability of mascara to asylum seekers but whether the Home Office voucher system should be abolished in favour of a fairer and more humane financial support for new arrivals. Expecting anyone to exist on £25 per week is asking too much of them and too little of us.
Canon David Partridge
Emsworth, Hants

Re your back page headline (United looking to brand Beckham, February 6), wouldn't electronic tagging be kinder to the boy wonder?
Neil Young
Kidlington, Oxon

So "David Beckham could shortly become the first footballer to be paid more for his image than his performance"? At 60 grand a week (or whatever he is on this week), I thought he already was!
Damian Robinson
London

webTitle: Letters: Don't feed telecom fat cats

fields.headline: Don't feed telecom fat cats
fields.trailText: A few months ago, the Guardian congratulated me for helping to design the British telecom auction that netted £22.47bn for the taxpayer. Now it identifies me as the villain responsible for the downfall of the telecom industry (Auction turns into French farce, February 3).
fields.body:
A few months ago, the Guardian congratulated me for helping to design the British telecom auction that netted £22.47bn for the taxpayer. Now it identifies me as the villain responsible for the downfall of the telecom industry (Auction turns into French farce, February 3). This u-turn is inspired by a fiasco in France in which only two operators proved willing to pay the £3.2bn demanded for the four licences on sale.

Neither the praise nor the blame is appropriate. The pioneers in designing auctions for telecom licences were American, and the auctioning of telecom licences continues in America without any fuss. An American auction held just before the French fiasco raised amounts comparable to our British auction without arousing cries of doom. As for the French fiasco, this was not an auction at all, but an old-fashioned beauty contest. Since I warned the French regulator what would happen if he pursued his plan, it is hard to be blamed for its failure.

In spite of the current hysteria, nobody knows whether the winners of the British telecom auction paid too much for their licences. Market sentiment sways this way and that, but it would be a great pity if the fat cats in the telecom industry were able to use the current downswing to discredit the auctioning of licences in favour of the old beauty contest regime.
Ken Binmore
University College, London
uctpa97@ucl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Insider's view of prison
fields.trailText: I commend Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, for his frank and, in my experience, accurate criticism of our prisons (Jail chief threatens to resign, February 6).
fields.body:
I commend Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, for his frank and, in my experience, accurate criticism of our prisons (Jail chief threatens to resign, February 6).

I spent seven months in prison last year and know the degrading and damaging impact of doing time in this country. Rather than being a danger to society, most of my fellow inmates were victims who had been failed by life time and again. Punishment and rehabilitation in the community would be far more appropriate and effective, providing the right resources were available, particularly drug rehab, housing, mental health and therapeutic provision. We have people who know how to do this work. Why don't we use them?

webTitle: Aeroflot drags smoking waiver from US

fields.headline: Aeroflot drags smoking waiver from US
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Passengers desperate for a cigarette during the 10-hour flight between Moscow and New York are savouring a rare victory over American officials who have been forced to exempt the Russian airline Aeroflot from their comprehensive ban.
fields.body:
Passengers desperate for a cigarette during the 10-hour flight between Moscow and New York are savouring a rare victory over American officials who have been forced to exempt the Russian airline Aeroflot from their comprehensive ban.

Rather than face a challenge by the Russians in the US courts, the US transport department has given Aeroflot a waiver on the White House ban.

The ban, issued in June, prohibits smoking on all international airlines operating to and from the US.

Aeroflot's current policy is to allow smoking on international flights lasting longer than three hours.

The waiver ends a six-month tussle between the Americans and the Russians.

Moscow warned that they would take court action against the White House, complained to international air regulators, and threatened to make US airlines flying to Russia carry Russian-speaking staff.

Aeroflot, which proclaimed smoking a sovereign and fundamental right under a UN charter, believes the decision provides it with a tobacco-friendly market niche.

Boris Yeliseyev, its senior lawyer, denounced the White House ban as interference in the affairs of other nations and a breach of article two of the UN charter on the sovereignty of UN member states.

The Americans, Aeroflot complained, were seeking to extend the writ of their laws to foreign legal subjects beyond US territory.

Aeroflot threatened to go to court in the US and also took its complaint to the International Air Transport Association, which gave its backing in October.

Aeroflot also warned that it would lobby to have Moscow oblige foreign airlines plying Russian routes to have Russian-speaking staff on board.

"It was legal ping-pong," Mr Yeliseyev told the business newspaper Vedomosti.

webTitle: 18 soldiers face dismissal after drugs tests

fields.headline: 18 soldiers face dismissal after drugs tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: In one the army's biggest ever actions against drugs, 18 soldiers from the 1st Battalion the King's Regiment face dismissal from the service after testing positive for cocaine and cannabis, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
In one the army's biggest ever actions against drugs, 18 soldiers from the 1st Battalion the King's Regiment face dismissal from the service after testing positive for cocaine and cannabis, it emerged yesterday.

The men, based at Weeton, Lancashire, were found to have traces of the drugs in their urine after the army tested 300 servicemen in the barracks in December.

The latest embarrassment to the army, following the dismissal of 15 members of the Light Dragoons for ecstasy and cannabis use last month, highlights the rise in the number of soldiers caught taking drugs.

Since random testing was introduced by the army in 1995, more than 2,300 soldiers have been dismissed from the service.

The latest figures available, for the first 10 months of last year, show drug taking to be on the rise, with 580 soldiers failing tests, compared with 485 for the whole of 1999.

The soldiers at Weeton who tested positive are mainly kingsmen - the regiment's equivalent to a private - plus a small number of lance-corporals.

Last year a total of 12 soldiers were thrown out of the battalion, which has served in Northern Ireland and boasts the Queen Mother as its colonel in chief, for drug taking.

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said: "There were 18 members of the battalion found to have provided positive samples in an army drugs test. Drug misuse is unacceptable and the normal course of action is that anyone found taking drugs will be removed from the army."

Although the army is seriously undermanned, with a shortage of just under 7,000 soldiers, it maintains a zero tolerance policy towards drug taking.

"These people are flying planes, driving tanks and handling live ammunition and we just cannot afford to have them in the army," the spokesman said.

However, he said that compared with society as a whole the army's record on drugs was good.

"When you consider we have carried out more than 390,000 drug tests - enough to test every soldier in the army four times over - only 0.58% have tested positive.

"In other workplaces the figure is likely to be nearer 7%."

webTitle: Leader: Prison reform starts with Jack Straw

fields.headline: Improving the hell holes
fields.standfirst: Prison reform starts with Jack Straw
fields.trailText: No prison director in living memory has been as blunt. In language even harsher than penal reformers use, Martin Narey condemned his own service for "a litany of failure and moral neglect" in a remarkably bold address to its annual conference this week.
fields.body:
No prison director in living memory has been as blunt. In language even harsher than penal reformers use, Martin Narey condemned his own service for "a litany of failure and moral neglect" in a remarkably bold address to its annual conference this week. He described some of the 136 prisons under his command as "hell holes", where inmates were denied dignity and treated as "a sub species". He went on: "I am not prepared to continue to apologise for failing prison after failing prison. I've had enough of trying to explain the very immorality of our treatment of some prisoners and the degradation of some establishments."

If there was any doubt within the institutions that their director was committed to change, there could be no doubt by the end. He openly declared that unless he won the support of managers and staff, he would seek "an easier way of earning a living". He explained: "The only reason, the only justification for my doing this job, the only thing that can make it remotely worthwhile, is a passionate belief that the apologies and the abject explanations will no longer be necessary."

Some progress - even in hell holes - has been made. The director rightly pointed out that lack of cash and excessive overcrowding have been used in the past to excuse the inexcusable. There is no excuse for filthy unclean prisons or refusing to treat inmates with respect. Neither costs much money. As last week's G2 prison series documented, private prisons helped shame the public into introducing more respect for inmates.

Yesterday, the director's indictment received the endorsement of Jack Straw, opening a rare opportunity for radical reform. The home secretary was unequivocal: "I entirely agree with him." Mr Straw went on to spell out what was needed to make such closed institutions more accountable: substantial external pressure to raise standards; tough inspection; and a good director general.

So the ball is now in the home secretary's court. There is one way he could reassure penal reformers that "substantial external pressure" and "tough inspection" will continue: the reappointment, as the chief inspector for prisons, of Sir David Ramsbotham. Mr Straw rightly paid tribute to the "excellent work" of Sir David yesterday. He has been unremitting in his pressure for reform and deservedly earned a reputation as an inspiring leader of the team of prison inspectors. He has also established a good working relationship with the director general, so what more effective duo could there be pressing for change? Yet, true to an unworthy Whitehall tradition, Sir David has been denied a second term. Senior mandarins - and seemingly ministers - still regard the robust independence, which the chief inspector has demonstrated, as a threat, rather than a trait that should be encouraged. This is their weakness, not his. Mr Straw should invite Sir David to accept a second term.

There were two important issues which Mr Narey ignored. The first was last week's call from the lord chief justice - supported by the chief inspector - for fewer people to be sent to prison. This could be excused on the grounds that it is "too political" in the run-up to an election. But the second falls directly within his remit: prison governors' complaints about an oppressive climate and the role of his deputy, Phil Wheatley. A government which is intent on eliminating bullying in schools, should be equally ruthless in eliminating it from the ranks of its administration. It is not just inmates who need respect; prison governors too require it.

fields.headline: Browning still beats Eminem
fields.trailText: I sincerely hope that Giles Foden is practising the irony that he praises Eminem so lavishly for (Just how good is he?, G2, February 5).
fields.body:
I sincerely hope that Giles Foden is practising the irony that he praises Eminem so lavishly for (Just how good is he?, G2, February 5). Apart from the absolute joke that is his comparison of the rapper with Robert Browning, I wouldn't have expected to see the sub-heading "Never mind the misogyny and homophobia" in the Telegraph, never mind the Guardian. Eminem and everything he stands for, ironic or not, is offensive. Full stop. Which doesn't in itself make bad art, but it does preclude pretentious articles from otherwise respected writers and broadsheets. Please don't do it again.
Jessica Meacham
Bristol

Though I suspect many of your readers may have been rendered apoplectic with rage by Giles Foden's article, I had to fight the urge to cheer when reading it. Eminem's critics would hardly attack Mick Jagger for endorsing Satanism (Sympathy For the Devil), or the veneration of murderers (Midnight Rambler), yet the right to freely adopt similar literary conceits is rarely, if ever, extended to performers operating in as aggressively "black" an idiom as hip-hop. Things will certainly be more interesting when next I find myself in a pub argument defending a rapper such as Eminem's use of the third person.
Paul McGee
London

Shortly after reading Giles Foden's rambling paean to Eminem's poetic skills, I witnessed a man in a shop abusing the female assistant in language which owed much to Eminem's art. Part of the point of criticism is to call artists to account for the social consequences of their work.

Poetic or not, Eminem's lyrics legitimise the growth in violence against women and gays. In failing to call Eminem to account, Foden's piece is not criticism at all; merely parasitic gush.
Neil Schofield
Brighton
schofield_neil@hotmail.com

The interesting question is not how good Eminem is but why it is that such angry and violent lyrics speak so loudly to people. Eminem's songs are, among other things, intense cries of pain: it is a world in pain that has so taken him to its heart.
Joe Devas
London

Although the lyrics to the sung section of Stan ("the morning rain clouds up my window") are indeed evocative and poignant, Eminem can't (and doesn't) claim the credit for them. They're sampled from Thank You, written and performed by Dido.
Stuart Nathan
London
snathan@centaur.co.uk

I assume the Guardian will be advertising for a new deputy literary editor once the men in white coats have taken poor Giles Foden into secure accommodation. Comparing the ravings of Eminem with those of poets like Browning and Eliot is preposterous.
Patrick Burke
Ramsgate, Kent
padraigb@dircon.co.uk

Giles Foden may be right or wrong on Eminem being a modern day Robert Browning. However I'll wager his lyrics will generate far more intelligent discussion over the coming years than those of the so-called Popstars who have plagued our television screens over the past weeks.
Steve Little
Lytham St Annes, Lancashire
steve@cliftonco.co.uk

Eminem has an even more eminently respectable antecedent than Robert Browning: Sir Cliff Richard. "Hey Slim, that's my girlfriend screamin' in the trunk" inescapably calls to mind "Gonna lock her up in a trunk, so no big hunk can steal her away from me" from Living Doll - a song which always seemed to me to have dark undertones.
Henry Phillips
Richmond, Surrey
hereishenry@hotmail.com

Rather than Robert Browning, Eminem would appear to have more in common with Elvis: a career based on the wholesale theft of urban black culture, which is then marketed as the radical alternative for a white suburban audience.

And for the record, the correct hip-hop slang is "phat", rather than "fat".
Bruce Barnard
Helston, Cornwall
bruce@phatbeats.freeserve.co.uk

Although it is only February, can I nominate Giles Foden's article as the most preposterous piece of writing we will see this year? It may well go down as the longest piece ever to appear in Private Eye's Pseuds Corner.
Simon Pointon
Southsea, Hants
SPointon@staff.southdowns.ac.uk

Most of the time I bear the tag "Guardian reader" with a degree of pride, but showcasing pretentious material like this gives me involuntary spasms of empathy with the Littlejohn/Bushell interpretation of the phrase. Not, I can assure you, a pleasant sensation.
Neil Stafford
Liverpool
neil9868@hotmail.com

Great article, Giles. Made me laugh, anyway. Sorry they got the date wrong - it was meant for publication on April 1st, wasn't it?
Deborah Bennison
Clifford, West Yorkshire
deb@britishlibrary.net

fields.headline: 6m-year-old forebear unveiled in Paris
fields.trailText: Scientists from France, Britain and Kenya who found what is believed to be the oldest fossilised remains of a hominid, an ancestor of modern man, north of Nairobi last year unveiled their discovery in Paris yesterday.
fields.body:
Scientists from France, Britain and Kenya who found what is believed to be the oldest fossilised remains of a hominid, an ancestor of modern man, north of Nairobi last year unveiled their discovery in Paris yesterday.

They proclaimed their discovery of the 6m-year-old "Millennium Ancestor" the greatest anthropological scoop of modern times.

It could provide a new insight into our prehuman ancestry, they said at the College de France. The creature is the closest link discovered between humans and apes, with a mixture of human and simian characteristics, they said.

Millennium Ancestor, a bi-ped, lived near a lake in dense woodland in the Baringo region of Kenya, about 150 miles from the capital.

He weighed between 40kgs and 60kgs, was about 1.4 metres tall (about the height of a large chimpanzee), and was probably a fruit-eater.

And "he" may have been she.

"Perhaps he was a young male, or maybe female," said the British geologist Dr Martin Pickford, who works at the College de France, and is co leader of the Kenya Paleontology Expedition with Dr Brigitte Senut.

"If we had found 50 or so pieces of his remains, it would be a little easier to say. We can say he was quite young when he died."

Dr Pickford, whose team presented 13 fossilised remains, established the fossil's age by studying the lava surrounding his body.

Millennium Ancestor is 3m years older than Lucy, whose remains, found in Ethiopia in 1974, were previously thought to be the oldest discovered homonid ancestor.

"This discovery opens a new chapter in the story of our human origins," Dr Pickford said. "What's more, he also opens a great debate about those origins."

webTitle: Saltwater camel is a distinct prospect

fields.headline: Saltwater camel is a distinct prospect
fields.trailText: A Sino-British team may have found a new species of camel in the remote salty wastes neighbouring Tibet. If the discovery is confirmed, the species, numbering fewer than 1,000, is more endangered than the iconic giant panda.
fields.byline: James Astill in Nairobi and Tim Radford
fields.body:
A Sino-British team may have found a new species of camel in the remote salty wastes neighbouring Tibet. If the discovery is confirmed, the species, numbering fewer than 1,000, is more endangered than the iconic giant panda.

Biologists held that the wild Bactrian camel, which roams the Gobi desert and the arid wastes of Xinjiang province, was the same species as the domesticated two-humped beast of burden.

But researchers at the UN Environmental Programme (Unep) in Nairobi said yesterday that preliminary genetic tests had confirmed what the Gobi nomads have always said: they are distinct species.

John Hare, founder of the Wild Camel Protection Foundation and leader of the research group, said the genetic sequence of the two camels differed by 3%. The genetic difference between humans and their nearest relative, the chimpanzee, is only 1.6%.

"These wild camels may be a different species never domesticated by humans," said Mr Hare, whose foundation is based in Benenden, Kent.

The wild camels live in the dunes of the Kum Tagh (sand mountain) region of Xinjiang - used for nuclear weapons tests and off limits to people since 1955 - and have adapted to the salty water bubbling up from beneath the sand.

"These camels can withstand enormous physiological stress," said Kate Rae, a trustee of the foundation. "Scientists are extremely interested to know how their liver, kidneys and lungs can withstand the salt."

In the past decade research-ers have identified a new ox, a new deer from Vietnam, a rabbit from Laos, and a new species of whale. But such additions are far outweighed by the steady extinction of species, now at the rate of three an hour.

The outlook for the wild camels is also dark. There could be 600 in China, perhaps 300 in Mongolia and perhaps 15 in captivity.

"The remoteness of the area has helped preserve these camels," Mr Hare said. "The fact that people were not allowed in by the Chinese government has also helped them survive.

"But with the cessation of nuclear tests, illegal hunters and miners ... are moving in. We found landmines put by the saltwater springs. So when the camels come to drink ... bang."

Conservationists are working out how to guard the Lop Nur camel reserve, bigger than Poland, which the Chinese government established in the Kum Tagh two years ago.

"These wild camels may be a different species never domesticated by humans," said Mr Hare, whose foundation is based in Benenden, Kent. The wild camels live in the dunes of the Kum Tagh (sand mountain) region of Xinjiang - used for nuclear weapons tests and off limits to people since 1955 - and have adapted to the salty water bubbling up from beneath the sand. "These camels can withstand enormous physiological stress," said Kate Rae, a trustee of the foundation. "Scientists are extremely interested to know how their liver, kidneys and lungs can withstand the salt." In the past decade research-ers have identified a new ox, a new deer from Vietnam, a rabbit from Laos, and a new species of whale. But such additions are far outweighed by the steady extinction of species, now at the rate of three an hour. The outlook for the wild camels is also dark. There could be 600 in China, perhaps 300 in Mongolia and perhaps 15 in captivity. "The remoteness of the area has helped preserve these camels," Mr Hare said. "The fact that people were not allowed in by the Chinese government has also helped them survive. "But with the cessation of nuclear tests, illegal hunters and miners ... are moving in. We found landmines put by the saltwater springs. So when the camels come to drink ... bang." Conservationists are working out how to guard the Lop Nur camel reserve, bigger than Poland, which the Chinese government established in the Kum Tagh two years ago.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Dentist cleared of killing girl, 5
fields.body:
Dentist cleared of killing girl, 5

Dentist Michael Lane and anaesthetist George Vanner were yesterday cleared at Preston crown court of the manslaughter of Karla Selley, five, who died following a tooth extraction at the Towngate dental surgery, in Leyland, near Preston.

50 hurt after chemical spill

More than 50 people were injured yesterday, 15 of them seriously, after titanium tetrachloride leaked from a tanker on an industrial estate in Tamworth, Staffordshire. The chemical releases hazardous hydrogen chloride on contact with the air.

Baroness Denton dies

Baroness Denton of Wakefield, the first woman minister to serve at the Northern Ireland Office, died yesterday aged 65. The Tory peer had been suffering from cancer.

Music royalties dispute settled

Trumpeter Freddie Staff, 72, once a session musician for Tom Jones and Shirley Bassey, yesterday settled with the Musicians' Union a high court dispute over information about the distribution of millions of pounds of royalties.

Woolworths bans girls mag

The high street store Woolworths has banned Mad About Boys, a controversial new magazine aimed at nine- to 12-year-old girls, which child experts say encourages them to dress inappropriately.

750 officers to police cup final

A total of 750 officers will police the Worthington Cup final between Liverpool and Birmingham City at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff on February 25. Some 150 officers are normally used for rugby internationals at the stadium.

Workman dies as mill collapses

A man died and three others were injured yesterday when sections of a mill they were renovating in Halifax collapsed on them. The Health and Safety Executive has launched an inquiry.

New cover for air passengers

Air passengers who develop deep vein thrombosis will be able to sue airlines under a new policy being offered by the insurance company Club Direct. Some estimates suggest the condition kills up to 2,000 Britons a year.

Store ordered to drop slogan

The electrical goods retailer Currys was yesterday banned from using its "unbeatable low prices" slogan in newspaper adverts by the Advertising Standards Authority, which found that it was often more expensive than its rival Comet.

webTitle: Phone threats terrifying, says Billie Piper tells court

fields.headline: Phone threats terrifying, says Billie Piper tells court
fields.trailText: Before Billie Piper walked into court yesterday to confront the woman accused of stalking her, her mother Mandy had reminded the jury: "We are talking about my daughter - not Billie the pop star."
fields.body:
Before Billie Piper walked into court yesterday to confront the woman accused of stalking her, her mother Mandy had reminded the jury: "We are talking about my daughter - not Billie the pop star."

To hear taped messages threatening to decapitate her child was "horrible," she told Blackfriars crown court in central London, as Juliet Peters, 32, accused of making the threatening late-night calls, sat a few feet away in the dock.

But the mother's words were swiftly forgotten as her daughter made her entrance. Reporters made fashion notes - she wore a bottle green trouser suit, with Nike trainers - while defence counsel Tom MacKinnon lauded her as "perhaps the English equivalent of Britney Spears".

Miss Piper, 18, told the jury she was left terrified and tearful when police played her the taped messages, left on her record company's answering machine.

"They were just awful, the worst thing I have ever had to listen to," she said. "I was scared about the effect it was going to have on my parents. I couldn't understand why anybody would want to say those things."

Peters allegedly began stalking Miss Piper after appearing in the audience on an episode of Channel Five's Pepsi Chart Show. She complained that the singer gave her a "sly, dirty look" in the lead-up to a commercial break.

The singer agreed when defence counsel asked her whether such "unwanted attention" had dogged her throughout her career.

She had received letters critical of her appearance, personality and lifestyle, sent by girls fixated on her then boyfriend Ritchie Neville, a singer with the boyband 5ive.

Mark Aldred, for the crown, asked how some of the letters compared with some of the telephoned death threats allegedly made by Miss Peters.

She replied that she had dismissed the letters "because the guy I was going out with at the time was a heart-throb, and had a lot of fans who were jealous or didn't like me".

Peters denies making five threats to kill the singer between August 14 and 25 last year, and four similar charges concerning the pop star's parents, Paul Piper and Mandy Kent. The trial continues.

webTitle: 'Nip' from tiger puts trainer in hospital

fields.headline: 'Nip' from tiger puts trainer in hospital
fields.trailText: The man who trained the Esso advertising tigers was dragged clear of a startled tigress yesterday after he tripped over during a play session and the animal swiped at him.
fields.body:
The man who trained the Esso advertising tigers was dragged clear of a startled tigress yesterday after he tripped over during a play session and the animal swiped at him.

Martin Lacey, 54, was taken to hospital with scratches and bites after the incident at Kasanga Manor, known locally as "Lincolnshire's little Africa", where he was exercising three of the 550lb adult animals in a cage.

Safety staff at the farm scared off the three-year-old tigress while the other two tigers backed away.

A friend of Mr Lacey, David Freeman, said that the trainer had been playing with the tigers and feeding them, when he fell over the tigress. "She instinctively turned round and nipped him on the leg, knee and then the shoulder," he said.

"We always have people there to help and they shouted and managed to scare all three tigers away."

Mr Lacey was in a satisfactory condition last night at the Pilgrim hospital, Boston.

He has trained wild animals for over 30 years, and brought the tigers to Kasanga, at Keal Cotes, near Spilsby, two years ago.

He was described by friends as highly experienced with tigers, which he has trained for circuses as well as the "Put a tiger in your tank" Esso campaign.

Lincolnshire police said the incident had been referred to the local East Lindsey district council. A council spokesman said checks would be made.

fields.headline: Eminem scoops NME's rap award
fields.trailText: Eminem, the rapper whose forthcoming UK tour has caused protests about homophobic and sexist lyrics, has won a key award at the alternative to the Brit Awards.
fields.body:
Eminem, the rapper whose forthcoming UK tour has caused protests about homophobic and sexist lyrics, has won a key award at the alternative to the Brit Awards.

The US singer, whose songs tell listeners to bludgeon women and "faggots" to death and "take drugs, rape sluts, make fun of gay clubs", won best hip-hop and rap act at the NME Carling Awards last night.

The awards, formerly known as the Brats, are voted by readers of NME magazine and are described as "a credible, anti-industry alternative" to the Brits, which are announced later this month and chosen by industry insiders.

Winning NME artists received a gong featuring a hand sticking its middle finger up. "We are giving the finger to the record industry," an NME spokesman said. But Eminem, a fan of the hand gesture, was absent from the NME awards in favour of attending the Brits on February 26.

The singer Robbie Williams beat Eminem and Big Brother's "Nasty" Nick Bateman to the "villain of the year" award. NME hero of the year was Oasis singer Liam Gallagher. The "godlike genius" award for lifetime achievement went to the Irish band U2.

Radiohead was named best band; All Saints won best pop act, despite speculation about a split; and Manchester singer Badly Drawn Boy was voted best solo artist.

The band Coldplay won the greatest number of awards, including best single, best new artist and Radio One session of the year.

NME editor Ben Knowles said: "This is an awards ceremony that means something to the bands, because it is not voted for by a committee."

webTitle: Stone wins appeal as case collapses

fields.headline: Stone wins appeal as case collapses
fields.trailText: Michael Stone, the man found guilty in 1998 of the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan, and the attempted murder of her other daughter Josie, could walk free from London's court of appeal tomorrow after winning his appeal against conviction.
fields.body:
Michael Stone, the man found guilty in 1998 of the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan, and the attempted murder of her other daughter Josie, could walk free from London's court of appeal tomorrow after winning his appeal against conviction.

After the crown case collapsed yesterday morning, three judges said they were minded to grant Stone's appeal and will meet again tomorrow to consider whether there should be a retrial or if Stone should be freed. They did not quash his conviction but are likely to do so tomorrow.

The crown admitted at the last minute that a crucial witnesses at Stone's original trial in 1998, Barry Thompson, had lied and could no longer be relied upon as a "a witness of truth".

It accepted that the crown would not have called Thompson as a witness if it had known he was lying.

Puzzled but looking pleased with the court's decision, Stone smiled at his family before being taken down from the dock. His sister Barbara, who campaigned against the original verdict, calling it a miscarriage of justice, thrust her arms in the air.

Outside the court she said: "I have always known Mick's innocent. He has always maintained his innocence. I have hoped the courts would recognise that and now he has the opportunity to prove it."

Stone's solicitor, Derek Hayward, said: "I am pleased so far, very pleased."

Thompson was one of three witnesses who claimed to have heard Stone confess in some way to the killings while he was in prison on remand. The day after Stone's convictions he told a newspaper reporter that he had lied in the witness box.

His evidence had provided crucial support for Damien Daley, a key witness in the trial who also claimed Stone confessed to him. During the trial, William Clegg QC, representing Stone, claimed that his client had been "fitted up by a bunch of criminals".

Stone was given three life sentences for the murders of Lin Russell and Megan, six, and the attempted murder of Josie, then nine, near their home at Chillenden, Kent, in 1996. They were tied up and beaten with a hammer in a ferocious 15-minute attack.

As Stone heard the original guilty verdicts he said: "I didn't do it your honour."

Yesterday, Mr Clegg told the judges: "There was no forensic evidence whatsoever linking him to the crime. Throughout extensive interviews with police he had consistently denied the offence. There was no identification evidence linking him to the scene. At best the evidence disclosed a knowledge of the area obtained while he stayed in a children's home not very far away in east Kent, a broad consistency with someone seen driving nearby and a failure to provide an alibi."

He told the court that Thompson had provided crucial support for Daley but that Thompson's account was now "wholly unreliable".

He said that during the trial all had "accepted the frailties of the crown case" and added: "The first ground of appeal is and always has been that Thompson has become completely discredited as a witness as he has now conceded and therefore the jury must have been quite inadvertently misled at trial into relying upon his evidence to provide support for that given by Daley."

Mr Clegg did not give the other grounds for appeal because Lord Justice Kennedy, Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Heather Hallet decided to cut short proceedings because they concluded that the appeal "must succeed" on the first ground alone.

Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, had submitted a three-point admission on Thompson and his evidence, which said the the crown could not "argue against the proposition that the jury's decision as regards Daley's evidence may have been influenced by their assessment of Thompson's".

Last night, a lawyer for Shaun Russell and his daugh ter Josie - who have rebuilt their lives in north Wales - said the family felt it "would be highly inappropriate to make any comment".

The court will reconvene tomorrow morning when Mr Clegg will argue that Stone should be freed and not made to face a retrial. He will claim that because of the enormous media interest in the case, his client will never receive a fair trial. The crown will demand a retrial.

webTitle: Mystery man testifies in Bin Laden trial

fields.headline: Mystery man testifies in Bin Laden trial
fields.trailText: A secret witness testified yesterday about his dealings with Osama bin Laden, the fugitive Saudi Arabian millionaire and terrorist who is said to have organised the four men who are now on trial for bombing two American embassies.
fields.body:
A secret witness testified yesterday about his dealings with Osama bin Laden, the fugitive Saudi Arabian millionaire and terrorist who is said to have organised the four men who are now on trial for bombing two American embassies.

The 1998 bombings in Kenya and Tanzania killed 224 people. Most were not Americans but local people.

Jamal Ahmed Alfadl, 37, known until yesterday only as CS-1, appeared in the old federal courthouse in Manhattan with a light beard, wearing a loose white T-shirt under a striped top over blue denims. The judge ordered artists drawing sketches of the court scene not to draw the Sudanese witness.

Speaking in barely decipherable English including many Arabic words, he had to halt frequently for an interpreter to explain what was said.

Mr Alfadl said that he had come to the United States in 1986, where he worked in a grocery store and raised money for the war in Afghanistan against the former Soviet Union.

He later made his way to Pakistan and then Afghanistan, where there was a meeting on countries' border.

"Somebody came and we talked about jihad, what we had to do," he testified. "Jihad means when the enemy comes to Muslim country and they can't push the enemy back, they ask for other brothers to help push the enemy out."

This somebody, Mr Alfadl said, was Abu Hajer al-Iraqi, a pseudonum for Osama Bin Laden. After prayers and discussion about the Russians "he make much about jihad".

Mr Alfadl says that he worked for Bin Laden until five years ago, when he was caught stealing money from the organisation and went on the run. He decided to cooperate with the Americans to save his family.

His evidence forms much of the indictment against the four men on trial. Two, charged with direct involvement in the bombings, face the death penalty; the other two, accused of being part of a wider conspiracy to kill Americans, could be jailed for life.

Mr Alfadl talked about a life moving from country to country through the Middle East and Asia, from guest house to hotel and from training camp to the front line in Afghanistan.

"When the Russians decided to leave Afghanistan, Bin Laden decide to make a group," he said. This "group" became the organisation known as al-Qaeda, which Bin Laden ran and which Mr Alfadl joined formally in 1989 or 1990, by taking an oath. "You swear to do whatever they ask you," he said.

Al-Qaeda was said to have a series of committees that dealt with areas including military affairs, money and business, Islamic studies, and the media. This last committee included a member who tagged Reuters on to the end of his name because of his skill in disseminating information.

Bin Laden decided to move al-Qaeda to the Sudan. "We didn't have too much business in Pakistan because the Russians had gone," Mr Alfadl told the jury.

webTitle: Children in South London 'worried' by violence

fields.headline: Murder they wrote
fields.standfirst: Pupils in Peckham told police that homicide 'worried them'. A few months later, Damilola Taylor was killed. By  Raekha Prasad
fields.trailText: Pupils in Peckham told police that homicide 'worried them'. A few months later, Damilola Taylor was killed. By Raekha Prasad
fields.body:
Last June, Sir John Stevens, commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, received a letter from three children in Peckham, south London. In neat, joined-up writing, the 10-year-olds expressed what later proved to be tragically prescient concerns. "We are scared that families are going to be split by crime," they wrote. "We would like to have more patrolling and protection from you."

The pupils of Bellenden primary school did not get a reply until after they sent a second letter in December, a month after the local killing of Damilola Taylor, who was also 10. Stevens was, perhaps, unaware that the three were expressing what had emerged as the main collective fear of Bellenden's year five - murder.

As part of a project, funded by Lambeth, Southwark and Lewisham health action zone, the 28 children were asked what concerned them about the community in which they lived. Among the predictable anxieties about dog mess, litter, smoking, drugs, burglary and bills, murder had appeared with unexpected and alarming frequency.

When asked to rank the most mentioned subjects on a scale of one to five, according to how serious and common they were and how much could be done about them, murder was chosen as the single most pressing issue.

It was, however, not the first time that children in the area had come up with such an arresting view. Two months earlier, at a Camberwell after-school project, 20 children aged 9-11 also identified murder as the biggest blight on their community.

"It's shocking to think children of this age are thinking these things," says Sara Gibbs, project worker for the action zone. "It may not be surprising in this area, where you regularly see appeals for witnesses for violent attacks and racial attacks on big yellow boards. But when it happened again, in the same area at the same time, and when you consider that they came up with almost 80 different issues, then I was surprised."

In further work with Gibbs, the Bellenden children discussed what they knew about violent crime and decided to interview the local mayor, shopkeepers and Southwark council's community safety officer to find out more.

A 17-year-old boy, André Drummond, had been murdered in a knife attack outside McDonald's in Camberwell. Gibbs says: "He was young. He was black. That really shocked them. In the school, the kids knew his family. They also mentioned Stephen Lawrence. There have been other murders around here. They're very media savvy - they know what's in the papers and they listen to the news.

"It's not just murder. They were aware of violence. They see a lot of information on police appeal boards about violent stabbings, racial attacks and rapes."

When a similar consultation project - using the same "child-to-child" methodology - was undertaken in Manchester, the youngsters chose dog fouling as their main concern. However, in the US city of Chicago, where sister projects operate, murder is often identified as the most pressing issue. "It's indicative of the area," saysd Gibbs. "It is to do with this inner-city part of London."

Further work showed that some of the south London children believed the incidence of murder to be higher than it actually was. They talked to the police and wrote to Stevens, as well as to a local newspaper; they produced cartoons, poems and raps, which they performed to the public; and they designed posters which were displayed in a local supermarket. The Bellenden children also went to a local secondary school to talk to older pupils about violence.

By the end of the projects, attitudes had changed. Anxiety about violence had eased and the children felt they could address it more easily. "Not all the adults they spoke to were helpful," Gibbs admits. "There was an attitude from some that thinking about murder wasn't a child's place, that this was a serious adult subject. But the children felt proud that they chose something serious. "

So when Gibbs decided to talk again to the children, after Damilola's murder, she was concerned that the positive work might have been undone. Instead, she found the children resilient. Yes, they were frightened and worried about going out - but they did not want Peckham's reputation sullied. "I don't like what people have said about this because people are going to think that London isn't a good place to live," said one child.

Touchingly, the youngsters described strategies they used to feel safer on the street. One said that if you felt you were being followed, you should look around for someone who "could be your mother" and bend down next to her, pretending to tie your shoelace.

"It was heavy stuff and I really didn't expect that, on coming back to London, children here would chose murder as their biggest concern," she says.

The child-to-child approach, adopted so far in 70 countries, was developed in 1979 by the Institute of Child Health in London. It was designed to be used in Africa, Asia and Latin America as a means of involving children in disease preven tion. In the west, it is intended to promote self-esteem and utilise children's abilities to communicate health messages to their peers.

The technique used in south London should be used throughout Britain, according to the Forum on Children and Violence, which campaigns for a less violent society for children and young people. The forum was founded in 1997 following a report by the Gulbenkian Foundation which was prompted by the 1993 murder of James Bulger.

Will McMahon, the forum's national coordinator, says there is an urgent need to collect evidence about children's experience of violence - particularly as the British Crime Survey only asks people over 16 whether they have experienced violence or intimidation. The forum is holding workshops with children to collate their views about violence and record their strategies for reducing it. "Children are very perceptive about what's going on around them and it's important they participate in solutions to feel safe," McMahon says. "Adults have to listen harder."

Capital offences

Children are much less likely to be murdered than adults, according to Home Office figures. There were 95 homicide victims aged 15 and under in 1998-99, compared to 232 victims aged 30-50. The majority of victims are acquainted with their attackers, the most common relationship being spouse or partner.

There were 159 homicides in London in 1998-99, according to the Metropolitan police.Southwark, of which Peckham and Camberwell are part, had the most murders of any borough, with 14 homicides during that time. Southwark had the second highest rate of violent crime in the capital, with 7,479 offences in the 1999 calendar year.

webTitle: Britain's first attempt to assess the quality and impact of urban design

fields.headline: Space probe
fields.standfirst: Alison Benjamin on Britain's first attempt to assess the quality and impact of urban design
fields.trailText: Alison Benjamin on Britain's first attempt to assess the quality and impact of urban design
fields.body:
Is it possible to quantify the benefits of good building design? A new official report makes a first stab at doing just that, assessing the economic, social and environmental value of recent development schemes in three big cities.

The report, released yesterday, is part of a government drive to improve the quality of urban design. It heaps praise on what it concludes is good and spares few feelings in damning what it sees as bad.

Office block developments accessible only by car, making no attempt to fit in with the surrounding environment or adding anything to the local community, are singled out as examples of poor design. Standard Court, in Nottingham, is branded "a disconnected place that does not welcome people in and offers them little once they are there".

By contrast, developments that are inviting, make an effort to blend with surroundings and offer a range of uses score highly on the report's system. Barbirolli Square, in Manchester, is described as "a gently animated public space with its own distinct character and sense of place and with a good quality of enclosure".

The report, The Value of Urban Design, was drawn up by researchers on behalf of the commission for architecture and the built environment (Cabe), the new government agency set up to boost building design, and the Department of the Environment. The study was launched at a conference, in London, held to build on Cabe's Better Public Buildings report, launched last October by Tony Blair.

The conference highlighted the role of central and local government in delivering good urban design beyond the regulatory planning process. Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, told delegates that quality design did not necessarily cost more to deliver, but offered strong competitive advantages.

The new report suggests that good rental returns and enhanced capital values go hand-in-hand with well-designed schemes. It calls on investors and developers to take on board the commercial evidence and on tenants to recognise the increased prestige that high quality, integrated architecture commands with clients - not to say the favourable impact it has on staff loyalty and health. Public authorities also benefit, it says, when run-down areas and amenities are returned to public use and urban centres are revitalised.

Researchers, from the Bartlett school of planning at University College London, compared pairs of predominantly commercial developments built at roughly the same time and chosen for their similarity in all respects except urban design. These were: Standard Court and Castle Wharf in Nottingham; Barbirolli Square and Exchange Quay in Greater Manchester; Brindleyplace in Birmingham and the Waterfront business park in nearby Dudley. Each development was gauged against a range of quantitative and qualitative measures such as rental returns, energy consumption, traffic generation and assessed vibrancy.

Exchange Quay, a Dallas-style development on the banks of the Manchester Ship Canal in Salford, is described as "a bland, faceless development with bland, faceless buildings and spaces" which makes little attempt to connect itself to its hinterland. "Very heavy security guard presence confirms this is predominately a private, rather than public, place," says the report.

Whereas Exchange Quay turns it back on its waterfront, Nottingham's Castle Wharf and Birmingham's Brindleyplace both scored highly for openly embracing their canal settings, locating pubs and restaurants to maximum effect.

However, according to Esterre Property Management, which manages Exchange Quay, the very features on which it is marked down are its selling points. Darren Tyson, estates supervisor, says: "There is only one fence. It is 7ft [2.1m] high, but there aren't any spikes. There is an estate right next door. I'm not saying everyone on it is rough, but you only have to speak to the police to know we have a need for security and our tenants [mainly insurance companies] demand it. They are paying for security, maintenance and landscaping."

The Manchester branch of Masons law firm moved out of Exchange Quay just over three years ago - to Barbirolli Square. Comprising two office blocks on one side of the square, with the Bridgewater concert hall on the other, the development is praised by the report. "The clever use of levels allows the central space to step down to a re-established canal basin on to which a new cafe opens up," it says.

Edward Davies, a partner at Masons, cites expansion as the reason for the move to Barbirolli and says most clients would have preferred the firm to stay put. "Exchange Quay was conveniently located just off the motorway, had surface parking and good security, and the Copthorne hotel was across the road for lunch. They thought it was wonderful."

While Exchange Quay offers investors returns of just 1% to 3%, Barbirolli commands the highest rents in Manchester and the office project is now valued at £60m, compared to its £27.5m cost. Such financial facts back up Cabe's argument that better design adds economic value. "Good urban design definitely pays back," says Jon Rouse, Cabe's chief executive.

Many have yet to be convinced. John Gilder, property director of the Mill Group, which developed part of Nottingham's Standard Court, insists he is content with his scheme's performance, despite the report's critical appraisal. Particularly scathing comment is passed by the researchers on the development's hardly used public arena. Gilder admits that the only people making use of the arena are skateboarders - and they are doing so illegally - and he concedes that Standard Court lacks the warmth, closeness and pleasant environment that make nearby Castle Wharf a "destination location".

Such shortcomings are said to illustrate the crucial role that local authority planning departments have to play in urban design and delivery of economic, social and environmental benefits. Departments can and should be proactive, says the report, and should positively set the design agenda through clear development plan policies, making funding conditional on good design and using the leverage offered by ownership of brownfield sites.

Significantly, two of the report's three lower-scoring developments had minimal local authority input, having come under the remit of either development corporations or enterprise zones. Cabe intends to work to ensure that the private/public urban regeneration companies proposed in the urban white paper learn from such mistakes.

The Value of Design is available at £25 from Thomas Telford on 020-7665 2464.
