fields.headline: Capital ideas
fields.standfirst: London unveils social exclusion plan
fields.trailText: London unveils social exclusion plan
fields.body:
A new approach to ensuring that economic and social regeneration go hand-in-hand will today be highlighted at a conference to mark the end of public consultation on an economic development strategy for London.

The strategy, being devised by the business-led London Development Agency (LDA), will form part of mayor Ken Livingstone's master plan for the future of the capital. It identifies nine key objectives, including helping disadvantaged people into work and prioritising knowledge and learning.

Michael Ward, LDA chief executive, says the strategy will represent a "third generation" in regional policy where a bottom-up, rather than a trickle-down, theory will be put into practice.

"This approach is very different from physical regeneration and hard-hat projects. What we are talking about is ensuring that the people who live in disadvantaged areas around the City of London have access to the jobs created by that major engine of development.

"Our core job will be social. We don't need to give grants to keep Chase Manhattan in the City, but we need to bring in those people who live cheek by jowl with prosperity, but have been excluded from it."

Ward says the way of achieving such aims is through partnerships with existing bodies, such as learning and skills councils and the small business service, and by funding innovative, community-led projects such as labour market intermediary bodies. These are firmly rooted in the community, he explains, but have links with business which ensure that the training they provide is targeted at what employers need.

Last year, 24 projects to develop Londoners' skills were funded by the LDA from a £6m skills development fund. Half the continuing projects are managed by the voluntary sector, which the agency recognises as a crucial player. Its draft strategy includes development of a London "compact" with the voluntary sector, support for capacity building by voluntary organisations and continued promotion of voluntary-led regeneration.

The London Voluntary Service Council says the draft strategy has some encouragement for the capital's voluntary sector. "There is recognition that an integrated approach, linking economic development and social inclusion initiatives, is essential. Furthermore, the voluntary sector is seen as an increasingly important force in regeneration programmes, being uniquely placed to involve local people."

One of the criticisms levelled at the other eight regional development agencies across England has been their failure to listen to local voices from community groups.

A study commissioned by the Department of the Environment, aiming to identify best practice in the development of regional strategies, is expected to point to a number of other key differences in the London approach.

The other eight may still be seen to be at the "second generation" stage of regional policy - targeting large capital grants and tax incentives to encourage investment. In the LDA's view, they have yet to focus on what chancellor Gordon Brown has termed the "essential building blocks of self-generating growth".

These include measures which tackle gaps in employment, skills knowledge and technology in grass-roots partnerships with local communities.

webTitle: National strategy urged to tackle problem of rural poverty

fields.headline: Breaking the silence
fields.standfirst: National strategy urged to tackle problem of rural poverty
fields.trailText: National strategy urged to tackle problem of rural poverty
fields.body:
Ministers should adopt a national strategy to address rural poverty, a report today argues. Existing measures are said not to have received the same commitment given to tackling urban poverty.

The report, commissioned by the countryside agency and produced by NCH, the children's charity, says families living on a low income in rural areas face different difficulties to their urban counterparts.

Researchers interviewed 138 adults and children aged between eight and 63 in Cornwall, Dorset, County Durham, Northumberland, Hampshire and North Yorkshire. The sample included lone parents, people with disabilities, care leavers and the homeless, and 70% were on benefits.

Annie Mullins, one of the report's authors and senior public policy officer for NCH, says the levels of isolation and exclusion that were discovered prompted the call for a response specifically tailored to the needs of rural people. "These people are silent voices. The government has focused on revitalising the economy and employment in last year's rural white paper. They have looked for the rural dimension within urban social exclusion policies, but we think that very specific strategies that deal with issues such as mental health and lone parents are necessary. The measures in the paper are very over-arching and not detailed or targeted enough for those marginalised in rural areas."

Mullins argues that the government's drive to get more lone parents into employment is attractive to many rural lone parents. "But where do they go for childcare?" she asks. "There are no SureStarts and no affordable childminders."

Margaret Clark, a director at the countryside agency, says that 96% of rural parishes have no public nursery, 50% have no public school and 83% have no GP. "The early work of the social exclusion unit has been in neighbourhood renewal, but in rural areas poverty may affect only a handful of people living in close proximity to people who are much better off. The solutions have to be different."

The report, Challenging the Rural Idyll, says interviewees were concerned about the narrow range of available jobs, often unskilled. They also complained of lack of local shops, with transport costs to supermarkets adding to their weekly expense. The majority did not have a bank account and used cash - the closure of local post offices and banks having hindered their access to money.

Laura, a lone mother of four from east Sussex, said: "It's no good saying it would be so much easier if you had your benefit paid into a bank account. How the hell are we supposed to get to the bank, and you can't get a bank account if you are unemployed anyway."

Rural health services were found to be limited, with many cottage hospitals having closed and several GP practices having been amalgamated with others based in towns. Many had to rely on friends for transport to a doctor.

The researchers found that children and young people in rural areas felt disadvantaged by a lack of further education and training opportunities. Leisure and entertainment facilities were limited and there was a lack of safe play areas, contributing to a high rate of drug and alcohol abuse among teenagers.

Casey, 17, from Cornwall, said: "You haven't got anything else to do. I used to go to the beach every Friday night and drink half a litre of vodka."

Further information from the countryside agency on 01242-52138, or at: www.countryside.gov.uk or www.nch.org.uk

webTitle: Changing the face of the NHS

fields.headline: Two become one
fields.standfirst: John Carvel  on the man charged with changing the face of the NHS
fields.trailText: John Carvel on the man charged with changing the face of the NHS
fields.body:
Nigel Crisp, permanent secretary at the Department of Health, has started, without fanfare, on a corporate merger that will change the face of the NHS.

It abandons the idea, hatched by the Thatcher government, that the health service should be run at arm's length from ministers by an executive board taking responsibility for all operational matters. That led, in 1991, to the creation of a separate management structure, based in Leeds and known since 1994 as the NHS executive.

After taking over three months ago, in a new job amalgamating NHS chief executive and health department permanent secretary, Crisp began to dismantle this never entirely convincing arrangement. "I am managing a merger," he says. "It's a merger of all the elements of the department. We have to carry out the same functions, but in a different way."

On his first day in office, he spent almost £500,000 reorganising the department's social care regions to make them correspond with the eight NHS regions. A single senior management board, including health and social services chiefs, has replaced the NHS executive board and parallel departmental bodies. Crisp emails a standard monthly newsletter to chief executives in the NHS and local government and they communicate on a common, private website.

This amalgamation at the top mirrors the plan for much closer integration of health and social services at grassroots level. As the permanent secretary puts it: "We can't operate centrally in silos and expect them to work in a fused way locally."

The health service still carries the NHS executive logo, but that organisation "has to some extent disappeared", Crisp says. It is too soon to say whether the reform will be taken to its logical conclusion. "You are asking a question we are about to address . . . We will be looking, over the next two months, at how well the department is organised to deliver the NHS plan and the changes in social care. At that point we may end up making further organisational changes."

Does this mean the health service has been centralised, with operational power reverting to ministers and their senior officials? And how does this square with the frequent protestation of Alan Milburn, health secretary, that the NHS cannot be run as a monolithic nationalised industry?

Crisp insists the NHS was never a single entity. While it is commonly described as the biggest employer in Europe, it is really a group of linked employers, including 400 trusts, 100 health authorities and thousands of self-employed GPs.

"We should ask what it would be like if we behaved as if we were one organisation. What would be the advantages if we were one NHS?

"Some of the ingredients are already in place. The NHS plan provided a corporate vision and there are now national standards for cancer and other key areas of clinical care."

The "one NHS" management strategy would ask what other important decisions should be taken nationally and then devolve everything else. "We are talking about local creativity within national standards," Crisp says, citing the promised "earned autonomy" for greater investment to meet local priorities.

This promise of devolution may still ring hollow to NHS managers at trust level, who complain of a constant flow of edicts from national and regional controllers. But Crisp says they will soon come to appreciate the extra autonomy being offered.

That does not mean there will be no more cracking of the whip when things go wrong. Last month, the chief executive of the Bedford hospitals trust resigned within hours of Crisp ordering an inquiry into newspaper pictures of bodies stored in an inappropriate overflow mortuary. He says he would not hesitate to intervene on a matter of public concern, even if no rules had been broken.

There will always be a tension between national standards and local flexibility, Crisp acknowledges. But he says: "If we were having this conversation in a year's time, people would be saying they have more discretion and I would be saying national standards are better established and we are more prepared to let go."

webTitle: A new human rights guide for those with learning disabilities

fields.headline: Free thinking
fields.standfirst: A new 'easy guide' to human rights could give more power to people with learning disabilities, says Matthew Brown
fields.trailText: A new 'easy guide' to human rights could give more power to people with learning disabilities, says Matthew Brown.
fields.body:
Like most couples, Kevin Mason and Joanne Proctor value their privacy. They live in the same house, so you might think that finding intimate time together would be relatively easy. For two fully grown adults, it should be.

But the house which Mason and Proctor (not their real names) live in is a group home for people with learning disabilities; and when Mason asks if he can have private time with his girlfriend in his bedroom, the staff refuse. Not surprisingly, 32-year-old Mason is far from happy. "We just want to be together, but we're not allowed. We have to kiss outside."

It may not seem like a violation of human rights to most people, but according to Andrew Lee, director of People First, a self-advocacy group for people with learning disabilities, that's exactly what it is.

"It's about power and control," says Lee. "People with learning disabilities are often in very vulnerable positions and their rights are easily abused." Often such "abuse" is not malicious: it just arises out of broad assumptions among social services, carers, even parents, about the ability of people like Mason and Proctor to make decisions for themselves.

John Harris, director of the British Institute of Learning Disabilities (Bild), believes such rights violations are "endemic". He says: "Anywhere you care to point your finger there's a rights issue - in education, employment, housing, transport, relationships and, especially, healthcare."

Lee cites a national survey by charity Mencap which found that 98% of people with learning disabilities were discriminated against on a daily basis by one or more people. He says he's heard a string of stories similar to Mason's and Proctor's.

Take the couple who have been partners for 20 years, but are told by support staff that they cannot stay together for longer than a weekend at a time. Then there's the People First member, a man in his 50s, who was told he could not go to a fundraising meeting because he had to make his bed. And there is the man left waiting outside the care home where he lives because he isn't allowed a key.

Harris believes the Human Rights Act, which came into force in October last year, could give people with learning disabilities a basis to act against such treatment. Tomorrow, at a conference in London, Bild is launching an "easy guide" to the legislation, written for people with learning disabilities, as well as carers, support workers and service deliverers.

"The key motive is to raise awareness of the act among people with learning disabilities," says the guide's co-author, Phil Coombs. "That means explaining the act in a simple and accessible way. So much information you see is poorly presented."

Coombs is manager of a community business called Working with Words, set up in 1997 by learning disability groups in Greenwich, south London, to produce information in a form and language appropriate to them. Although it is part-funded by Greenwich social services, the project takes orders from outside organisations and charges for its work. The business also turns out accessible versions of local authority documents and college handbooks, using graphics and websites designed by those who have learning disabilities.

Working with Words devised and produced the human rights guide, and an accompanying poster, in response to a request from people with learning disabilities who had met to talk about the act and, not surprisingly, found it difficult to understand.

"The Human Rights Act is an important piece of legislation," says Coombs. "It's very applicable to people with learning disabilities, but it won't help them unless they know what it means."

The poster uses simple ideas of "rights" and "wrongs" to spell out the freedoms protected by the act, while the guide includes personal experiences of abuse as described by people with learning disabilities. Coombs thinks such experiences will be recognised by other groups, such as elderly people and those with mental health problems.

Harris has no doubt that it is a much-needed document. "The Human Rights Act is important in that it flags up a whole range of issues," he says. "This gives us an opportunity to illustrate how people with learning disabilities are simply not treated as citizens with similar rights to other people."

"We've been a society that's based on dealing with learning disabilities by excluding people. Now we're starting to see that has to change. Human rights are a great basis to do it."

Harris points out that, for decades, people with learning disabilities have been judged and controlled as a group, whereas human rights thinking demands that the dignity of each individual is respected. For Lee, this is what makes an accessible version of the act so important. "If people know about it, imagine the impact it could have," he says. "We can use it to take action."

The guide has been welcomed in the wider human rights field, too. Francesca Klug, director of the Human Rights Act research unit at King's College, London, which is staging tomorrow's conference, says: "This is exactly the sort of thing that should be happening. The act is only going to create the kind of human rights culture that will change attitudes and practices if people take initiatives themselves in their own groups and settings, and explore what potential it has."

Exactly what protection the act will give through the courts is less clear, however. Caroline Gooding, special adviser on the act to the disability rights commission (DRC), points out that while articles such as the right to privacy and family life, and the right to marry and have a family, seem directly relevant to people with learning disabilities, the legal scope and power of such a complex piece of legislation will only be worked out over time.

"My fear is that judges won't address human rights in a progressive way as far as people with learning disabilities are concerned," Gooding says. "At the moment, there is no enforcement agency, such as a human rights commission, nor is the DRC able to take Human Rights Act cases. What's more, the article on freedom from discrimination does not explicitly mention disability and, anyway, it is only applicable in relation to how the other rights are protected."

According to Michael Gunn, professor of law at Nottingham Trent University, the real importance of the act, and Bild's guide to it, is that it will make people think about and talk about human rights. "The fact that the Human Rights Act is there will encourage debate in itself," Gunn says. "Public authorities have a duty to comply with the act so they will have to think: 'Have we got the balance right between supporting people with learning disabilities and protecting them from abusive control?' It raises the profile of human rights issues."

And in everyday cases, like Mason's and Proctor's, it could be that which counts most.

 The Easy Guide to the Human Rights Act is available at £8 plus 40p p&p from Plymbridge Distributors on 01752-202301.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: A central reason for local control

fields.headline: A central reason for local control
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: It is billed as a victory for Ken Livingstone. But it will also be a victory for local over central control - the proposed transfer of key decisions in London's tube restructuring from Whitehall to the mayor's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley.
fields.body:
It is billed as a victory for Ken Livingstone. But it will also be a victory for local over central control - the proposed transfer of key decisions in London's tube restructuring from Whitehall to the mayor's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley. True, it took the celebrated American boss to negotiate the deal, but the plan involves the most high profile transfer of power from the centre to local level for years.

Are there any signs of this happening elsewhere? A few, on a smaller scale. Yet they point to an emerging mood, which suggests there is growing recognition in Whitehall that "joined up" government is important, but not everything can be done by ad hoc bodies or agencies. Cabinet ministers have been resisting the creation of more action zones.

Look at drugs. Having set up local drug action teams - where power was shared by multiple agencies, among them health, police and local councils - ministers conceded last month that local councils must take the lead in looking after social welfare. The teams are now to be headed by an elected council member with a specific drug "portfolio".

There is a mixed message on urban regeneration. Last month, the prime minister set out plans to tackle the 2,000 worst estates promising to change the government's philosophy and to act now "as a partner, not master" over local communities. New moves to help the 88 local councils with the country's 840 poorest wards will funnel more Whitehall money down to neighbourhood level. But the precise relationship between local councils and the new boards and managers at neighbourhood level that are to be created, is still unclear.

Then there is health, the most centralised system in the land. Local managers have long resented the avalanche of directives coming down from the centre - over 200 a year on everything from ambulances to "zoonoses" (transmissible animal diseases). Now under a new grading system, health bodies assessed as doing well will get "earned autonomy". Sounds an advance, but in reality the new freedom this bestows over how to spend local performance fund money involves less than 1% of an NHS trust budget. Why not give pilot projects varying amounts and see what happens?

Now they are in opposition, there are no louder advocates of "localism" than the Tories. They have even talked of putting social security on a local basis, ignoring the internal migration that this would generate. But remember who took London's tube lines away from local control and handed it to Whitehall. Margaret Thatcher, the great centraliser, when she abolished the Greater London Council - just one of a succession of anti-local measures.

webTitle: Blunkett praises community spirit in voluntary groups

fields.headline: Escape to the future
fields.standfirst: Blunkett praises community spirit in voluntary groups
fields.trailText: Blunkett praises community spirit in voluntary groups
fields.body:
All secondary school pupils should be getting the chance to take part in voluntary activity by 2003, education and employment secretary David Blunkett will today announce.

The opportunity to volunteer should become an automatic part of the mandatory study of citizenship, the minister will say when he addresses the annual conference of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO).

Blunkett will present volunteering as a means by which young people can escape social exclusion. He will point to schemes which have successfully countered racism and drug misuse, as well as helped rebuild fractured communities.

The conference, which is sup ported by the Guardian, will also be addressed by Conservative leader William Hague. The NCVO is expected to issue a strong call for British business leaders to dig deeper for charity - and for government to exert pressure on them if they fail to match the higher levels of corporate giving that prevail in the US.

Opinion survey findings to be released by the NCVO will suggest that almost two in three people think that British businesses do not do enough for charity.

Blunkett's address will follow his announcement yesterday of a tripling - to £3m - in the size of the government's "community champions" fund, which has so far helped more than 700 individuals and community groups to build their skills and encourage others to get involved in regeneration activity.

The expanded fund should bring a greater focus on marginalised groups such as older volunteers and people with disabilities, the minister said. "We need local people to get fully involved in driving change forward if we are to see real improvements in our deprived communities."

Blunkett was presenting awards from the fund to the 29 latest community champions, including Wahid-ur Rahman, of the Oldham Bangladeshi Association's "healthy heart" mentoring project, and Lai Lim, of the Doncaster Chinese Women's Group.

webTitle: Body of evidence at Bedford hospital

fields.headline: Body of evidence at Bedford hospital
fields.standfirst: Patrick Butler investigates the real story behind the Bedford hospital trust 'bodies in the chapel' scandal and asks what happened next?
fields.trailText: Patrick Butler investigates the real story behind the Bedford hospital trust 'bodies in the chapel' scandal and asks what happened next?
fields.body:
For two days in January the Bedford hospital trust "bodies in the chapel" scandal gripped the nation after several newspapers published pictures of seven corpses stored in a hospital "chapel".

There was public shock, ministerial outrage and retribution in the form of a sacked manager. An inquiry was launched and pledges were made that such an outrage should never happen again.

But now the media storm has blown over, what really happened? What did the inquiry, which reported last week, discover? And what happened next?

How did the scandal emerge?

Bedfordshire on Sunday and the Sunday Telegraph (followed by several other newspapers) published photographs on January 14 that showed seven bodies wrapped in sheets lying on the floor of the "chapel" of rest. The story was generally presented as evidence of an NHS in crisis, and an affront to human dignity.

Why were the bodies in the chapel?

The door of a temporary mortuary storage facility was inaccessible due to a defective door. The storage capacity of the main mortuary had become "increasingly inadequate" over the past decade, partly because of closure of old facilities and because of under investment in new facilities. Last winter, despite leasing an additional refrigerated body store facility, at one time more than 20 bodies were placed at on the floor of the chapel.

Who knew that the chapel was being used in this way?

Trust chief executive Ken Williams told the inquiry he was aware that the practice of temporarily placing bodies in the chapel had been taking place "for at least five years". Porters and mortuary workers knew, as did local Unison official Willy White, to whom union members had reported the problem. The trust board was unaware of the practice.

Isn't treating bodies in this way obviously bad practice?

The coroner was not overtly shocked. He told the inquiry that "use of the chapel area (in this way) was not in itself wrong at times of particular pressure, provided that it was used appropriately and with due regard for the dignity of the diseased". Similarly, pathology consultants at the trust on the whole "did not see (this practice) as untoward".

Why didn't the chaplain complain about the use of his chapel?

The chapel of rest is not a place of religious worship but an unrefrigerated, carpeted annexe of the main mortuary used to allow relatives to view a deceased relative (but not when bodies were stored there). It is a secure area, and not normally accessible to the public.

Why didn't Unison contact the trust board about the bodies in the chapel, rather than contacting the local newspaper?

Mr White said there was "a culture in the hospital which had prevented people feeling able to raise their concerns internally". The inquiry report says that, while this may have been true for "blue collar" staff, the majority of professional staff felt the culture of the trust was "friendly and open". The trust had a whistleblowing policy in place but it had never been used.

Was this just Unison settling old scores?

Managers and medical staff told the inquiry the incident could be traced to a bitter management-Unison feud over the dismissal of a staff member last year, and that the taking of the photographs was "a deliberate act" in a campaign to discredit the chief executive "by any means". Mr White said he was simply raising a serious issue of malpractice at the trust.

If the mortuary is "secure", how did a photographer gain access?

There were two sets of mortuary keys, one in the porter's lodge and one in the casualty department. No trust employee interviewed would admit to allowing the journalists access to the mortuary. The inquiry concludes that it "was unable to establish who had breached security and more importantly patient confidentiality by using their access to these keys".

If bodies are wrapped in sheets before being placed in the chapel, how was one of the bodies identified from pictures in the newspapers?

Part of the face and legs of one of the bodies was exposed on one of the bodies, which could have been an accident or could have been posed. The inquiry says that most staff "refused to believe that the photographs could have been obtained except by tampering with the bodies and their coverings beforehand". The director and photographer of the Bedfordshire on Sunday stated categorically that they "did not touch or interfere with the bodies".

Why did the faulty mortuary door take so long to fix?

A management mix-up meant that neither the estates manager nor the maintenance manager would take responsibility for the matter. Middle managers in pathology and the resource directorate also ignored the problems and failed to alert senior managers. The inquiry found that some staff felt that if they raised concerns about such matters they were ignored, "so they did not bother and adopted a make-do-and-mend' philosophy".

Who is to blame for the scandal?

The report concludes that "failings in the management processes and management accountability at the trust" were principally to blame, and as a result Mr Williams resigned. It also noted how staff shortages, historical underfunding of capital projects at the hospital, and poor procurement practice relating to the temporary mortuary also contributed. The inquiry was clearly angry at the role of both Mr White and the Bedfordshire on Sunday, although it did not directly apportion blame.

Was trust chief executive Ken Williams sacked, or did he resign?

Formally, he resigned, although many managers believe he was pushed. Mr Williams was on local television on the Sunday saying it was not a resigning issue. Less than 24 hours later, after stories had appeared in the national papers relating that health secretary Alan Milburn had "hit the roof" over the affair, Mr Williams met regional officials. After this meeting, he resigned. Regional director Peter Houghton told the press: "Being an honourable man, Ken Williams agreed he should stand down (our emphasis)." Technically the health secretary has no powers to directly "sack" NHS trust managers - although he will acquire these powers when the health and social care bill becomes law.

The practice of storing bodies in the chapel has ceased. Relatives have been sent a letter of apology with the offer of a meeting with the trust to receive a full explanation, and counselling. There is now only one set of mortuary keys, to which access is now restricted. The mortuary doors have now been fixed, and a CCTV system has been installed. The trust is considering increasing mortuary capacity, and is seeking to hire another mortician. The coroner is seeking a detailed explanation from the trust as to how the breach of security happened. The trust and Unison are to meet to "rebuild relationships".

fields.headline: Leading lights
fields.standfirst: The beacon awards praise good practice in councils. But are they more work than they are worth?  Simon Parker  reports
fields.trailText: The beacon awards praise good practice in councils. But are they more work than they are worth? Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
There will be some modest celebrations today at Oxfordshire county council. The authority has just learned that its trading standards department has won a "beacon council" award - a recognition by the government that it provides some of the best services in the country.

If it had been up to the leader of the council's Conservative group, however, Oxfordshire might not have applied for it at all. Keith Mitchell is "somewhat sceptical" about the scheme. He says: "If you do apply for beacon status, you do it for the kudos, not the reward."

The beacon awards scheme have been running for two years, but there is already evidence that Mitchell is far from alone in local government in becoming disillusioned with it. Chief among concerns are the costs of becoming a beacon and the fact that beacon status currently offers little in terms of extra funding or extra spending freedoms.

The scheme was devised as a means to spread good practice by identifying the best councils and then inviting other authorities to learn from them. Almost all councils in England and Wales have attended a beacon event and ministers believe the approach is proving a success.

But the number of applications fell last year. In the initial flurry of enthusiasm for the scheme's first round, the government received almost 270 bids. In the second round, that fell to 173. The government believes that an element of self-selection has entered the process as councils realise how tough are the standards.

But Tory local government spokesman Nigel Waterson offers a different explanation. The beacon scheme is "expensive and time consuming," he says. "Local residents know better than ministers whether their local council is performing well and delivering the services they need."

Money is certainly an issue for councils. The beacon application process eats up precious time and funds, as do the roadshows and open days that successful authorities have to organise to share their good practice. Although the government does provide financial support for successful beacons, local government minister Hilary Armstrong has admitted that the scheme does leave some councils out of pocket. As Mitchell says: "The reward is tiny. It's something like £20,000 at the end of the day."

To combat the perceived lack of reward in becoming a beacon, ministers have promised a "beacons phase two", in which successful councils could win new freedoms and flexibilities - including the power to raise extra local business rates, or toincrease council tax levels without fear of capping. The government has yet to set a timetable for this, despite pressure from county councils. Their umbrella group, the County Councils Network, has met local government minister Beverley Hughes to push her on the issue - but has failed to get an answer.

Armstrong argues that councils which apply for the scheme are already reaping rewards. "The key thing is that, if authorities learn from what's going on elsewhere, they'll learn ways of saving money through greater efficiency," she says. "Those that are beacons in one service area should be learning from other areas."

Changes seem inevitable in the beacon scheme, largely because the original proposals for phase two are already becoming obsolete. Plans for reforming local government finance include handing councils more control of the business rate, and local public service agreements (PSAs) promise authorities a wide range of new freedoms and flexibilities. Both of these policy moves will allow all councils to benefit, not just the best.

There is nothing to suggest, however, that this will mean scrapping the beacon scheme. Armstrong says: "We actually believe that there is good practice, but that local authorities don't learn from each other, so they're reinventing the wheel. That doesn't help the public, who want their council to be driving forward improvements.

"Beacons allow all councils to see what is good practice and what they can learn from that. I think that's only good."

Drawing a lesson from Sunderland

The Wear riverside used to be dominated by shipyard cranes. Sunderland has won beacon council status partly for transforming an area scarred by the demise of shipbuilding into part of the coast-to-coast cycle and sculpture trail, the largest public arts project in Britain.

Sunderland built the St Peter's riverside sculpture trail -Taking Flight -over six years through a team of artists working with the local community. The council also won beacon status - for regeneration through culture, sport and tourism - for helping to turn a derelict former colliery site in the north of the city into Sunderland football club's Stadium of Light, persuading them not to move to greenfield land.

The authority is helping residents of the city's deprived east end build a new sports centre, an electronic village hall and a job training centre. When the community put in its own application for the project, funding body Sport England turned it down. With the local authority in the lead, however, the project should provide a focus for the east end's strong community spirit, as well as a means for residents to improve their health and employment prospects.

fields.headline: An inspiring choice
fields.standfirst: Disability campaigner's lifetime achievement award
fields.trailText: Disability campaigner's lifetime achievement award
fields.body:
A disability consultant, who himself has cerebral palsy and began his working life in a cotton mill, has been honoured with a lifetime achievement award by charity Leonard Cheshire.

Alan Counsell, from Bletchley, Buckinghamshire, has devoted his life to supporting, teaching and advising disabled people. He trained as a nurse, social worker and rehabilitation officer and spent much of the 1970s working at a residential school for children with disabilities, helping integrate them into the mainstream. He has run his own consultancy, Focus disAbility, since 1990, training and advising public and private organisation on all aspects of disability.

Counsell's honour came in Leonard Cheshire's annual Enabled awards, nominations for which come only from disabled people. One nomination described him as "the most inspiring person I have ever met". Nominator Sarah Bush, from Merseyside, said: "Blisteringly intelligent and hugely compassionate, his contribution to the disabled community cannot be overestimated."

Other awards went to the Chipstead Sailing Club in Sevenoaks, Kent (sports organisation); Susan Cook, from Essex (individual achievement, for her work with people with Klinefelters' syndrome); Warrington Community Health Care NHS trust (community affairs involvement); Mary Cowern, from Llanelli (volunteer of the year, for her work with charity Arthritis Care); and the I Can Do That magazine, produced by the Liverpoool Echo (regional media).

David Brindle, editor of Guardian Society, received the national media award. His nomination said he had offered "a rare platform for disabled people's interests and concerns".

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: trail
fields.body:
Gnawing doubts

Magistrates in Nottingham were told by a man accused of stealing a piece of cheese from a supermarket that he had only taken it to share with his pet rat.
Nottingham Evening Post, 21.1.01 (K Rimmer, Nottingham)

Locked in love

A man whose girlfriend refused to let him into her house in Connah's Quay, Flintshire, got her to call the police so he could be arrested and sleep the night in a cell.
Mold and Buckley Chronicle, 12.1.01 (L Sylvia, Wrexham)

Clouds over Ibiza

A factory worker from Newbridge, Gwent, was sacked for taking part in a live radio competition in which he won a two-week holiday in Ibiza.
Shropshire Star, 13.1.01 (A Prout, Newtown)

Puzzling coincidence

A man given a jigsaw puzzle by his daughter discovered that the completed picture showed his late wife on a paddle steamer on the Norfolk Broads.
Brighton Evening Argus, 21.1.01 (John Beeken, Saltdean)

Badge of shame

A traffic warden in Birmingham admitted using her father's disabled badge so that she could park all day without paying to do her work.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 25.1.01 (Simon Briggs, Warley)

Ripon yarns

Firefighters at Boroughbridge, North Yorkshire, had to call for help from colleagues in Ripon, six miles away, because thick smoke from a fire in their station prevented them reaching their engines.
Manchester Metro 24.1.01 (Jon Booth, Stockport)

In the blue strip

The manager of a local football team in Barnstaple, Devon, took just four months to raise the money for a new set of kit after introducing 50p fines for players swearing.
Birmingham Evening Mail 9.1.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

In hot water

Robbers who held up a post office in Wigan also stole a kettle so that they could use the hot water to clear ice from the getaway car's windscreen.
Manchester Evening News, 18.1.01 (K Elliott, Bradshaw)

Forked tongues

The Crimestoppers hotline number has been embossed on plastic cutlery used in Hertfordshire police cells as a reminder to prisoners that they can pass on information anonymously.
Police Review, 19.1.01 (N Hartley, Rossendale)

Weather or not

A woman whose roof was damaged after a heavy snowfall in Derby has had a £400 insurance claim rejected because the company says Met Office records show only a very light fall that day.
Derby Evening Telegraph, 18.1.01 (S Cowley, Belper)

Patchy description

A drunken man managed to withdraw a total of £15,000 from a friend's account after staff in Inverness phoned the bank where the account was held and were given an accurate description of "a scruffy alcoholic with an eye patch".
Highland News, 21.1.01 (Marc Hindley, Nairn)

Crestfallen

Jaguar's plans to build a £200m factory for its Formula One motor racing team were held up when a colony of great crested newts, a protected species, was discovered on the development site.
East Anglian Daily Times, 17.1.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Bowled out

A fraud trial in Exeter had to be halted when the judge declared that he had once played cricket with one of the witnesses.
Express and Echo, 25.1.01 (L Peters, Cullompton)

Crime waves

Eight sailors were fined for speeding after being caught in radar traps set up on the River Arun at Arundel, Sussex.
Evening Standard, 21.1.01 (Roger Price, Wethersfield)

webTitle: Are Bangladeshi tanneries to blame for health problems?

fields.headline: Hell from leather
fields.standfirst: Are Bangladeshi tanneries to blame for health problems?
fields.trailText: Are Bangladeshi tanneries to blame for health problems?
fields.body:
Mirazul Hossain Chowdhury is angry. The 40-year-old businessman throws his arms in a gesture of helplessness. "I wish I could move elsewhere permanently," he says. "This is like living in a hell where you slowly, but surely, embrace death."

Chowdhury is talking of Hazaribagh, a crowded residential district of almost 500,000 people in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka. His wife died of kidney problems two years ago and, like so many others in the district, he fears the health risks from the toxic chemicals being released daily from leather tanneries dotted among their homes.

With no one apparently interested in countering this pollution, many people wonder if they are doomed to die by slow poisoning.

The leather processing plants have sprouted up haphazardly over the last 50 years. Of Bangladesh's 300 tanneries, Hazaribagh has 90%, with 277 small and medium-sized plants concentrated in 25 hectares of land. According to a study conducted by BKH, a Dutch consulting firm, the tanneries release 7.7m litres of liquid and 88 tonnes of solid toxic substances daily. With no proper drainage system for waste disposal and no treatment plant, the toxic waste dumped in the area is left to accumulate unchecked.

Experts say the industrial waste causes dangerous levels of ground and air pollution in the area. "The impact is so easily visible that you don't need to carry out any laboratory tests for confirmation," says Ravi Gopal Biswas, deputy director of the environment department.

The homes and other buildings in Hazaribagh have a yellowish appearance - a manifestation of air pollution. And the ground water is found to be highly contaminated.

Several chemicals used in the tanneries are blamed for the pollution, but it is the sulphur dioxide and chromium which are considered most harmful to the environment and human health.

The stench produced by the tanneries is so overpowering that visitors are overcome by nausea.

No wonder most of the Hazaribagh residents suffer from a host of ailments, including jaundice, lung infections, skin diseases, ulcer and cancer. "It's hard to find an individual who does not have some kind of ailment," says Dr MA Hasan, director of the Environment Research and Skin Care Institute. The institute recently surveyed 140 families and 90% of them were found to be affected.

Environment department officials take exception to the charge that they do not care. "It's not true that we're doing nothing," says an official of the Directorate of Environment. "Numerous studies have been carried out aimed at finding a solution." Most, he says, recommend shifting the tanneries out of Hazaribagh to a place far from the capital city.

But so far all attempts to move the tanneries have been torpedoed by powerful industrial interests. "They're rich and powerful and the politicians don't want to antagonise them," says an official who asked not to be named.

The leather sector earns a substantial part of the country's hard currency. Last year it earned about $280m (£190m )out of the country's total export earning of $5.7 bn.

"This is complete nonsense. They're blaming us to cover up their own inefficiencies," says MA Majed, director of Apex, Bangladesh's biggest tannery. "We're ready to move anytime, provided they give us the land and other infrastructure facilities."

Unable to relocate the factories, the government has promised to build a treatment plant in Hazaribagh. So far only one factory has installed a plant.

The institute recently surveyed 140 families and 90% of them were found to be affected. Environment department officials take exception to the charge that they do not care. "It's not true that we're doing nothing," says an official of the Directorate of Environment. "Numerous studies have been carried out aimed at finding a solution." Most, he says, recommend shifting the tanneries out of Hazaribagh to a place far from the capital city. But so far all attempts to move the tanneries have been torpedoed by powerful industrial interests. "They're rich and powerful and the politicians don't want to antagonise them," says an official who asked not to be named. The leather sector earns a substantial part of the country's hard currency. Last year it earned about $280m (£190m )out of the country's total export earning of $5.7 bn. "This is complete nonsense. They're blaming us to cover up their own inefficiencies," says MA Majed, director of Apex, Bangladesh's biggest tannery. "We're ready to move anytime, provided they give us the land and other infrastructure facilities." Unable to relocate the factories, the government has promised to build a treatment plant in Hazaribagh. So far only one factory has installed a plant.

webTitle: The UAE faces the fact of global warming

fields.headline: Threat that faces us all
fields.standfirst: A leading oil producing nation confronts the fact that clean energy is needed to combat the danger of global warming
fields.trailText: A leading oil producing nation confronts the fact that clean energy is needed to combat the danger of global warming
fields.byline: Sheikh Hamdan bin Zayed Al Nahyan
fields.body:
Earlier this week, the environment ministers of the 21 Arab countries adopted the Abu Dhabi Declaration, which lays out a strategy for sustainable use of environmental resources throughout the Arab world for the 21st century.

In the past few weeks, the report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has starkly confirmed the threat posed by global warming, and we have seen the Galapagos Islands become the latest victims of a major oil spill.

These are not the only man-made environmental threats. Away from the headlines, chainsaws are destroying rainforests, dams are silting up rivers and pesticides threaten both wildlife and the soil from which food to feed an ever-growing world population must be derived.

Thanks to an explosion of environmental pressure groups, we now hear much more about how we are mortgaging our children's future, but there is little sign of concrete action from policymakers as the warnings become louder and are backed up by more and more evidence.

In the Middle East, we have a special need to pay attention to these warnings. Many of the countries of the region are low-lying and short of water, and we are under threat from rising sea levels and desertification. By the end of this century, sea levels could rise by as much as 88cm.

This could flood not only coastal areas of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), but also much of the heavily populated Nile delta in Egypt and the lower reaches of the Tigris and Euphrates river system in Iraq. Meanwhile, a rapidly rising population places ever-growing demands on our natural resources.

In the UAE, we are getting promising results from research into capturing clean energy from the sun through a new generation of solar panels. Before long it will be possible for us to construct buildings with photovoltaic panels that will generate most of their own energy requirements. A major achievement in recent years has been a dramatic reduction in the flaring of gases from onshore and offshore oilfields. In 1995, some 250m cubic feet of gas a day were flared in Abu Dhabi. Today, we are down to 56m - a 78% reduction in just five years. Our objective is a zero flaring policy.

The stakes are high for us, and for our planet.

Sheikh Hamdan bin Zayed Al Nahyan is minister of state for foreign affairs of the United Arab Emirates and deputy chairman of Abu Dhabi's Environmental Research and Wildlife Development Agency, ERWDA.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Highway to nothing
fields.body:
Highway to nothing

The Newbury bypass is the best road in Britain. Well, sort of. A scientific study conducted by local wildlife groups and academics has found that the nine-mile length of road has barely leaked any heavy metals on to surrounding land or into river courses. This is mainly, they report, because the Highways Agency's design using nine "balancing ponds" of water traps and filtration systems, has worked as planned. The bad news is that this is the only road in Britain to be so well protected. Which in turn begs the question why doesn't every stretch of new and upgraded road have a system like this?

Risky business

It seems that the US can't even give its GM animal food away now. On the back of British supermarkets and the poultry industry saying "no thanks" to GM animal feed last week, word reaches Eco soundings that the US has now withdrawn a $4m donation of GM animal food maize after both the Serbs and the Croats in Bosnia got worried about health risks. "The inclusion of the GM corn [in aid] is not unusual," the US embassy said, adding "such corn is routinely exported all over the world for human and animal consumption". No more, it seems.

Scotland the brave

Useful joined-up thinking in English Nature. What Nicholas Woolley (an EN council member) does in Scotland is "not a problem for us," says a spokesman. North of the border, Woolley, rural portfolio fund asset manager for insurance giant Eagle Star, is not getting such an easy ride. He is masterminding a scheme to build 48 homes in the tiny village of Nethy Bridge, inside the proposed Cairngorms National Park and on 22 acres occupied by Caledonian pines, a species of which Scotland has lost 99%. There are fears that developers are rushing to get planning permission to beat the deadline when the new Scottish national parks are designated. Duncan Bryden, of the Scottish Wildlife Trust is on the case - intent on slowing down Woolley's "undue haste."

Up in the air

Goodbye Magrox, the experimental fuel that British Nuclear Fuels was developing to keep the Magnox stations open at Wylfa, in Anglesey, and Oldbury, Gloucestershire for up to 20 years. Another nail in the coffin of the UK's target of a 20% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions which relied on continued nuclear production.

webTitle: Why is weaponry that can have the same effect as landmines still being produced?

fields.headline: Making a killing
fields.standfirst: They kill, they maim and they are banned worldwide. So why is weaponry that can have the same effect as landmines still being produced? By  Paul Donovan
fields.trailText: They kill, they maim and they are banned worldwide. So why is weaponry that can have the same effect as landmines still being produced? By Paul Donovan
fields.body:
It is now three years since a remarkable campaign waged by individuals, voluntary groups, non-governmental organisations and a princess won a worldwide ban on anti-personnel landmines. As the images of maimed children filled screens and front pages, the call for a ban grew ever louder. Finally, the politicians could resist no longer and, in December 1997, an international treaty banning anti-personnel landmines was agreed in Ottawa.

The signing of the Ottawa treaty marked not only the nadir of the campaign but also the moment when landmines slipped from the public spotlight. The problem, it appeared to most people, was solved.

The events that followed the signing of the Ottawa treaty make disappointing reading as governments have failed to live up to funding promises. And, worryingly, companies are building and selling bigger, more lethal weaponry which can have the same effect as anti-personnel mines.

"At the time the treaty was signed, it was recognised that all landmines which could be set off by a person should be banned", says Richard Lloyd, of the campaigning charity Landmine Action. "But since then we have found some companies and countries have made unbanned anti-tank mines which are more lethal for people."

From BAe Systems/Royal Ordnance comes the Mk 7 anti-tank blast mine that includes an "anti-disturbance" double impulse fuse which detonates when rotated on its axis. Then there is the AT2 anti-tank mine, with an integral "anti-handling" device. The Multiple Launch Rocket System (MLRS), containing the AT2, is made by a consortium of European companies, including British company Hunting Engineering. The MLRS propels rockets containing a number of AT2 anti-tank-mines, which have an integral anti-handling device. The Ministry of defence stocks about 100,000 of these lethal weapons. But what of the ban, and didn't the MoD very publicly destroy all its stocks.

A spokesman for Hunting acknowledged that anti-tank mines with sensitive fuses could kill personnel, but said: "We have supplied this equipment to the German company Diehl, who have supplied MLR2 to the German and British armies. It has been manufactured within German and British Army requirements."

The increased production of anti-tank mines fitted with sensitive fuses is a direct result of loopholes in the Ottawa treaty. While the treaty bans anti-personnel landmines, the devil is in the definition.

"The major weakness of the definition is that it is set by design, not effect," says Rae McGrath, nobel laureate and former director of the Mines Advisory Group. "A maker could escape liability by arguing that the weapon was designed to be a washing machine but just happened to have the effect of a landmine. If any weapon has the effect of an anti-personnel mine, it should be banned."

It is this loophole which is allowing companies to build bigger and more lethal anti-personnel weapons than ever before. It has also enabled the MoD to make a public show of destroying redundant anti-personnel landmines while actually stocking up with the new lethal anti-tank variety.

"I don't care about the technology or who makes the AT2 mine," says McGrath. "At the moment, what worries me is that British companies and the MoD are involved in producing and putting into service the MLRS, which will result in a mine which will act as an anti-personnel mine. This is at a time when taxpayers' money is being spent on clearing up landmines in other countries.

Another area where the Ottawa treaty has been tested and found wanting is that of enforcement. Some 16 months ago, a Romanian company was exposed offering banned anti-personnel landmines for sale at the government-sponsored arms show. The government set up an inquiry after Romtehnica was discovered offering the banned weapons for sale at the Defence Systems and Equipment international exhibition in Surrey in September 1999.

The MoD police took statements from the various people involved in exposing the company and a case file was passed to the crown prosecution service, which says that the file is still open. The company's defence was that its sales promotion material was out of date and should not have been on display.

Lloyd is disappointed at the lack of progress: "There has been a surprising lack of progress in investigating and coming to some conclusion about the Romanian company," he says. "Silence is all we have heard."

However, it is not all bad news. Some 138 countries have now signed the Ottawa treaty, with 110 ratifying it. There have been 22m stockpiled anti-personnel landmines destroyed over the past three years by more than 50 nations. Over the past year, seven of the largest demining programmes cleared a combined total of 168m square metres of land. The number of producer nations has also dropped from 54 to 16.

But there is still much to do, with more than 250m anti-personnel landmines remaining in the arsenals of 105 nations. China holds the biggest stockpile, with 110m anti-personnel landmines, followed by Russia with 60-70m. The US retains a holding of 11m, although it has a moratorium on exports.

Anti-personnel landmines also continue to be laid by the Russians in Chechnya and by warring forces in Angola. Government forces in Burma and Sri Lanka and rebel forces in Uganda, Somalia and Colombia also continue to use the banned weapon.

Lloyd believes slow progress is being made. "I think the tap is being turned off but it has not yet stopped, and the pressure needs to be kept up," says Lloyd. He also believes that the G8 countries have a moral obligation to contribute more to anti-personnel landmine clearance.

The UK government has contributed £17m to demining and to landmine victim support.

fields.headline: Reader's letters
fields.trailText: letters
fields.body:
Adopting a US import

Concurrent planning, in which agencies place babies with parents desperate to adopt them while also claiming to work with birth parents, is an attempt to repeal the laws of human nature (The fast track, January 31).

Such schemes recruit parents who are desperate to adopt a child. The parents are told, in effect: "Remember, our first goal is still to try to reunite this child with his or her birth parents. You must try to help achieve that goal. But if, by some chance, you fail, then you get what you really want - someone else's child for your very own."

The real attitude of parents in these programmes was aptly summed up by one such parent in New Jersey who told the New York Times: "I'm on a plane to South America if they think they're getting this baby back."

Contrary to the common stereotype, many parents who lose their children to foster care are neither brutally abusive nor hopelessly addicted. Far more common are cases in which a family's poverty is confused with child "neglect". Other cases fall on a broad continuum between the extremes, the parents neither all victim nor all villain.

What these cases have in common is that the families could have been kept safely together with the right kind of services. That's worth doing not for the sake of the parents, but for the sake of the children, who often do not oblige us by hating their parents the way we may think they should.

Indeed, a University of Florida study found that even infants born with cocaine in their systems developed better when left with birth parents capable of caring for them than when placed in substitute care. For these infants, the separation from their mothers was more toxic than the cocaine.

But for many who work in foster care systems, adoption has always been the dessert on the child welfare menu; working with birth families is the broccoli. Concurrent planning hands out the dessert without making workers eat their broccoli first. In the US, it is helping turn the child welfare system into the ultimate middle-class entitlement: step right up and take a poor person's child for your very own. It's an American import that should have been turned back at the border.

Richard Wexler
Executive director, National Coalition for Child Protection Reform, Alexandria, Virginia, USA

Breath of fresh air

David Brandon is right to highlight the true and unglossed picture of the present state of mental health charity Mind (Letters, January 31).

Judi Clements's replacement as chief executive will inherit many problems, from the need to recruit skilled staff with mental health knowledge to the need to listen to, and act upon, members' concerns and complaints that are now swept under the carpet.

As a member and supporter of my local Mind organisation, I am hopeful that the appointment of a new chief executive at national level will breathe fresh air into the organisation.

Carol Underwood
Fenny Drayton, Warwickshire

Benefits of PCs

As a fellow resident, I share some of the concerns about the place of CCTV in policing the population of Nottingham (Letters, January 24). Indeed, such concerns have been expressed by many residents and passed to the police through the partnership council (PC), of which I am a member.

Your correspondent appears to confuse the PC with the city council. The PC is independent of, though working closely with, the council and seeks to communicate the experience of a diverse community, its ideas and aspirations, and to effect change in public services.

On the theme of crime and safety, the PC engaged local people in the development of an action plan that suggested a very different approach to tackling the problems of inner-city Nottingham. From this consultation has emerged an array of projects, including a community mediation scheme; a lock-fitting project which also seeks to train unemployed residents; and a scheme which provides training and support to ex-offenders looking for employment. A very successful victim/offender mediation project, piloted from our resident action plan, has now been extended city-wide with government funding.

The PC cannot and does not claim to have effectively involved or consulted everyone, but it does offer genuine opportunities to challenge and shape public services and, even in our small way, we believe we have achieved a great deal.

Mike Rowe
Nottingham

Limiting power

I, and many of my professional colleagues, welcome some aspects of the white paper proposals for reform of mental health legislation (Doors slammed, January 17).

Like Genevra Richardson, however, many clinical psychologists are concerned at the breadth and scope of the proposed powers. They clearly need considerable redrafting if, as Richardson says, "the gateway to compulsion is not to be far, far too wide".

Peter Kinderman
Reader in clinical psychology, University of Liverpool

Nelson's column

As a schoolboy in Nelson in the late 1940s, I used to watch Lancashire League cricket. Older spectators talked of Learie Constantine with awe and affection and he must have been the first black man most had seen (Letters, January 24).

Nelson was at that time referred to as "little Moscow" because of the famous firebrand left-wing MP, Sydney Silverman, who among other things was a leader in the campaign to abolish capital punishment.

Peter Wood
London

fields.headline: Family back in spotlight
fields.trailText: Josie Russell has struggled to develop into an ordinary carefree youngster since the hammer attack in July 1996, which left her mother Lin and sister Megandead.
fields.body:
Josie Russell has struggled to develop into an ordinary carefree youngster since the hammer attack in July 1996, which left her mother Lin and sister Megandead.

They had been walking down an isolated footpath in Chillenden, Kent, when they wereattacked. Josie, who suffered severe head injuries, was left to die. She was so brain-damaged that doctors were afraid she might never speak again.

But she has grown into a courageous 13-year-old with the help of her father, and a secure and close-knit circle of friends and supportive teachers.

The healing process involved moving with her father, Shaun, from the family home in Kent to begin a new life in north Wales in December 1996.

In September 1999 she spoke of her happiness at starting secondary school. "I wish Lin could see me, and Megan of course. I always miss them - but they live in my heart," she told the Sun.

Josie provided video evidence for Michael Stone's trial. She was captured on grainy footage relating the trauma, using scale models to re-enact the scene, in the halting, disjointed language that resulted from her injuries.

Despite fighting back to health, Josie was reported in October to have the reading age of a nine-year-old.
fields.bodyText: Josie Russell has struggled to develop into an ordinary carefree youngster since the hammer attack in July 1996, which left her mother Lin and sister Megandead. They had been walking down an isolated footpath in Chillenden, Kent, when they wereattacked. Josie, who suffered severe head injuries, was left to die. She was so brain-damaged that doctors were afraid she might never speak again. But she has grown into a courageous 13-year-old with the help of her father, and a secure and close-knit circle of friends and supportive teachers. The healing process involved moving with her father, Shaun, from the family home in Kent to begin a new life in north Wales in December 1996. In September 1999 she spoke of her happiness at starting secondary school. "I wish Lin could see me, and Megan of course. I always miss them - but they live in my heart," she told the Sun. Josie provided video evidence for Michael Stone's trial. She was captured on grainy footage relating the trauma, using scale models to re-enact the scene, in the halting, disjointed language that resulted from her injuries. Despite fighting back to health, Josie was reported in October to have the reading age of a nine-year-old.

fields.headline: McLaren puts Killie in the fast lane
fields.standfirst: McLaren 39, Dargo 69, Canero 78
fields.trailText: CIS Insurance Cup final St Mirren 0 - 3 Kilmarnock
fields.body:
Kilmarnock booked a place in the last night, against one of the Old Firm, with a comfortable victory over St Mirren.

Andy McLaren gave them a half-time advantage with a header and second-half goals from Craig Dargo and Peter Canero made absolutely sure.

The first chance of the evening fell to Saints, though, when Chris Kerr crossed from the left and Mark Yardley outjumped two defenders but his header went narrowly wide.

Killie countered with a long diagonal ball from McLaren which allowed Dargo to get behind the defence, but he could get no more than a faint touch to the fast-moving ball.

Paul Rudden then showed a fair degree of skill to flick the ball between Killie's McLaren and Martin Baker and skip free, but his lay back to Gary Bowman deserved better than a ponderous first touch which forced him to sidestep to avoid a challenge before shooting weakly at the keeper.

Killie then created an even better chance as another long ball unlocked the Saints defence. McLaren rose unmarked but mistimed his header and could only watch the ball bounce off the turf into Ludovic Roy's hands.

Saints won their first corner after 30 minutes and Chris Kerr swung the ball in to the near post and it needed Mitchell to head off the line from Yardley, who had flicked it towards the far corner.

Almost immediately Killie went to the other end and though Paul Wright got goalside of Sergei Baltacha to deflect Gary Holt's low ball towards the target, once again Roy was equal to the effort.

Saints soon found themselves in trouble when their short-corner routine failed to trouble Killie, who launched a counter-attack that saw McLaren race down the right wing. Though he fired across goal and inches wide, he made amends within seconds as Wright crossed from the right and he outjumped Rudden to head past Roy.

After 69 minutes Saints had a corner cleared and Killie countered at tremendous speed. Dargo was the man on the move and he motored through to curl a beautifully weighted shot high past Roy and into the net. It was a goal worthy of clinching any semi-final.

Then Canero made sure his team would be back at Hampden for next month's final when he stabbed the ball home from close range after Holt had won a header in the area following a free-kick.

Kilmarnock : Marshall; MacPherson, McGowne, Dindeleux, Canero, Baker, Holt, Mitchell (Reilly, 81), McLaren, Dargo (Fowler, 81), Wright (Cocard, 75).

Referee : K Clark

webTitle: Leader: The Stone case could get worse

fields.headline: Justice undone
fields.standfirst: The Stone case could get worse
fields.trailText: Michael Stone was convicted of the murder of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan and the attempted murder of Megan's sister Josie. At Maidstone crown court in 1998, the trial judge said the acceptability of the confession Stone made to fellow prisoner Damien Daley depended on the credibility of Barry Thompson, another inmate.
fields.body:
Michael Stone was convicted of the murder of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan and the attempted murder of Megan's sister Josie. At Maidstone crown court in 1998, the trial judge said the acceptability of the confession Stone made to fellow prisoner Damien Daley depended on the credibility of Barry Thompson, another inmate. Yesterday government lawyers said they no longer held Thompson to be a truthful witness and as a result the appeal court is set to allow Stone's challenge. Justice miscarried.

The judgment will damage public confidence in the criminal justice system, even if it also shows the appellate procedure working as it was intended. The miscarriage is not on the scale which shook the system in the 1970s and 1980s. We are talking about a dishonest witness, not police perjury or planted evidence. Even so, whatever happens tomorrow when the appeal court disposes of the case, Kent police have questions to answer, particularly their use of paid informants and their preparation of this case.

Things could get worse if Stone's conviction is quashed but a re-trial ordered. The noise will be cacophonous and it may be especially difficult to guarantee a fair hearing. The details of the murder, let alone Stone's personality, have been the subject of extraordinarily detailed attention. Stone might seek compensation, leading to tabloid frenzy.

Social policy reform, notably community treatment orders for mentally ill people, took some of its impetus from the Stone case. The old cliche returns to haunt legislators: hard cases make bad law. There were already grounds for doubt about the indeterminate reviewable hospital order, under which dangerous people with a severe personality disorder could be detained, not for what they have done, but for what they might do. This latest development should make legislators even more cautious.

fields.headline: Dons pass Venables examination
fields.standfirst: Photo gallery
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 0 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
Moderate eccentrics they may be compared with the Crazy Gang of old, but Wimbledon were back ruffling Premiership feathers last night to barge Terry Venables's renaissance on Teesside momentarily off course.

A desperate draw, with both teams stuttering on a sandpit of a pitch, earned Terry Burton's resilient Dons a second chance to vie for a fifth-round trip to Wycombe. The smattering of local support in the 20,625 crowd, windswept and chilled to the bone, were grumbling their way to the exits long before the final whistle. Boro may be unbeaten in 11 matches but they will not relish a midweek replay at Selhurst Park, where the scars remain vivid from Venables' bitter divorce from Crystal Palace in 1998.

"We tried to play football with that swirling wind on a bumpy surface," he sighed with frustration, "but Wimbledon deserved what they got. We looked a little tired and didn't have that dynamic edge, especially in our support play. If we can pick that spark up again we'll be fine."

The last time the Dons were on Teesside, 31,400 fans were numbed by similar goalless mush. Just over 14 months on, Boro had October's Worthington Cup defeat in south London to avenge - one of only three wins at Selhurst Park by Wimbledon this season. Paul Ince, with Sven-Goran Eriksson watching, reacted by thrashed a 25-yard shot just wide after only 18 seconds and Hamilton Ricard headed over from point-blank range seven minutes later.

But, with the crowd noise rarely rising beyond the whispers of a cinema auditorium, Boro soon floundered as Wimbledon's Trond Andersen and Damien Francis stifled their midfield. Even without the unfit John Hartson the chances came; Par Karlsson's volley was blocked on the line by Christian Karembeu, and Patrick Agyemang, who can run 100 metres quicker than it took the Tannoy announcer to pronounce his name, air-kicked in front of goal.

Boro's nerves were further grated when a low shot by Peter Hawkins bobbled off the turf and squirmed beneath Mark Schwarzer's body but a flick of his shirt was enough to deflect the ball for a corner.

The uneven surface was hardly suited to the refined touches of Alen Boksic but sporadic glimpses of the Croatian's class brightened proceedings. He had hit the Dons' side netting before, with seven minutes of a scrappy first half left, he curled a delightful free-kick towards the top corner, only for Kelvin Davis to tip the shot wide.

The former Luton goalkeeper promptly had to parry Ugo Ehiogu's close-range attempt - "That was a special save," conceded Venables - before Boksic headed the rebound against a post. "This is his first full season with us and he's been fantastic," Burton said of Davis. "He's maturing and, with a bit of luck on his side, he will get even better."

His best was already good enough to palm Ricard's thumping header wide early in the second half, but such was the visitors' work rate and Boro's desperation that the First Division side calmly controlled the pace of the match and should have capitalised on one of their 11 corners.

"But the whole performance delighted me," said Burton. "We asked our lads to come and perform against world-class opponents, so for a lot of our young players this can only be a benefit. We may not have won many at home this season but we're unbeaten at home in 2001. All right, we may only have played there once, but we've got no problem with Selhurst."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: United hit Yankee jackpot
fields.standfirst: 'Super club' tie-up with top baseball team expands global dominance
fields.trailText: Man United will today sign a revolutionary deal worth tens of millions of pounds to become a "super club" with the New York Yankees baseball team.
fields.body:
Manchester United will capture another slice of the sporting globe today by signing a revolutionary deal to become a "super club" with the New York Yankees baseball team, in an agreement which is potentially worth tens of millions of pounds.

An official announcement will be made in New York today. United's chief executive Peter Kenyon and Sir Bobby Charlton have travelled to the US to finalise a package which the Premiership champions confidently expect will consolidate their status as the world's richest football club.

The Yankees' owner, YankeeNets, also owns the New Jersey Nets basketball team and New Jersey Devils ice hockey club and it signed a commercial tie-up in December with the beaten Super Bowl finalists the New York Giants.

The plan is to form a "super club" which will be able to package itself to potential sponsors and television networks and, on a more basic level, increase merchandise sales by stocking one another's souvenirs and kits.

Neither Kenyon nor the YankeeNets chairman Harvey Schiller was willing to comment last night but it is understood that the next step will be to invite others such as Juventus, Real Madrid, Barcelona and Bayern Munich into the fold.

The Yankees are one of the few sports teams in the world who have the financial muscle to negotiate on the same plateau as United. They were valued recently at around £400m and, though that figure is less than half United's current worth, their financial potential may be even bigger. They have become known as "America's team" after winning three of the last four World Series and a record 26 overall, and there is no more famous sporting name or brand in the US.

The key difference with United is that rather than being a public limited company the Yankees are owned by George Steinbrenner, one of the more notorious characters in US sport because of his infamous short fuse and habit of making impulsive decisions.

United are understood to be disappointed that details of the agreement have been leaked before they could prepare an official announcement, and there are obvious concerns that they will face accusations from supporters of becoming even further detached from their roots.

"United have been accused before of trying to make a quick buck, and now they literally will be," said Oliver Houston of the Shareholders United pressure group. "We are going yet further down the road where the nation's premier sport is guilty of Americanisation and over-commercialism."

Nevertheless, in an industry where money is king, the Old Trafford hierarchy believe they have pulled off another massive coup after their recent agreement of a 13-year kit sponsorship deal with Nike worth £302.9m.
