webTitle: Little promises Hull's show will go on

fields.headline: Little promises Hull's show will go on
fields.trailText: Brian Little's side have been locked out of their Boothferry Park ground for the second time in nine months, his club face a winding-up order in the High Court and neither he nor his players have been paid for five weeks, but the Hull City manager has vowed to carry on in spite of the threat that Saturday's game against Leyton Orient may not go ahead.
fields.body:
Brian Little's side have been locked out of their Boothferry Park ground for the second time in nine months, his club face a winding-up order in the High Court and neither he nor his players have been paid for five weeks, but the Hull City manager has vowed to carry on in spite of the threat that Saturday's game against Leyton Orient may not go ahead.

"We are totally focused on playing Leyton Orient on Saturday unless someone tells us otherwise," he said.

Little and his squad reported for training yesterday morning even though employees of the owner of Boothferry Park, David Lloyd, had padlocked the ground at 7am.

Lloyd, Britain's former tennis Davis Cup captain, sold the club to a group of local businessmen but still owns the ground, and Hull City owe him thousands of pounds in rent. Notices were pinned up saying no one would be allowed into the ground until all debts were settled.

"We have to stand firm," Lloyd told Radio 5 Live. He defended his action, adding: "It's the only way to bring the parties to the table. I want the parties involved - the owners, the council and the Inland Revenue - to come to a deal."

Hull also face a winding-up order from Customs and Excise and the Inland Revenue in the High Court today over £500,000 in unpaid VAT. City officials are trying to head off that action by requesting a voluntary administration order prior to the winding-up hearing.

Hull's chairman Nick Buchanan is adamant that the club are not about to go under: "We still have to get on with the business of securing the long-term future of this football club and nothing will deflect us from that. While being locked out of the ground is inconvenient, it's just something else that we have to deal with.

"If we have to play at Scunthorpe, Grimsby, York, Mansfield or anywhere else we will do. David Lloyd will not win because if he does there will be no Hull City Football Club."

Leicester City have paid Altrincham £50,000 to make Kevin Ellison the first player to move from a Conference club to the Premiership. The striker impressed during a trial spell at Filbert Street and signed a 2-year deal. If he makes the grade, City could pay a further £50,000 for the 21-year-old Merseysider in appearance- related instalments.

Burnley have made an initial inquiry about signing Coventry's Australian international striker John Aloisi, who joined the Sky Blues for £650,000 from Portsmouth two years ago but has been unable to hold down a first-team place at Highfield Road.

fields.headline: RPO/ Temirkanov
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
History has not been kind to Rachmaninov's Symphonic Dances. Even when it was premiered, in 1941, by Eugene Ormandy's Philadelphia Orchestra, its late-romantic style was hopelessly out of date. Rachmaninov composed it in New York, and died in Beverly Hills in 1943. He was in exile not just from his native Russia but also from the modernist aesthetics of composers such as Schoenberg and Stravinsky - who, ironically, also lived in Hollywood at the end of their careers.

But Yuri Temirkanov was in no mood to apologise for Rachmaninov. His performance of the Dances with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra was unashamedly voluptuous. His flamboyant style and total immersion in this repertoire - he has been principal conductor of the St Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra since 1988 - made a convincing case for Rachmaninov's last orchestral piece.

For all the rose-tinted charm of the central waltz movement, it was the exhilaration of the two outer dances that was most memorable. Far from the sentimental, soupy sound that afflicts many performances, the orchestration was lean and taut. And in the elaborate final dance there was nothing mawkish about the quotation from the Dies Irae chant. The appearance of this symbol of death in the music's final paragraph was chillingly effective.

Unlike the devil-may-care romanticism of Rachmaninov, Prokofiev's Second Violin Concerto grapples with the problem of how to be a "modernist" composer while still appealing to audiences. It is usually seen as one of Prokofiev's sunniest pieces, but violinist Leila Josefowicz's performance seethed with tempestuous energy. She was more concerned with communicating the music's drama than producing a consistently polished sound, but in the slow movement she found a register of tenderness and calm, around which the orchestra spun a delicate web.

Prokofiev's Lieutenant Kije Suite opened the concert, but even the sleighbells and snow of the famous Troika could not eclipse the vividness of Josefowicz's performance.

fields.headline: Neil Finn's karaoke night
fields.standfirst:
Neil Finn
Palace Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Neil Finn
Palace Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
This one-off gig felt like a party where most of the guests already knew each other: every New Zealander in the northern hemisphere seemed to have turned out to see pop's most celebrated Kiwi.

The Palace is the theatre where Les Miserables has been playing for 16 years, and the floppy-quiffed tunesmith could not stop himself breaking into stentorian renditions of "My Name is Jean Valjean" on the flimsiest of pretexts. The intimacy of the theatre also brought the crowd close enough to the former Crowded House singer to shout out advice and requests. Finn cheerfully fielded all of them, and handed out chocolates.

He began conventionally enough, bouncing on with an acoustic guitar to sing When You Come and You're Not the Girl You Think You Are, but Finn was in the mood for taking some risks. He invited members of the audience on stage to accompany him, apparently unrehearsed. A gangly bloke called Stephen proved adept on piano, and they were joined by Mickey for a very creditable rendition of Four Seasons in One Day. Finn looked delighted.

The performance had at least one serious motive - to plug Finn's forthcoming album, One Nil. As digital cameras recorded the occasion for a webcast, Finn introduced his hastily assembled band - Dave on drums, Sebastian on bass and former Prince acolytes Wendy Melvoin and Lisa Coleman on guitar and piano. Finn had bumped into Wendy and Lisa in Los Angeles, and they ended up all over the new album, with Melvoin sharing five writing credits.

Finn admitted the band were under-rehearsed, but watching skilful musicians working out their moves in public always brings a tingle of excitement. Some of the new songs - such as the wistful Wherever You Are - are classic Finn, while others spin off into jazz-inflected territory (such as Lisa's meandering keyboard outro to Secret God). Don't Ask Why is bouncing funk-rock built around a tortuous riff.

But the crowd wanted some old favourites. There was a heart-stopping arrangement of Private Universe, with Finn and Wendy interlocking guitars over Lisa's hushed keyboards. For Weather With You, Finn plucked out of the audience a chap called Steve, who just happened to know the guitar chords and harmonies back to front. The show closed with Don't Dream It's Over, Lisa supplying the stately Procol Harum-esque organ break. Flaming marvellous.

fields.headline: Lloyds and Goldman target rich
fields.standfirst:
Banks join forces to chase the wealthy high flyers

Money site
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB and US investment bank Goldman Sachs have joined forces to set up a new business targeting Britain's growing number of wealthy individuals.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB and US investment bank Goldman Sachs have joined forces to set up a new business targeting Britain's growing number of wealthy individuals.

The move means research by influential Goldman Sachs analysts, such as Gavyn Davies and Abby Cohen, will be directly available to retail investors for the first time.

The new business, which will be launched in the summer under the brand name Create, is aimed at people earning more than £60,000 a year or with assets of more than £100,000.

Lloyds TSB claims it already has 1m customers who fit these criteria and aims to double the £300m of pre-tax profit it makes each year from so-called wealth management within the next four years.

The move is the latest in a series of attempts by leading financial services firms to try to win business from the "mass affluent" - a growing group of people ranging from post-war baby boomers to new e-entrepreneurs. Abbey National has set up Inscape, while HSBC has joined Merrill Lynch to target wealthy individuals.

According to a report by analysts at Commerzbank, the mass affluent market will grow 10% from the 24m people across Europe who fit into this bracket. Explaining why banks and and other financial firms are so eager to tap into this area, Commerzbank calculated yesterday that up to 20% of banks' and insurance companies' profits could be generated by these clients.

Laurel Powers-Freeling, the managing director of wealth management at Lloyds, said Create was intended to have a modern feel, which was attractive to "intelligent people" who are not interested in the traditional private banking services more often offered to more upper-crust customers.

Under the terms of the arrangement with Goldman Sachs, customers of Create will be able to receive the research by Goldman Sachs' analysts and also be given the opportunity to buy shares in initial public offerings by the companies Goldman Sachs is advising.

Create is made up of four different prongs designed to attract specific types of affluent customers and has been set a target to attract 250,000 customers by the end of next year. One of the products includes a "sweeping" account, which allows customers to automatically sweep their savings and loans into one account.

Analysts at Fox-Pitt, Kelton said: "The bank will spend £100m-£200m [by 2002] on wealth management and foresees profits of £600m by 2005. This partly explains their abandonment of the cost income ratio [efficiency] target".

fields.headline: Child's-eye views with an adult focus
fields.standfirst:
Wendy Ewald
Stills Gallery, Edinburgh
****
fields.trailText:
Wendy Ewald
Stills Gallery, Edinburgh
****
fields.body:
Wendy Ewald makes child's play of photography. Since 1969, the American photographer has travelled to often troubled parts of the world - South Africa, India, Saudi Arabia, Morocco - and to communities under pressure, whether from poverty, racial tension or religious stricture. Wherever she lived for an extended period, she collaborated with local children.

While she takes documentary photographs from an outsider's perspective, the children take their own snapshots. Ewald then mixes these up and presents them on the same artistic level, challenging the hierarchies between artist and subject, outsider and community, adult and child. This might not now sound the stuff of wild radicalism, but it was three decades ago, when her project on an Indian reservation in Canada revealed the levels of squalor, dysfunction and alcoholism through the children's photographs, not her own.

At first glance, Secret Games, Ewald's intense, packed exhibition of images and words (the children's stories sometimes desperately moving, other times trite and foolish) might look like any other in which the adult photographer captures children on film. During the private view, a man ranted to me about photographers objectifying children, making them dress up. He blushed when I pointed out that the images he was especially bothered by were children's self-portraits.

As well as being novel in form, Ewald's journeys into very different social and political contexts provide a sense of the status of the image across the globe. In the US-based projects, the children were image-savvy, though sometimes frighteningly clueless about history and racial difference; in Saudi Arabia, women used their children to represent them, so unused were they to self-representation.

In Colombia, children from the slums had no concept of using a viewfinder - without windows or television, the idea of seeing the world through anything was alien. In South Africa, white children could not believe black kids could use cameras; the black children were too frightened to take photographs out on the heavily policed streets.

In Ewald's first non-photographic venture, a new video installation more explicitly directs the children involved, with a clearly pedagogic aim. Working with North Carolina youngsters, Ewald got them to research and role-play different identities: children caught up in the Holocaust, their parents, and Nazi sympathisers. There might not be such a thrilling sense of secret games in this work - the children are doing as they are told - but it still packs a punch, because the young Americans know so little of Holocaust history. In the research period, one child thought Jews were Catholics; another that Nazis were people who made pretty bracelets.

Suddenly you realise that this is anything but play time.

 Until March 17. Details: 0131-622 6200.

webTitle: Theatre review: A Moon for the Misbegotten

fields.headline: O'Neill production that misses the point
fields.standfirst:
A Moon for the Misbegotten
Royal Exchange, Manchester
**
fields.trailText:
A Moon for the Misbegotten
Royal Exchange, Manchester
**
fields.body:
Eugene O'Neill's last play, written in 1943, is like a coda to Long Day's Journey Into Night. Played with passion, as it was in David Leveaux's 1983 revival at the Riverside Studios, it can be devastating. But although conscientiously competent, Matthew Lloyd's new production lacks O'Neill's peculiar cornered desperation.

In outline, the play sounds like rustic melodrama. We are down on the farm in backwoods Connecticut in 1923. Phil Hogan, an Irish-American tenant farmer, is terrified that his scratchy bit of land will be sold. To forestall that, he tries to get his hulking daughter, Josie, into bed with his womanising landlord, James Tyrone Jr.

But O'Neill remorselessly strips away the layers of pretence. Phil, we learn, is driven not by avarice but by paternal love. Josie, widely seen as a scandalous whore, is really a lovelorn innocent. And Tyrone, under his fake Broadway sophistication, is a guilt-ridden wreck craving posthumous absolution.

It is a play of gradual disclosure, one that arouses expectations of blarneying comedy and mortgage melodrama only to subvert them. Lloyd's production starts with the advantage of a fine set by Di Seymour that captures the sense of rural decay: cracked windows suspended from the flies, a dead bird impaled on a pole, ploughshares rusting in the yard. But the first half needs to be played with an ebullient, Boucicault-like staginess if the later revelations are to surprise us. By denying O'Neill's exaggerated theatricality, Lloyd robs the climax of its power.

The play is also hell to cast. Josie, nearly six feet tall and weighing 180lb, describes herself as "an ugly overgrown lump of a woman". Helen Schlesinger, however, has fine-boned features and a palpable physical attractiveness. She does all that acting can do by burying hatchets in wood stumps and squaring up with her fists to a richly effete neighbour. Her moonlit assignation with Tyrone has a deep maternal tenderness, but it is hard to believe this is her last, despairing emotional chance. Even more crucially, Finbar Lynch, though a suitably dapper dandy, never makes you feel that Tyrone's final confession of whoring while accompanying his mother's train-borne coffin is wrung from the depths of an anguished soul.

The best performance comes from Gerard Murphy as Josie's father. He has the right barrel-shaped bulk and implies the deviousness of a man who would use his own daughter as a blackmailing decoy. The truth, of course, is otherwise but Murphy gives us the bold theatrical outline in order to undermine it. He alone seems fully to grasp the point: that it is precisely because the play starts as comic Irish melodrama that its poetic revelation of human desperation is finally overwhelming.

 Until February 24. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

fields.headline: Insurers duck mis-selling bill
fields.standfirst:
Industry accused of sharp practice

Money site
fields.trailText: Industry accused of sharp practice
fields.body:
Most insurance companies made policyholders foot the £13.5bn compensation bill for victims of pensions mis-selling, the Consumers' Association claimed yesterday. It attacked "sharp practices" in the £400bn life industry.

The CA said that of 73 shareholder-owned companies forced to pay compensation, only four took the money from investors. The rest raided the "orphan assets" of policyholders, built up over many years by underpaying the full returns on investments.

The CA's report, With-Profit Funds; Profits at the consumers' expense, also alleges:

 Chronic underpayment on policies, giving insurance companies £45bn in orphan assets (worth £4,500 per head to 10m policyholders) to pay out in compensation cases or to shareholders.

 Misleading advertising of high past returns, often as much as 12-15% a year, which only a small number of people achieve. The CA said that even after seven years of payments into an endowment policy, the real return is minus 1.9% if the policy is cashed in. After 10 years, returns creep up to 4%. The CA blames hefty up-front charges and commissions.

 Around £18bn in tax benefits on pensions has been wasted due to high charges rather than translated into better returns.

 Last year about £500m was paid out in commission on with-profits savings bonds alone, which the CA says will be met by reaching into other policyholders' reserves.

 CA director Sheila McKechnie yesterday called on the chancellor to set up an independent public inquiry into with-profits policies, which make up £400bn of the £765bn invested in life insurance and pensions. She called for a ban on high front-end commissions and charges, direct product regulation by the government to cap charges at 1% per annum and new rules to ensure policyholders gain access to 90% of orphan assets.

"We started this after we were shocked to find that compensation for pension mis-selling was coming from policyholders' own funds," Ms McKechnie said. "This is a sobering report about an industry that is incredibly old-fashioned and no longer suited to today's consumers,"

Norwich Union immediately condemned the report. Deputy chief actuary John Lister said: "Ms McKechnie says that with-profits is unsuitable for most people. That's absolute rubbish. With-profits investment is eminently suitable for low to medium-risk investors.

"The suggestion that charges are loaded on to policies in the early years is also outdated ... and the implication that we are siphoning off orphan assets is simply not true."

The CA was backed last night by Liberal Democrat shadow trade secretary Vincent Cable.

He said: "Gordon Brown has let consumers down over insurance mis-selling. He has created a firewall between himself and the industry by subcontracting out responsibility to the financial services authority which is not able to deal with the problems."

webTitle: Property values go up the down staircase

fields.headline: Property values go up the down staircase
fields.standfirst:
Nationwide and Halifax at odds

Money site
fields.trailText: Nationwide and Halifax at odds.
fields.body:
Annual house price inflation has hit a five-year low, with the average UK property now worth just 0.9% more than it was a year ago. No, that's not right ... house prices are surging upwards and January saw the biggest monthly rise for almost eight years, lifting the annual rate of property price inflation to 11.2%.

Confused? You will be if you pay any attention to the Halifax and Nationwide's monthly statistics. These allegedly authoritative indices are once again at loggerheads over where they see the housing market going. Following a brief spell last year when they appeared to be in agreement, the two mortgage lenders have produced figures for January that would seem to suggest one or the other (or both) cannot add up.

On Thursday, the Nationwide cheered homeowners with news that prices jumped 2.5% last month, or £40 a day -one of the biggest rises since the boom days of 1988-89. Yesterday Halifax poured cold water on the matter, declaring that prices were virtually flat and had increased by just 0.1% last month, driving the annual rate of house price growth down from 3.1% in December to 0.9% in January.

Both indices are compiled in broadly the same way, over the same time period, so how can they come up with such dramatically different sets of figures? The Halifax was at a loss yesterday to explain the discrepancy, saying it did not know why these differences arose and adding: "It would be much better if we did both come out with similar figures."

Its figures were published just as members of the Bank of England monetary policy committee were sitting down to discuss what should happen to interest rates - taking into account things like house prices.

Perhaps the Bank should send a troubleshooter round to find out which is right. Or, perhaps the mortgage industry as a whole can come up with a single, centralised index.

Missing the boat

An old rule of investment says that if you spot a bandwagon you've already missed it. So what are we to make of plans by Lloyds TSB, the most upmarket of our high-street lenders, and Goldman Sachs, Wall Street's bluest investment banking chip, joining together to target the "mass affluent"?

These are the new rich, as identified by Silicon Valley's Jim Clark, the founder of Netscape, who knew he was not the type to have his freshly acquired wealth managed by stuffy Swiss institutions and who also realised that many thousands like him were being created every week - young entrepreneurs who were unwilling or unable to manage their new money in an old-fashioned way.

The result was myCFO.com (as in chief financial officer). But, as with so much dot.commery, the idea was quickly hijacked by the old economy. The past year has seen everyone from Merrill Lynch to Abbey National trying to cash in, offering dressed-up banking and broking services.

Since then markets have tanked on both sides of the Atlantic, the Fed has been forced into an emergency rate cut and consumer debt is said to be spiralling out of control. The new Goldman/Lloyds venture is called Create. Yet the market they are chasing has already begun to self-destruct.

Magic circles

Galen Holdings' most famous shareholder is Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, who inherited a stake of just under 3% when the Northern Ireland healthcare firm bought US rival Warner Chilcott in September.

The world's most successful geek is yet to show much of an interest - he has not exercised his right to quiz the management, nor has he popped down to County Armagh to look round. Chairman John King remarked: "I very much doubt whether Bill Gates knows he's a Galen shareholder."

That could soon change. Galen is entering a make-or-break period. Its little rubber circles, which are inserted into a woman's vagina to release hormone replacement therapy, should be approved by the FDA within weeks.

If successful, these intra-vaginal rings have a huge number of applications, from providing contraception to preventing the spread of HIV or acting as a "female Viagra". They release medicine very slowly into the body, can stay in for three months and are apparently undetectable once inside.

Critics doubt whether women will really be keen to have such an item inside them. It is a tough one for the City's (mostly male) analysts to work out. But if women do take to it, Galen could be on to a genuine breakthrough in health care. Galen's two founders are already worth a combined £500m. If the rubber ring takes off, it won't be long before news of their wealth reaches Seattle. Mr Gates could soon be crashing his software with excitement.

Magic circles Galen Holdings' most famous shareholder is Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, who inherited a stake of just under 3% when the Northern Ireland healthcare firm bought US rival Warner Chilcott in September. The world's most successful geek is yet to show much of an interest - he has not exercised his right to quiz the management, nor has he popped down to County Armagh to look round. Chairman John King remarked: "I very much doubt whether Bill Gates knows he's a Galen shareholder." That could soon change. Galen is entering a make-or-break period. Its little rubber circles, which are inserted into a woman's vagina to release hormone replacement therapy, should be approved by the FDA within weeks. If successful, these intra-vaginal rings have a huge number of applications, from providing contraception to preventing the spread of HIV or acting as a "female Viagra". They release medicine very slowly into the body, can stay in for three months and are apparently undetectable once inside. Critics doubt whether women will really be keen to have such an item inside them. It is a tough one for the City's (mostly male) analysts to work out. But if women do take to it, Galen could be on to a genuine breakthrough in health care. Galen's two founders are already worth a combined £500m. If the rubber ring takes off, it won't be long before news of their wealth reaches Seattle. Mr Gates could soon be crashing his software with excitement.

fields.headline: Twelfth Night
fields.standfirst:
Playhouse, Liverpool
***
fields.trailText:
Playhouse, Liverpool
***
fields.body:
What does it feel like to fall in love? There are moments in James Kerr's production - set in a stormy, damp Illyria - that capture the lurch of the stomach and the tingle down the spine so intently and so violently that you know exactly. It is the next best thing to falling in love yourself.

In Olivia's heart it is always raining, but when she meets Viola, disguised as a boy, it is as if the sun has come out in some secret part of her. This stiff, stern matron is suddenly stricken with an expansive, gesticular madness. It is like a gawky black lamb gambolling: ridiculous and touching.

There are plenty of other melting moments in an enjoyable evening. It sometimes lacks comic edge and doesn't quite capture the yearning loss felt by those, particularly Malvolio, who have made complete fools of themselves over love, but it remains an artful piece of storytelling.

Kerr and designer Colin Falconer give it a clean and thoroughly modern feel. The bleach-boarded stage stays bare almost throughout, and curtains telescope up and down at the back to reveal thunderstruck skies or patches of blue horizon. At the end the stars come out and twinkle over the happy lovers. It is effective, even if the mechanics are sometimes distracting.

But Kerr's great strength is to be able to tell a story and, in the process, create stage pictures that are beautifully simple and often simply beautiful. It reminded me of the early work of Declan Donnellan and Cheek by Jowl in both its clarity and aesthetic.

In the early scenes, the attempt to create an easy, conversational style sometimes leads to gabbling, and there is a loss of energy in the second half. The best scenes almost always involve Claire Price's wonderful Olivia, a big-boned beauty who rejects Orsino's advances only to be caught off guard by love.

The first scene between Olivia and the disguised Viola is terrific not just for its giddy quality but also for the way it plays upon gender and the idea that perhaps what Olivia most likes about this man is that he is so like a woman.

There is some under-casting, but Priyanga Elan's Viola grows in confidence and she has the ability to really hold an audience when she is perfectly still. Stephen Beresford makes the most of Sir Andrew Aguecheek, turning him into a chinless wonder, and when Ian Gelder's much misused Malvolio vows that he will have revenge it is as if an icy chill has gripped Illyria and crept into the lovers' hearts.

 Until February 17. Box office: 0151-709 4776.

webTitle: Interest rate cut may come this time

fields.headline: Interest rate cut may come this time
fields.standfirst:
News Analysis US economic slowdown could tip the scales at Bank of England's monetary policy committee weighs its options

Money site
fields.trailText: The long wait may soon be over. It is a full year since the Bank of England's monetary policy committee deemed it necessary to change interest rates but, as its nine members begin two days of deliberations this morning, expectations are running high that the cost of borrowing is coming down.
fields.body:
The long wait may soon be over. It is a full year since the Bank of England's monetary policy committee deemed it necessary to change interest rates but, as its nine members begin two days of deliberations this morning, expectations are running high that the cost of borrowing is coming down.

Several factors point towards a small cut in rates. For one thing, last month's vote was a real cliff-hanger, with the committee voting by the narrowest of margins for the 6% status quo. It would only take one of the five members who opposed a cut last month to swap sides for the balance of power to shift.

What is more, while there have been mixed signals coming out of the domestic economy, the international outlook has been deteriorating rapidly. The US Federal Reserve lopped a full percentage point off US interest rates in January amid considerable evidence that the country's economy has run into a brick wall. Only yesterday a survey claimed that US companies announced a record 142,200 layoffs in January.

Then, there is the fact that the Bank has undershot the government's inflation target. The MPC's mandate is specific: it is to keep inflation at 2.5%, no higher and no lower. Yet for almost two years inflation has been lower than 2.5% - not by much, but by enough and for long enough for some members of the committee to raise the subject at the last meeting.

Some of Britain's foremost economic forecasters believe that inflation is set to go still lower over the coming months, as last year's steep rise in petrol prices starts to wash out of the inflation numbers. The National Institute for Economic and Social Research believes that inflation will fall below 1.5% by the end of this year. "That will mean that the governor of the Bank of England will have to write an explanatory letter to the chancellor setting out how he intends to raise inflation."

It is a sign of how well-behaved inflation has been in recent years that Sir Eddie George has not been obliged to put pen to paper since the Bank was first given responsibility for setting rates in the spring of 1997. But it would certainly be easier for him to explain the MPC's failure to keep inflation high enough if he and his colleagues had already cut rates.

Finally, there is the political dimension. One of the main factors cited by Gordon Brown when he granted the Bank operational independence was that it would take the politics out of monetary policy. There would, the chancellor said, be no more messing around with interest rates in the run-up to elections. However, turning monetary policy into a purely technocratic affair may prove more difficult in practice than it would appear in theory. The next meeting of the MPC takes place just after the Budget, and cutting rates then would look like an endorsement of Mr Brown's fiscal policy. By the time the April meeting rolls around, the parties will probably be on the hustings and the highly charged political environment will make it even harder for the MPC to contemplate a change in rates.

As a result, unless rates are moved tomorrow, they may be stuck at 6% for the next three months. Given that monetary policy only works with a time lag, it might be argued that a short delay would not matter that much. But the US experience has indicated that in a modern economy there can be sudden and dramatic mood swings. Putting in place a confidence-boosting measure now will have its attractions to some MPC members.

Although that might give the impression that a rate cut is an odds-on certainty, tomorrow's decision is not quite as clear cut as that. Those who counselled caution at last month's meeting may not have seen much in the economic data in the meantime to persuade them to change their minds. The economy grew by only 0.3% in the fourth quarter, well below its potential, but there were a couple of special factors causing a slowdown in output from the energy sector and from transport in the chaos that followed the Hatfield rail crash.

Recent news from manufacturing has been mixed. Yesterday's industrial production figures for December showed manufacturing output up 0.3% for the second successive month, with the slow but unspectacular improvement reflecting the differing fortunes of Britain's various industrial sectors. The metal industries - as reflected in the big job losses announced by Corus - are suffering, but the hi-tech end of manufacturing is still doing well. Recent surveys from the Confederation of British Industry, the British Chambers of Commerce and the Engineering Employers Federation have all been slightly more upbeat, perhaps as a result of the slight fall in the value of the pound.

Roger Bootle, economic adviser to Deloitte & Touche says that tomorrow's decision will not be clear cut, but that the second reduction in the US last week, prompted by the precipitous collapse in confidence, removes the risk that the MPC will be seen as the Fed's poodle. "A rate cut now would be an insurance policy against similar falls in confidence over here, which may be more difficult to reverse than forestall."

fields.headline: Niall Griffiths's top 10 Welsh books
fields.trailText: Niall Griffiths's first novel, Grits, a vernacular tale of addicts and drifters in rural Wales, won him the title 'the Welsh Irvine Welsh'. His second novel, Sheepshagger, is set in the same landscape; it tells the story of Ianto, a feral mountain boy who wreaks terrible vengeance on those he feels have stolen his homeland
fields.body:
Niall Griffiths's first novel, Grits, a vernacular tale of addicts and drifters in rural Wales, won him the title 'the Welsh Irvine Welsh'. His second novel, Sheepshagger, is set in the same landscape; it tells the story of Ianto, a feral mountain boy who wreaks terrible vengeance on those he feels have stolen his homeland.
Read the Guardian review
Buy Sheepshagger at Amazon.co.uk

"The difficulty in compiling such a list is, of course, keeping the books down to a mere 10. There's always a scrap with yourself over what to leave out; what you jettison today may seem utterly indispensable tomorrow, or even after tea. So what I've done here is list the 10 Welsh books which, in varying ways, influenced my most recent novel, Sheepshagger; the books which would undam the wordflow when it was temporarily blocked. Which is as good a criterion as any.

The order is roughly chronological, although all but the first are 20th century. Nearly all of them are poetry, as well. Hmmmm. And they're all by men. Hmmmm again."

1. Selected Poems by Dafydd ap Gwilym
Contemporary of, and superior to, Chaucer. This man roamed mountains and forests, got rat-arsed in hill inns, tupped wenches, and wrote poems about it. Raucous, irreverent, and dead, dead funny. And lovely in parts too, in his poems of birds and water, in his evocation of the cabin he built in the woods for himself and his favourite missus. Sadness for a world lost, but isn't that what we're made of? Random quote: "I am a leaper bold."

2. My People Blimey by Caradoc Evans
Think of Royston Vasey, and then think of something darker, funnier, more absurd, more unsettling. Not easy I know, but here it is, in the tiny rural Welsh community of this collection of short stories. The transliteration of Welsh directly into English in economical, almost painfully spare language creates a deeply peculiar linguistic world, dreamlike and eerie. This man was willing to be reviled as the price of exposing the corruption and hypocrisy of non-conformism. Black-clad, thickly bearded big men booming in chapels; painful births on storm-torn mountains; old ladies eaten by rats. Mad, worrying, horrifying. Random quote: "fled from the house of sacrifice".

3. One Moonlit Night by Caradog Pritchard
See above. And see the black lake; the tiny houses in the night; the bodies floating bloated in the water. Unremittingly dark, determinedly cheerless. Or at least that's the prevailing memory; go back to it (which I do, again and again) and you'll find a perfect evocation of childhood and a twisted, quirky humour. Brave, bizarre, brilliant. Random quote: "He was going to be hanged in Caernarfon."

4. In Parenthesis by David Jones
One of the best epic poems of the last century. No, one of the best epic poems ever. A speculum into the collective psyche. How myths of our making go to shape us for such things as the unimaginable carnage of the first world war. How everything we label 'civilisation' is founded on very thin ice, and how horrible are the things that lurk beneath. Phantasmagoric and, at the same time, true. Which is perfect for our age. Random quote: "Plug and splinter/Shin and fibula."

5. Collected Poems and Collected Stories by Dylan Thomas
He had to be in here, didn't he? Forget what you know of Dylan the pisshead, the letch, the boyo, and focus on Dylan the writer. He's the man for the joy in language, the rapture and terror in the world. He created forms of expression utterly, uniquely his. The mystery and innocence of all that we do. A bottle of Irish, a view of the mountains, and the words of this man = joy. Random quote: "a turtle in a hearse".

6. Collected Poems by RS Thomas
Grumpy old clergyman, sour old sod. Extolled the virtues of forcing everyone west of the border to speak Cymraeg yet wrote in Saesneg so loads of people would read him. Would ignore people who asked him directions, or send them the wrong way. Truly, a cantankerous get. But lookit: few words, and the universalisation in them of human yearning. Amazing. Read a good definition of 'apophantism', read this book, and you'll be lost for months, years, ever. Essential. Random quote: You've just had one.

7. So Long, Hector Bebb by Ron Berry
The book which, at the age of about nine, alerted me to the possibilities of speaking for and within one's own community. A vernacular mimetic truth, strong, lyrical, infinitely sad. A voice, a dialect, a commensurately firm identity and the rage resultant when that is lost or robbed. Talking of which, some immoral bugger half-inched my copy ages ago, and it's been long out of print. No luck in second-hand shops either. Somebody, please, reprint it - or failing that, somebody please send me a copy. I'd be eternally grateful, and a tad happier than I am now. Plus I'd pay. Honest. Random quote: can't remember. I was nine years old, for God's sake.

8. The Welsh Extremist by Ned Thomas
Non-fiction, and frightening; not because of its promotion of militancy, heck no, but because of its revelations and analysis concerning the insidious and evil hegemonic takeover of whole countries, entire ways of life. On behalf of all oppressed nations, and for the individual creative effort threatened by the barren swamp of enforced uniformity. As vital now as it was in the 70s, and as important as Franz Fanon's The Wretched of the Earth. Endorsed by Raymond Williams, and he knew a thing or two. Random quote: "Cracach."

9. Red Landscapes: New and Selected Poems by Mike Jenkins
A Welsh Lallans. Hopelessness in the sink estates, as brilliantly caught as in John Welch's Estates documentary. As far removed from the fudge box view of Wales as the reality is. The Welsh revival starts here: profound political commitment allied with a bone-deep sympathy for blighted lives. Surprising flashes of surreal humour, too. Random quote: "a tourist's luxury".

10. Edge Territory by Lloyd Robson
Or indeed anything else by him, or even one of his intense, confrontational, energetic, inyerface machine gun-stutter readings. Some of the best dialect writing in these islands, ever. The way he plays with voice and typology is wondrous, life-affirming. Drugs, dialect, sex, violence, fun, anger, happiness; it's all here, in Kairdiff as well as Scotland. Read it. Random quote: "Dylan is dead or ain't you noticed? Read the living poets."

Which undermines my list somewhat, apart from the last two items, and Ned Thomas at number seven, but he's not a poet. So, yet again: Hmmmmm...

fields.headline: Investors cool on Abbey deal
fields.standfirst: No rush to back merger with Bank of Scotland
fields.trailText: Leading institutional investors will wait for the outcome of any full-scale competition investigation into Lloyds TSB's £20bn takeover of Abbey National rather than endorse a merger between Abbey and Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
Leading institutional investors will wait for the outcome of any full-scale competition investigation into Lloyds TSB's £20bn takeover of Abbey National rather than endorse a merger between Abbey and Bank of Scotland.

Senior fund managers said yesterday they were in no hurry to back Abbey's attempt to merge with BoS, which has been cleared on competition grounds by the government. Lloyds TSB could learn next week whether it will have to face a fullcompetition review - which could take six months to complete. City sources have speculated that a move to refer the Lloyds bid to the competition commission would prompt BoS and Abbey to reveal the terms of their merger, which is expected to value Abbey at less than the approach by Lloyds.

"No shareholder is going to endorse Abbey's tie-up with BoS because there is nothing in it for them," one said last night. The shareholder's comments were backed up by other Abbey investors, some of whom are being courted by Lloyds TSB's chief executive Peter Ellwood in an attempt to win support for its bid.

The shareholders aired their views ahead of the meeting today of the merger panel, which plays an important role in giving advice to the office of fair trading director general, John Vickers, about competition concerns.

The government has until February 23 to publish the decision although sources indicated yesterday that the City might not have to wait that long to learn the outcome.

The Trades Union Congress yesterday took one of the last chances available to call on the government to refer the proposed takeover to the competition commission.
